author: {'steamid': '76561198273361249', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1710292589}
review:
Uma evolução bem clara em todos os aspectos em relação ao primeiro jogo, apesar de ser injusta uma comparação de um jogo de 2022 para um de 2014. O estilo visual e artístico é muito bom, assim como os efeitos sonoros. Algumas trilhas da OST são bem marcantes também, enquanto outras nem tanto. A trama apresenta vários personagens que você pode escolher pra jogar a campanha principal, cada um com uma história inicialmente diferente, e que se cruzam da metade pro final do jogo.

Apesar de ter um início lento, cada fase tem uma ideia central, com mecânicas características que ajudam a dar uma variada na gameplay. Nem sempre é uma ideia boa, mas eu gosto bastante desse aspecto no jogo, e isso engrena de vez da metade pro fim. As lutas contra chefes (não todas) podem ser bem empolgantes também, sendo bem satisfatório aprender os padrões de ataque. Outro ponto positivo é o fato de que, apesar de se inspirar em Sonic, as fases não se resumem a apenas acelerar de um modo que eu mal consigo ver detalhes das fases e dos inimigos, isso é um ponto extremamente positivo pra mim.

O principal problema que eu tive com o jogo foi a duração das fases. Todas exageradamente longas, cada uma levando em torno de uns 20 minutos de duração, se você for uma pessoa como eu que gosta de procurar por segredos e explorar bem. As cutscenes do jogo podem ser bem maçantes e com um humor que eu particularmente não gosto muito. Além disso, o tutorial o jogo dá uma impressão de que há vários recursos para utilizar no combate, mas, pelo menos na personagem que eu joguei (Milla), só precisei de um único ataque para todos os inimigos durante o jogo todo. Todos os outros eram bem descartáveis e não tão úteis.

Um bom jogo de plataforma 2D, uma evolução significativa em relação ao primeiro, mas longe de ser perfeito. Ainda assim, recomendo para aqueles períodos de intervalo entre um jogo grande e outro. E se acabar curtindo muito, há bastante conteúdo, com histórias separadas para cada personagem, e uma certa variação na gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198292727070', 'num_games_owned': 83, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3436, 'last_played': 1710023278}
review:
[h1]Was it worth the seven-year wait?[/h1]

Sequels are never easy, even more so when the original is so beloved. Balancing the things that made the original great with innovations that make a sequel stand out is a difficult act, and not one every studio can succeed at. When done poorly, players just get more of the same, or in the worst cases, a whole that is lesser than the sum of its parts. When done well, players get a fresh experience that iterates on the original's successes while avoiding its flaws.

Freedom Planet, a love-letter to the 16-bit era, was one such beloved title, and the developers had their work cut out for them. With such a fantastic first entry, the sequel would need to do so much more, while still keeping the spirit of the original intact. A seven-year development period followed, and at long last, the game was released. But how did it do? Was it a fantastic follow-up to the original, or does it fall short--

Of course it's good. It's really good. It's so good. It's one of the best 2D platformers, period. We can cut the theatrics now.

Almost everything the first game did, the second game does just as well, if not better. The artwork is more detailed and thematic, and the visual effects are fantastic. The gameplay is refined far beyond the first game, giving the characters a new array of well-balanced abilities that give them versatility without making them more powerful. Every character is fun to play. Nearly every stage flows immaculately, even on a first play. The mechanics are beautifully balanced, allowing for a surprising degree of player expression without any blatantly overpowered options. The sound effects are great, and the voice acting is as well. The music is thematic and fits the setting perfectly. The story, probably the most contentious part of both games, has a great degree of depth and thought put into it, and it avoids the tonal and pacing issues of the first game's.

The game has been out for two years or so now, but I bought it a little bit later. I just got around to writing a review because I couldn't find the right words to accurately express how good this game is. Even this barely scratches the surface of how I feel. There's so much to it, I couldn't possibly cover it all.

Are you on the fence if you should buy this game? Here's a quick guide:
* [b]Did you enjoy the first Freedom Planet?[/b] This game is everything you could ever want in a sequel and more. You should buy FP2.
* [b]Did you not enjoy the first Freedom Planet?[/b] FP2 improves the weak aspects of FP1 while improving the strong ones. You should buy FP2.
* [b]Have you not played Freedom Planet?[/b] FP2 is a great game, even on its own. You should buy FP2.
* [b]Do you enjoy the games of a certain blue-quilled mascot?[/b] FP2 isn't the same, but it's similar, and it's very good. You should buy FP2.
* [b]Do you enjoy 2D platformers at all?[/b] FP2 is a good 2D platformer. You should buy FP2.
* [b]Do you hate fun?[/b] FP2 might change your mind. You should buy FP2.
* [b]Do you hate Steam and/or PC gaming?[/b] The console releases are coming up very soon! You should buy FP2.
* [b]Are you not represented by this list?[/b] Now you are. Also, you should buy FP2.

Also, there's a free sample version of the first stage, so try that out! The full game is even better.

Okay, that's all. Buy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199095005266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 339, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1712368785}
review:
This is by far my favorite platformer ever.
At first, I thought this was going to be a basic Sonic styled platformer, but oh well that wasn't the case at all.

The gameplay, the level design, the music, the visuals, the characters, the world,
they’re all just perfect, seriously.
The music, especially, is something really special.

Right now i'm at my second playthrough, and its still as fun as the first one. Having 4 very distinct playable characters makes the replayability really good too.
The difficulty is also very well balanced. The system itself is pretty creative, you can equip and unequip items to change your level of difficulty on the overworld map, when you feel like it.

The only negative things I can say about this game is that:
1- *SOME* cutscenes are, I think, a bit cringe or too long for nothing
2- spamming ennemies really isn't a good stage gimmick (cough cough Zulon Jungle)

(btw ignore my play time of 5 minutes, I wasn't playing through Steam)

author: {'steamid': '76561198147456249', 'num_games_owned': 138, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 59, 'playtime_at_review': 2025, 'last_played': 1712313710}
review:
Wonderful story and voice acting that only enhances the experience of each stage. Great setpieces. Crisp and fun gameplay that you can adjust the difficulty as you see fit. Level design improved from the first game. A zoomed-out camera that can have all of the sprites in full-resolution with an easy to install mod. A great classic-feeling sonic-type game with active time combat and full movesets, works very well. The pixel art never misses, the game is drop-dead gorgeous. A must play that nearly perfects what the first Freedom Planet had. An ideal sequel that knocks it out of the park.

Your first playthrough will easily hit double-digits in your playtime, which already makes the game worth the price for a single character. Multiple playthroughs, exploring, or speedrunning/S-ranking will all add lots of playtime to those looking for a deeper experience with the gameplay. I highly recommend to anyone even SLIGHTLY interested in 2D platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198294958037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3633, 'last_played': 1705902680}
review:
An amazing action platformer with blending its speed and characters' combat abilities for fresh feeling fast paced game play. The varying play styles of the characters allow replaying the stages as each one to offer its own challenges, and sometimes shortcuts (Ancestral Forge is the best level to try to exploit everyone's abilities with, it was really fun seeing a potential way to skip parts by either freezing enemies and making a nice staircases to areas early with Neera Li or flying as high as I can then giving myself a little boost with Milla's projectile power.) Only downside I could list would be seeing the story from multiple sides, the game offering 4 playable characters with some unique cut scenes for each. It really feels like the story was written with only playing as Lilac in mind as playing with the other characters makes the story feel a lot more underwhelming with character specific cut scenes outside of Lilac's story sometimes feeling like afterthoughts.

For an action 2D platformer though, its a must play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131765592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1704859902}
review:
[b]From the gameplay, to the story, to the visuals and even the music, this game has pretty much refined and perfected everything that was in the first game, and even added some incredibly good extra stuff.[/b]

The levels are all so much fun and enjoyable to get through, there wasn't a single one that I though was bad. The spritework in each of them is gorgeous, every song in every level is so insanely good and the level design is so well made. Seriously, there was one level in particular that was absolutely massive and had quite a lot of puzzles, and it took 28 minutes for me to beat it, and yet it didn't feel like it took that long at all, I was actually surprised when I looked at the timer and saw the time, I was having so much fun I didn't see it pass.

The bosses are all so great and enjoyable to fight now, especially with the addition of the guard/dodge in this game. This one move completely erased all of the problems I had with a portion of the bosses from FP1. Now when I get hit by an attack I think "Damn it, I should have dodged that" instead of "There was no possible way I could've avoided that, bullshit". I also absolutely LOVE how, when you're defeated in a fight, you can use a stock to choose to either go back to the last checkpoint with full health to try the fight again from the start or you can revive yourself immediately with a tiny amount of health and resume the fight. This completely eliminates any kind of possible frustration that there could've been from nearly defeating a boss, but then getting hit at the last second and having to do it all over again, as it allows the player to have control over that and have him choose what would be the best play. I've never seen a game do that before and it's such an incredibly INGENIUS idea. 

The story is just SO much better than the first one. It's so engaging and interesting, you're just constantly at the edge of your seat wondering what's going to happen next and you just never know. The characters are all so well written and awesome, and the voice acting is so well done.

I could go on and on about how fucking fantastic this game, it's seriously a masterpiece, and I'll remember it as one of the best I have ever played.

HIGHLY recommend anyone to check this game out, it's an unforgettable experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021903868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1665545168}
review:
While I ultimately recommend it, the game does hit some fairly ridiculous difficulty spikes on a few bosses about midway through. They sort of come out of nowhere, too, rather than a gradual ramp-up. Left a bit of a sour taste in my mouth. The first game was balanced a lot better IMO.

If you can push past it, though, there's a lot to love - the art, soundtrack, and character banter are all amazing, just like the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023491651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 1654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1654, 'last_played': 1694724076}
review:
Bardzo porządny klon Sonica, który w jakiś sposób przeszedł bez echa.  Można grać 4 postaciami i każda z nich ma nieco inne story, chociaż główna linia fabularna zostaje taka sama.  Gra ma w sobie same bangery w soundtracku. Końcowi bossowie stanowią spore wyzwanie. Problemy i pierdółki z pierwszej szczęści zostały ogarnięte,  cała gra prezentuje się znacznie lepiej od poprzedniczki. Jedynie co nieco mnie rozczarowało to to że nie próbowali pushować nieco mocniej humoru. Są sceny humorystyczne ale trochę to wygląda jakby ktoś devom powiedział,  hehe pamiętajcie by nie zrobić zbyt śmieszne. To bardzo nitpickowa uwaga ale serio nie mam do czego innego się przyczepić. 

PS: Askal ty choju.

review: No shit, this is probably the 2nd best platformer I've ever played imo. It's got heaps of content to go through, lots of replay value, a surprisingly and frankly unnecessarily good story with great voicework, beautiful pixel art, tight controls and 4 extremely fun and diverse characters to play. It's really good. Just play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045149740', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 454, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1666850491}
review:
I must admit something.... 

I've never played a Sonic game, and can't quite understand why, but somehow I guess if make the main characters less cringe, I said less cringe, and make the cast female centric and generally funny at times. It's not what you think, I know this game comes across as one of those games, you know a...... 
......good one. 

The story is not sexual at all, even if some fans might wish it was. As a non-furry this game gets my seal approval for it's great chiptune soundtrack, insane amount of quality and variety in levels, enemies and bosses. There is some jank when levels zoom out as they get pixelated from not having different levels of detail, you can tell that because they didn't want to waste money so the scope of the game could be massive for a 12 hour Sonic-like game. One more praise I'll also give it is I didn't expect a Sonic-clone to have some bosses that feel like that could have come from more souls-like centric games. 

You can also play as any of the 4 cast of characters, so replay value if you care. But getting to play as a dragon that's main attack is using her hair is just too badass. I hope to see a sequel, as I'm now a fan and hopefully not a.....


It's clickbait: because how else do get people to click on a video:
https://youtu.be/o70O8V-ajyo

author: {'steamid': '76561198259663408', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1710445055}
review:
好玩！虽然等了这么久你才打九折让我很不爽，但是还是买单了
打完一周目，感觉是近年少有的高质量横版动作
画风可爱，操作顺畅，剧情也挺不错，虽然不是什么很有深度的剧情，但是在严肃和诙谐之间取得一个非常不错的平衡
看憨憨米拉的台词真是一大乐趣0v0

不过要圈一下缺点：
严格来说只有一个，你TM分明是中国要素满满的游戏，随处可见的汉字牌匾、路标、人名、国风建筑、音乐风格之类的
但是你中文台词为什么不做啊！我觉得二代比一代销量差这么多，很大一部分原因就是台词语言太少了 
对着翻译软件一点点看完剧情真的很影响体验啊，更别说steam界面直接写了仅英文，劝退的玩家太多了

总结，游戏很棒，不过因为语言问题，英文不好的同学需要一点点对着翻译看剧情，不过如果是对剧情不感兴趣的就随意吧

author: {'steamid': '76561198292832123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8872, 'last_played': 1709431356}
review:
I'm not sure how to put it into words but I love almost everything about this game.

 It's incredibly fun to play, all the characters feel different and the level design compliments them very well. I enjoyed the story, and the way it sets up some levels makes them far more enjoyable and memorable. The various hubs you can visit in Adventure Mode are great to hangout in and the npcs really make the world feel lived in. The world map is cute and also really helps all of Avalice feel connected. The music is absolutely amazing and adds a lot to the atmosphere of the levels. There's also so many fun side modes like sparring with other characters, boss rematches, and various challenges. 

[u] [h3] Some specific things I liked [/h3] [/u]

Some items like the "Life Oscillation" one are pretty cool and fun to use. 

Dragon Valley is a fantastic starting stage, the level flows well and the art and music are phenomenal!

[spoiler] Globe Opera really feels like it's going to be the final part of the game and does an amazing job of tricking you into thinking that, despite all the evidence that it's not the final part. [/spoiler]

The Floating Island Map has especially wonderful art and music, I could sit on that screen for hours! (to be honest most of the world map makes me feel like that, but the Floating Island map is probably my favorite)

[spoiler] Tidal Gate's placement in the story could not be better. After the high-stakes and stress of the prior stages, Tidal Gate is a beautiful stage that feels open and gives you a breather. The music for Tidal Gate is also fun and energetic, further helping lessen the tension from the previous stages. (having Parusa and the Floating Island in the background really sparks the urge to explore them too!) [/spoiler]

The in-stage character dialogue is charming and makes each stage it's in feel like an active part of the story.

[spoiler] The gallery is really cool and the reward for rebuilding all the exhibits is awesome! [/spoiler]

[spoiler] The secret final level is great and it's central mechanic really stands out! It's boss is also amazing with a great callback to Brevon in both the fight and its music. [/spoiler]

[u] [h3] Some specific things I didn't like as much [/h3] [/u]

The ranking system is neat, but it could definitely use some changes to allow defeating enemies and collecting crystals to contribute to getting a high rank, as opposed to just using the brave stones and ignoring everything.

I'm pretty sure the way you earn the time capsules was a result of running out of dev time, but it's still unfortunate they're only obtainable in the Battlesphere.

Incredibly minor thing but I wish you could toggle whether the Battlesphere boss rematches would use the Battlesphere tiles and background or their original tiles and backgrounds. Some of the boss fights just don't look as cool and clash a bit with the Battlesphere tiles. 

[u] [h3] Final thoughts [/h3] [/u]
There's so much I like about this game that I didn't mention here, I don't think a single review does it justice! If you're on the fence about this game, give it a try! I couldn't recommend it enough! (it also has a demo if you just want to try that!) Also GalaxyTrail is still fixing bugs and adding stuff which is awesome!

[u] [h3] Final Final thoughts [/h3] [/u]
This game makes me happy ^w^

author: {'steamid': '76561198136668586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1663679224}
review:
[h1] TLDR: 10/10 THEY MADE LILAC BETTER SOMEHOW I'M DEAD SERIOUS [/h1]

Ignore my playtime, almost all of my playtime was when I had no internet. I have finished the game as Lilac and Carol.

I think for how closely I followed the development of this game, for how much of an absolute fucking reply guy I was in Sabrina DiDuro's and GalaxyTrail's tweets just expressing how hype I was for this game, I have done a disservice for not writing a review sooner.

Let me start by saying, I do not consider either of these games 'Sonic' games, and their identity should not be likened to Sonic. They are wholly different experiences that only ultimately share the very baseline DNA of 'Going Fucking Hard' with the blue blur. With that said, Freedom Planet 1 was, for many years of my life, what i considered 'The Best Sonic Game'--if Sonic made a game exactly like Freedom Planet, just with a sonic skin and sonic-themed movesets, it would probably still not be as fun as Freedom Planet. I've played Freedom Planet 1 so many fucking times, at this point, it's probably more than I've ever played Cave Story.

Freedom Planet 2 is [i] so insanely superior to the first game that i don't even know where to begin. [/i] After completing Lilac's story, I said, holy fuck, I feel like I got my money's worth and a half. I can't bang out a run of FP2 in one day like I can FP1, but that's more than okay to me. The game is immaculate. If you played Freedom Planet 1 and you thought to yourself, damn, this can't get better, well, TOO BAD, MORON, because [b] apparently it can. [/b] The combat feels better, the characters have all received a massive glow up that makes them so much more fun to play that after playing this game, I don't think I *can* go back to Freedom Planet 1. 

Much like Freedom Planet 1, the crown jewel of this game is Lilac. With new moves that interact with her dash, the ability to uppercut out of a jump, and her cyclone no longer taking any meter, it's like Freedom Planet 1 was you playing the game with fucking training wheels. Carol and Milla are both very fun to play in this game, way better than they were in the first game. Had Lilac stayed the same as she was in FP1, I would not be able to pick a favorite. However, for all the improvements made to Carol and Milla, Lilac matched those in spades. If I had one complaint with this game, it's that Lilac is *too fun.* She makes me not want to play as the other characters, because even though they ARE fun, Lilac is so well designed I start to feel like everything in the platformer genre was just the buildup to Sash "Lilac Freedom Planet 2" Lilac.

One other complaint I would say I have, unfortunately, I don't think Neera is very fun at all. The power character type is interesting, but I don't feel like she does anything particularly useful with it and she doesn't make fighting feel any more satisfying than it does with Carol, and neither of them are as fun as Lilac. Even so, at her worst, she is still inherently fun to move around with like the others.

The soundtrack to FP2 is, much like the first game, an absolute fucking banger. Just amazing all around. Like, if I had to make any criticisms, it's that Merga's motif isn't quite as good as Brevon's. The storytelling in this game is also far better than it was in FP1, managing to stick a lot closer to the tone I think they intended. There are still a few moments, jokes mainly, that I don't think landed, but at the end of the day I think the game does a much better job, though I do think while Merga is a great villain, she does somewhat live in the shadow of Brevon and how perfect he was.

My only other complaint regarding the story of this game is something I hope can be adressed in Freedom Planet 3, provided it happens. There will be some story spoilers for the ending of Lilac's story ahead, so just, you know, read at your own risk.

The ending clarifying and establishing Lilac and Carol's relationship as a romantic one is something I'm sort of conflicted about. In my head, when I think about it, I like this relationship. It makes sense. They're cute together. However, unfortunately, this is only really something that extends into my head. Part of the plot of FP2 is based on Carol going off on her own and getting into trouble, and Lilac and Carol having these repeated disagreements that put strain on their relationship. This makes sense and I think is a good hardship that the two overcoming helps them understand their feelings for each other better, but my real issue comes in the fact that we unfortunately only see them disagree and fight. There are so few scenes in Freedom Planet 1 or 2 where the two of them are shown to be friends, to know each other well and get along in a way that isn't specifically a team rally declaring that they can do anything. Off the top of my head, I can only think of the scene where they're watching the movie in the first game, and even then, part of that is based on Milla, and more serves to establish Milla as a friend of Carol and Lilac, but not actually doing much in terms of the friendship between Carol and Lilac specifically. To be clear, I don't say this because I want to pick apart the writing of this game, I just want the relationship between the two protagonists to be as good as possible because I love these games. I hope for the future of the series, we can see more interactions of the two of them just being... friends. Lovers too, of course, but I think first and foremost friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032091709', 'num_games_owned': 1149, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1701332539}
review:
Personally I can't play the game for more then one level without the new sprites distracting me because of how different and just plain bad the characters look in this new style, the height of the characters is my biggest complaint with the new sprites it's massively distracting and just plain doesn't look good and Milla in that Kung Fu stance looks SO stupid.

The personality changes are nonsensical to the point where they just don't feel like the same characters anymore, and the soundtrack is nowhere near as good as the first game. The ONLY improvement is the look of the stages (Not the stage layouts) and even then not all of them.

For a game that we waited eight years for this is just disappointing, if I was given the option to use the original sprites or designs for the characters that would at least let me play the stages without being bothered by the sprites.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001198523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 776, 'last_played': 1663386629}
review:
I waited years for this. YEARS. I loved the first game so very much. This one though? I don't know what it is. The movement doesn't feel right, the story just was kinda bad if im being honest (not like the first was that great but it hit the cheesy in a decent way for me.) it was uninteresting as i went through the bits i did and the more developed the plot got the less interesting it became. Even the level design feels off and wrong.

I think the biggest thing for me is that the game feels like its trying to make combat the major focus and its not what i came to the first one for. It doesn't feel in depth enough for it and i feel takes away from the platforming terribly.

I tried very hard to like the game after being pretty excited for this release but god i felt so let down. Clearly it's found an audience and i don't want people to hate on it but it doesn't click with me which kinda makes me sad.

author: {'steamid': '76561199179680638', 'num_games_owned': 32, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1700979025}

author: {'steamid': '76561198290238998', 'num_games_owned': 99, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 3499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3480, 'last_played': 1702866937}
review:
A much better game then it's predecessor. Though there is one thing I miss and that comes mostly from the story. Don't get me wrong, the story is good, better even, but it is does lack what I would call "unapologetic confidence". An unfiltered desire to impress, to show something beyond cool without even considering second guessing yourself. Something that was in every SEGA in the Dreamcast era. Some might call it "camp", but most would call it "cringe", so I am most likely in the minority.

Gameplay; A nice improvement across the board. Overall I found myself less energy starved, which would sometimes break the sense of flow because I had to wait around for my energy to refill. They brought carefully though out solution to the problem of 1 and 2 is a much better game because of it:
[list]
  [*]Lilac: She barely changed, but what they added to her I can't live without now. No being able to cancel Dragon Boast was an obvious flaw which they fixed gracefully with Boost Breaker. An awesome offensive tool to boot.
  [*]Carol: She is now fun to play as without her bike! And it won't break either! Wild kick has been replaced with a bladed disk (or her bike if she has it) and, while I sorta miss Wild Kick, it it a great offence tool that now double as a movement tool. Not to mention a cool way to go on and out of her bike. She desperately needed a movement tool, and they gave her the most fitting one.
  [*]Milla: A complete overall from 1 and she is very fun to control now. Her cube still fill her offensive, defensive and movement needs, but does it so in a more frantic way. She can pack a punch now and she can summon her cube instantly now. She is now harder and more fun to master and on par with the others. All that without sacrificing what made her unique.
  [*]Neera: The newcomer. She is the simplest one of the cast. Fun to control and the easiest to build up speed with and her running attack. She is supposed to be the power character, but I found her attack to be a bit awkward to land. Still a fun character to play as that convoy personality in her moveset just like the others.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561199147561611', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 20, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1711658595}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 ilk oyunun üzerine koyarak oynanışını bölüm dizaynının katkısıyla bayağı eğlenceli kılmıştır, müzikleri tek kelimeyle şaheser.
bosslar çok eğlenceli hatta battlesphere isimli bir yerde hepsini tekrar oynayabiliyoruz ancak bosslar ilk oyun kadar zor değiller, bu bir eksi mi ? hayır :D





SPOİLER ALERT !!!



Hikayeye gelirsek kötü adamı fazla beğendiğimi söyleyemem, Merga konusunda hayal kırıklığına uğradığım:Ben onu acımasız ve başarılı birisi olarak bekliyordum, gel gör ki oyunda magister'ın bize "en büyük korkumuz" diye hitap ettiği bu kötü karakterin oyunun sonlarında bakunawa ile ay'ı patlatmaya kalkışmak ve shang tu sarayını ele geçirmek dışında "aslında sarayı ele geçiren askal lol" başarılı bir olayı yoktu.
Mesela ilk oyundaki Lord Brevon amacına ulaşmak adına bütün Shuigang krallığını öldürüp bütün krallıkları birbirine düşürürek gezegenin enerji kaynağını çalmayı başarmıştı, aynı zamanda kendisi ana karakterimizi işkenceyle neredeyse öldürüyordu.
ayrıca ilk oyundaki olaylardan 3 yıl sonra halk'ın ilk oyundaki Lord Brevon'ın büyük istilasını yalanlaması zırvalıktan başka bir şey değil,dediğim gibi bu adam bütün krallıkları birbirine düşürüp bütün gezegen'in enerji kaynağını çalmayı başarmış birisiydi.

Onun dışında karakterler ve dialogları fena değildi fakat Merga'nın çıktığı sahneler dışında oyunun ilk oyundaki ciddiliğin yanına bile yaklaşamadığını fark ettim.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198029904609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 321, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1700796109}
review:
Nah. The rest of the game is good, but the combat sucks so, so bad. There's a reason Street Fighter doesn't have Sonic ice physics. Adding a dedicated parry button makes things a bit better, but the parry button does absolutely jack when enemy attacks have so few startup frames or run for several seconds dealing damage every frame. You read something wrong and you can take half bar off of a single attack.

Combat works in Sonic because your character is mostly hurtbox, and enemies mostly aren't, so the slippy slidey physics don't feel too punishing. Here, it's reversed. The hurtboxes on your attacks are tiny, and enemies are mostly hurtbox most of the time, so trying to hit a foe feels like sticking your hand into a tumble dryer full of syringes.

Some characters have a slightly better kit for combat, but they take the joy out of platforming. You can also use equipment---but you'd better not use it too early, because it decreases the rate at which you earn the currency needed to buy equipment.

I really wanted to like this, but I did not.

However, you might.

Freedom Planet 2 is in every way an improvement on its predecessor. It's a little more smooth. A little more interesting. A little more comfortable in its own skin.

The voice acting is still really solid, and the plot's a little more engaging---though it's still Sonic OC stuff, so if that bothered you the first time around, it'll bother you here as well. The's art's stellar, and there's some great, extremely articulated sprites. There's even a world map, although the game locks you into episodes so it's not quite free roam.

If the first game clicked with you, you'll have a fantastic time here. I know there's folks for which the combat feels natural and interesting---you might be one of those.

I'd recommend trying the first game first, especially since this one doesn't recap much plot, and I hope it does well enough that we get a third game for me to try and also bounce off the controls of.

Edit: Found a combination of equipment that works for me, and this makes the difficulty level feel far more normal. You have to progress enough to get the equipment, so the first half of the game ends up being weirdly harder than the second half, but getting pinballed around into seven million hurtboxes feels less bad when you have literally any iframes. There's still some odd choices for stages (really, really slow puzzle levels that drag on for 15--20 minutes), but less risk of getting walled by a boss at the end of one, and the stages that do feel good feel really good. There's some extremely clever level and boss design that was getting obfuscated by the high difficulty. This review is still a thumbs up, but now a much less cautious one. It's not like FP1, where even on easy fights were absolutely brutal.

2nd Edit: Absolutely not. Good god that's seven phases on the final boss and it turns into a tohou at the end. Slippy slidey butter physics feel miserable against something that's playing like an MVC tournament Zero. It's more interesting and beatable than the boss of FP1, but I'm not gonna grind it. If this game clicks for you, you'll have a great time. If it does not, you will not.

review: An amazing fast paced platformer where every single stage seems to have its own gimmick. In one stage, you have to go behind waterfalls to avoid and traverse behind things in your path, and in another, you have to dodge around two enemy teams fighting each other. Great bossfights and engaging diverse character kits wrap the gift that is this game in bow and paper. The story is great with a lot to unpack in secrets and voicelines. 9.5 out of 10. One of the best game's I've ever played

author: {'steamid': '76561198056113748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2205, 'last_played': 1701661309}
review:
This is probably the singular best sequel to a game in terms of sheer execution of the ambition and improvements. Considering FP1 was originally a Sonic fan game, and then comparing it to FP2, it's a straight 5:1 improvement on a galactic scale. Everything is leaps and bounds better: story, pacing, character gameplay, level design, enemies, graphics, art diversity, world expansion, and voice acting. There is no singular element that wasn't massively overhauled to improvement while fitting with their new designs.

Gameplay:
All characters--sans Lilac, I think--got overhauls to their gameplay kit to make them unique, but also much more fun and capable to play. Each character has various methods of attacking, and they all have different mobility options.

While Lilac plays largely the same, she gained the Guard function like all of the characters, but hers comes with a character-specific dash attached to it.

Carol got a *massive* gameplay improvement overall, primarily to her motorcycle functionality. She is also wildly faster than the first game, so she no longer feels miserable to play off of her bike. I actually played most of the game off of it, and didn't practice with it, and I never felt like she was 'slow' because of. I enjoyed her playthrough a lot.

There's a big emphasis on speedrunning this game, as well as multiple difficulties, and further ways to challenge yourself or make it easier. If you are not into this game's difficulty, you can set it to easy and use items and potions to make it even more accessible. You will NOT miss any story if you decide to do this; nothing is locked behind Hard Mode, etc.

Milla has also received gameplay improvements, though I didn't play her in the first game. She has a shield, multiple ranged options, a float, but is relatively slow on the baseline mobility. This isn't actually an issue, and she is actually capable of beating stage times faster than Lilac when you use the various techniques available in her kit to maintain speed. I'm not finished with her playthrough, yet.

Neera is the new character, and her gameplay was actually quite enjoyable. She has the simplest method of acceleration, and an incredible horizontal mobility available to her. While her combat kit has more of a 'stand your ground' feel to it, she has some interesting tools that can help her out in situations. Like the other characters, she has variances in her kit that make her better or worse than others, depending on the situation/boss.

Story:
All cutscenes, and including in-between stage dialogue, are fully voice acted. The voice acting has improved a lot since FP1 for each character returning. There is some incredibly emotional deliveries by several characters, showcasing their range and skill. The story itself is quite expansive, namely building the world, and continuing from the first game with a lot of cohesion. The writing of the dialogue is strong to every character's personality and presentation, and no one feels "dumb" or out of place in how they respond to situations. This is used to be both comical, and serious, at times. Each character has special interactions with other characters in their own playthroughs, and additional cutscenes the others won't see. For example, Lilac has more/special interactions with Merga, while Carol has additional ones with Corazon. Due to some timing of how missions play out in the sequence in each story, characters will have perspectives from different cutscenes in different places, even. They really put a lot of effort into fleshing this out, and it shows. As for the totality of the story, it's not bad. Some might find it generic, but it's very polished otherwise.

The addition of Neera was a surprise, but welcome design. She is actually a great character, and I think they did a fantastic job with her inclusion.

Level Design:
Some of the new levels are fantastic, both visually, and gameplay-wise. Some kind of drag, and how you feel about that will be subjective. I don't enjoy Shade Armory or Ancestral Forge that much, but Lunar Cannon is an absolute visual masterpiece and experience, and Weapons Core is incredibly sad in relation to the story. No level was absolutely painful to play, and due to the differences in the characters, they will each have varying levels of difficulty/ease in each one. I like this differentiation between the characters' kits actually making them unique to play.

Art:
You can just look at a screenshot comparison if you want to see how big a contrast is. FP2 has solidified new designs for every character, and they are fantastically detailed, with the sprite work going so far as conveying their emotions in tandem with the voice acting super well. The levels are pretty, and distinct, and the game never feels like it has a visual clutter to it. The bosses are also sporting fantastic designs, along with the visual effects. Truly one of my all-time favorite sprite-centric games.

Music:
This soundtrack is amaz~zing. Absolute bangers on it. Even the opening menu is fantastic, though I think Lightning Tower or the final two boss tracks might be my favorites. Seriously, give it a listen.

FINAL WORD:
If you are into action-platformers or any kind, I cannot recommend this game enough. Recommending FP1 is... hard, though the story is extremely relevant to this game. Whether you want to get the first is up to you, but I absolutely think this is worth a play. It spent a long time in development, but what we got is a masterpiece of a sequel through and through.

I'm curious about the inspirations to this game, as Lilac plays most like Sparkster from Rocket Knight Adventures (2), though each character sort of functions like they have a similar charge system for their strongest abilities. Sometimes I also feel like Gunstar Heroes was an inspiration. And, of course, Sonic was the original inspiration.

author: {'steamid': '76561199041956065', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1350, 'last_played': 1699134292}
review: Freedom Planet and Freedom Planet 2 are some of my favourite "Sonic the Hedgehog" games. There were a couple of maze-like levels that I found had annoying parts, but most of the levels are very fun to rip through. They are usually vibrant and have some cool, speed-related gameplay ideas that are the type of innovation that 2D Sonic games could use more of. Bosses are typically fun. The characters are usually fun and/or corny, but the story-line is quite dark, which can give it an uneven tone. Not that either are bad, but there may be some tonal whiplash.  Overall, the game is really good: 7.8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073063049', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 30, 'playtime_at_review': 3498, 'last_played': 1712267033}
review:
Spectacular sequel. I love that they took their time and packed this absoulte masterpiece. 
I enjoyed every part of it. Waiting so long and being able to live an evolved world of Avalice felt like being at home.
Pretty much everything improved from the first chapter I'd say.
The art style is just gorgeous, even a lot of NPCs seem to be important character for how much personality the style gives to them. The music is fantastic as well, I listen to it while working from time to time.
Not to say that is a perfect game, but I couldn't point out any major flaws, and my first playthrough in the story was one of my best experiences in the last years (but it was also due to the fact that I loved the world and character and was curious to know how the story went).

It's simple, immediate to play, stylish, cool story, amazing characters (which clearly you enjoy a lot more if you played the first, although it's still enjoyable as the focus is the gameplay), and most important very fun to play. Playstyle is very different depending on the character, but at least for me everyone is fun to play with

author: {'steamid': '76561198888044914', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5563, 'last_played': 1696086597}
review:
Freedom Planet или Freedom Planet 2? Ответ: однозначно вторая часть "Свободной Планеты"! В ней прекрасно почти все! Есть, конечно, несколько нюансов, но к ним придираться не особо хочется. Графика, выполненная в pixelart стиле яркая, не режет глаз, левел-дизайн пестрит разнообразием, а персонажи меня прям порадовали, особенно Милла и Нирра. Сюжет от банального клише "Добро против Зла" (как это было в первой части) перешел на тему конфликта, основанного на ошибках прошлого и печальной истории главного антагониста. Саундтрек тоже на высшем уровне, я слышал, что большинство претензий именно к музыке, но это полный бред, саундтрек отличный, некоторые композиции отсылают к первой части игры. 
Обязательно пройдите игру за всех персонажей, чтобы выбрать для себя любимую. 

P.S. небольшой спойлер, чтобы предупредить тех, кому этот момент может испортить впечатление от игры. Дело в том, что Мерга (главная злодейка игры) - лесбиянка. Да-да, знаю, многим это уже надоело, но уверяю вас, может я плохо разбираюсь в сюжетах, но лично для меня этот момент не портит игру от слова совсем ибо разработчики очень грамотно прописали персонажа, а не как Activision-Blizzard, EA и Ubisoft. Для кого-то это может быть все ровно не приятно, но я к этому не стану предъявлять претензии. Отдаю должное Сабрине Дидуро и всей команде GalaxyTrail!

author: {'steamid': '76561198135271909', 'num_games_owned': 467, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1982, 'last_played': 1696168282}
review:
This is my second time finishing this game and I’m convinced it’s one of the best platformers thusfar this decade. The gamefeel is on point balancing fast speeds with robust combat mechanics. Even though you zip through levels at breakneck paces, the camera readjusts itself for every occasion and there’s even an option to make it more or less adaptable to your speed. The presentation is delightful with bright, beautiful pixel art and excellent sound design with great music, too.

I think the reason why FP2 isn’t more celebrated is because it’s a surprisingly dedicated experience. All the characters have robust movesets that get some taking used to, even if the basic control scheme is simple and intuitive. Despite the overt Sonic inspirations, the game is very fight focused– taking a lot of verbs from character action games (including a very necessary guard mechanic). Many levels are sprawling– a number of them clocking over ten minutes if you do a lot of exploring– and almost [i]ALL[/i] of them feature a boss fight at the end. The challenge level ramps up quickly. The first time I played this game, I saw a lot of game overs.

Those aren’t [i]flaws[/i], but I think most people would be caught off-guard by the amount of Give A Damn the player has to bring to Freedom Planet 2. There’s an easy mode, and I haven’t tried it, but I think even if it makes getting to credits less of a trial, it’s probably an inelegant solution in which the ferocity of the game will still ebb on players. This game will take most 10 to 15 hours and by the end– partially in thanks of the game’s intense final act– the players will have had their fill.

But I guess what I’m saying is: Freedom Planet 2 is a [i]feast[/i]. It’s A Lot but what’s there is very good and will be an irreplaceable platforming experience for some players, myself included. Tackling this casually– it’s probably a good time but not something exemplary. I hope this game finds an audience with those that would really cherish, though, because it’s something truly special.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989384438', 'num_games_owned': 3309, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 3608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3244, 'last_played': 1708392078}
review:
It took a while for the game to click with me, but once it did I grew to enjoy it even more than the first game which I already liked a lot! It's basically just more Freedom Planet, everything cranked up a notch, as any good sequel should strive to do.

It's a big, BIG game. Almost 30 full stages with a smattering of towns, boss stages and optional challenges. I reached a point where I assumed it was the end of the game and didn't realize I wasn't even halfway done! The levels are huge and the pixel art is gorgeous to look at, all the levels have their own quirks and gimmicks, like one being entirely progressed vertically, one having you collect keys to proceed, yes there's even a water level but don't worry because it's not a slog like a lot of other games, there's a lot of boosters and the ability to swim to keep this sort of level from slowing things down.

There's a few stages that are purely just long boss encounters, and the side-scrolling horizontal shooter stage makes a return here too. There are some arena gauntlet style challenges unlocked as you progress that have you do things like navigate a maze, defeat waves of enemies in a particularly cumbersome arena and basically show a mastery of the mechanics introduced in all the levels you've finished so far.

Currency earned can be spent on items you can equip that either help or hinder your progress. The more hindrance you have, the higher your completion rank will be on the stage results and the more currency you earn. So for example, you could equip an item that gives you only 1 life, but doing so would give you more rewards at the end, which is a neat idea. There's also a museum you can spend currency in to unlock dioramas of all the bosses in the game, it doesn't serve any functional purpose other than being just something else you can work to collect. Some equippable items can only be found in hidden areas in stages, the stages with items unfound are marked which is helpful so you know what you're missing from where. The last collectible worth mentioning are the vinyl records which unlock music tracks.

And on the subject of music, the soundtrack in this game slaps hard.

Easily one of the best 2D platformers ever made, you won't regret picking it up if those sorts of games are your thing.

The issues I do have are quite nitpicky and I fully acknowledge it's just me being a whiner and don't much detract from the overall enjoyment, but the three things I personally felt didn't work...

1) The story. At best it's a serviceable way of tying all the stages together, but it's just not that interesting as a story and there's too much of it. As someone who is very susceptible to emotional storytelling and grows attached to endearing characters, I felt absolutely nothing here. It's not that it's a small part of the game, either. A lot of time and effort goes into the cutscenes which just makes it all the more grating because I see what they're trying to do and falling flat. Also, "classic mode" for playing without cutscenes is only unlocked after beating the game.
Edit: Thinking about it more, it's probably less to do with the actual story being bad and just the way it's presented. It's way too dialogue-heavy and would have worked better with a show-don't-tell approach, because it's not an overly complicated plot once you trim the fat and cut the threads that don't lead anywhere.

2) The main characters. I'm not big on their designs even in the first game, but even less so for their redesigns. What makes this worse is that pretty much every new NPC added in this game looks far better than all the returning characters. I imagine the idea was to try and distance the series from Sonic games by making the characters taller and without the big heads, which worked great for all these original characters designed from the ground up with this new style in mind, but makes the original characters stand out in a bad way.

3) Lilac gameplay. This is more of a me-problem I guess, but I really dislike her cyclone ability. It's a double-jump that makes her spin like a tornado and cause damage as she goes and I have three gripes here. One, the tornado will keep spinning for a short while after landing on ground and if you try to jump before the spin animation stops, you only jump at around half the height as usual. Two, the constant voice sample when using a skill that you'll be using most of the time becomes annoying and there's no option to turn it off without disabling all voices in the game entirely. Three, it also seems to be the strongest attack you have and I spent a good portion of my first playthrough assuming that the super attack and melee combos would be the biggest damage dealers on bosses when I should have just been spamming double-jump.

review: Almost a year after this game came out, I'm finally writing on here that it is truly a sequel that was worth the wait, and it improves on the original in pretty much every way, when the first game was already great. It's bigger, plays better, sounds better, looks better, and even the storytelling is improved. author: {'steamid': '76561198054690449', 'num_games_owned': 1377, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 3205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3205, 'last_played': 1691279793}
review:
If you like 2D Sonic games and/or Freedom Planet 1, you'll have a good time here.  There are indications of the series trying to carve out its own identity and the story offers possibilities for a third game (I hope there's a third game anyways).  

The game runs stable, but there is the occasional bug where loading up will take a little while, but no outright freezes.  My main gripe is the lack of stage variety between playable characters.  They all play the same stages in the same order, though the play styles vary greatly with each character.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972544686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 951, 'last_played': 1691010376}
review:
Great follow-up to Freedom Planet. Neera is a good addition to the playable cast being more combat-oriented than the other characters, the returning characters have new moves and are more fun to play as (especially Milla), the new Guard mechanic is a lot of fun to play with once you get the hang of it, and there's a huge new set of varied levels. The new graphics look great - if the first game felt like a long-lost Genesis game, the sequel feels like a long-lost Saturn game. The music doesn't have as many catchy melodies as the first game's soundtrack but it's still very good.

There's also a new item system where you can buy and equip items before a level, but I mostly didn't bother with it because almost all of the items are to make the game easier in various ways and I felt the standard difficulty was reasonable. There are a small handful of items that increase the difficulty but also give a bonus to your ranking at the end of the stage.

My biggest complaint is that Classic Mode isn't available from the start like it was in FP1. I didn't like the first game's story/writing at all, and I gave the sequel a chance but I didn't like this one's story/writing at all either. Adventure Mode at least lets you skip all the cutscenes, but there are still occasional interruptions like mid-stage dialogue and hub areas, and you don't get the short dialogue-free boss intro scenes that Classic Mode has.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082511092', 'num_games_owned': 702, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2775, 'last_played': 1692158808}
review:
This game is honestly one of my favorite platformers of all time, and I loved FP1 heavily.

It's got pretty sprites, lots of levels that don't overstay their welcome, and good replayability.

And the parry mechanic in this game is really good and fun to use, major points for that mechanic alone.

Also, it comes with decent item loadouts, which I liked.

The only few things that I prefer in FP1 over FP2 are the following:

[h1]1 - The Music: [/h1]
The OST in this game is still great and lively, it's just that FP1 does that better imo, some of the soundtracks feel like they're messing something to make 'em pop.

Overall, great music, Nalao Lake is probably my favorite.

[h1]2 - The Main Villain, Merga: [/h1]
I personally think the story is structured better than in the first one, but at the same time FP1 has the better main villain, [b]Lord Brevon[/b].

Honestly, Lord Brevon is one of my favorite indie villains, smuggy and violent. The (in)famous torture scene in FP1 is what made me love him. You might call me an edgy for it, I don't mind, I feel like game stories should bring out the violence in villains, I mean he's a villain, of course he would be violent, it's makes the fiction a bit more real, but not too real imo.

Merga in the other hand just didn't hit the mark for me, I don't really hate her or even dislike her, she's just not as exciting as Brevon, not even close.
Good villain introduction, and a cool ass ship she got, but spoiler alert in the true ending, it made her lamer for me personally.
Not bad, but it isn't Brevon.

This game has 4 playable character, 3 of them are fun to play, but the character that I was interested in the most to try, Neera Li, came as a bit of a disappointment.
She's the "hardest" to play yes, I usually love playing the challenging characters, but she's really not that fun to play, I could get into details why, but I'll just she's doesn't feel as rewarding as playing the other 3 characters.

Overall, a fantastic game, shame it released at a very bad time, I wish it was more popular if it had a proper release date.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008230359', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1688838106}
review:
Freedom Planet 1 was really good, so I don't understand what happened with Freedom Planet 2. 

I like the pixel art, character design and overall presentation. The music is pretty good too. Unfortunately that's where my praise ends. 

There's no way to play the levels without being forced into story mode. The level design is rather long and boring. The story and NPC's really don't add any weight to the story. It reads like a sonic satam fan fiction and there's nothing wrong with that in itself but the tone is too inconsistent that I don't really buy it. Boss battles are very annoying, with very odd hit boxes and way too much HP, even on beginner mode. It honestly feels like a game that doesn't know what it wants to be, inspired by both MegaMan X4+ and Sonic. I really wanted to like this game, but the entire thing just felt like a chore to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198966882450', 'num_games_owned': 58, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 111, 'playtime_at_review': 3532, 'last_played': 1712256562}
review: A fantastic action platformer that is worth your time if your willing to learn it's mechanics. It has a great difficulty system in which items can be equipped to make the game easier or harder in various different aspects. It also contains combat gameplay that will really test your reflexes. Endearing characters and a pretty good story make this one a joy to playthrough. Pick this one up if you enjoy high-speed platformers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198337293465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3598, 'last_played': 1701963226}
review:
TL;DR
If you enjoy the 2D Sonic games or just fast 2D platformers in general, you literally can't go wrong with this game whatsoever. 9/10


TS;DR
I was a bit hesitant on picking this game up at first, but one 100% run through the game later, and I can safely say this game is simply a god-tier 2D Platformer. The artstyle, music, writing, characters, controls, level design, and everything in between all fit neatly together to make an amazing ride from start to end. All 4 characters feel so fun and different to play that it honestly makes repeat playthroughs worth it and super enjoyable (It's also cool seeing your specific character's POV in the story). As with most Sonic games, there's nothing like mastering a stage and being able to breeze past obstacles at light speeds. All the stages feel like playgrounds all with different toys to mess with.
Man. What a good game lol
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198414305084', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 257, 'playtime_at_review': 2037, 'last_played': 1711591532}
review:
I haven't finished the game lol but I've played over 60% the game probably as Neera.

Feels like the first game, which I love, although SOMEHOW with all the bugs the first game had like if the system was ported. The bugs aren't bad though, they won't usually ruin anything. They're more-so the FUN type of bugs.

I genuinely think FP1 and FP2's boss design is some of the best boss design I've seen in a game, well... this and Pizza Tower. I wish more bosses in games allowed you to absolutely floor them if you exploit every nook and cranny of the boss or if you have the know-how to attack the boss and dodge simultaneously.

The new parry system is fun too once you get it down, it allows you to get through stuff way faster with a little bit of timing or to even attack bosses faster, it has it's limits so you have to understand those before you REALLY get into doing that stuff. I think this is probably one of the main reasons this game feels different despite the old movement system and gameplay based off FP1. 

I also like the new implementation of the full charge attacks, they feel really good to use here unlike FP1. In FP1 they felt kind of unsatisfying to use for the power VS how long they took to charge.


The movement is really fun like REALLY fun.  I genuinely didn't expect Neera to actually feel different but she feels great to play movement and combat-wise.  

The stages in this game look actually insanely beautiful, no seriously, there's pixel art backgrounds with several parallax layers which make the stages look MASSIVE! Most of the stages feel very distinct and have unique themes that make them stand out.

There's also a bunch of talk-able NPCs with dialog for several points in the game. Several lobby areas where you can buy really fun modifiers that boost how many crystals you get.

The music is really good! Definetely sounds distinct from FP1 and it feels more intense in most cases.

Story's pretty good, I don't have much area to judge in there since I don't know much about story writing also because I haven't finished the story.

It's really fun and despite being long as heck, doesn't bore me like most games by the later stages. I'd genuinely put this as my GOTY.

author: {'steamid': '76561199403330906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3823, 'last_played': 1689176592}
review:
Es un muy buen juego.
Mejora el sistema de combate con los 3 personajes principales y  agrega un nuevo personaje para esta secuela. Ahora, cada personaje se juega diferente y son muchísimo más disfrutables los combates contra jefes.
Dejando de lado que hay escenarios en donde hay uno que otro enemigo posicionado de manera cuestionables, los niveles son bastante mejores que la primera entrega. No se como describirlos, pero se sienten más fluidos, más rapidos; y cuando empiezas a conocer los mapas te das cuenta de las alternativas que tienes para acabar un nivel en el menor tiempo posible.
La música es maravillosa, sea o no que te guste este juego, es imposible negar que la compositora de la misma hizo un gran trabajo. Tiene bastantes temas pegadizos, de esos que se te quedan pegados y hasta taradeas de vez en cuando.
Dejando de lado, que tengo una que otra queja con los potencioadores y el jefe final del juego, seguire pensando que es un juego maravilloso.
Sabrina Diduro se lucio muchisimo dirigiendo este juego, ojala algun dia salga tanto un parche con el idioma español, asi como una 3ra entrega que resuelva las dudas que dejo la secuela.
Por mi parte recomiendo este juego y que se animen a jugarlo y probarlo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026498129', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 910, 'last_played': 1686859775}
review:
I dont understand what the positive hype is around this game. Its an average one at best. Even though the game looks very good and has an alright story behind it. 

Its a 2D high speed platformer similar to sonic, but with fighting mechanics added into it. Now this is a really great idea and the boss fights can be fun, but GalaxyTrail messed up on one important thing. The Guard/Parry move. It has this weird delay to it where you have to press it before the projectile or attack hits you, not when its about it hit you. Your character will gain some I-frames and negate the attack entirely. It doesnt really help either when you are being attacked by multiple enemies or projectiles. I dont understand why they dropped the ball on this and they should look at other games on how parry is done right. Guard is useful in some situations but useless in most others. You might as well dodge by jumping over the projectile and not worry about guarding at all.

Another issue is the level design. A lot of the level layouts can be confusing and very chaotic. There are also these mini puzzles that can be confusing or difficult to navigate. There were some levels that were done right and those being the ones with very long roads and few enemies in between. None of that jump puzzle BS either.

The story is an okay one, but it kind of has a disappointing ending with a cliffhanger and it calls for another sequel to be made. [Spoiler] What the heck happened to Merga after the whole Bakunawa gets destroyed? Lilac said she was going to search for her but we dont even get a cut scene for it. [/Spoiler] Is this included in the secret ending?  Fuck that, Im not playing through the whole game again to try and get it. Its been a frustrating experience for me already. [Spoiler] Also I dont like how the other villians just got a slap on the wrist for treason. Like come on! Put them in jail for awhile! [/Spoiler]

Anyways, Freedom Planet 2 is mostly a frustrating experience. With its chaotic level design, cheap boss fights, and a broken guard move that is almost pointless. I wouldnt give this game a full recommendation. 

Hopefully the next sequel they will learn from their mistakes by making a functional guard move, and overall improve on the level designs and bosses so it can be called a fair challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198432565652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 7302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5718, 'last_played': 1705780643}
review:
Bem, Freedom Planet 2, a tão aguardada sequência do primeiro.
Já adianto que o game é awesome, muito bonito e bem gostoso de jogar.

De upgrades na gameplay, agora você pode se defender! (adeus dano barato!)

Aqui você pode zerar o game com uma de 4 personagem, cada uma tendo suas habilidades e divergências no plot (com seus plots próprios, mas totalmente ligados ao principal, e as fases são todas as mesmas).
Falando individualmente delas:
A Lilac tá igual ao primeiro, bem eficaz, mas com troques novos como o Boost Cancel e aquele dash pra frente depois da defesa.
A Carol está totalmente diferente, tendo muitos mais ataques e artifícios que a fazem ser super versátil, de encontro a sua versão do primeiro game em que você é bem vulnerável (tendo só os chutes em sequência como defesa). Esses artifícios incluem um chute aéreo que te mantém no ar, uma voadora que te ajuda a pegar muita velocidade e o disco que te faz grudar no inimigo.
A Milla tá bem diferentona também, bem adaptada a uma gameplay mais frenética, tendo um foco bem maior em seus cubos em vez de ataques físicos. Além de refletir, ela ainda atira cubinhos e solta o laser de forma bem mais rápida.
A Neera é a nova e pra mim é a mais legal. Dá muito dano, porém é meio complicado de se jogar com ela por conta de sua precisão com os ataques, é bem fácil de acabar ultrapassando o inimigo ao atacá-lo, mas ao pegar o jeito... todo mundo some. A habilidade Focus faz com que ela aumente muito sua velocidade de ataque e, se estiver dentro do consumo da barrinha, pode largar uma magia no final (você pode manter a barrinha ao atingir inimigos também!)

A dificuldade do jogo é bem interessante, bem customizável, não há "easy", "normal" e "hard", as opções apenas já predefinem um set de itens (sejam pedras que te dão vantagens ou Brave Stones, que dão desvantagens) e configurações que você pode modificar por conta em qualquer momento do game. Quanto ao game em si, ela é justa quando a fase não sobrecarrega de inimigos na tela.

Quanto ao plot, fiquei satisfeito, explorando a lore de Avalice e de sua "época colonial", porém neste mundo não houve independência. 
O plot da Lilac é sobre ela descobrindo sobre o passado sombrio de sua espécie, dando até mesmo uma revelação sobre seu próprio passado. 
O plot da Carol é com sua irmã, que está com a vilã, sendo vista como inimiga por suas companheiras e tendo que lidar com essa divergência. Gosto de suas interações.
O plot da Milla dá mais detalhes sobre seu passado, só o momento em que ela fica com medo de suas amigas a verem como um monstro por também ser de outro planeta (contando com seu propósito de combate) que ficou meio bobinho demais, mas vai que a intenção era justamente que ela estivesse sendo boba e apenas precisava que alguém deixasse isso claro (quem nunca :v). A propósito, ela de fato tem pais ou ela é uma bio-arma completamente artificial?
O plot da Neera é com ela se tornando um pouco mais tolerante a resoluções mais tranquilas das situações ao invés de ser radical. Achei o mais fraco, mas eu gostei bastante da personagem e suas interações.
A vilã é bacana, ela intimida e é bem forte, porém ainda prefiro o Brevon pois, por conta do plot, você perde o medo dela e começa a ter dó, já o Brevon é intimidador do início ao fim ("I would like to see you try" é mil vezes melhor que as 48 frases que ela solta no começo da boss fight.). Apesar disso, a lore dela é bacana e compensa essa desvantagem (que pode ser meramente frescura minha :v)

Os personagens novos são bem legais, a Corazon deixa a campanha da Carol bem interessante, o Aaa fornece momentos cômicos, o Capitão Kalaw é bem divertido e o Askal é... bem, sua motivação e perda de controle da situação é interessante, mas ele e sua relação com a Neera ficaram obscuros demais (ou eu que dei uma de tonto e não percebi nada, dando a impressão de que foi bem superficial).
Serpentine... bem, ele virou uma piada. Por um lado isso é bom pois agora ele tem uma personalidade mais visível, por outro lado perdeu qualquer intimidação que ele poderia provocar, mas no fim eu mentiria se dissesse que ele não me divertiu.
Spade... ficou bem legal! Seus sprites além de o deixarem super carismático visualmente, sua personalidade convencida casou super bem com os mesmos.

As fases são divertidas, sendo até mesmo bacaninhas de se explorar (mesmo sendo jogo de correr). No máximo a Inverso Dynamo e aquelas fases da treta entre o Serpentine e o Aaa que são um saco, dá pra tomar muito dano barato.

A trilha sonora é bacana, gosto bastante dos temas de Parusa, minhas favoritas são a da Gravity Bubble, Ancient Forge e a da Adventure Square.

De defeitos, só uns bugs aqui e ali (como o escudo da Milla deixando passar projéteis, mas aconteceu só em duas boss fights específicas) e a Brave Stone do timer não ser bem balanceada nas rematches da Battlesphere, 1 minuto pra todos os chefões (desisti de uns 3), mas as 5 fases lunares da Merga você tem 3 minutos (sobram uns 2min30). 

Falando na Battlesphere, achei ela fraca, você joga suas fases mais por obrigação de zerar o game de verdade, pelo dever em vez da diversão. Talvez se houvessem objetivos mais definidos e recompensas bem mais interessantes.

Falando nisso de "zerar de verdade", talvez seria bem mais divertido ter que encontrar as Time Capsules nas fases (talvez resolvendo um puzzlezinho fácil no processo) em vez de todas menos uma ficarem na Battlesphere, e a única que você de fato tem que encontrar fica super exposto.

Mas bem, essas foram minhas impressões após ter platinado o game, valeu a pena o tempo investido. 
Obrigado, Galaxy Trail, pela experiência!


(E a Milla continua adorável.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198146390507', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1065, 'last_played': 1685919036}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010898209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3320, 'last_played': 1685904100}
review:
The sequel that got hit with 4 years of delays, maybe 5, it was so long I can't remember. With all that time, it had big expectations from me to live up to, and fortunately it came out pretty good. It's clear if you played the first game that with the sequel they wanted to set themselves apart a bit more from the spiky blue guy who runs fast, redesigning the characters and adding a little more focus to the combat. Fans of Sonic games or the first Freedom Planet should absolutely give this one a go... There's even a free demo!

In general, the entire scale of the game compared to the last one is much larger as one would expect. While the levels are shorter, being comprised of stage rather than 2 parts separated by a miniboss, there are a lot more of them. There's an additional playable character bringing the total to 4. There's an area you can freely revisit that has a bunch of short challenges and a few minigames to partake in. There's even a secret ending!

Every character's mobility has been improves since the last game as well, so navigating the stages can be a little easier, and there's an ingenious option to zoom the camera out when you're speeding around! And there's a new guard feature, so incoming unavoidable attacks can still be dodged with some good timing.

It's hard to comment on the game's difficulty, as it's tied to optional items you can equip/remove when selecting a stage. I found it to be pretty fair overall, though without the items I believe it's a little too easy, and using those items increase your rewards at the end of a stage, so they're worth using if you care about ranks or 100%ing the game.

Possibly the most welcome improvement of all: The voice volume slider. No longer do you have to subject yourself to the sometimes grating voice acting this game offers, though you'll miss out on one NPC voiced by Chris Sabat if you do.

Oh, the soundtrack is good too. It's a great game overall, and a worthy sequel. It may be even better than the first, personally I'd say are equal.

author: {'steamid': '76561199068241514', 'num_games_owned': 68, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 90, 'playtime_at_review': 1919, 'last_played': 1712354229}
review: One of the best video game experiences I've ever had, made even better after playing through the first game. I could see a lot of passion was put into it. It feels great controlling each character, smashing up robots and speeding through the large set of stages. The hub areas do a great job at making the world feel big and each npc gets their own unique dialogue, with their own personalities. The music is great as well. The story, writing, and voice acting all come together to make something pretty cool. The visuals look spectacular, with some of the best sprites and backgrounds I've ever seen in a game. Everything looks so beautiful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126428399', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1775, 'last_played': 1710088945}
review: Absolutely incredible platformer and an even better sequel. I've been burned many many many many times by sequels that fail to live up to name of its predecessor, losing the charm that made the original so interesting/fun, and I am very happy to say that this game does not fall among them. While the first game existed mainly as an homage to the classic Sonic games, this game strikes further out from this material without leaving behind much of what was so good about its source, and I have to say I think it turned out pretty well. It certainly doesn't skimp on the length of the story as well, as there were several points where I was expecting the game to be drawing towards a satisfactory conclusion before having a whole new area open up with more levels. Upon writing this, I have only beaten the game twice in 30 hours (Lilac and Neera) without going excessively for collectibles or for speedrunning, so I think it's a pretty fair assessment of the games length. Speaking of the story, its quality hasn't changed much from its predecessor, so if the story/voice-acting of the original really turned you off of it, then I'm sure that this game will do much of the same. The voices are of noticeably better quality, but there are still a good few lines here-and-there that I feel had some odd-directions behind it. Regardless, I would overwhelmingly say that this game is worth playing, even without having completed the original, and I feel so sad about the fact that this game doesn't seem to be as big or popular as it deserves to be. There are so many aspects to this game that show the fine hand of detail that went into crafting these environments for such a diverse range of character abilities that no other platformer I've seen, AAA, indie, or otherwise, can compete.
