review: This was a really fun time! The gameplay improvements over the original really feel right at home and it's a very polished experience. As for the story, I really enjoyed the new characters, especially Merga. I do think the game feels like the middle chapter of a trilogy though. Without spoiling things, even when getting the true ending it still feels a bit anti-climatic. It's more of a setup for what may happen next than a stand alone entry I feel. Regardless, I'm very much looking forward to what Galax Trails has in store for the future!

review: A fantastic 2D platformer in the 16-bit style. There are tons of levels and each of them does a good job introducing and playing with a new game mechanic. The sense of speed is done really well here, it's super satisfying. I could never get into Sonic, but I think this game nails how it should have been.

author: {'steamid': '76561199366292597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1184, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1712450426}
review: Esse jogo é uma grande surpresa. Muito ágil, fluido e divertido. Tem várias cutscenes, mas elas não cansam você e não atrapalham o ritmo do jogo. As personagens têm um estilo mais fofinho e infantil, mas são criativas e carismáticas. O jogo tem até voice acting. Enfim, tudo muito bem feito. Jamais pensei que teria tanta diversão com um jogo 2d em 2023.

author: {'steamid': '76561199133488274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2519, 'last_played': 1703767932}
review:
after 100%ing the game, i believe that this game is pretty darn good. the game has a very customisable difficulty and lets you think of different ways of beating stages with the help or curse of items. The gameplay is clean and fast pased, think of it as Gunstar Heroes fused with Sonic. the music, although a bit of a downgrade from the first game, it does have a lot of good tunes. my only ick about the music is where they put the music. According the composer who got DMed a similar question, They had little to no clue where the music was going to be where. this leads to the music just not fitting the scenario. eg, the boss themes. although they are bops, they don't sound like boss themes. a later stage in the game uses the "snowfields" motif from the first game, which to me doesn't fit the stage. the graphics, are stunning. Seriously, Tyson Tan did a incredible job on the sprite work. The story telling is a vast inprovement compared to the first game, no more is there inconsistent mic quality and random changes between "cooties" and electric torture. it's told superbly and I still think Jason Lord takes the cake with his performance.

Overall, this game is a blast to go through and i'd give it a 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015890349', 'num_games_owned': 68, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 4668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1703995221}
review:
I'm just getting warmed up in this game and I'm already having a fantastic time. This game is huge and is a must to have game in your library. Once you got to like Sonic games or Freedom Planet 1, you'll be happy playing this one.

What are the best features to mention? Well, there's plenty:

- Absolutely nice graphics despite it being pixelated and butterlight PC specs is just enough for this.

- Really rich story and layers of gameplays with missions to select during our adventure.

- Really challenging stages with tons of items to use in order to form specific playstyles.

- Characters has "types" to organize of what are the best abilities they have but non of them are lacking in speed if used the right way just as usual.

- Major Zhao and his golden moments. Just never gets old. (+5 RATING)

- The return of Spade! Holy Jesus we see a badass character in new colours! What a time to be alive!

- Literally everyone's kit and playstyle has been changed a little bit since FP1 plus we have Neera which is a big one.

- Battle and Training arena being implemented in the game, where I can fight other characters.

- Towns with great environs and cool citizens.

- When the main heroines are there to fight for you alongside your chosen character in the story is a satisfaction matter. I love every second of it just like how I loved to see it in the first game.

There's a lot other wholesome elements to mention ahead about the game, so this review will be edited later as I get in-depth experience of the game entirely.

Deserves the perfect 10/10, no questions.

author: {'steamid': '76561199229631605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1702429541}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053280840', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 7521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1619, 'last_played': 1706241525}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 has been a great time and am very happy with how it turned out. I was and am a huge fan of the first game. I remember getting it on the Wii U back in 2015 and enjoying the hell out of it. Now we have a sequel and how does it far against the first? 

Well, there are certainly differences. The combat has had some tweaks, mainly with the addition of a dodge/parry. I think this does make the fighting overall easier, but more fluid and engaging.

The Characters have also gotten some tweaks to their combat and how they traverse the stage. Lilac pretty much follows the same concept as the first game. Carol is still Carol, but instead of the move where she does a flurry of kicks, she now has a circular-bladed weapon that she throws, and can also jump too, giving her more movement options. I can't comment on Milla however, because I didn't play her through the first game. 

The visuals and art style have also gotten a huge upgrade, and I feel it helps to distinguish it more from Sonic games and gives it more of its own unique identity. It also makes the world feel so grand when traveling through the stages and looking off into the beautiful landscape. It's obvious a lot of love and hard work went into the pixel art and they truly did a great job. 

The story wasn't of much importance to me in the first game, and truthfully I vaguely remember what happened. What I do remember from the first game though was how corny a lot of the cut scenes were. In FP2 I feel like the story has improved simply from the fact that there weren't any cheesy lines that made me want to skip the scenes. In fact, there were a few moments that legit gave me a good laugh. Overall, I enjoyed the story well enough, and it was engaging enough to make me want to keep playing. 

Now one thing I did want to mention, is that the game feels really grand, almost too grand. I meant in terms of size. These levels are long with many different paths you can take. As a completionist, it can be rather daunting going through trying to find all the collectibles. There is so much to explore in each stage and can be easy to overlook a little nook or cranny where the item is hiding. This is one downside for me, but after playing through all the stages, I realized it wasn't as bad as I though, but still an annoyance, at least in regards to finding the collectibles. 

Overall I love Freedom Planet 2. It has fun, exciting and challenging gameplay with lovable characters (minus Neera) and a beautiful world. I think most people who enjoyed the first one will enjoy FP2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044795510', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1688309574}
review:
Freedom Planet is one of my most favorite franchise ever. The sequel has amazing gameplay and fun story just like the original with fantastic music and stages and fun boss battles. I still haven't beaten the game yet BUT I'm already excited for a 3rd one when I finish this game. I'm not kidding... This is the kind of game you need to experience! DiDuro is a fuckin genius! Everyone behind developing this game are Gods! 

This game deserves a Game of the Year Awards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051123143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1729, 'last_played': 1673910163}
review:
If you enjoyed the first Freedom Planet, you have no reason not to play this game, amazing sequel that delivers on all the aspects that made the first game great, packed with some improvements. Thumbs up to the added gameplay options and tweaks on pre-existing playable characters, especially for Carol.

And if you did not play Freedom Planet before, you definitely should if you enjoy fast-paced platforming with multiple playable characters, diverse levels and a banger soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104488872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1663778407}
review:
If you enjoyed how the first game played out, then you'll like how this game kept everything you loved and turned things up to 11!
Great music. Character gameplay has improved and they feel more diverse than previously, especially with the addition of another character in the playable roster. Bosses are fun and the story...
My word, the STORY!
Just play the game for yourself. It's honestly worth the money and it helps support the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031619767', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 3756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1708380383}
review:
This game took every minor gripe I had with the original and came out with an absolute masterpiece. I'm seriously blown away by the quality, the amount of content, and the surprisingly very enjoyable story. It masterfully takes the best of the genre and merges it all into a near-perfect package,

If you're a fan of this kind of game at all, do yourself a favor and pick this game up. I guarantee at the very least you'll like it. Inherent to the sonic dna in this game, at first the game will be a bit tricky, but as you progress you'll have the movement and flow click with you and make you eager to dive back in and time-attack or play through again with the different characters.

This really is more than that though, this game stands on its own two feet with a unique identity of its own, and with a game THIS good, I really look forward to whatever the days may be working on in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269473406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 314, 'playtime_at_review': 2651, 'last_played': 1712286491}
review: If you like 2D platformers, there's no reason not to get this one. It's a great time and there's a good amount of content, need I say more?

author: {'steamid': '76561199287954614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1679696716}
review: So far platforming and story is very fun and the level designs are unique and interesting. The pixel art is honestly fantastic and a lot of the stages had me in awe. The only criticisms I would have is that stages are quite long than what most platformers are like (tho obviously similar to the first game) and the bosses can be pretty frustrating at times, though even that is pretty preferential. Definitely give this one a shot if you liked the first game or you're just a sonic fan idk.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074042816', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 818, 'last_played': 1710057085}
review: A very worthy successor to the first, even surpassing it in some areas. The story surprised me in its quality, and getting to know more about the world of Avalice was very intriguing. The gameplay was good as well, though I am sure it would be even more enjoyable for someone who grew up playing games like the 2D Sonic games (which I did not). The voice acting was great once again, as well as the sound design as a whole. Admittedly, the music was not quite as good as the first's (with some exceptions), but it doesn't detract from the game too much. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198115338032', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1123, 'last_played': 1673478229}
review: Beautiful looking spritework with some of the most fun platforming I've played yet, really charming characters and a surprisingly interesting story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205894283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2035, 'last_played': 1687932507}
review:
In some ways, this game is better than the first; in others, it's honestly not as good.

A lot of what I enjoyed about the first game is brought back here. The story takes place 3 years later and focuses on a new threat named Merga, the last of the Water Dragons who wants to destroy Avalice and wipe out the Earth Dragons. It's a much deeper story, one that focuses on political intrigue and social prejudices throughout the 3 Kingdoms of Avalice and its many species. There's also more backstory given to the characters, such as Lilac being the other remaining Water Dragon, and her origins with the Red Scarves. Carol has a sister, Corazon, who's working with Merga, and her main conflict is convincing Cory to defeat Merga instead. Milla's backstory is further elaborated, revealing who and where her parents are, but I won't give it away here. Neera Li joins Team Lilac, and is shown to have a hard time trusting people as she's constantly being betrayed; she has a black-and-white view of the world, calling everyone either an ally or an enemy; her loyalty to Shang Tu is sometimes taken to the extreme; but over the course of the game, Lilac and Milla help her to open up and have faith in their group. And, of course, the writing once again balances out with plenty of charming character interactions, which is the main source of comedy again.

However, this game's plot falls into the same trap as the first game: some of the cutscenes still go on WAY too long and slow the pacing down; the only way they're sped up here is that dialogue plays out automatically, moving from one line to the next, unlike the first game where you had to keep pushing one button after every textbox. 

There are also instances where the game diverges from the main plot, and has the player go through 3 episodes in any order they want; the episodes have their own subplots that do connect to the main plot, but still make it go on longer than necessary.

Otherwise, it's a great continuation of the plot that fleshes out Avalice and sets the stakes for the next game.

I should also bring attention to the presentation. The pixel art is more detailed and expressive than the first game, leading to a wider range of emotions and more fluent movements from each character. The environments have a bigger color scheme, which makes many of the stages look gorgeous! And they take it a step further by making some objects 3D polygonal models that are well integrated into the 2D setting.

The audio is a slight downgrade, but only slightly. The music has a few REALLY good tracks, but it's not as memorable or energized as the first game. The voice actors are just slightly less convincing than they were in the first game, and the sound mixing has the same issue, where the music can sometimes be louder than the dialogue; but they still give good performances that sell the characters pretty well.

As for the gameplay, there's a LOT of improvement.

Lilac can use her double jump without draining her blue meter and go straight into a dragon boost without waiting for the meter to fill back up. THANK YOU. She's easily the fastest character in the game, at the cost of having weaker attacks than the rest of the characters, something I found more noticeable during boss fights.

Carol still has her motorbike which can ride up walls, but she also has the Jump Disc, a projectile to throw at enemies and even magnetize to them for a few seconds, dealing more damage; the Disc also lets her teleport, making it easier to jump across large gaps or travel up to high ledges.

Milla's shield can now block almost anything; in fact, it can bounce most projectiles back at enemies, causing them to take damage, which is useful defense AND offense. She can also summon her big green gelatin blocks a lot faster, which she can either fire as a laser, like before, or she can shoot out tiny green bullets until the cube is depleted. And of course, she still has her floating ability, which is still fun to use.

Neera is the powerhouse character, who can freeze enemies for a short time, and use her "Focus" ability to make her attacks faster and stronger. If you feel she moves too slow, you can speed her up by mashing the attack button, which forms an ice trail underneath her to slide across the ground like she's ice skating; this can make her sometimes move faster than Lilac!

But beyond individual differences, each character has basic moves and abilities that they all share.

They can all perform basic melee attacks, which vary in damage, status effects, and targeting based on which direction you tilt the control stick. 

As for defenses, the items in this game act similar to the elemental shields from Sonic 3 & Knuckles; letting you breath underwater, protecting you from fire or electricity, magnetizing collectibles towards you, or just providing basic protection like the shields from Sonic 1 and 2. And each character has a guard maneuver, which blocks enemy attacks and prevents you from taking too much damage, which is essential for the boss fights. 

Speaking of which, the bosses all have visible health bars, which also determines when the player reaches the next phase of the fight.

And, I should mention that, as a game inspired by 2D Sonic, the high-speed platforming is expanded. If Freedom Planet was a combination of Sonic Advance 1 and 2, Freedom Planet 2 is closer to Sonic Advance 2; once again, acceleration goes from zero to sixty, and they've introduced boost rings and grind rails, both of which keep your character ZOOMING across terrain. It's still the best thing about the gameplay!

But then there are the downsides of the gameplay; for one thing, the main campaign is TWICE as long as the first and ends up overstaying its welcome again. In fact, some stages here go on for 20 to 30 minutes at a time! Never mind Sonic, that's way too long for ANY 2D platformer. I've already mentioned the episodic structure that makes the campaign go on longer, but there's also exploration in between stages. The world maps are one thing, and they mark your next destination with red exclamation points; but then they have you going through HUBWORLDS in a 2D game! You have to go talk to certain characters in this or that building to watch the next cutscene, you have side missions to complete by talking to townsfolk, and there's NPC's in each area, some of whom offer their own perspectives on the events of the main plot. It's not terrible, but it still comes off as padding.

Finally, on top of all this, Freedom Planet 2 has a true ending that you unlock by finding 13 time capsules! You do this by finding one in a HUBWORLD (the top of the tall building in the beach area), and then the other 12 are rewarded to you for completing Battlesphere Challenges. To give this game SOME credit, they made it super easy to find and collect these time capsules, just like collecting Chaos Emeralds in a Sonic game. It's better than other games where you go FAR out of your way to complete cryptic nonsense you'd only know about by using a guide. Here, it's just a small diversion that adds a little more time to your playthrough and involves the same content as regular stages. In that regard, the game is fair, but it still adds more extra steps to a campaign that's already bloated with content. I only went after the true ending with Lilac, because I just wanted to finish the game with the other characters and move on. I will say that the true ending has one more stage, and a cool final boss that gets me excited for Team Lilac's next adventure!

Freedom Planet 2 makes improvements to the first game, and it's still a fun 2D platformer that took me for a WILD ride. Whether you're a Sonic fan, or you've played the first Freedom Planet, or both in my case, you owe it to yourself to play this game. But make sure you have enough free time and enough patience, because it's also a much heftier time sink, and you may be worn out by the end.

review:
This game takes "the rule of cool" to a new level, especially in the last half of the game. The boss fights really stood out to me with some of them I would consider some of the most unique and awesome fights in any game.
Outside of that the music is great, the visuals are great, the game play is great. Really I think the only weak point is a just ok story but even that has its moments. If you liked the first Freedom Planet this one is an improvement in every way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042175122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1366, 'last_played': 1674522153}
review:
One of the best 2D platformers around, honestly.
At its core, it's a lot like Sonic, but with tighter movement and quick, satisfying combat, both melee and ranged.

Stages are a great blend of Sonic-like rollercoaster sections with fast paced platforming and combat, and take place across a huge variety of environments, all fleshed out with fantastic pixel art and catchy music. To top it off, there's a massive amount of bosses, many of which are considerably challenging, and are quite satisfying to beat.

As a sequel to FP1, it improves almost everything. It adds a world map, with towns and shops to buy items that can either ease the difficulty or make it much harder, if you want to chase those perfect scores. There's even arena challenges on top of all the regular levels, and a museum, for viewing the fantastic boss models you've faced along the way. It really built up the world as a whole and it feels like they went the extra mile.

It's pretty great. Definitely pick this one up if you want some retro style platforming fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198314432311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1673381407}
review:
ケモノキャラが素晴らしく可愛いゲームであり、アクションが素晴らしく面白いゲームでもある。
最初に４人のキャラから一人を選んでプレイする。最初にやる人は普通にライラックが一番やりやすいと思ったけど、正直誰でやっても楽しい。私はキャロルでバイク乗ってる時が一番好きかも
キャラ固有の技が豊富で誰を選んでも快適でかゆい所に手が届くようなアクションが楽しめる。

ある程度のスピードが出てたら水面も走れるみたいな演出も最高だった

私は普段２Ｄアクションはスピードで駆け抜けるよりもじっくり辺りを探索するのが好きなんだけどそんなプレイヤーでも楽しめる。
広くアクションゲーム好きにオススメ出来るゲームだと思う。
[list]
[*]前作からの変更点↓
[/list]
ガードボタンが加わって一瞬敵の攻撃を無効化する事が出来るようになった。
更にステージに入る時に難易度を緩和してくれたり、逆に上げたりするようなアイテムを付着する事が出来る。

英語の難易度は中級くらいかなあ。調べればわかるけど、分かり辛いのもある。
ちゃんと会話の中身を知りたい人はカットシーン中にポーズをすれば画面を止めれるんでそれで調べながらやる事が出来ます。

キャラのドット絵も綺麗だけど、アニメーションも綺麗でキャラの表情とか仕草が活き活きしてる。
会話読む為に画面止めた時、このキャラこんな可愛い仕草してたのかみたいなのが分かる時がある。そういう所も本当好き。

author: {'steamid': '76561198364032661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2202, 'last_played': 1672145390}
review:
Literal Masterpiece. 
7 years in development well spent, and they DELIVERED! 
First off, this game's gameplay improves massively over the first game, which was already fairly good on its own. This? This is just the perfect 2D speed platformer. It's so good it basically puts every 2D Sonic game to SHAME.

It's gonna take you a little while playing around with the controls to understand how to make the most out of the mechanics in this game, so please do not get discouraged early, there is a very rewarding learning curve as you progress through the game. Not to mention that many of the stages are meant to be replayed, either to lower the time, or find new secrets. 
Your first run of a stage might take you, idk 7~10 minutes for most. 
Then once you get acquainted with the mechanics, you'll see that time be cut in half if not even more. 

All 4 playable characters have their own strengths and weaknesses, but they all perform about the same once you've picked up some practice. Often you'll find yourself going to different parts of the stages with different characters. 

The story? TLDR: It's a story about colonialism with a tragic character. Not spoiling much else, but do go out of your way to collect the time capsules, they hold some VERY juicy information regarding the lore. 
Another thing of note is that each character has specific cutscenes throughout the story, so I highly recommend playing through it with all 4, or at the very least with Lilac and Carol, since those two hold the most specific cutscenes of all the 4 characters. 

The 2D sprites in this game are BEAUTIFUL. The main 4 characters are extremely expressive, the side characters have pretty good variety, the NPCs are honestly really cute, I love how bats look in this game. I know that the lead dev's favorite animal is a bat, so no wonder why they look awesome. The stages are wildly varied, with many details hidden in the background, as well as other attention to detail elements that you'd only noticed if you stopped to look. 

THE VOICE ACTING, OH BROTHER THE VOICE ACTING. 
General Serpentine's VA is awesome, love hearing him. 
Both Neera and Merga have crazy good emotional performances, love them both. 
Milla's voice fits her character way too well, and a massive improvement over the first game. 
Same for Carol. 
Glad to hear Lilac again. 

Despite all the sadness in the game, there is also a lot of hilarious stuff, a lot of which you'll find in those character specific cutscenes I mentioned earlier. 

BUY THE GAME, IT'S STUPID GOOD! I 100% it and speedran the game with all 4 characters, managing to beat it under 2 hours with each. Short and sweet. 
Your first run will definitely take WAY longer however. 

Btw Neera supremacy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153902491', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 178, 'playtime_at_review': 4166, 'last_played': 1712336894}
review:
[h1] The time I spend waiting for this game was worth it, at least in my case [/h1]

Still haven't finished the game with all the characters, but with the time I spend on it, I think I can say about the game from my first experience.

Freedom Planet 2 made a outstanding step from the first game: in gameplay, story-telling, soundtrack and art-style. 
In my first time playing it I really got a tough time navigating through the stages and fighting the bosses(I died a lot), got a few infuriating moments, fortunately it wasn't lasted so long, took me almost the entire day to finish the game. I had fun? Mhm! I had a lot of fun!

After replaying it, things get easier to manage even with other characters, which I consider to be my real experience with this Indie game that started as a Sonic Fangame, I'm very glad they decided to change the plans, because if wasn't because of this change, I wouldn't never be able to meet such a amazing platformer game and the community built by this game and developers.



Btw, Try Shang Mu Architect!!

review: Esse é simplesmente um dos melhores jogos que eu já joguei na vida. História super bacana, arte mais do que fabulosa, músicas incríveis, personagens nem tenho palavras, alguns chefes épicos, outros chatos pra desgraça, outros super criativos. Esse jogo não deixou a desejar em nenhum ponto, ao menos na minha opinião. Teve uns bugs bem engraçados como travar na parede e tals, mas fora isso, eu amei o jogo. Um adicional: meus cumprimentos ao gênio que fez aquela última fase maldita, miserável e difícil que eu levei uns 2 dias pra passar.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994002775', 'num_games_owned': 6538, 'num_reviews': 1438, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1677289340}
review:
Forget Sonic, there is a new here in town!
In Freedom Planet 2 you and the heroes of Avalice fight against the greatest threat ever.
An ancient danger has awakened in the depths of the ocean.
Merga, a water dragon from the time of Avalice's oldest war has been freed from her crystal prison and war is about to break out, but our heroes are divided.
Will the girls manage to stay together during these difficult times? In this game, which still resembles Sonic quite a lot, you fight your way through a world where cats are green, motorcycles drive up walls and monster girls triumph in battle.
You take control of Lilac, Carol, Milla or Neera, each with their own unique play style.

Watch my first gameplay here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l1hOLAN_QG8

The game also works great on a steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jv3eo09E3mY

author: {'steamid': '76561198008974596', 'num_games_owned': 558, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1674352492}
review:
Long story short; the game is definitely an improvement over the first game in all except soundtrack and I will probably come back to this game every now and then after finishing it.

The long story though; I find it tough to actually call this game amazing. The game itself does get very bombastic in ways a Treasure game would go... But I can't help but think something is missing from the adrenaline as weird as it sounds?

I'll start talking on gameplay, this game has 4 playable characters being Lilac, Carol and Milla returning from the first and Neera who was also that first game but was an NPC/Boss in that game.
- Lilac practically plays the same as her first game rendition with her dragon boost being able to fire her in 6 directions at a burst of speed with a ton of QoL touches that have her game play feel more smooth. 
- Carol is a brawler/ninja hybrid character who takes after a ton of similar play styles, though definitely find a refresh in this game with some new moves and abilities
- Milla has been overhauled to have her kit more geared towards combat instead of her weird puzzle platformer move set. She actually feels like a proper character in this game compared to the first.
- Neera is more focused on heavy hitting combat, more so than Carol in the sense that all of her kit revolves around hitting things. She's probably the most awkward to get a hold on since stages are so big in this game with not many focusing on mini-boss/boss encounters.
The variety in character does make it so there's a lot of variety in terms of approaching the game and what characters you may find enjoyable or feel fall flat. I'd still say Lilac is the main poster girl of the game though with Carol being a fun alternative, Milla being a little more tricky but fitting and Neera... Well I'll give it to her that she's relatively straight forward and not awkward to where she's a detriment.

To bring attention to stages, a lot of them are pretty great in terms of set pieces and building up to bosses. This is where the Treasure comparison really steps in with bosses being more present within some stages before actually fighting them. It really sets a bombastic tone in which stuff is happening within the levels not always just being still pieces. Though there are later stages where enemies and obstacles can become more crazy than they probably should be. 
Now the game does have a "guard" mechanic that's more or less a sort of lenient parry but I don't think it's a mechanics that's fleshed out to the degree it should be. There are moments where the parry window do save me only to find that I'm still within an attack and take the hit anyway in some sections. I'd imagine if you're going to high ranks or stages this would be infuriating to deal with but just going from point A to B it's more slightly annoying than anything. I'd probably have some kind of invincible dash instead of a parry but that's probably due to what kind of games I play (I know Lilac has a dash like that but you have to hold down the button and I find that awkward).

I probably should've mentioned story earlier but this is definitely more of a game where they want to sell you on the game play rather than the story. Not to dog on it of course as it's a pretty dense story and a lot of stuff happens that follows up the first game and does impact the characters. A water dragon named Merga has reawakened and is aiming to ressurect a warship called Bakunawa to eliminate the planet the characters live on and each character has their own perspective with their own stories.
The story was a weak point of the first game for being INCREDIBLY melodramatic and going on longer than the actual stages of the game which thankfully this game tones the length down IMMENSELY. I would say overall this games story is much better... BUT there's still a sore point in the sense it still seems pretty melodramatic. This isn't helped by the fact most of the voice acting in the game is nearly as amateur as the first game. Granted a fair lot of the voice actors have done several voice roles before and do sound fine in this game, not gonna list VA names but I'll just say the player characters are awkward to listen to when they need to be stern or upset in cut scenes. I'd probably say Merga doesn't sound right when she's screaming also, the voice and the sprite are pretty separate from each other in this case. Everyone else is mostly fine though whoever came up with Aaa, who gimmick is that they're prone to screaming should be slapped on the wrist and I'm going easy saying that.

Graphically the game is pretty great with a ton of lovely stage designs, though with how compared Freedom Planet in general is to Sonic it should be noted that the character design is leaning more into more furry and animalistic traits than anything resembling a toon design, though there are still elements of that for some characters and that's not to say it's all devoid of toon-ish designs. I think it's pretty apparent they're going for something more typical of anime and manga which does still have those exaggerations. I say this because there are hub worlds which have NPCs populate them and there is a LOT of variation between them. Though bringing up the hub worlds, some are definitely less pretty than others with a lot of them seemingly using assets that the levels don't use(?) especially noticeable with some elements of them not behaving as they would in the other levels.

Sound wise it's pretty good, though I WILL say I do think the soundtrack is a bit of a mark down. There's definitely good beats still present here and there but I'd struggle to say that many of the tracks really assist the tone or bombastic nature of the levels or events. Crazy to say since Woofle does return for various tracks but I'd struggle to say some of her stuff here is truly strong? Granted there are four other people working on the soundtrack also with some of the people seemingly new to composition so I'd chalk it up to a lot of new talents trying to find footing here.

Overall whilst I might've been more harsh for a positive review, I still think this is a game worth checking out. If you loved the first game then you'll probably love this game even more. If you liked the first one but had issues then this game is still worth it though it does still fall short in a few places the first did. If you didn't like the first game then I doubt this will change your mind.

I like it enough to where I'll probably protest the third game that releases in 2040 to give Lilac a rival character in the form of some scarlet tiger which somehow encourages her to not be so melodramatic, Carol going through something that mimics her VA's carer path (lightly anyway) and Milla maybe losing braincells as she creates some things. Also make Spade playable you cowards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180199726', 'num_games_owned': 55, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1037, 'last_played': 1695674591}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069469195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1709427674}
review:
Great game. Perfect sequel.

Like the first this is a very 'Sonic-esque' game with the focus shifted more toward combat and platforming than speed. The gameplay is much tighter and more rewarding this time around and with 4 very distinct characters to use it's also very replayable. Big recommend.

Pros:
- Very customizable difficulty. There are items and potions that will grant buffs and drawbacks and these will decrease/ increase your score respectively. 
- Vibrant, enjoyable setting. The first game felt a bit bland to me, but the setting feels much more engaging this time around. The antagonists in particular. 
- I feel I need to give a special shoutout to the absurd number of unique NPCs running around. A lot of the designs are great and fill out the world a lot. 

My only complaints with Freedom Planet 2 are carryovers from the first. Specifically:
- Some levels have a tendency to drag on. Granted there aren't 'zones' like in Sonic games where a level is divided into 2/3 smaller sections, but there were many gimmick filled levels here where even the par time was over ten minutes. And because the levels are so sprawling it can be bit daunting to form a pathway in your mind. 
- The melodrama gets to be a bit much even for me. A lot of the story is solid and enjoyable there are a few moments that maybe reach too far and made me cringe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034701137', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1671058050}
review:
I really enjoyed the original Freedom Planet, so it's a shame to say I didn't particularly enjoy the sequel. While it's a decent enough platformer in its own right, it's a whole host of little things that come together to make the game an absolute slog to get through.

Firstly, the game is long. I mean long! One playthrough of the game with one character, not going out of my way to find all the secrets and so forth, took 12 hours. There are FOUR playable characters. By comparison, for Sonic Mania I've done a complete playthrough with every character (Sonic, Tails, Knuckles, and Sonic with Ray and Mighty) 100% all collectables and achievements and that's taken just under 20 hours total.

This wouldn't be such an issue if the game did anything truly interesting, but it doesn't. If you're a fan of platforming games - particularly Sonic - everything the game throws at you, you've seen before. That in and of itself isn't a bad thing, but the levels are way too long. The average level takes about 10min to complete. They would have benefited a great deal from being shorter and snappier. I also felt that I could never quite see enough of the stage area at any one time. If an off-screen enemy is able to shoot at you that's not good game design IMO. Worse still is that some of these are total filler. One in particular sees you having to collect several keys in order to rise a bridge to get to another area. If this level had been left out it would have made absolutely no difference. There are several levels like this.

The enemies are all very spongy, even the most basic needing at least two hits, which is not great for a fast paced game like this. The further on you go the more spongy they become. And the bosses are absolutely ridiculous! Some fights end up being more like a bullet hell game and, again, they are spongy as a soaked matrass! The final boss has six phases - count 'em - SIX! It's ludicrous! Add to this that several bosses you have to fight more than once and it truly becomes a chore.

While the story of the first game had a kind of cheesy Saturday-morning-cartoon charm, here it is dragged out so long that it just becomes boring and tedious. I almost never skip cutscenes in games, story is one of the things I really enjoy, but it didn't take long for me to start skipping them here. It's just not interesting.

There are items in the game to buy and use, but I found myself basically ignoring them. Partly because they didn't seem to make any discernible difference to the gameplay, but also because the game is so restrictive over what you can use it's just not worth the bother.

"Tedious" is probably the best word I can use to describe Freedom Planet 2. It's like the devs took every single idea they had and crammed it into the game, resulting in a bloated, tiresome mess. If they had reeled things back a bit, ditched the extraneous levels and boss encounters and generally tightened things up this could have been so much better.

Apart from the four playable characters and the items mentioned above, there are also heaps of collectables and a "Classic Mode" to entice you back to replay the game. However, after the absolute slog of getting through just ONE character's story, I can't see myself returning to this at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986817619', 'num_games_owned': 454, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1673978078}
review:
What is Freedom Planet 2?

Freedom Planet 2 is the sequel to Freedom Planet 1, and tried to take steps to differentiate itself from being game in the similar style to Sonic the Hedgehog, which it'll naturally be compared to. As a 2D, pixel art, side scrolling platformer. 

Freedom Planet 2 was released on September 13th, 2022 across Windows, Linux, Switch, Playstation, and Xbox. With the Dev and Publisher being GalaxyTrail. It's quite the substantial development since Freedom Planet 1, which was largely a single person accomplishment growing into a fairly size-able indie team. Especially since the first game was a Kickstarter Project and the sequel was entirely funded by that success. 

-=-=- Art -=-=-
The Art, and Character Design has taken a significant change of pace due to the inclusion of Tyson Tan, who did fan art of the various characters after the first game and was brought on to design the characters for the sequel. As a result, the design of the game has taken a notable change from the previous game's design limitations.

Lilac has had a huge overhaul in terms of her design, while the rest of the cast has remained largely the same. With some small changes here and there to accentuate their various quirks. 

-=-=-Gameplay-=-=-
Gameplay and Story is broken into a four character narrative with points where the story breaks off and the characters perform individual tasks related to their individual goals while beginning and ending at the same point. 

Each Character does play differently enough from each other, but I felt like Lilac, whose the series protagonist (and the frontliner, in Purple) at times feels like this game was designed around the other characters rather than her. 

Lilac (Purple Dragon) is defined as a "Speed" character, Carol (Green Cat) a "Brawler", Milla (A Dog that I keep thinking is a Rabbit) as an "Explorer" and Neera (Panda) with "Power."

Each Character has their own quirks, Lilac is quite mobile, Carol is designed more around the combat changes since the first game, Milla is geared towards exploring environments, and Neera is a hybrid of the three with her own unique quirks. 

Freedom Planet 2 has a much stronger emphasis on combat this time round, and I don't know how I feel about it. Each boss encounter involves breaking through a bosses defenses before hitting the boss again to remove a hit point. 

I NEVER figured out how to use the Guard  or Parry mechanic. There is nothing that explains how that works beyond a bit of tutorial text (without demonstration.) 

This makes boss fights potentially drag on quite a bit. As you get used to the nature of how the fight goes, and then you have to make sure to capitalize on opportunities as they come.

I didn't mind it, but I can see where people can get frustrated by it. So be aware. Beyond that, there was at least three bosses of note that felt like unnecessary difficulty spikes. 

As a change from the first game, there's a continue mechanic that involves spending the crystal currency you pick up during a given level to revive yourself either on the spot (with significantly less health) or at a check point for full health. I'd rather respawn at the point where I died then replay through a cutscene (even if you can skip it) to restart a fight. This felt like a feature that wasn't really thought out. 

Most levels consist of moving right, with the occasional left segment while trying to get to checkpoints. The levels are large and varied with some unique element to break them up. I found some of the ideas behind these levels to be rather enjoyable and they broke up what I expected from a 2D sidescroller. 

The levels can stretch into being rather long. These are not short 5 minute romps. Some can get upwards to 10-12 minutes from my experience. While they are rather large, I didn't have too many instances where I didn't know where to go or what to do. 

There is equipment this time round and it took a bit for me to get used to it. 

There are various potions that you can buy from Milla during the game that allot a small bonus to your game-play, such as increasing run speed, jump height, damage, defense, etc. They don't really explain how this mechanic works, so I had to figure out that you need to go to the bottle icon, then move over to the particular potion I wanted to add, then press "up" to add it to the bottle. This feels like an oversight.

There are also equipment you can find in chests, but these are rather well hidden. So I can't really comment on them as I found one that made the aforementioned Defense/Parry Mechanic worthless and nothing else. 

I beat the game as Lilac and started two alternative runs as Milla and Neera. Both of whom start out with the same starting mission and have the same cutscenes, but from different perspectives: which is a nice touch. 

There are moments where Carol and Milla leave the team, so I'm interested to see if those come with wholly unique levels. 

-=-=-Story-=-=-
There are two modes available, the intended "Adventure" mode which includes moving around an isometric map and checking in on non-combat and zones.

There is also a Classic Mode which skips the plot and goes from area to area with the non-combat areas linked together into one large (growing) shop to make various purchases. 

You do not need to have played the First Game to enjoy the sequel. As I didn't. I had watched a play-through of the First Game, but hadn't had the opportunity to pick it up. You will miss out on some context, some jokes, and references to the first game, but I don't feel it's totally necessary. 

Following from the Steam Page: The story consists of Merga, a Water Dragon freeing herself from a prison and her ambitions for the world at large. With the four aforementioned heroines getting wrapped up in trying to stop her from her goals. 

Freedom Planet 2 expands on the world around the three Kingdoms from the first game and continues from where it left off.

I can't really talk about the story without spoiling it, and I enjoyed my time with it. I didn't feel my time was wasted. 

-=-=-Final Thoughts-=-=-
I completed the game, as Lilac, at about 8 hours and started two separate runs as Milla and Neera. While there was initial interest in continuing to see how the other characters go through the plot, I don't know if I'll actually play through the game (at least right now anyway) with the others. 

If you're looking for a 2D Sidescroller that is evocative of (2D) Sonic, while trying to become it's own thing: then I'd recommend Freedom Planet 2. There's some growing pains, but the sequel builds on the original and is one of those cases where the second game IS better than the original.

review:
I have been eyeing this game for some time when i first learned of this game being made.  i saw the character previews, saw the adventure mode, saw the new character and just overall, excited for what adventure i would be going on after the first game that set things in motion, Freedom Planet, searing good memories into my brain with all that it had to offer.

With that said, OMG YES BUY THIS GAME, THIS GAME IS ABSOLUTELY BEAUTIFUL AND CHARACTERS ARE STILL THE SAME IF NOT BETTER, THE MUSIC IS SO DAMN GOOD, IM STILL BOPPING MY HEAD TO THIS SOUNDTRACK.  THE STORY IS SO GOOD TOO AND NEVER AM I IN A DULL MOMENT WITH THIS GAME, I ONLY COMPLETED THE GAME WITH ONE THE CHARACTERS AND IM ALREADY WANTING TO COMPLETE IT WITH THEM ALL

author: {'steamid': '76561198158039513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1710527458}
review:
Since i've (unfortunately) bought it, might as well leave a review.

A huge disappointment compared to the first game making a large amount of fundamental mistakes no platformer designer should make.

Let's start with graphics. Are they pretty and detailed? Yes. Do they go together? No. There is zero visual hierarchy between ground, enemies and platforms for 90% of the game, it actually hurts eyes when playing.
The Krita guy is on the team providing designs that didn't translate into pixel art at all. A giant mech is cool when it actually moves like a giant mech and not 2 jpegs. First game at least constructed it's enemies from more parts, this one uses so few most bosses look baffling, especially the green bird aka lancer, or parts of giant mech during transormation that literally look like they are tposing.

One would think that's already pretty bad - but there is more, and this time relating to gameplay. This game relies on BLOCKING for avoiding damage. A sonic style platformer on BLOCKING. Bosses feel right out of contra/mega man except you have neither precision nor range to deal with them in a fun way. So you mostly block till they are near you and then use your strongest attack. You never have an opportunity to use any other attacks, so they are kinda overall useless.

There is also awful screen crunch. You either play zoomed in and can't see anything cause it's always off-screen but still agroed and actively attacking, or camera zooms out massacring the pixel art cause i don't have 4k monitor, but at least it's playable that way.

Levels are overreliant on gimmicks and puzzles and most damage is pretty much unavoidable and they take 10-20 minutes on top of that. There is also  no singposting in terms of directions, and those levels want you to backtrack quite often.

The game wants you to play 4 times to get the full story for every character, but doesn't offer any new content besides their movesets, all of which feel awkward in context of level design and especially bosses. If you play only one character - you get the main plot, but every other character looks like unlikeable asshole because you see their actions but not motives. Did i mention one campaign is 20 hours long? Yeah.

I really loved the first game and was sure this one wouldn't disappoint, and it did in ways i couldn't even imagine, because 1st game's artstyle and levels seemed to be expertly designed, and even more annoying elements like having to manually charge dragon dash removed pretty early on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198966733144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 791, 'last_played': 1697069897}
review:
They are speed.


New Entry: Fast Opportunity.

When the first game came out, we all have this proportionate expectation of the product coming out good or bad. While it isn't too good, it also wasn't that bad. This game is a huge step up from what they've put into, with simple controls (mostly) and high momentum potential. There can still be a few bugs, but it doesn't stop players who play this game casually, competitively or for completion.

Each character has their own unique dialogue in certain scenarios, including their own combat style. Much like the first, each scene is replicated in true action; by any means it isn't a still picture. Their personalities and purposes are deeply noticeable, but they hit hard (in a good way) in the heart and mind. The flow of the writing and levels, no matter which order it is chosen, makes sense and doesn't force you to go from a low difficulty to a higher one. The landscape is polished to visually appeal each level, map and hub. I certainly got stuck on the eye candy no doubt about it. If Avalice was a real place, well we wouldn't necessarily survive would we? Then again, those four aren't going to stop fighting chaos.

I would highly recommend this game to people who crave adrenaline, action and quirky characters.

End Entry.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972084094', 'num_games_owned': 1134, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1487, 'last_played': 1685693375}
review:
[b]tl;dr:[/b] You can parry static pools of lava.

Incredible follow-up to the original [i]Freedom Planet[/i] that improves upon it immensely. To list out the ways:

[list][*]The core "what if [i]Sonic[/i], [i]Rocket Knight Adventures[/i] and [i]Mega Man X4[/i] got mixed in a blender" conceit remains - you still run around ramps like the blue hedgehog and his buddies did on the Genesis while attacking with punches and kicks that don't feel dissimilar from swinging the Z-Saber around, which works better than it sounds owing to the lack of contact damage (enemies must be actively attacking or otherwise obviously spiky to hurt you). However, the returning non-Lilac characters have been heavily reworked such that they aren't so obviously worse than her this time around. Milla, in particular, went from a very technical character with slow-charging and clumsy attacks to a very versatile ranged character with multiple attack options always available. Carol's motorcycle is no longer made of toilet paper, and newcomer Neera can be a heavy damage-dealer if you practice a bit with her.
[*]The dodge mechanic adds so much to the gameplay flow that returning to the first game after playing this, I keep trying to dodge attacks and lamenting the move's absence. The timing is generous enough that even somebody as bad at parrying in a [i]Souls[/i] game like myself can make it work fairly regularly, and it's much more versatile than it first appears - as noted at the top of the review, I've seen speedruns of the volcano stage where the runner repeatedly lands in a large lava pool but takes no damage because the dodge is active just long enough to tank the hit and let them jump back out of it - a concept that is patently ridiculous in all the right ways.
[*]The relic and potion systems add some nice variety to the mix. Some can take the edge off a really tough boss fight if you're struggling, while the Brave Stones can bring out serious challenges like one-hit KOs or forcing time limits if you wish to get any crystal payout for clearing the stage. Some even have some fun synergies - one achievement specifically relies on the interplay between [spoiler]the relic that turns all crystals into health petals and the relic that turns all health petals into crystals, resulting in both turning into red crystals that add to your crystal count while slightly healing you[/spoiler].
[*]Lives actually mean something now; losing all of them will incur a penalty to your in-game spending money for the potions/music vinyls and decimate your ranking, instead of toothlessly letting you continue from the last checkpoint without penalty as the first game did. (If you're completely out of in-game cash, you can beat up a punching bag until you've earned the necessary fee, effectively paying in time instead. If this sounds like pay-to-win, don't fret - there is no premium currency in this game.)
[*]The boss battles remain the furious Treasure-inspired clashes they were in the first game, but are now even larger and intricate, and are considerably more plentiful. They're almost entirely joys to fight, which is good, because the game later pulls an id Software and makes some of them normal stage enemies.
[*]The graphics are considerably more detailed, fluid and well-drawn than the first time around. The nearly seven-year development period clearly paid off here, as well as the bump in vertical resolution from 240 to 360.
[*]The music is incredible. I think I may still be more partial to the soundtrack of the first game, but the stage themes have some serious jams in there - Zao Land, Shade Armory, Globe Opera 1 & 2, Zulon Jungle, Magma Starscape, Inversion Dynamo, all bangers.
[*]The plot of the first game was pretty clumsily delivered, all told, but this one manages to stick the landing without bombarding you with 12-15 minute plot dumps this time around. Maybe a low bar, but when it tackles heavy subject matter (colonialism, in this case), it doesn't come off nearly as tonally dissonant as the first game did with its infamous torture scene. Also, it has Christopher Sabat as not-Vegeta, so that kicks ass. (It should be noted, though, that as of writing, Classic Mode is locked behind beating the game once as any character; those who don't care for the plot will find themselves hitting "Skip Scene" a lot that first time through.)[/list]

All-in-all: highly recommended for anyone with an interest in tightly-tuned action games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993167180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2360, 'last_played': 1664117781}
review:
Возвращение отличного последователя Соника. Тот же самый Freedom Planet, только лучше. Более детальная графика, улучшенный геймплей и прокачанный сюжет. Теперь у нас сразу целых 4 персонажа на выбор, хоть и история практически одинаковая у всех, у каждого есть свои уникальные моменты. В игре очень много диалогов для платформера, некоторые катсцены могут идти минут по 10, полностью озвученные, но проматываются автоматически, в отличии от первой части, что мне не особо нравится. Для любителей копаться в лоре появились "Хабы", в которых можно поговорить с обитателями мира и узнать историю мира или последние новости. Так же можно покупать предметы, которые являются своего рода "системой настройки сложности под себя". Если вам слишком легко играть, можете нацепить амулет на 1 хп. Это влияет на ранг прохождения уровни и ТОЛЬКО это, время значения не имеет. А за ранг отсыпят больше кристаллов, которые наконец имеют смысл в отличии от первой части, именно на них покупаются предметы. В минус можно записать невозможность поиграть в Classic Mode со старта, открывается только после прохождения за любого персонажа. Понятно что сценаристы старались, писали диалоги и все дела, но не все играют в платформеры ради сюжета.

Рекомендовано всем любителям платформеров. Ждем третью часть, может до 3D дорастем.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035748037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1975, 'last_played': 1669703365}
review:
Another fantastic 2D momentum-based platformer from GalaxyTrail. This one builds on the gameplay concepts explored in the first Freedom Planet to deliver dozens of interesting and fun levels. Considering how little love this genre gets in general, if you're a fan of it then you really should be playing this game.

A controller is recommended, of course, but given the game uses digital input (i.e. you might wind up using the d-pad rather than the analog stick) a keyboard is also fine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056180431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2877, 'last_played': 1703909092}
review:
Amazingly great. A lot of the time you're going too fast to enjoy the backgrounds and details, but all of it is remarkably thoughtful and well done. With the combat, though it's not exactly deep, it is well thought out and fun, and the dodge they added allows the pace to stay high during boss fights and flying through the stage, with music that's pretty much all 8/10 to 10/10 (I'm thinking Toby Fox level of instrumental music quality).
Take the story with all the grace of a pg-13 game. The voice acting is good and made with dedicated actors, but be prepared for some Saturday morning cartoon quips and reminiscent dialogue, especially if that isn't something you're into. The world itself definitely has charm, this new game having hubs and npcs to talk to while you have downtime between stages. It makes the world feel even more alive and charming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028535642', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 8330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 30, 'playtime_at_review': 1359, 'last_played': 1712264493}
review:
I'll make this short and sweet (aka tl;dr). If you like Freedom Planet 1, this gives you ALOT more to do. This game is an obvious pick up. If you like Sonic games, you'll like this. If you like Shantae and just want something different, maybe this is for you. Maybe you just want a good 'ole platformer; this game got you covered too.

However, if you are new to the Freedom Planet series, welcome! Enjoy this fast-paced platformer with great art design that may or may not have actual fursonas on display for everyone to see! If you want to play the first Freedom Planet game to catch up on plot, go right ahead and DON'T unspoiler the next section. That is just to get people caught up so that they don't have to play the first one, if they don't want to. I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU PLAY THE FIRST ONE FOR THE SOUNDTRACK HOWEVER. PLEASE PLAY FREEDOM PLANET 1. HOLY DOG, THAT GAME SLAPS.

If you don't want to play Freedom Planet 1, then the plot of Freedom Planet 1 is that [spoiler] a warlord crash landed on T h e  F r e e d o m P l a n e t - Avalice, then proceeded to fuck some shit up among three major cities, tortured two children, and got defeated in a way that the Kingdom Stone, a master emerald that was powering a city, got shattered and gave its energy to the whole planet. I explicitly mention the torture part because it's what piqued my interest in the series. You may judge me for that, but please realize extremely quickly that I am a total degenerate. [/spoiler]


This game plays like a combo of Shantae and Sonic. If you are a fan of those games, you'll love this game. Speedy platforming with large levels, player has a health bar and enemies that don't get taken down in a single hit. Although the levels are large, I never really felt myself getting fatigued or tired from playing in them. Edit: These stages are LONG. In a good way; you'll 100% be feeling like you got your money's worth.

Even though I've only played this game as Sash Lilac (and I'm not even finished), I can go ahead and say with great confidence that this game also is "a banger". While it doesn't have as many quirks as the first game (animated bloopers [?], goofy little things with menus, and overall feeling like a godlike fan game that JUST got by into getting released) as well as the soundtrack missing a certain energy*, I still think this game is very much worth every cent. Edit: I'm on my doge playthrough, Milia has the best sound design, but not too much story deviations so far. Feels like I'm playing the same game but as a different character. I feel that playing Neera will be the same. Kinda of a let down, but Milia and Neera are cool as fuck and the stages are pretty nice so I don't mind it.


* alot of the soundtrack in this game is missing... something and so feels alot of hit-or-miss than the first one. I can't quite put my finger on it. Maybe it's less bass and beats? Maybe it's slower paced? Maybe it's the instrumentation? Maybe a little of all 3?)

really tl;dr; Game make me go "whoohoo" in the brain space. Maybe game make you brain do same. Go get.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098074522', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1084, 'last_played': 1672022169}
review:
Jak dla mnie najlepiej wydane 8 dych w  życiu. Gaalxy Trail dał nam po prostu genialny Sequel. to co działało we FP 1, zostało lekko usprawnione, a każdej postaci dodano jeden  dodatkowy ruch, każdy specyficzny tylko dla niej (Carol np rzuca specjalnym dyskiem), dano też każdej postaci inwentarz, jednak nie wszystkie przedmioty mogą pomóc. Grafika zaś jest piękna, tak samo jak muzyka. Zaś historia to majstersztyk, którego nie powstydziłby się tytuł AAA - zawiła z 2 dnem, sojusznik może się okazać tak naprawdę wrogiem wróg zaś może się okazać nam bliższy niż się wydaje. Freedom Planet 2 ciężko zakwalifikować do jednej kategorii, bowiem jest niej wiele dobrych elementów, które razem razem tworzą wspaniałą platformówkę, która spodoba się nie tylko starym wyjadaczom, ale też tym którzy zaczynają przygodę z tym gatunkiem, czy grami ogólnie. Własnie dlatego to dla mnie murowany kandydat na grę roku jeśli chodzi o Steam   
PS Gra w tym Roku wychodzi na Switcha w Grudniu ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197969301459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1669552999}
review:
이거 출시하기를 엄청 고대했는데 잠시 일때문에 신경 안쓰는 동안 스리슬쩍 출시했네요. 
게임 아직 중반도 안갔지만 평가 적는 이유는 단순히 어워드 때문에(...)...

제작자가 소닉의 그늘에서 벗어나고 독자적 게임을 만들려고 노력했다고 하는데 반은 성공했다고 생각합니다. 단순하지만 다체로운 액션, 지역마다 집어넣기 위해 고심한 각종 기믹들,  각 개성을 가진 캐릭터들 전부 마음에 듭니다. 반은 어쩔 수 없는 부분인데 속도감 있는 횡스크롤 플레이 게임이 근본 토대이기 때문에 해보면 여전히 소닉과 비슷한 느낌이 드는 건 어쩔 수 없습니다.

올해 해본 횡스크롤 도트 액션중에 닌자 거북이도 재미있었긴 했지만 그냥 별 생각 없이 존에서 내달리며 난장판을 만드는 느낌은 프리덤 플레닛이 최고라 이쪽에 손을 들어주고싶네요. 뭐가 우월하다라기보단 그냥 취향에 따라 갈리는 요소로 닌자거북이도 상당히 재미있게 했었습니다.

최근에 맥북을 구입했는데 맥에서 안돌아가는건 좀 아쉽긴 하네요. 패드만 연결되면 어디서든 즐길 수 있는 최고의 게임이라 생각하는데 말이죠.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009352668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1940, 'last_played': 1673109785}
review:
If you played the first, you'll almost certainly love this. If you haven't, I still think you'll love this.

The original was a brilliant throwback to Sonic and Gunstar Heroes, and this neatly distills the formula into an even better experience. The characters are all charming and play very unique and distinct from each other, so playing the game from one to another feels like an entirely different experience. The storyline is simple but entertaining, and if you don't care about that, there's a Classic Mode that just gives you the gameplay. It even has a few branching paths and a "secret" ending you can get under certain conditions. And for FP1 fans, you'll be happy to know the story pacing is much better here: you'll never be stuck in cutscenes for [i]too[/i] long before it's back to gameplay.

On a technical level, the levels are technically brilliant. (Eh? Ehhhh? Oh never mind...) They're huge with numerous pathways, and taking the time to explore can yield some nice bonuses, though nothing is stopping you from trying to speed through them. They're also a visual treat with excellent pixel art and gorgeous backgrounds. And just about every single one has some unique gimmick or mechanic that shows up just for that level and then may never come back again... no surprise to fans of FP1, which similarly featured unique one-and-done level mechanics: a testament to the love and dedication that went into the game at a fundamental level. And of course, each level is capped off with a highly unique boss battle.

It also helps that the controls are responsive and very easy to get the hang of, so if you're getting in trouble, it's not because the game is cheap, it's because you screwed up.

A big change to the game is the new Items and Potions that let you customize and modify your experience. Some of them can make the game easier, while others are designed to make it much harder. More health, more lives, more speed? Not a problem. You'd rather play the game as a one-hit KO? Also not a problem!

In terms of criticism, I don't have much, but here goes:
-The music is still great, but I don't think it has quite as many earworms as FP1. None of it is ever annoying or uninspired, but I don't find myself humming it quite like I did the first game. And that's the meanest thing I can say about an OST that is still stellar.
-The game is also significantly harder than FP1, which might be a plus for some folks. Admittedly, that's partly because the game really expects you to get good and use the new Guard mechanic and the Items and Potions, but, on the other hand, those aspects aren't taught as well as they could be either, even in the optional tutorial.

Those minor gripes aside, this game is well worth your time and money. If you're a fan of retro throwbacks or just excellent gameplay in general, I highly recommend this one. Hopefully we get a Freedom Planet 3 within the next decade!

author: {'steamid': '76561198146809898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2977, 'last_played': 1667513765}
review:
The first Freedom Planet was a game that held a very special place in my heart, not only for being a solid Sonic-esqe action platformer, but also for being incredibly inspiring to me as it initially started life as a Sonic fan project and it starred characters that I remember from browsing DeviantArt in the mid 2000s, since I have my own passion project I have had in the works that started out as a fan project.

And now after waiting almost 7 years, listening to the Alpha OST religiously, seeing awesome fan art and watching the community grow, Freedom Planet 2 is finally here. 

And it's bigger and better than before!

The gameplay is greatly expanded upon with the characters feeling a lot more versatile thanks to some new moves such as Lilac's Boost Breaker, Carol's Jump Disc and Milla's Cube Blaster. And the new playable character, Neera can be very satisfying once you get the hang of her powerhouse-like playstyle. 
The addition of a dodge button, the various hub worlds, the ability to revive yourself at the cost of a stock Smash-Bros style and ways to customise your play experience with the Potions, Brave Stones and various other difficulty options are very welcome.
And the stages are still as fun, creative and action packed as ever, with big shout outs to Airship Sigwada, Globe Opera and Tidal Gate to name a few.

One of my only real gripes with the first game as fun the story was, there were things that the game either forget to tell about or weren't properly explained such as the character's backstories. Not only does this game "mostly" address them, but greatly expands on the lore and world-building with it's more in-depth story and characters. There are a lot of fun and heartfelt moments along with some interesting themes,  twists and stuff left open for a potential sequel.

The visuals, character designs and sprite work for this game are genuinely gorgeous and are some of best I have seen for a game of this type. And the music absolutely slaps!

It has been quite the journey to see the evolution of this series from it's humble beginnings to now. After waiting a long time for this game, it didn't disappoint! 
I had a blast with this treasure of a game that deserves to be up there with the other indie greats such as Shovel Knight & Shantae!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016042724', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1665749780}

review:
Freedom Planet 2 is a phenomenal game. And one that, against all odds, I feel should be game of the year. 
There's not much I can say that hasn't already been said before. The amount of love and care that went into this is astounding. The visual style and music are breathtaking and instant classics.
The 7 years it took to develop this game clearly show, through the refined combat and platforming that just keeps bringing you back for more. This game is most certainly worth your time and investment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050372876', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1847, 'last_played': 1681081071}
review:
A really great sequel to already good game, bringing a lot of new things to the formula while polishing what worked in previous game, again giving a nice "easy to learn hard to master" gameplay now with new character, and more fleshed out movesets for past characters

Story is interesting and good to see it focus on threat that comes from  the Avalice itself and gives us reason to learn more of the history of the world while trying to stop it and fact characters stories have more separate branches while seemgly not making any exclusive locations to accomodate these is nice touch, also true ending might be oen of the strongest emotional moments i expirianced in games for a long while but it's a secret for reason so no spoilers

Movement is really feeling good and rewards keeping up the speed, but also gives a lot of room for choosing different paths, even if it might seem like there is a lot of automation actually a lot of elements still demand active imput to keep working, but downside to it is there isn't as much to seek for on stages as in previous game, which helps with making stages be more streamlined and allowe better speedrun tactics but lostbit of a charm of previous games slightly labirynthian stage desing, also addition of rail gringing is fun, adds a lot of spectacle and dynamic sections but fact that to change direction of it we need to disconnect from the rail makes it feel unfinished, and seem to be actively makign some platformign sectiosn relying on rails feel bit awkward to pull off without skipping rail grinding entierly 

Combat again feels very well weaved into speedster platforming, with quite decent amount of new options to  work with, entire new guard mechanis (which honetly feels more like a doge but it's a nitpick on naming) giving even more invisiframes to use when trying to avoid taking damage, definetly comes in handy, especially that for side activities like restorign the gallery, or buing items to get "Treassure hunter" achievment secondary currency, cores, are pretty much neccessary and they only drop after defeating enemies (some types of enemies don't drop them but haven't seen a stage without any core dropping ones mixed in), also change that really huert me in my playtrough was redusing amount of health we get back while using extra life (now named stock), in previous game it was half the health by default, now it's like one point and can be brought back to 3 with potions but still feels like harsh change, especially that alternative of coming back with full health but on checkpoint can often mean loss of a lot of progress

New item system feels like really fun way to manually adjust dificulty  of the game to your own preferences, feel like there could still be more room for different bravestone modifiers to play around with challenging effects but current set already gives plenty of options

The overworld map system is really nice, having to watch the big scale overview of locations we explore, seeing some changes happening to map as we progress the story, also some clever ways to to spice up traversing across certain natural barriers, one  nitpick is that 2 specific trasnsitions (from Parusa to Sky Bridge and from Sky Bridge to Paraise Prime) are bit lengthy, put back to back and considering i had to do them a lot wehn getting all vinyls and items for achievemnts they started getting on my nerves

Over all fun game for fans of speedster platformers, still think might be better entry point for people new to the genre than 1st game with item system, but story does have a lot of plot points that are explained well enough but might feel exagerated without expiriancing story of 1st game
