author: {'steamid': '76561197998116681', 'num_games_owned': 3146, 'num_reviews': 600, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1669232179}
review:
Version 1.1.8r

Sanik was advertised like gotta go fast. But when it finally came out people instead got a slow and tedious generic platformer with a lot of dying, slow moving platforms and even going left. No matter what it tries, the franchise still can’t deliver on their promise (if we don’t count the endless runners for smartphones). Even the best sanik games allow to go fast only to the peak sportsmen who memorized the layouts and are younger than mid 20s when the human brain stops developing and starts rotting into alzheimer. The general public has to stumble and fail and go slow across the stupid platforms.

Freedom Planet was on the the right path of fixing sanik. The game made the levels almost play themselves on normal difficulties and offered a ton of HP. They still weren’t perfect choose your own roller-coasters, but you could go fast. To add more gameplay to the game it has tough bosses. On the normal difficulty you still can face-roll through all the levels yet be stuck on a boss-fight for an hour. The challenge was pleasant and offered a good contrast. Only a couple of bosses were drawn-out fights of attrition.

Having a platformer about meaningful speed is what sanik imagined. But it never achieved it, and the popularity of infinite runners proves that people want that.

Hope is the first step on the road to disappointment.

People expect sequels to improve upon the game, to keep the good parts and fix the bad parts. Even the Assassin’s Creed‘s sequel somehow became a playable game compared to the first one. I waited 7 years for this game. But rather than improving upon the first game it went far in other direction. It’s not sanik-1-bad but it is very bad. Instead if making the sequel tighter they decided to make it phatter with unnecessary clutter.

You were the chosen one! It was said that you would destroy the Sith, not join them! 

The entire level-design is unnecessary clutter. Instead of doubling down and making levels longer and even more streamlined, it made them into the giant buggy repetitive directionless convoluted slog of sanik labyrinth. There is a ton of dumb platforming and stupid no-brain puzzles. You don’t go fast to the right, you wander around in samey-looking rooms made of the same elements and hit the dumb walls all the time. There is a lot of precise platforming and waiting for the platforms to appear or move nearer.

There’s a terrible mandatory scroll-shooter section, and your weapons are garbage while the enemies are giving you bullet hell. And everything is filled with unnecessary clutter, it’s impossible to read the screen behind all those stupid explosions and to see your hitbox in relation to dangerous bullets.

When you get to play as a giant robot, instead of being the coolest part of the game like in Enclave or Psychonauts, it’s the worst part of the game. The robot can’t kill anything, the tiny enemies are not even damaged by it. It can’t traverse the level specifically made for it, it doesn’t fit anywhere and you have to get lucky to squeeze it through the narrow ways you are actually supposed to go through. It controls like an absolute arse.
But well, all controls in the game are fiddly and unresponsive. Even if you get the result you wanted, you still achieve it not through synergy with the game’s systems, but by unsure suggestions and leeway.

The levels are filled to the brim with stupid suckerpunch enemies and traps. Whose idea it was to add scam foes that kite you no matter the speed you are running at? They are always out of your reach but tie their damage output to your position. The game is dispensing unavoidable damage unless you slow down to a crawl. And not only you have to do that to avoid damage but to deal it too. All the enemies instead of dying from one hit are severe damage sponges. Even the first enemy in the game in the tutorial takes several hits on normal. That is if you can even hit it. And unlike sanik you don’t deal damage while jumping. You receive it. All of this is killing the pacing, who thought that adding a ton of combat into sanik can improve it? What is this, Freedom Unleashed?

All of the combat is unnecessary clutter. Your boost deals barely any damage and it is hard to aim. It’s more of a traversal power than a combat ability, despite granting invincibility. The spin doesn’t drain the meter anymore but its attack is very weak too, and also it’s hard to hit anything with it. Well it’s hard to hit anything with anything because all the enemies have annoying hitboxes. Yet they all are made of lava and easily deal damage to your giant hitbox without even touching it. The stupid block button (because a sanik game needed a stupid block button) repositions you back into damage. And well stunlocks for 50% damage is a common occurrence.

Most of the bosses in the first game were an enjoyable challenge. You can clearly see what you have to do and you are doing it. But this time the bosses are spazzing boring damage-soakers that are often turn the game into a bullet hell. A lot of them outright run away off-screen so you can’t even reach them while they pour death from above. They are plain not fun, starting with the first one, their patterns are primitive and there is no agency. But they have absolute tons of HP and just soak damage for an hour. The final boss is cancer. You have to beat her three times before you get a checkpoint while she fills the screen with unpredictable damage. Good luck fighting a one-armed bandit with dogshit controls, dogshit hitboxes, dogshit jumps and dogshit combat. The house always wins.

And all of that is enveloped with a terrible unnecessary clatter overworld map. Like, okay, you want to allow people to replay the levels and you’ve added asinine grind for money and materials. You’ve added shops selling the collectibles and garbage skills that are mostly useless. But why the absolute hell the navigation on the map is so bad? Why the hell it is multiscreen and with terrible node positions instead of unambiguous orthogonal roads between them? Why it wastes so much time on walking? Why it locks you away from the shops and earlier levels during the mid-game? Why the hell you are offered to chose one of the three levels all the time, if you play all three anyway? If there’s an overworld why lock that choice instead of offering branching paths? If there’s an overworld why is there no character selection screen? Why do you have to create a separate profile and be stuck with your choice? And yes there is no pause button on the map screen it still blasts music on focus loss.

The adventures of Lavaboy and Sharkgirl in 3-D

The story is unnecessary clutter. The first game featured teenedgy trash barely comprehensible convoluted story with terrible fandub voice acting. And it all is fitting and the characters are kinda endearing.

But this time we have to suffer through barely comprehensible convoluted story with terrible fandub voice acting that thinks it’s Zookeeper’s Schindler visiting John Raabe in Nanking. It’s second-hand embarrassing baby hitler dindunaffin. It’s a boring and self-serious garbage with more holes than a black hole. [url=https://milkandhate.wordpress.com/2022/11/24/freedom-planet-2/]The part about the story where she screams "freedomin' time" didn't fit here due to characters limit[/url]

I wanted to love this game, i went out of my way to purchase it by any means necessary once i saw that it was finally released. But before the 30% completion i realized that this is just mentally draining and embarassing, that i hate it and never want to see it again. And that’s before my life has turned into constant existential dread with me hoping for any game to be at least just a little bit not terrible so it can give me a small respite. I had to force myself to finish it, a level per several days.

Unnecessary clutter out of unnecessary clutter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146270095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3465, 'last_played': 1690621750}
review:
I don't have a beefy PC, so 2D indie games are my main guilty pleasure, especially 2D side scrolling platformers. Freedom Planet 1 happens to be the first game I remember buying on Steam within launch week, and I had fun exploring the levels, listening to the soundtracks, trying out the different characters.

Fast forward to 2022 and we now have Freedom Planet 2, and the developers definitely have much more work invested here. More levels (more than double the size of the first game), more soundtracks, a longer storyline, more characters, more pixels! The stages also all have something setting themselves apart from each other, each stage has its own theme / gimmick. They even threw in extra stuff like the museum and battlesphere which are decent additions.

This 2nd game seems to have taken at least 8 years to release, and that's already with some ideas scaled back or left out, so that they could release what we have today. The plus side is, the devs are quick to try and fix/patch most bugs.

If a 3rd game is planned, count me in as one of those excited for it. Freedom Planet was originally inspired by Sonic the Hedgehog games, but I think I had more fun with just FP1 + FP2, compared to playing Sonic(s) 1,2 CD, 3 and Mania combined.

The story is nothing impressive, but they manage to merge all of the likeable characters in one big story. Recommend 8/10 fun but simplistic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301579284', 'num_games_owned': 54, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 106, 'playtime_at_review': 2481, 'last_played': 1712258214}
review:
After 7 years of development, GalaxyTrail released the sequel to Freedom Planet, a Sonic fangame turned full-fledged indie with cues from Sonic, Treasure, Mega Man, and more. The first game was already stellar, but with the hype that built up over the game's development cycle, the new eager fans (myself included) who got caught up in the wave from the console ports of the first game, and a highly passionate team with high ambitions, how did this sequel fare? I'll cut to the chase: it did [i]amazingly well.[/i]

Picking up three years after the end of the previous game, although Brevon's been long gone since his invasion of Avalice, a lasting peace has been difficult, what with a recent string of mysterious attacks. As such, Lilac, Carol, and Milla, our heroines, are summoned by the Royal Magister of Shang Tu to help investigate the matter and figure out what exactly is going on, with Lieutenant Neera Li accompanying them on their mission. What starts out as some seemingly disconnected incidents, however, lead back to a phantom from Avalice's past, one who has spent the past three years plotting her revenge...

Summary aside, this game's story is absolutely stellar, helped by there being an actual writing team this time. The main cast's gotten older and wiser, the new characters, heroic and antagonistic alike, are incredibly written, making their arcs and character dynamics very compelling, and had me appreciate those I already did [strike]Milla[/strike] even more than before. What also helps is the strong VA work by everybody on the cast, be it the returning faces such as Dawn M. Bennett (Lilac), Edwyn Tiong (The Magister), and Alejandro Saab (Zao), or the new additions to the cast, such as Christopher Sabat (Askal), Morgan Berry (Merga), and Lindsay Jones (Corazon). Even better, the voice acting quality is consistent by virtue of Christopher Sabat allowing the cast to record in his studio, Okratron 5000. I admit, my earlier summary of the story is only scratching the surface, but given how it's so impactful in its writing and handles really well heavy subjects in its back half,[spoiler]especially that of colonialism and its related subjects,[/spoiler]I do hope you forgive me for not elaborating much more on that matter. Trust me, it's well worth it.

On the gameplay side, the returning playable cast feel amazing in motion, having picked up new tools that extend their already solid moveset (Lilac's Boost Breaker and Blink Dash), address their old moveset's key shortcomings (Carol's new melee options, Jump Disc, and bike reworks), or both (Milla's revamped Phantom Cube gameplay and her new melee attacks). Neera, an NPC and boss turned playable, also feels quite solid in motion, being lacking in a solid airgame but compensating with a strong combat-oriented movepool that can melt bosses when used right. This great feel, supplanted with the incredibly versatile new guard technique, works in tandem amazing well with the stage design, covering all kinds of fun challenges, from the pipe networks in Sherlin Park to the amusement park feel that is Zaoland. The strong stage design is complimented with some incredible bosses that are tough, but all manageable and satisfying to defeat, even if some of them, during endgame especially, ask players to have a strong understanding of all their tools to overcome them.

The sound design is as strong as ever, with the stage themes covering all kinds of great moods that match their stages, the map themes suiting the overall feel of their areas, and the new hub areas having great songs to accompany their more downtime-oriented design. Leila Wilson (otherwise known as Woofle) and Falk Au Yeong have created some incredible compositions that help make the game incredibly memorable.

Visually...it's sprite art. Need I say any more? The art shift away from the chibi style to a more proportioned design, beyond acting as a great look at how the cast's matured, also manages to make them look just as adorable as they were before, or even moreso [strike]Milla[/strike] with all the great animation that game has to compliment its sprites. On top of that, the various locations, stages, maps, and hubs alike, are incredibly beautiful and make them an even bigger joy to run through. Just be mindful of some latergame stages, the shaders they use for their 3D elements isn't exactly the nicest on older systems, although it's nothing unplayable.

Overall, this game is an indie masterpiece that has had so much love put into it, I could go on and on about what I enjoyed, [i]and this is only scratching the surface.[/i] I wholeheartedly recommend this game to fans of the first game, Treasure fans, Sonic fans, or just anyone in general looking for a really good indie platformer.

Verdict: Worth your time!
Final remarks: Seriously, please play this game, I adore it so much~

review: While I only have a couple of hours in this game so far, I gotta say it's a huge step up from what the first Freedom Planet was. Bugs from the first game have been removed, the level design has been improved from its predecessor, and each playable character feels unique and fun to play on top of that. If you enjoy the 2D Sonic games and treasure games as well, then you'll enjoy this game. I strongly recommend picking this game up for anyone who's a fan of 2D platformers. Freedom Planet 2 is exactly what a sequel should be, a great game that improves on what the first already did very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198316470715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 1665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1331, 'last_played': 1700857371}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is one of the most amazing game I have played, easily.

The game is one amazing ride from start to finish, the game is an amazing speed based platformer that really pushes and masters the 2D Style Speed platforming levels that most may know Sonic for and they all just feel fantastic along side the phenomenal OST (which by the way, please put up for purchase on Steam) which just makes every moment feel full of life and be fun to explore. The game managed to beat all my expectations and surpass the original game in every way possible.

The support after launch has also been phenomenal as well with the first week getting an update to fix issues I never knew were there as my experience was bug free. The amount of effort put into the game here trumps AAA studios and is embarrassing for other games, namely Sonic Origins which came out a buggy mess and has remained that way.

My only main issue is Classic Mode being locked behind game completion as the story is definitely not for everyone and the game does feel better to just play going level to level.

Do yourself a favour and get this game if you have any interest in platformers, especially Speed Based ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198883388960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3291, 'last_played': 1699384265}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 é bom demais!!!

Perfeito
Pegou tudo que era bom no primeiro jogo e deixou 10x melhor
NÃO 100X MELHOR!
As músicas me marcam, os chefes são difíceis se for ficar muito ousado. As fazes não são entediantes, sempre tem algo pra você fazer seja procurar os discos ou upgrade ou apenas aproveitar o cenário e a pixel art muito belas.
Tem cidades onde você pode ir e conversar com as pessoas, cada um com sua personalidade única e desing furry bem fofinho que o artista faz, assim você não sente que o mundo é só "vai lá e bate nos caras maus"
Você pode tirar fotos no meio do seu jogo, e fazer poses! pegar momentos engraçados com isso é maravilhoso, tipo um míssel vindo na sua direção e você consegue pegar perfeitamente o momento que ele esta colado na face do personagem.
As músicas como do primeiro jogo são expetaculares, combinam perfeitamente com cada cada fase englobando seu estilo. Fase de máquinas? Uma música mais intrustrial e eletrônica! Fase num parque? Uma música bem divertida e energizada como a própria fase que chove inimigos.

Sem contar a trilha sonora de cada personagem que tem.
Muitas conquistas! Uma vilã foda, um mapa onde você pode escolher ir pra onde você quiser, Rank's, treinamento que pela primeira vez em um jogo foi a primeira coisa que fui fazer e eu tomei um pau.
Se eu não passar 100 horas nesse jogo, eu provavelmente terei morrido de alguma coisa, porque puta que pariu

Os melhores 50 reais da minha vida, nunca ri tanto e fiquei agindo igual um retardado de tão feliz que eu estava. Aaaah! Valeu muito a espera de 7 anos.

Meu jogo favorito. Obrigado GalaxyTrail!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025169706', 'num_games_owned': 1260, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1668847492}
review:
5/10 game. If you want Freedom Planet at its best, play the first one. 
Ambitious, but with a lot of problems. The devs put in a lot of work but it on average doesn't feel as engaging as the first one, even with the bigger scope. Some aspects even feel worse on average, especially the writing and boss fights. 
Freedom Planet 2 is clearly a labor of love, but if I told you it was worth every penny it would be a white lie. Worth playing, but only if you've played the first and found yourself wanting more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065262847', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1811, 'last_played': 1705808893}
review:
Not the 10/10 people seem to think it is, but still absolutely worth the price.

[h2] Mediocre Early Game [/h2]
Many of the games early stages are relatively weak. ([b]If you're looking to use steam's refund period as a trial, make sure to select "Robot Rampage" when you have the option[b], this will get you to the good stages earlier) Not terrible, but not great either. (Avian Museum, Airship Sigwada, Zao Land, and Shenlin Park) There are some pretty rough issues distinguishing the background from the foreground, and unmemorable music and bosses. There's also some pretty rough camera issues, where you need to maintain a high speed to see what's ahead of you, even in some enclosed boss fights. I didn't hate it, but it certainly left a weak first impression compared to it's predecessor. None of this is helped by long, insignificant cutscenes and constantly throwing you into hub areas.

[h2] Great Midgame, Excellent Endgame [/h2]
Thankfully, though, the game gets much better about a third of the way in (*if you follow the recommended stage order, some can be done out of order) Bosses get good, then great, most of the soundtrack is amazing, and it's clear what is actually a solid object (thank god.) There are triggers that zoom the camera out when you need to see what's around you - these were notably missing in the levels I mentioned above.

By the final stretch of my first playthrough, I was thoroughly in love. Once the game picked up, it never let me down. The last few stages were some of the best.

This is a very long game though, at least for what it is. There 24 lengthy stages and an average playthrough lasts a little under 10 hours. Don't try to do it all in one go or you [i]will[/i] get burnt out before the end. It also supports framerates well above 60, which is sadly rare for 2D games.

[h2] Technical Issues [/h2]
I played the game about two months after launch, and only experienced a two major gameplay issues, both of which are now fixed. At launch, it was seemingly pretty buggy, but now seems rock solid.

There is one major issue though, the game doesn't scale properly to resolutions above 1080p, leading to a slightly blurry image. The game's pixel art is lovely, and look better with sharper pixels. I use the app [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/993090/Lossless_Scaling/]Lossless Scaling[/url] set to nearest neighbor for my 1440p monitor. It works great, but you really shouldn't need a piece of paid external software for your game to look right. This is being looked into, but as of writing there's doesn't seem to be a fix in the works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040532743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1669306895}

author: {'steamid': '76561198818823555', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2738, 'last_played': 1708566951}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 feels and looks a million times better then the first Freedom Planet. Don't get me wrong, I love the first Freedom Planet, but I never felt as strong of a pull to bring me back in for another round, and I especially didn't feel as connected to the whole cast, or the world as I did before.

Freedom Planet 2 comes with EXCELLENT world building, acting, levels, bosses, difficulty, writing, and it comes packaged with the same old charm. One thing I was really worried about going from FP1 to FP2 is I wouldn't like the designs present here as much as I did before. However in-game they felt right at home, and really enhanced and highlighted exactly how dull the designs were prior.

The animations were excellent, the pixel art this time around got such a beautiful boost, no longer looking muddy at times, and generally looking like a place I would love to live in. I would love to go Parusa with it's wonderful lush tropical landscape or Shang Tu, with it's gorgeous locals and bright blue cities.

Something else I realy loved was the episodic format. Whether it's the Battlesphere or uncovering what is the cause of the mysterious snow, or even just trying to stop Sky Pirates from invading the Museum, it is a pure delight to go through everything each area has to offer.

There was an excellent replay value where damn near every section of the story had something new to discover from another characters view, and I can't wait to play this game over and over.

Thank you GalaxyTrail for making another great indie classic.

review: Freedom Planet 2 is a game which builds upon the original and manages to improve upon it in almost every way. author: {'steamid': '76561198043786835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1668460615}
review:
I wish I could give some sort of "meh" or "10/20" review. 

There are some bad stuff in this game like some levels going on for too long, having cluttered visuals and bad enemy / obstacle placements, being forced to play the story (whereas in the first game you had classic mode), and some good like the characters sprites, some levels actually being fun and the game controls well.

But I'm giving a negative review because of one big problem. And it's a warning to potential buyers: Of all the games I played in my life, this is the only one that gave me motion sickness and almost made me puke.
Some levels when they are really cluttered visually, and when you are going really fast can make you sick. The Battlesphere and the Lava / volcano levels later in the game are prime examples.

And the boss that came after the lava levels had a background animation that was going so fast, not only was it distracting, it also gave me motion sickness and I just had to quit the game.

If you had experience with motion sickness while playing games, don't buy this game and instead check out the first game. As for the others who didn't experience any, be careful.

I reported this issue in the discord server but was told it was spoilers ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: {'steamid': '76561198420033904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 171, 'playtime_at_review': 2150, 'last_played': 1712437595}
review:
O Jogo é espetacular! Os gráficos são bonitos, e tem um level design ótimo que deixa as fases divertidas de se passar. Cada uma das quatro bonecas disponíveis no jogo tem sua jogabilidade diferenciada. Assim o jogador pode se divertir em fazer as quatro campanhas. Porém as campanhas serão as mesmas para as quatro personagens, diferente do primeiro jogo, no qual as companhas de cada personagem se diferenciam levemente.
A trilha sonora é outro show a parte. Tem uma diversidade de ritmos bem rica e com várias referências ao jogo anterior. Espero que lancem a trilha sonora logo na plataforma para eu poder comprar. Ou então coloquem nas plataformas musicais como Spotify ou Deezer.
O jogo teve várias inovações em comparação ao primeiro, tendo bem mais conteúdos. Temos mais fases! Muito mais chefes (que pode até ficar cansativo nesse aspecto). Um "hub" no qual você fica falando com npcs, e até mesmos itens equipáveis. Esses item podem ser benéficos, que facilitam a jogatina, ou podem atrapalhar (estes são conhecidos como "Brave Stones"). Equipar essas Brave Stones lhe concedem bônus no fim da fases.
Algumas fases podem bugar. Não sei é problema do jogo ou é por causa do meu PC de batata. Mas as fases 21, 24 e 25 podem apresentar falhas como pixies todo borrados.
Enfim, esse é uma continuação digna desse belo jogo de plataforma 2D!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966632480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1668365737}
review:
If you like high quality 2D platformers in the same vein as Sonic, pick it up, it's really really good.

Gameplay is a more streamlined version of FP1 with new dodge mechanics. The game can be played slow and steady or at extreme speed as it should. Length was fairly decent, clocking in at about 8 hours to finish the whole story on Lilac, I'm assuming the other characters have unique story scenes and even some stages, but I haven't tried them yet.

I also feel it's necessary to point out that this game has really impressive visuals and set pieces for a 2d platformer. The soundtrack is also host to many bangers. 

Freedom Planet 2 took what made the first game special and improved upon it greatly, further distancing itself from Sonic. This no longer feels like a Sonic love letter and more like its own franchise.

review: This game is great. While perhaps not challenging, its engaging and the boss fights are a lot of fun. Some creative design in having something like a rock bender like fighter having a delayed drop of rocks when he lands with a slam, for example. The OST has some bangers. The voice acting is great. the writing is fun with that saterday morning cartoon/ anime feel, the sprit art is fantastic, and . If you liked the first one, you will love this. If you found the first one frustrating, almost all of those elements are gone. The team clearly listened and improved on what they could. So yeah, rock on, hope to see a 3rd game.

review:
This is a step up compared to the prequel (which was really good on its own already) in almost every way. I absolutely love the attention to detail put into this game, the music is great, the spritework is excellent, and it's filled with bits that add a lot more worldbuilding and personality to the world of Avalice.
Freedom Planet 2 is genuinely the best platformer I have ever played and I can't stress over how much I recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037372051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1667772421}
review:
Just like the first game, this is a criminally overlooked modern classic that blows the series that inspired it out of the water. Freedom Planet might have started out as a love letter to Sonic, but it improves on and surpasses it in almost every way. The tight gameplay, the flow of the levels, the incredible bosses, the lovely art, and the 10/10 soundtrack easily make this one of my games of the year. If there's any part of you that likes 2D action games, you owe it to yourself to play this.

By and large Freedom Planet 2 is very reminiscent of the first game, though you don't have to have played FP1 to enjoy it. It's a bigger, slicker, tighter, and better paced experience than the original, hitting all of the same highs while offering more than twice as much game this time around. 

The gameplay has seen numerous small improvements like the addition of one or two extra moves for each character, along with a parry button that really helps take some of the boss fights to the next level. It's amazing to maintain your speed and momentum mid-fight by parrying your way through an attack rather than having to slow down and carefully dodge.

The storytelling, as well, is probably the most notably improved area compared to the prequel. The FP games are bubbly and enthusiastic, but they do read like Sonic fanfiction at times. This is part of their charm for me, but regardless of whether the cheesy blend of silly humour and high drama works for you, it's delivered in a far more digestible manner this time around. FP1 suffered from trying to cram a world full of political factions, side characters, and interplanetary war into a linear action game, with cutscenes sometimes just as long as the levels they followed. FP2 carries all of this over, but with more stages and hub areas full of optional dialogue to dilute the cutscenes, resulting in much better pacing overall. The script also feels tighter, with the humour hitting the mark more often and the world building feeling natural rather than bloated.

The addition of a fourth playable character and a bunch of optional challenges also helps to flesh out the playtime. If you want hours and hours of Freedom Planet, this game has it for you. This does lead into my one criticism of the game, though; while I'd say the overall quality of the experience is easily on par with FP1, it feels a bit more stretched. I found the gimmicky stages to be more conspicuous in FP2, and some of them felt like misfires. While it does modulate the pacing to intersperse fast actiony levels with slower puzzley and exploration-based ones, the action stages are universally better suited to the game's mechanics. I found the dedicated boss stages a lot more enjoyable than the ones that had me backtracking in multiple directions or hunting down keys to progress. I wouldn't have minded if the game had fewer, but more tightly designed levels.

I could gush for a long time about how awesome some of the boss fights are, how many bangers the soundtrack has, or how the game pulls off a finale that's both similar and different enough from FP1 to stand toe-to-toe with it, but it's easier to just say that this game is incredible. Galaxy Trail have succeeded in putting out a fantastic sequel to Freedom Planet that I hope garners all the recognition it deserves some day. They've taken this subgenre and made it their own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013146396', 'num_games_owned': 1655, 'num_reviews': 2129, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1667754439}
review:
МУСОР

Несмотря на местами очень крутой по глубине и свежести механик платформер, это ОЧЕНЬ ПОГАНЫЙ ЗАКОС ПОД СОНИКА.
Первая часть мне понравилась, но эта выбесила буквально за час, и каждый уровень ощущался как ЁБАНОЕ НАКАЗАНИЕ. Как минимум потому, что авторы ВООБЩЕ не учли НИЧЕГО после первой игры, и всё отвратительное если не усилили, так убирать не стали.
Очевидно, что это копирка синего ежа - причём оммажи иногда переходят в полную копирку оригинала. Например, некоторые уровни или механики.
И всё это было бы отлично, если бы эта фиолетовая сука НОРМАЛЬНО УПРАВЛЯЛАСЬ.

Помните, как в классическом Сонике приходилось страдать от его инертности и тупых способностей?
Помните, как в Сонике, в СПИННО-МОЗГОВОМ ГЕЙМПЛЕЕ, ЗА ПОПЫТКИ СКОРОСТНОГО ПРОХОЖДЕНИЯ НАКАЗЫВАЛИ?
Помните, как почти ни один враг не умирал с одного удара, и приходилось если уж не потеть над каждым мобом, то хотя бы УБЕГАТЬ ОТ НЕГО ПО ВОЗМОЖНОСТИ?
Помните, как ВООБЩЕ ВСЕ ВРАГИ БЫЛИ БЫСТРЕЕ ГЕРОЯ?
Помните, как даже во время СОБСТВЕННЫХ АТАК ёж вообще никак не был защищён?
Помните ПЛАТНЫЕ ЧЕКПОИНТЫ?
Помните УЕБАНСКИЙ САУНДТРЕК, КОТОРЫЙ СОСТОИТ ТОЛЬКО ИЗ БЕСКОНЕЧНОГО ШУМА ЭЛЕКТРОГИТАРЫ, И ВЫКЛЮЧАЕШЬ ЕГО СПУСТЯ ПАРУ УРОВНЕЙ?
Помните ЕБАНЫХ БОССОВ, КОТОРЫХ НЕЛЬЗЯ ПРОЙТИ БЕЗ ПИЗДЮЛЕЙ?
Помните финального босса в 5+ СТАДИЙ?
Помните ТУПЫЕ КАТСЦЕНЫ С ВИЗЖАЩИМИ БАБАМИ?
Помните ТУПОЙ СЮЖЕТ НИ О ЧЁМ, ОТ ВЫРЕЗАНИЯ КОТОРОГО ИГРА БЫ НИЧЕГО НЕ ПОТЕРЯЛА?
Помните ЦЕЛЫЕ УРОВНИ ПРОСТО НА ПОХОДИТЬ И ПОПИЗДЕТЬ С НЕНУЖНЫМИ ПЕРСОНАЖАМИ? БЕЗ СКОРОСТИ.
Помните КАРТУ МИРА, В КОТОРОЙ ЕЩЁ И ЗАПУТАТЬСЯ МОЖНО?

А я вот, блять, НЕ ПОМНЮ.

Ни одной игры от этой студии 100% больше не куплю.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032241711', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1387, 'last_played': 1668466672}
review:
Good length, high replayability due to 4 characters.
Music was good, I think im a bit more partial to the first game's music though.
Story has that same kind of charm, cant help but smile at the goofy antics.
Gameplay wise I think it does stages better than FP1 did, but FP1 had some really cool bosses and this one had less of them.
overall highly recommend if you enjoyed the first one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024469507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2690, 'last_played': 1667731738}
review:
Been having a blast with this game, this one is a massive improvement over the first one and the developers did an outstanding job :D . Each character brings something new and fresh to the table and the story is quite the ride till the end. The overworld was a good idea to implement and gives you the chance to collect every collectible and complete every mini-game.

Few downsides is that not everything is flawless. It suffers from a few bugs and glitches here and there, but still plays like no problem for the most of it, give the developers your feedback and the time to polish it up to outshine.

It can get repetitive with each character with minor story differences from each side, not as diverse and having exclusive stages as the first one. Some of the stages can still be a little long, but most of them are better shortend over the first game and gives you a fair chance before encountering any bigger main boss fights. Some of the music isn't perfectly looped and can feel a bit weird out of place.

Overall, it may not be for everyone. But if you love the gameplay, the story and every loveable character for it has to offer, i highly recommend this to everyone.   ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561199147117438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1851, 'last_played': 1710988613}
review:
The first Freedom Planet game was what I always wanted from the 2D Sonic Series. Overtime, while I still love Sonic, I felt that the games had gotten kinda stale. There was no meaningful growth. Freedom Planet addressed all issues that I had with the series while, creating story and characters that I enjoy much more than what I get from the Sonic series. When I played the game years ago, I was hoping that there would be another one that pushed the Freedom Planet series forward. What I didn't expect is how much Freedom Planet 2 did that. 

This is an excellent game, and while I want to write a longer review for the game (which is something that I am going to do) I will leave my score for it which is 9.5/10. Damn near perfect in my eyes. One of the best indie games I have ever played not called Hollow Knight. I hope that the series continues after this and doesn't take 7 years.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561199399434052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5922, 'last_played': 1688124733}
review: Freedom planet 2 is an incredible experience and is easily a must buy if you enjoyed the first game. Everything has been improved and expanded upon: from the absolutely gorgeous pixel art, to the infectiously catchy soundtrack and the overall much better pacing. The background lore for lilac, the squad and Avalice as a whole has also been expanded upon, presented very nicely through a well written narrative that actually features quite a sympathetic antagonist. On the gameplay side of things, each character handles well and can take advantage of weaving their way through the multiple pathways of each stage in their own unique fashion. Some characters are better suited fr specific purposes however: Lilac is great for speed and would generally be considered the easy mode, whereas Neera is a boss killer whom lacks mobility in comparison to the other heroins. Speaking of bosses, they're all a treat to fight, having well telegraphed attack patterns and make good use of the games' new dodge mechanic, but some less experienced players may have trouble with the insane speeds of later ones. To compensate for players of all skill levels, the settings menu has a plethora of accessibility options including free revives, auto guarding, reducing the cost of continues and increasing the sensitivity of the screen zoom out, among others. In addition to these options, if they weren't enough the game itself includes a shop system, accessed from vendors in hubs. As a side note these hubs all have their own atmosphere and incredibly charming NPCs that add to the feeling of this world being alive. Most of them have unique dialogue linking to different story events, some dialogue being character specific. Anyways, the shop system acts as a way for players to spend their currency rewarded by exploring stages on a multitude of items that either assist players, or hinder them in exchange for a higher rank and crystal bonus at the end of stages. If you want to be an absolute powerhouse then you can equip yourself with a full attack potion if you really want to, but if you want to go for those elusive rainbow S ranks, try using on hit KO and get through a stage without being damaged at all. Thankfully the ranking system has no in game effects outside of achievements and a higher bonus, so going after high ranks isn't necessary if it's not comfortable. Freedom planet 2 takes you on a tour of Avalice, with stunning visuals, amazing level design, a banging soundtrack, endearing characters, a smooth difficulty curve and bosses with so much spectacle. it's one of the most fun and well crafted experiences I've had in a video game and if you couldn't already tell, I love it to death. Wonderful 2D platformer, would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119033823', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1667485875}

review: An absolutely charming game with fun characters, interesting story, exceedingly good pixel art, great soundtrack and gameplay that just feels *good*. The movement is easily one of the better parts of the already great game. The four playable characters each have different playing styles and story perspectives, giving the game a good dose of replayability as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136843944', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1628, 'last_played': 1710908301}
review:
Recently, I did a big playthrough of the original Freedom Planet, and now its sequel. Both games are exceptional in quality, and keep the nostalgic feeling in its gameplay, visuals, and music. I could not rate this game, and this franchise, highly enough with the caliber of work done by Galaxy Trail.

My only complaint is that the official soundtrack is [u]only[/u] available through the vinyls in-game and not for download/purchase. Please, take my money, I beg you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198221549660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 68, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1712448953}
review: By far one of the best sequels I've played, Freedom Planet 2 takes what worked about the first game and makes it better! The character roster of Lilac, Carol, and Milla with the addition of Neera being playable creates for some added diversity and allows one to view the story from multiple different perspectives. The gameplay mechanics keep the core formula the same while adding new things to make them fresh. The first game had a lot of Sonic the Hedgehog inspiration and while it still shows here, it's not quite as apparent especially in terms of graphics and animation. While it does maintain a similar retro vibe, the animation has significantly improved with characters having many more unique animations in cutscenes and gameplay. The story has also upped the drama by comparison to the first game and delivers on non-stop, heart-pounding action throughout. Building on everything that worked about the first game is what many good sequels should strive to do and Freedom Planet 2 delivers magnificently!

author: {'steamid': '76561198090836382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 16, 'playtime_at_review': 1215, 'last_played': 1711509914}

This game was all too well worth the wait, you won't be dissapointed!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005601881', 'num_games_owned': 1613, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2955, 'last_played': 1667429463}
review:
Prologue

  When Freedom Planet 1 came out in 2014, it quickly became my Game of the Year, and in 2015, a sequel was announced, but I never expected for it to come out seven fucking years later, after I had accumulated over 57 hours of playtime in the first title at the time of this writing, now, seven years is a long time, but was the wait worth it? Spoilers, it was, just look at my playtime for FP2, but now I'll tell you why this sequel works so well.

Graphics

  No joke, this is the best-looking 2D indie game I've ever seen. FP2 genuinely reminded me of Castlevania Symphony of the Night when it came to background detail and sheer amount of animation frames for anything, from the main characters to enemies and citizens you can talk to, every single level looks drop-dead gorgeous and even the most non-important NPC looks great and have way more frames of animation than they needed, but the artists went above and beyond anyway.

  The first game already had a solid presentation, but the sequel improves on it even further, there are even some 3D models this time around, which made the SOTN parallels stronger, and just like in that game, they don't look out of place because they were used for things that would've been difficult if not outright impossible to pull off in traditional 2D, and if they could, wouldn't have nearly as much impact.

  FP1 already looked like a Saturn game, but FP2 looks even more like one with the combination of richly-detailed 2D sprites and backgrounds with 3D models. However, my one and only complaint about the visuals would be the completely static water in Paradise Prime, considering how perfect this game looks, a small lake that doesn't animate in any way sticks out like a sore thumb.

Sound

  Woofle returns as this game's composer, and just like with the first game, she absolutely nailed the soundtrack, with catchier songs and now there are way more of them, you know it's going to be good when even the songs that play in the World Map are absolute bangers. I'm not a musician, so I have no way of describing what makes this soundtrack so good, you just have to take my word for it.

  The sound effects are just as good, if not even better than in the first title, no complaints there, they're still very distinct and I would never mistake where they came from if I heard them outside of this game.

Story

  Now here's a surprise, the story in Freedom Planet 1 was a very contentious topic and I have good news for everyone, the second game has improved the narrative quite a bit, with dark themes but without any overly indulgent scenes like the infamous electrical torture scene in FP1.

  It shows restraint, and I really like how playing as different characters led to different dialogue in some cutscenes, the first game already had that, but with the much lengthier campaign and more exclusive scenes, it makes playing as all four characters more worth it this time around.

  The voice acting has also recieved a noticeable improvement, dialogue was recorded in a professional studio so no longer there are differences in audio quality, returning actors improved their performances even more compared to the first title and the new actors have very solid delivery.

The only mixed bag for me about the story would be the villain, while her motivations are much more understandable compared to Brevon in FP1, in my opinion she is nowhere near as charismatic, Brevon was a bastard but he was OUR bastard, while Merga didn't really win me over. Towards the end of the game she also makes a questionable decision, especially considering her culture, but I won't go into spoilers.

Gameplay

  The high-speed action platformer formula returns in this sequel, with even more improvements, some subtle, others not so much. Starting with the obvious enhancements, characters control and feel even more responsive, the screen sometimes zooms out to give you a better field of view (and you can adjust it in the options menu!), a world map has been implemented, hub levels are a thing and now there is a dodge button, which gives you invincibility frames when you press it.

  Not gonna lie, when I started playing this game, I almost never used the dodge, but as the levels became more intense and more stray projectiles started flying over the screen, I was constantly pressing that button, and the same thing happened with the bosses.

  Level design became bigger and bolder, and for the most part, it works wonderfully, I can safely say that 95% of the levels in this game are a blast to play, and even the worst stages in the game are nowhere near as painful as, say, the worst levels in the Mega Man X series, if you're familiar with those. If not, then rest assured, you ain't gonna die a million times and spend an ungodly amount of time trying to get past them. Rule of thumb is, if the level you're in ain't called Inversion Dynamo, you're good. The other weak levels are just jank.

  If 95% doesn't sound like a good enough percentage for you, let me put this into perspective: It took me over 10 (probably closer to 20) playthroughs for me to achieve my current playtime in Freedom Planet 1. In Freedom Planet 2, I got 49 hours on it (at the time of this writing, of course) after only four. This is a MUCH longer game, with a lot more content waiting to be seen by the player. Granted, I played on Adventure Mode, which has cutscenes, but even then, there are way more levels in this game and some of them can be very long - I don't have a problem with long levels as long as they're interesting and checkpoints are well-placed, and the long bois in Freedom Planet 2 pass that test with flying colours.

  Aside from the regular levels, Freedom Planet 2 also added Hub levels, which have no enemies and it's just you, vibing and talking to NPCs (there are a LOT of them, too), and ocasionally, playing a minigame or just admiring the scenery.

  No longer used just for extra lives, crystals can also be exchanged for gold gems, which are used to buy various items, many of which helpful in nature, such as giving you a Damage Over Time effect when you hit an enemy (particularly helpful for bosses) or giving you an extra life petal, while others increase the game's difficulty in various ways and give you access to higher rankings (without those items, the best rank you can get in a level is A).

  The biggest addition in terms of side content, however, is the Battlesphere, which might sound familiar to anyone that played the Ratchet & Clank games, it's an arena with various challenges, boss rematches and a baseball minigame, and as the game goes on, more of those first two unlock, and in fact, beating all challenges is mandatory to obtain the best ending, but it's not the most difficult "good ending" to get I've seen in a game.

  Speaking of difficulty, Freedom Planet 1 was a challenging game, and while the sequel might be easier in some aspects, it can be more difficult in others, such as boss fights, in my opinion some of these tough boys 'n gals can be harder than even the last boss of the first game, but at the same time, these fights are QUICK, if they last over two minutes, either the boss has a big health bar or something's going horribly wrong. You die fast, but so do your enemies, and that's exactly the kind of boss fight I prefer in games.

Conclusion

  I spent two hours writing this review just to try to convince more people to buy Freedom Planet 2, especially that coward Woolie, and the only way I have of finishing up here is, just try it - There's a demo and if you want to see more of the game, within the 2-hour refund period you can get a good glimpse of what it has to offer, especially if you skip cutscenes. Freedom Planet 1 is no longer my favourite indie game of all time because its sequel is now finally out.




Can't wait to play Freedom Planet 3 in 2035!

author: {'steamid': '76561198141237463', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4341, 'last_played': 1694746759}
review:
The short summary: 11/10
Much like its predecessor, Freedom Planet 2 is a side-scrolling, platforming adventure along the same vein as classic Sonic the Hedgehog games.  But Freedom Planet 2 has improved upon the original in almost every way, having grown from its Sonic-inspired roots into something more distinctive and unique.  Freedom Planet 2 feels much more fleshed out with a lot more story, which is just what I was craving most from the original; I wanted to learn more about these characters and this universe, and Freedom Planet 2 scratched that itch; though having played through all four characters' campaigns with the "true ending," questions around the history of Avalice remain,  which I hope to see answered in future Freedom Planet games, DLC, or other media.  Even if you haven't played the original (which you absolutely should), Freedom Planet 2 is well worth a playthrough.  


The full review:
Much like the original Freedom Planet, this is a side-scrolling platformer featuring four playable heroines, each one with their own style and characteristics.  Your first play through will be in Adventure Mode, which in my opinion is the best way to experience the game, because one thing FP2 does way better than the original is story.

Cutscenes and dialogue flow better than they did in the original, with quality voice acting and funny moments throughout.  Many of these scenes are the same regardless of which character you play, but some are exclusive to each character, so to get the full story you'll have to play through as all four characters, but in my opinion that is just part of the fun!

Gameplay is pretty simialr to FP1, except now we have more fine-tuned controls and returning characters have had their move-sets reworked. The biggest feature is the introduction of Guarding, allowing you to completely evade damage if well timed.  Traversing levels and battling bosses feels much more fluid and is super satisfying. 

The art style has been greatly improved upon from the FP1 style, and the levels themselves sport unique themes and charm, complete with amazing background music, much like the levels of FP1 did.  While FP2 dropped the collectible Cards of FP1, there are still secrets to be found within the levels, primarily Vinyls to unlock music and a few Brave Stones.

Speaking of which, Brave Stones and Potions are a new feature added to enhance the gameplay.  Throughout your adventure you will collect Gems and Orbs, both of which can be exchanged into Gold Gems. Gold Gems are rarely found within levels too.  You can mix and match Potions to give yourself different buffs, such as increasing attack damage or making your attacks heal you a little bit.  Brave Stones can also offer buffs, but many act as difficulty multipliers, and you are rewarded with extra Gems for completing levels with detrimental Brave Stones equipped. I love this system because it allows players to tailor the difficultly to their liking, and gives them options if they find themselves struggling at a particular area.

Additionally, if you're the completionist type, there's a Gallery in Adventure Mode that you can donate resources to in order to complete exhibits.  They're neat to look at, but in my opinion the main treat here is that you get access to a special gallery upon completing all the exhibits.  This special gallery shows off some behind-the-scenes stuff from the development of FP2, including early concept art and scrapped assets, so if you're into that kind of stuff, completing the Gallery is a worthwhile endeavor!

As a final point, I've noticed some comments about issues playing the game (crashes, softlocks, etc.) so if you experienced problems before, I'd recommend giving the game another try.  The Developers have already released several updates to fix bugs and even add a few new features; it's obvious to me that this game was a labor of love for them and that they want this to be the best experience it can be after all this time since FP1. :)

All in all, I've thoroughly enjoyed my time with Freedom Planet 2.  At the time of my writing this, I've completed all four characters' stories in Adventure Mode and unlocked all but two secret achievements.  I love the characters, I love the gameplay, I love the game world, and I don't plan to stop playing until I've done everything this game has to offer!

review:
Was it worth the wait?

Yes, Yes it was, I have been waiting for this game ever since its announcement and it does not disappoint!
The characters are much more fleshed out compared to FP1. 
The story is intense, funny, and sad at times, Levels and Bosses are most of the time pretty solid, Loved the extra stuff to make it feel original then from FP1, and the music is Amazing, Seriously Listen to the Bakunawa (World map) Theme!
All I ask is from GalaxyTrail is to keep the Freedom Planet story going with a new game!
This is my Favorite game I ever played and it was definitely worth the nearly 7 year wait!

review:
A worthy sequel to the original Freedom Planet that expands upon it's world and gameplay in so many ways that it's simply amazing. Introduction of mechanics like guarding, revivals and even things like being able to cancel Lilac's signature Dragon Boost makes this game so much more friendly towards "filthy casuals" such as myself! I love how much personality all the characters have and it really shows through interactions they have during the cutscenes and everything. If you've ever played the original Freedom Planet or any Treasure Genesis/Mega Drive games. Get. This. Game. You will absolutely LOVE it to bits. 
If I was offered a Freedom Planet 3, I would scream a "Yes" at the top of my lungs. Kudos, GalaxyTrail. Kudos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026522726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1613, 'last_played': 1677100040}
review:
A great sequel to a great game, adding in some new ideas and doing them well.

Both games feel like a cross between 2d Sonic and Megaman Zero to me, with the focus on mobility and ability to speedrun levels combined with a health bar and focus on melee combat: especially against bosses.

The biggest change is the dodge button, which puts your character into an invulnerable state briefly, lasting a bit longer if something that would have hit them is blocked, while preventing them from attacking for the duration with a brief but potentially punishing cooldown. This can let you take down bosses aggressively with good timing.

Each character moves and fights differently, with an expansion on the movesets of Freedom Planet and good use of a quickly refilling Energy meter tied to signature moves.

For instance, Carol the Wildcat is the only one that can roll and do Megaman X style wall kicks, with three unique attack options in the air. Her signature move is the Jump Disk, which she throws in a direction of your choosing for decent damage, and can jump to it for roll damage and invincibility frames for a time, comboing into her aerial moves.

Neera the Frost Night, on the other hand, has a double jump, lunge combo, down attack, slower hits with a bit more reach, a focus state where she attacks faster, and what I'd call spells that use a full energy meter each and come in big vertical attack, freeze/ damage horizontal projectile, or a down attack that makes ice traps she can consume to bounce off of.

The stages and bosses are (mostly) the same for different characters with, but they all have some exclusive scenes and information to their point of view for extra variety.

The story fits the old mix of a lighthearted base with big stakes and darker moments overshadowing it, and being able to talk to NPCs in hubs really fleshes out the world.

If you liked the first one buying this is a no brainer: if you haven't tried it I'd recommend starting with the first for context, though I think this is the superior game.

review:
Jogasso, já tava esperando o lançamento faz muito tempo
Um dos melhores que joguei esse ano, capricharam demais no level design, ele melhora tudo do primeiro e expande; Explorar as fases é extremamente divertido, cada uma é como se fosse um playground pra vc explorar e brincar a vontade, o que impede do jogo ficar maçante pela quantidade absurda de fases, vc passa uma e já quer ir pra próxima pensando em qual vai ser o cenário, quais serão os inimigos e qual a ost, que também tá ótima assim como no primeiro jogo

author: {'steamid': '76561198347793028', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 18828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 384, 'playtime_at_review': 7878, 'last_played': 1712263127}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is amazing and better than the first one in every way. 

I have waited a long time for this game and i can definitely say that it was worth the wait. Freedom Planet 1 was pretty much my favorite game of all time and they managed to make something that i love even more and i'm very thankful for every hour that was spend with making this game!!

The Levels are incredibly creative and every single one of them has something special that makes it stand out. The Leveldesign is also absolutely amazing, really intuitive and fluid. The controls are just as fluid and it's just fun to move the Character around. The Bosses are also really creative and can be a great challenge, once you've learned them you can whack them easily and that's really fun! So yea, everything about the Gameplay is perfection! 

The pixel art is probably the most beautiful pixel art that i have ever seen, espacially the Hub Worlds are so pretty. Same goes for the Character and Enemy desings, really detailed and you can tell that there was put a lot of love and care into designing everything. 

The music is just as great as in the first one, pretty much every song is a banger. Only complaint is that it often sounds a little too soft, i prefer the powerful songs with guitars in it and there was a little less of that in this game then i would have liked but it's still amazing. The music also often captures the feelings of the Characters really well in specific situations. 

Now to the Story. I already loved the story in the first game but they have gone wild with the Story in this one. I loved watching every single Cutcene and Learning about the lore. It's often really dramatic but also has a lot of jokes, sometimes it can also get really dark and i just love it regardless of what is happening right now, it always has my interest. The Hubworlds also have a bunch of NPC's that have a lot to say so yea, you can learn a lot about the world and their Characters and i love everything about it. 

The Game also has so much optional content that you can really spend lots of hours with completing it and every second of that was amazing for me. 

Now to some of the bad stuff, which isn't much. So the only thing about the Story that bothered me is that it kind of ends with a teaser for more of the story and it took 8 years for this game to come out, so i want to know more about the Story and how it will continue but there i will have to wait a lot of years until anything will be continued. I like the ending but i just want more of the story xD 

The other thing that is bothering me (mostly for the first days that the game was out) is the lack if polish. I encountered a lot of bugs and softlocks and i didn't expected so many bugs after the game was being worked on for so long, but they are fixing it faster than i can look so that isn't a problem anymore. 

So yea, the game is just amazing, amazing AND amazing. I want to thank Sabrina DiDuro and everyone at Galaxytrail for making this masterpiece of a game. I'm incredibly thankful for your hard work, thank you. I can't stop gushing about it, buy it, play it and fall in love with it. 

10/10 My Favorite game ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091788274', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1666513501}

author: {'steamid': '76561198076721797', 'num_games_owned': 915, 'num_reviews': 778, 'playtime_forever': 2699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2699, 'last_played': 1666770980}
review:
Imagine a really good game, that you play the hell out of. And then imagine it got a sequel, that's even better. You don't have to imagine it.

No but, like, for real, FP2 is on basically every front, just... better Freedom Planet. The characters feel better to control and are a lot more balanced while also feeling much different from each other - Lilac's still my go-to, and generally the easiest, but even Carol and Milla feel really good in their own ways, and Neera... well, she struggles a little, but, she's not unfun to play either since the game's core movement mechanics are just, really good, and she has her moments. My biggest gripe is... her focus ability is just, useless and actively obtrusive to using her other special moves, and tying it to her guard makes it impossible not to use it... it's not great. Oh speaking of which. The guard in this game is SO GOOD. But the game never tutorializes it! It's practically essential to fighting bosses and even platforming through stages at times, but the very extensive tutorial stages all leave it out for no good reason! Use the guard more. It's worth it.

The stages. There are even more of them than before. Blew my mind when I got to what felt like an endgame sequence only to discover I was only halfway done and there was so much more left. Every stage has its own gimmicks, whether they be platforming mechanics, structure, or remixes of previous elements into something new. And they each have so much personality as a result - I feel stages trend ever so slightly shorter than in the first game (for the most part) but all leave their mark even stronger because of it, and just on the basis of how good movement feels in general, they're almost all fun to play.

The bosses, I feel like one thing the game learned was to throw in more "duel" type bosses than the first game had, since they tend to be the most interesting and challenging, and, yeah, all of those types of bosses rule, but the giant robots are of solid variety and generally exciting to fight as well, though there are a few exceptions - hello, giant clam of tedium - and I feel like the primary reason bosses overall feel better in this game is simply due to combat as a whole feeling better, but like... it's good stuff.

The story is... so, so much better. Merga is an actually compelling villain with complex motives and actual emotional stakes... like, Brevon is cool as a "love to hate" type of villain but... the game has Serpentine for that, if you really want that type of villain, and a whole gang of co-villains backing up Merga for just, all sorts of chaos. Top that off with improved character interactions and better voice acting (Merga's VA in particular just does an incredible job) as well as a story that both does well to flesh out the lore of the world and tell an engaging tale in its own right with an obvious real-world parallel... it's a bit optimistic in its outlook, sure, but I think it works given the style and target demographic of a game like this. Also, no torture scene this time. That's pretty important.

If I do have any criticisms with the story, it's that... Neera's role is questionable. She kinda feels there just to be there. She doesn't drive any portion of the plot, has almost no unique character scenes (besides two alternate scenes with one character where... they ultimately play out the same as other characters' and don't really add a ton). And on the flipside... on the whole, this is clearly Lilac's story, and the others are just along for the ride, which is obvious when you consider who each main characters' foil is - Carol, Milla, and Neera each get co-villain foils while Lilac's is Merga herself, and only she gets some of the most key story scenes that /really/ drive home the emotional stakes. I guess there's nothing that could be done about that, but, it's at least noticeable.

I'm not really a fan of the lives system in this game - it encourages exploration within the levels, I guess, but you're only really gonna do that once, to look for each stages' collectibles, and then after that it's not really worth the effort to gather 250 gems just for an extra stock. The lives in the first game were... meaningless, basically, but I think that was for the better, because lives systems just suck and, considering gems already have their uses outside of gaining lives, it really feels like a mechanic that could've been easily removed without hurting the game in any way. Just, like... limit the # of low-health revivals you're allowed and, boom, lives no longer need to exist.

I also just think the true final stage sucks and... doesn't have any purpose, either, really. The stage is an annoying stealth level, the boss is dramatically less interesting or fun than the normal final boss, and storywise it just serves to throw an extra wrench by way of an uninteresting antagonist character. Plus, the means to unlock it (by doing battlesphere challenges) is... fine, but again feels weirdly mismatched to what that actually unlocks, and, annoyingly, there's no way to view the last four time capsules before beating the game, which kinda makes the scene prefacing the final level come out of nowhere since a good bit of context is missing. I dunno, this entire last arc just feels mishandled.

I do feel the actual difficulty of the time trial times in this game is much easier & achievements on the whole not as hard, but given the amount of extra time it takes just to clear the game (my hasty third and fourth playthroughs both clocked 6.5 hours) I think this was a change for the better, in the end - kept frustration at bay.

Oh, and, presentation-wise, the game looks and sounds gorgeous, but that's like... obvious. Of course it does. It's Freedom Planet.

Obvious I'm not without my nitpicks, but the fact that I played this game for 45 hours and enjoyed the vast majority of them despite going through the story four times speaks to the quality of the game as a whole - there's so much to do, and it's all so good. I barely even touched on the training dojo, the arena battles, the story hubs chock full of NPCs to speak with, the charm and potion systems, the ranking system - which, admittedly, is not super fleshed out or interesting, but whatever, it works.

I guess this is just a really long-winded way of saying trans rights.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018818592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 2110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1555, 'last_played': 1667114609}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is a great speed-platformer with a cheesy yet charming story, world, and cast of characters.

It's a better Sonic game than any Sonic game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024994929', 'num_games_owned': 1191, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1666756299}
review:
It's incredible how much they've improved on for the first game polish, level design, removal of bugs. I had a ton with the first one too.

I don't normally write reviews, but I enjoyed so much of this game and had genuine fun all throughout. It's a Sonic and Treasure game combined and both parts are done extremely well. All the levels make you feel like you're going really fast and doing really cool an unique actions all throughout the levels. The Level variety is incredible so many familiar gimmicks and a lot of new ones as well, and none of them bog down the level. All throughout you're just blazing through the stages even while doing puzzles everything has this seamless and effortless feel to the gameplay. The difficulty is really well done never brutally hard, but in the perfect sweet spot that you'll lose all your lives, but still get a chance to clear the part you're stuck on.

There's four playable characters so lots of replayability as well as time attack and a bunch of side things to do. The music is incredible fits the theming and has a lot of ear worms you'll want to listen to again and again. The only issue I have with the game is the story it's very corny and not serious, but the game play is so incredible and in a way the "Saturday Morning Cartoon" - esque cartoon is a nostalgic trip. 

Buy this game it's worth every penny at full price so much love and care went into the craft of this seamless experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998875622', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1373, 'last_played': 1669829579}
review:
An astounding improvement over the first Freedom Planet, and a 2D platforming triumph. Don't miss this game.

(also it runs great on Steam Deck! The only downside is that there are black bars on the top and bottom of the screen, since it only runs at a 16 x 9 aspect ratio. GalaxyTrail, may we please have support for other aspect ratios? I'd love to play this on my ultrawide and my CRT!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198077298276', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 150, 'playtime_at_review': 2866, 'last_played': 1712285019}
review:
After having a game time of about two day and completed all four characters, I can say it was a ride.
The game may be hard for those who aren't familiar with this format, but at least it has assists for easier game-play.
Other than that, this game is great. The look, the characters, the lore of the previous game and never been heard before, and all the fun with solid move-sets of the characters.

I recommend you to play the first game first if you haven't, otherwise get this game.
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198176420439', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1700420349}
review:
Esse é o melhor jogo de plataforma que já joguei!!!
Quando eu compre do Freedom Planet 1(coisa de mais de 5 anos atras), já tinha noticias que ia ter Freedom Planet 2, acho até que já tinha a demo. E deu pra ver onde foram esses anos de desenvolvimento.
Freedom Planet 2 tem uma caralhada de inimigos, as fases são muito grandes cheio de birfucações mas que você dificilmente vai se perder. O jogo praticamente sempre está de apresentado algo novo, uma nova mecânica.
Foram 8 horas para finalizar só com a personagem principal e ainda falta os outros 3 ou 4 para finalizar.
Eu achei o Freemdom Planet 1 bom, mas essa continuação é praticamente perfeita.
Uma dica pra quem for jogar é não ficar tentando matar todos os inimigos que vê, eu fiz isso no começo Freemdom Planet 1 e atrapalhou minha experiência, derrote só os inimigos necessários ou um ou outro se tiver vontade.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144050464', 'num_games_owned': 1029, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1710970328}

author: {'steamid': '76561199174037039', 'num_games_owned': 13, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1708879524}
review:
Da ich den ersten Teil auch schon mehrmals gespielt hatte und davon ein Let's Play gemacht hatte, musste ich bei diesem Spiel unbedingt zuschlagen, kurz und knapp gibt es von mir noch die pros und cons

pro
Guter Soundtrack
Knopfbelegung frei konfigurierbar
ansprechender Grafikstil
Ausgewogene Schwierigkeitsstufen

contra
leider nur auf englisch (wobei ich darauf hoffe, das in zukünftigen Updates, Sprachen hinzukommen, das war ja beim ersten Teil auch der Fall)

Ich kann jedem nicht nur Freedom Planet 2, sondern auch Freedom Planet, also den ersten Teil uneingeschränkt empfehlen

author: {'steamid': '76561198120975934', 'num_games_owned': 83, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 341, 'playtime_at_review': 4579, 'last_played': 1712311080}
review:
After completing the game 100% all achievements I have to say this game is a true masterpiece of a sequel I loved every single moment, everything from the characters, story and music. 

Merga was a amazing antagonist. I hope the content they have planned for this game explores her more

I can can't recommend this game enough. go and buy it please and maybe we may see a 3rd game in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017925958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 32938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 50, 'playtime_at_review': 9023, 'last_played': 1712311801}
review:
This game is easily my new favorite action platformer. Movement tech and physics in this game are just so much fun to play with. Even if physics seem to be somewhat broken, but honestly it all works so well when you get the hang of it. Wish I didn't have previous experience from the first Freedom Planet game so I could blindly learn to play it all over again.

Soundtrack is awesome. Story is fine. Characters are fun. VA took a step up. Pixel graphics are cool and varied throughout the whole journey. There is a lot that is improved over the first game. Some changes are subjective, but it is nice that FP1 and 2 are pretty different games compared to each other.

Game is being updated with bug fixes, graphics and new quality of life features as well and I hope that trend keeps on going. Thanks for all the effort put into the game.

Waiting for the release was worth it and I'm glad that I got to experience it. Thanks!
