author: {'steamid': '76561198347544601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1705882584}
review:
This game kicks ass, not just as a sequel to the already amazing Freedom Planet, but as a game in general.
It's a massive improvement to the first game.

The controls feel slightly better the first game. Not only that but you have a guard button now. And it fits extremely well with the game. At times, it feels like a fighting game but suited well with platforming, as the guard button do another action, like air dashing for the cool purple dragon. It also makes the boss fights feel even more epic and badass, cuz you can kick their ass hard if you learn the guard.

Levels are also amazing. More has been done to separate one level from another. Each has even more distinct features and gimmicks to toy around with. Levels are also paced much better. Each level is shorter than the first game but it's a good thing here as there are more levels.

The boss fights were fantastic in the first game and they are just as fantastic here. The added guard button and improved controls make the boss fights a spectacle to behold. The game also feels more fair to newcomers with certain mechanics that can caters to your play style. 

Music is just as good as the first game. Top notch. Feels the mood perfectly. Certain songs carry leitmotifs from the first game. Can listen to it anytime!

The graphics are awesome as hell. Sprites moves beautifully and graceful. The background are some of the best scenery porn I have seen. Characters are really expressive too.

The story is the biggest improvement over the first game. The story feels more complex. Some characters develop over the course of the game. Character interactions and story moments can be fun, goofy or serious when needed. The world building is also surprisingly great.

There are hub worlds in this game. It makes the game's world feel alive. NPC's are great as well. They are harmless at worst and lively at best. They fit well.

I really loved my first playthrough and I can't wait to play even more.

November 2022 edit: This game also kick ass on the Steam Deck! Best action you can play on the toilet!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053061565', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1663318795}
review:
This is a quick, dirty and early review because while I'm still working on finishing my Lilac playthrough, I've been enjoying the game a lot! It feels like a truly worthy successor to the first game and additionally follows up on plot points from it, letting it flow seamlessly into the new storyline. It's also just written and voice acted far better, making the story easier to get invested in with less distractions like Carol's bathroom mic from the first game.

However, here's mainly why I'm writing this - I do recommend maybe holding off for a little bit because the game has been getting a LOT of patches lately, some of which are pretty major fixes like controller issues, save file corruption and music loop points. Playing the game at launch for me felt pretty good for the most part and I didn't have any real problems aside from weird controller binding problems (which were fixed!)

I'll update my review later on when I finish playing the game as all four characters.

(I got this as a gift from a friend!)

review: Took everything that was awesome about the first and amplified it by a lot while also further establishing it's own identity. Pixel art is absolutely awesome and the developers nailed the old school Sega Saturn aesthetic perfectly by using stippling and other dirty (in a good way) tricks common of that era and the game looks absolutely gorgeous on anything that can properly fake an analog display common of that time. Gameplay is every bit as good as this looks thanks to fun boss fights, massive and well laid out levels, and characters with very distinct playstyles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010268995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1072, 'last_played': 1698495380}
review:
[h1]Spoiler free review[/h1]

[h2]Overall quality of the Game[/h2]

Very Satisfactory this game is absolutely worth your time!

[h2]Technical Quality of the Game[/h2]

Very Satisfied, it runs well even with Proton emulation under an obscure Linux Distribution.
There have been FPS issues in the first Freedom Planet during certain scenes like when the bosses exploded or during certain boss fights, i am happy to Report that there are no noticeable FPS issues this time!

My hardware:

CPU: four core, Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-4670
Graphicscard: GeForce GTX 1060 6GB
RAM: 16 GB DDR3
OS: Arch linux (proton was used to run the game)

[h2]Music and Graphics[/h2]

Same or even better then FP1, the Music is very nicely done and reminds me of games like jazz jackrabbit.

[h2]Gameplay and Difficulty[/h2]

You can choose between four different characters, each of them has different abilities and play styles.

I also like to mention the way difficulty is managed in this game, because the player has a lot of options to tailor their gaming experience. You can either be the super hardcore player by actively sabotaging your health and lives with certain items to create an especially hard challenge for yourself, or you can also craft or buy certain items to make it easier on yourself. There is also a timer for each level and high scores which makes the game interesting for completionists and speed runners.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071608650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 155, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1712079320}
review:
I really enjoy this game.  It is a very good sequel to the first game and much bigger.  I've now played with everyone expect Lilac (Saving her for last), but I very much enjoyed everything I've played so far.
I love the references to Gunstar placed here and there, as well as just how beautiful this game is.  Characters are great as well, and the music.  Absolutely love it.
If there is one flaw I do have with the game it's lava level.  I think there needs to be a better showing of the cool spots you can stay in to drop the temperature gauge down, as it took me my next play through with Neera to figure it out.

Other than that.  This game is such a blast to play, and I look forward to playing all of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143145171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 9458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6342, 'last_played': 1694312557}
review:
The tagline surrounding FP2 is "There has never been a game like Freedom Planet 2." And that's true, though not for lack of trying! I get the impression a lot of Saturn and PS1 games were trying to have this kinda of impact, to be this sense of scale, but lacked the technology. Even the original FP1 lacks the experience that pulled off as complete a package as this game manages.

If you have a nostalgia or even a retro-fascination for the cool-factor stylings of Gunstar Heroes or Astal or even something more world-building focused like Klonoa or Symphony of the Night, Freedom Planet 2 puts the vibes of the era together in ways I've never seen before: Fun, fast-paced gameplay with extremely interesting gimmicks and environments, all wrapped up in a fun story that actually manages to feel poignant and inspiring in a way so few games manage.

Bosses take a bit of time to learn and 2 doesn't pull its punches - especially where the achievements are concerned - but that only helps take me back to an era that games seem to think they evolved out of, when really they just shifted away from something fun to something else equally fun. Beautiful ost and passionate creatives behind every pixelated corner, I wholeheartedly recommend anyone who's been wondering where all the good 5th Generation nostalgia games have been give FP2 a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088777022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1664585279}
review:
The game's not horrible.  Play Lilac since she avoids most combat and doubles up on Iframes.   Combat's a mess as anyone would expect from a speed-based melee game without any mitigation or lock-on.  You'll win every fight though, since you have a near-nill cooldown iframe button (and again, Lilac can stack frames). 

The story's pretty awful, in the sense that it once again starts "fun" then tries to get weighty but at least no one's being tortured this time around. 

...Dammit, I got caught up in the hype when I made the purchase.  Really should have seen this coming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041344526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1813, 'last_played': 1676802955}
review:
Freedom Planet 1 has a lot of bugs, but you have to look to find most of them. In Freedom Planet 2, it's very hard to play the game without running into soft-locks, buggy collision, and other oddities that make the game feel somewhere between unpolished and lazy. A buggy mess in its current state, but hopefully with time this issue will be remedied.

Do not buy this game if your device cannot run it at a stable 60FPS. Because this game does not use a fixed high-precision physics timestep, if your game lags... you can clip through walls, teleporters, slopes, enemies, projectiles, you-name-it. And it's not just you that can clip through things, so can vital stage gimmicks like large falling objects that break blocks to reveal the way forwards, which causes a soft-lock. There are sections of the game where you have to kill all the enemies in an arena to progress, however if any of them clip out-of-bounds then you will be stuck and have to restart from the beginning.

There are several stages that have outright enemy spam. Some stages go on for far too long (Ancestral Forge, I'm looking at you), or just feel unpolished. A lot of the stages have incredibly stretched or squashed tiles all over the place; and very bland or repetitive tiling. The stages in FP1 always had a lot of variation, and were split into distinct segments which usually had slightly varying themes to keep the levels feeling fresh, and I feel that Freedom Planet 2 did not manage to do the same. A lot of stages are so samey that I can't even tell where I am up to even though I've played the stage. On a related note, since the camera can zoom out in this game the stages seem to have been designed to be [i]much[/i] bigger in visual scale, but they tend to just feel like they've got lots of vacant areas with not much going on instead.

The game uses a "better" version of the life system, but ultimately just feels punishing compared to Freedom Planet 1, where lives didn't matter (except at the end of Fortune Night). This system can be turned off, but I wish I could just rack up lives like in Freedom Planet 1 or Super Mario Bros. 3 (with a cap, of course) and then use them to revive when I need to.

Seemingly in order to compensate for not designing the game's enemies and projectiles to be reasonably avoidable, there's a new "guard" system which is very similar to Sonic 3's instashield, except that you can use it on the ground. However, the mechanic doesn't serve its function very well. There seems to be a delay when guarding, and you can't guard after just being hit. Additionally, guarding doesn't last long enough for you to make it out of harm's way the majority of the time and it doesn't neutralise or destroy projectiles you've guarded from, which leads large projectiles to just hit you anyway because you can't move normally while guarding.

Freedom Planet 1 didn't have an overly deep story, but personally I found it serviceable enough. For the sequel, the world of Avalice obviously needed to be expanded a lot, and there's a lot of interesting political themes in this game. However, I feel that ultimately the main conflict of the game is quite contrived. The game attempts to humanise its main villain by [spoiler]giving them a cute gay romance backstory, but the character also refers to themself as the embodiment of violence which makes it pretty hard to empathise with them[/spoiler].

Lastly, I'd like to mention this game's absolute strongest point: Freedom Planet 2 has some seriously kick-ass artwork. Some of its stages are outright gorgeous, and the poor stage composition shouldn't take away from the fact that the game's artwork is very visually appealing and varied. Some of the backgrounds struggle to stand-out a little, but I feel that that is not a huge issue.

...

Oh yeah I forgot, this game has music! Uhh... some of it is just lame (most of the boss music), most of it is pretty forgettable (I forgot), and some of it is really kickass (Shade Armoury & [spoiler]Bakunawa's map music[/spoiler]).

author: {'steamid': '76561198040347197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 888, 'last_played': 1665865468}
review:
To be clear, I'm a huge fan of the first game. I called it "doing Sonic better than Sonic does Sonic". It was an outstanding game and this is a disappointing sequel.

I'll start with the good stuff, graphics and game play. It feels really good to play, really snappy and fluid. And the pixel art is extremely detailed and looks like a huge amount of time, effort and love went into it. I'm particularly a fan of the sprite of one of the bosses which is a huge rabbit mech, which is just really impressive. In general the bosses are a highlight of this game.

I want to say however that the game play suffers because of the actual level design. It's extremely unintuitive and confusing. There's too many puzzles. In the majority of levels I would be zooming around before realising either i'm going in circles somehow, or there's a sealed door or something else that just stops me dead. And I have no idea where i'm going or what to do. Honestly in this kind of game, that is a running, action spectacle, there shouldn't ever be a single moment where I'm trying to figure out what i'm supposed to be doing. To put things in perspective, Sonic levels average 3-6 minutes each. Want to know the longest time I spent in a level here? 63'25''13. Yes, over an hour. For just one of the 24 levels. This was due to it being an extremely unintuitive and complex puzzle heavy level. It was open in design and featured underwater sections and water level changing mechanics. Yes, 2D water temple mechanics. It should be obvious but it never, ever is. The levels are overly long, averaging over ten minutes, without being broken into two acts.

Next, the music is bad. Pretty much every track from the first game was a banger. The music here is generic and doesn't fit the energetic nature of the game or the tone of some of the things in it. I can imagine in my head several of the bangers in the first game like i'm listening to them right now. I don't remember a single track from this sequel. With the exception of one or two remixes taken from the first game. So you know, another composers work. Garbage.

The story even in the first game was divisive. But most wanted the option to skip it, which they added. it was called classic mode and just threw you into action packed level after level, with only the context of what happens in the stages. Bizarrely, this was completely removed in this sequel, which forces many many cut scenes on you and throws you into completely pointless hub worlds filled with NPC's. I watched the cut scenes during the first half of the game and it drifted between feeling aimless, boring or making pretty poor attempts at humour. Writing humour is difficult and so many things intended to be funny came off as irritating or cringe. Specifically there's a few whole characters who are intentionally obnoxious and annoying. They aren't minor characters either, they appear many many many times as bosses and in cut scenes with their catchphrases and shrieking laughter. I also don't want to sit down in a Sonic game with NPCs and study the games lore in a library (actual moment in the game). I get it, you made your expansive rich lore, but I don't care, I just want to play the game and I don't think many people do care about the war between the ancient war between the dragons and the snake mechanoids or whatever.

I encouraged Freedom Planet 1 to branch out from its inspirations, because i truly believed it was better than them. Turns out a lot of people said that to them because they really did. They expanded the scope of absolutely everything. Everything is bigger, richer, more populated, more believable, more beautiful... More bloated. It lost it's way somewhere. I am imagining the devs of this game like a Game Master from DnD or another tabletop. Just writing and filling this game with so many ideas, passion and love. Some things work, most things don't, and there's a lot of it. And somewhere in the process the fundamentals of this kind of action game were lost.

What would i suggest is this. Bring down the scope. It doesn't need to be bigger to be better. Shorter levels, or at least split it up into acts again. Every level should be linear. Splitting paths are fine, dead ends and a million puzzles aren't. If you must dedicate huge resources to your lore, characters, hub worlds, cut scenes, voice acting, make it optional. Or just don't and tell the story through game play, like your genesis inspirations manage. Less is more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118935059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1666507939}

author: {'steamid': '76561198162707855', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1229, 'last_played': 1708959792}
review: As a huge fan of the first game, I've been eagerly awaiting Freedom Planet 2 ever since it was announced 6 years ago, now that ive finally finished it. It's everything i could have ever wanted. If i had any genuine complaints is sometimes im not a fan of the character writing, but that's just me. If you love fast paced action platformers with a good amount of difficulty, robust character movesets, and an emphasis in tough boss fights, please play this game, and show everyone at GalaxyTrail some love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962875429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1703998793}
review:
I feel a little bad for this, because the friend who recommended this game to me might see it -- but I kind of hate this game.

One problem is that it's way too complicated.  For my money, at least, a Sonic game should be simple: you jump through enemies to kill them, you avoid obstacles, and you run to the right.  This game has four characters, with combos, direction-sensitive inputs, special moves, a dodge mechanic, and gear: it's half-way to being a medroidvania.  I'm fine with metroidvanias, but I don't think the combination works.

This game also commits some of the cardinal sins of boss battles -- again, at least for my money.  Some boss battles have multiple phases; if you die, you have to start over from the first phase; and some of them have long cutscenes with dialog before the fight, and that's where you pick up every time.  At least they're skippable, thank god.

I also kind of hate some of the characters -- they're pretty much just stock characters, and they're not particularly likable or interesting takes on those tired archetypes.  And the writing is pretty insipid.  And I get it, it's a videogame, not the theatre, but still.  I think they're trying to be genre-aware and "meta," and I kind of think how absolutely conventional and cliched they're being is supposed to be part of the joke, but I don't think it comes off.  (Call me a pretentious prick if you want.)

I particularly loathe Carol the Wildcat.  She very much reminds me of the kind of friend who's still breaking plates and pouring syrup on the table even though he's 25 now, not 5, and it's not being a "free spirit" or "wacky" anymore, now it's just being an impulsive, selfish asshole.  I kind of like Neera Li, because her reaction to the rest of the cast is like my reaction to the rest of the cast: she finds them frustrating and wants to shoot them.

Maybe kind of inevitable, but kind of like any game where you've got different characters with multiple moves and special mechanics, I feel like the character balance might not be great.  In particular, I think Neera really suffers because she can't move during her Sniper Drive.  There are couple of bosses that move around a lot, that Carol seems to be able to just kind of cling to their face and slash, but Neera really struggles to keep up with and hit.  Although it's entirely possible that I'm just missing something, or that I suck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047456549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1861, 'last_played': 1664669763}

author: {'steamid': '76561198150933645', 'num_games_owned': 280, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1669173577}
review:
Во всём превосходит оригинал.

Великолепная музыка, множество красочных оригинальных уровней с повышенной динамикой в левел-дизайне.
Сюжет больше не строит из себя напыщенную драму, он проще, катсцены не длятся по пол часа.
А дизайн персонажей от Tyson Tan приятен глазу, тут даже над НИПами в хабах постарались.
Кристаллики наконец-то имеют смысл.

Из минусов разве что:
- Разделение игровых персонажей по сохранениям, с внедрением карты уровней можно было дать возможность выбирать каждую героиню по мере сюжета.
- Попытались раскрыть лор, круто, но почему не до конца.
- Обучение в сюжетке за Лайлак может сильно затруднить прохождение, так как не рассказывает об Boost Breaker, а боссы на него сильно опираются.
- Есть всё же парочка идиотских уровней, к примеру Nalao Lake.

Очень рекомендую и оригинал и вторую часть для любителей скоростных платформеров, бросающих вызов игроку, хотя в игре есть опции и для казуалов.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059183339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1667356665}
review:
Based on early impressions: 

Lovable heroines: Check
Bangin' soundtrack: Check
Tight controls and fast paced platforming: Check 
Brutal boss encounters that will keep you on your toes: Check
Cheesy dialogue: Check 

It's a Freedom Planet game. 

The core mechanics of the original are improved and expanded upon and the heroines have been re-balanced giving Milla and Carol the same satisfying feeling to play as Lilac (who in the first was arguably the best kitted character by a long-shot) while retaining the unique play-style between all 4 playable characters. Neera's kit, unfortunately, I feel plays a little too stiffly for the high-speed action. 

For the platformer expert the boss encounters, so far, have been easier than in Freedom Planet 1 but it's definitely balanced out by the fact that the difference between a death and a game over is no longer mere formality. On expert mode a game over will leave you with the choice of either restarting the stage from the beginning or buying your way back to your most recent checkpoint with a not unsubstantial sum of your hard-earned crystals. 

There are items that can be obtained that can offer nominal improvements to your characters (or even add additional challenge in exchange for a higher bonus at the end of the level) but for the purist it is far from a mandatory part of the game and empty item slots give you a nominal increase to your end of level bonus so the item system is definitely balanced with the purists (who would probably rather ignore the item system) in mind- even to the point that two key bonus challenge items are automatically equipped at the start of an expert play-through. 

My two biggest complaints would be that Neera just doesn't feel anywhere near as satisfying to play as one of the original trio and on some of the longer boss fights the boss music will stop dead for a couple of seconds before restarting instead of looping smoothly. 

I will update the review later if the experience falls off, otherwise just assume that the entire game is rated:
[b][i]Dragon Valley theme stuck in my head for 48 hours straight[/i][/b] out of 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198177319065', 'num_games_owned': 127, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 236, 'playtime_at_review': 1362, 'last_played': 1711763695}
review:
7 years in development, and just as excited to play the game as I was back then. Man... I was 13 when this game was initially announced... But I digress.

I can EASILY say that this game is an improvement across the board. Fun as hell levels, amazing gameplay styles, you get to interact with the world, which in turn let's you know more about it, and the story is a massive improvement over the first (That being said, the ending felt a little underwhelming).

If this game is on sale, buy it. I'd the game ISN'T on sale, buy it anyway. Then play it until you're sick of it. (Take breaks though, the campaign is pretty long for a high speed platformer, and the constant adrenaline can get you exhausted). I would recommend this game to everyone. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198148725040', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 3550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3055, 'last_played': 1686616914}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is an Action Platformer game that wanted to be more than the predecessor and for me it did.

Starting in Graphics, They look vivid and with better quality, some of the scenary shows more details comparing to the original. The Characters designs shows improvements and now they look grown up, after 3 years they should and the world has change a lot during that time too.

Story, oh boy, one of the weak parts of the original game due to pacing going light and dark too much and it was too long, well here I see a better pacing where the beginning is more light hearted until the main villain arrives where the story goes serious, I know about the comic relief moments but for me it is fine to just stop for a bit and shows that the characters even if they are focus, they still can have a laugh at times.

Music, For me both games have great soundtracks, I prefer to enjoy both and that is. each game have bangers so it is up your taste.

Finally Level Design, Some say maps are long and well it feels like that in some ocasions but when you learn them, the don´t fell like that, I know Ancestral Forge and Clockwork Arboretum are the longest ones but after my second run, I already know what to do so I was going fast as possible on them.

Freedom Planet 2 does what a sequel needs to do, improve from the original while adding new stuffs, I know the game was buggy after lunch(as every game) but in the end I got fun and enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975755126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1583, 'last_played': 1664558500}
review:
An improvement of the earlier title in most cases. The voice acting/sound engineering is still not exactly the best, but it has been recorded on better gear than... webcam mikes or whatever they used last time.

If anything, the divergent combat model between the playable characters sometimes offers a fair deal of frustration as some are just plain better built than others with more access to I-frames and safe attacks.

Still recommended, especially as an Indie title for a genre that we don't see that often. Support it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198090473094', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 691, 'last_played': 1678862307}

author: {'steamid': '76561198132051372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1693727462}
review:
The fact that this game is released and I finally have a chance to play it is honestly almost surreal. I was in the middle of high school when the first trailer dropped out of nowhere, and here I am now, graduated and finally getting a chance to play the sequel to one of my favorite games.

And in almost every way, it absolutely lives up to those expectations. First off, the game is BEAUTIFUL. The sprite-work was already fantastic in the first game, but Galaxytrail went above and beyond to make sure every inch of this game is dripping in color and detailed animation. It's absolute eyecandy and I can't get enough.

The gameplay is just as fast and as thrilling as before, with huge, incredibly complex stages full of unique enemies, unique set pieces, and plenty of personality that make each of them super memorable. There were a couple stages where I ended up getting lost and spending a few minutes backtracking to try to figure out what my objective was, but those moments are rare and I'm sure those stages will become less confusing on multiple playthroughs. And while the boss fights in the first Freedom Planet are hard to top, I'd say that a few bosses in this game end up doing just that, with fast-paced, frantic fights that are extremely thrilling and challenging.

The story is overall very good. Things feel quite a lot cheerier and goofier than certain moments in the first game, and while I personally missed those darker moments, I still appreciated the charming, fun-loving writing with a lot of strong humor. The heroes are all just as likable and as memorable as before, with a few of them getting some serious glow-ups. I always thought that Milla and Neera were both written just fine in the previous game, but this sequel's interpretation of them make them so much more interesting and enjoyable. And while I don't think that Merga, this game's primary antagonist, quite lives up to the awesomely evil Lord Brevon from the previous game, she still has enough impact on the story as well as enough of a cool factor to make her a strong, memorable villain.

The only strict downgrade I'd have to mention is the soundtrack. The previous game's soundtrack is honestly one of my favorite game soundtracks of all time. It was packed to the brim with banger after banger, and it made the stages and the boss fights so much more exciting. And while this game's soundtrack certainly isn't bad, I also can't say it quite lives up. There were a few moments I was wondering why I wasn't feeling as pumped up as similar moments from the last game, and everytime I realized that it was because the music wasn't quite doing for me. Don't get me wrong, the music is still excellent and there are absolutely a few standout tracks, I just can't say it's all a homerun like the first game's.

I can't recommend this game enough. The negatives I experienced are nothing more than minor bugs and nitpicks, and the experience was WAY more than worth the 25 buck pricetag. GalaxyTrail deserves your money. Kindly fork it over and play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198288189392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1686822790}
review:
It has been a long, long time since I last came across a game that is so satisfying in so many different aspects.

Exciting action. Interesting stage gimmicks. Challenging boss fights.

Fluid story. Great tension. Realistic and affectionate acting.

Comprehensive worldview. Fine-detailed maps. Interesting citizens.

Matured game mechanics. Customizable abilities. Fun side-quests.

The official website states that Freedom Planet 2 aims to "define Freedom Planet's identity as a franchise". They did it. I want to see Spade get his own game some day (don't mind if I have to wait until 2030). I want to know how General Gong and Neera went from ordinary citizens to leaders of the army. I want to learn more about other planets out there.

Great job, GalaxyTrail. I love it!

(Small note: As a Chinese, I have mixed feelings to see so many Oriental elements built into the game by Western designers. I appreciate all the research put into them. I can feel the passion and hard work. The result is erm... adorably awkward.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198255000347', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1664189403}
review:
At the very least for context, I love Freedom Planet 1, game was fun as hell, still boot it up every now and then to this day and it's loosely a part of a more emotional area of my life.
So you can imagine my excitement and hype for Freedom Planet 2.

Yet holy fuck, the game just gives me a headache playing it.

Levels go on for way too long
Enemies are everywhere and completely kill any sense of momentum unless it's a designated sequence
Why do the bossfights suck now, what happened to Robo Panther or the Syntax Train, everything is just an arena brawl against unfair opponents
The purpose of a barely functional guard button in a high speed platformer, not sure why that's there
Forgettable music

Still at least enjoy the characters, the pixel art style and the actual controls aside from the guard feel great

but this feels like a massive downgrade, might give it some time but I can't see myself going back to finish off Carol, Milla or Neera Li's story. Game just isn't fun

author: {'steamid': '76561198080033152', 'num_games_owned': 594, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1706992225}
review:
A bit different from the first game, with a greater focus on combat and action. Each character has an expanded move set compared to the first and theres a dodge button that has you do a spin in place to become invincible for a time. It can be a bit tricky to get a hang of but it feels great when things are working. 

The soundtrack is great, the character designs are great, the game is fun. There is a demo, so like just try it out and you'll know if it is your thing or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980464130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 1731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1583, 'last_played': 1670790015}
review:
idk where to begin! There's so much game to play.
Captures the feeling of a Treasure-sort of side scrolling action game where it's a very high speed, fun, often demanding challenge with a lot of over the top comic book personality! 
Very easy to recommend, especially now that they have more items and powerups to make some of the later, very demanding bosses more manageable! 

The game's continued to receive updates to polish the quality up further! Easy recommend for platformer fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970270716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1167, 'last_played': 1666374972}
review:
Another good game in the FP series. The seven-year wait was *mostly* worth it, because the game is higher-quality than the first in multiple ways. The script-writing is vastly improved, and there's a ton of content and inventive environmental mechanics, at least for a so-called "Sonic clone." Tyson Tan's character designs breathe some new life into it visually, too.

The levels are all more or less designed to be accessible for each of the characters, so there's no more character-specific level alterations or weird side-stages that would make some of the playable characters feel like they’re an afterthought. However, this unified level design also means that some of the visceral speed and action present in the first game was lost in translation, which starts to lower the all-important drama-factor that made the first FP so memorable. Actually, the dramatization is lower in the cut scenes, too (torture scene from the first game, anyone? Dail's father being beheaded in the first two minutes?). The main villain is also, I would say, a lot less threatening than Brevon for a whole host of reasons I won't spoil—despite the stakes still theoretically being high.

I was also sometimes confused as to what on earth I was fighting in a given stage. It's obvious that not everything is some Brevon-aligned remnant rampaging mindlessly around, but if it isn't that... then what is it? Why do some of these early stages have enemies at all? All it would take is a quick, simple explanation as to why we have to fight things in order to trigger a sense of urgency in the player (Shenlin Park and Phoenix Highway come to mind).

Emotional gravity and plot aside, all of the levels now have more of a "puzzle-platformer" feel to them, as do some of the bosses. Point-dodging with an actual button is a thing in this game (unlike the first one), but it's obviously not something you can mash fast enough to dodge every attack on the harder fights. Neera and Carol really only have dodging as an option to defend themselves consistently; Lilac's invincibility frames with the dragon-boost make it just a tad OP since it also allows you to deal damage and go flying in a direction on top of the invincibility. Milla's shield is really good for protection if you get better at reflexively using it, and several bosses can have projectiles reflected to deal damage against them (also OP). Carol can technically use her wheel-toss jump to go invincible for a couple of frames, but just try doing that consistently and not getting hit by something anyway—half the time, you’re better off throwing it for some ranged damage and not jumping to its location at all.

Sometimes, certain characters struggle on specific boss fights because their character-specific mechanics just can't keep up as well as others’ do. People might find Neera to be a challenge in particular—no shield like Milla, and no ultra-fast close-range attacks like Lilac and Carol. Neera can use her focus-state to start hitting faster, but it drains her special meter, disallowing use of "frost arts." It's unfortunately also bound to the same button as "dodge," meaning you'll accidentally trigger the focus state while just trying to survive instead of using it for burst windows. As of this writing, I'm apparently part of only 3% of players that've beaten the game as Neera (which I did without items/potions all the way through), and I'm interested to see how much that percentage increases over time. 

Overall, the playability of the whole roster is much better than the first game, but there are still some snags and balance issues. Actually, I liked having a more challenging character to play, but some other people may not. If in doubt, just play Lilac (speed and beatdown), or secondarily, Milla (ranged attacks, shield, jumping really high).

One of the cooler features is the item system. Items modify how you run levels—they can either be used to make the levels easier in various ways, or they can be used to make the levels harder in order to get achievements and amped-up currency rewards. Since this game series (much like Sonic) is one that people enjoy replaying to keep refining their personal bests and exploring levels, the addition of optional modifiers to your runs is a really good inclusion to stretch the content even further.

The soundtrack is also good, once again. I'd say it's ranked just slightly lower than the first, but there are some really good tracks here. In particular, listen to: Shenlin Park, Globe Opera 1, Adventure Square, Ancestral Forge, Magma Starscape and Bakunawa Rush.

FP2 doesn’t quite reach the visceral and explosive heights of the first one, but it’s still a really good game with attractive retro-graphics, lots of unique levels and enjoyable combat. Just watch out for that final fight if you're playing it on hard with Neera...

Overall score: 4/5

**Many thanks to Sabrina DiDuro and the rest of the team for delivering this game to us!

author: {'steamid': '76561198356418822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 10, 'playtime_at_review': 5399, 'last_played': 1712281707}

author: {'steamid': '76561198050391500', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1848, 'last_played': 1707592178}
review:
If this game just looks like "some sonic clone platformer game thing", you'll be surprised to discover that Freedom Planet 2 is so much more.

I've yet to see another platformer that features combat as satisfying as this. Dancing around your enemies as you destroy them with the unique abilities of the game's 4 playable characters only gets better as you become more proficient with the game. 
That, plus the various movement options making traversing through the levels feel incredibly smooth, give the game that sense of player expression through gameplay by allowing you to approach different obstacles in whatever way you'd find more satisfying.

I can't emphasize the word "satisfying" enough, it really is the best way to describe the gameplay.
Seriously, give this game a shot. It's worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017675839', 'num_games_owned': 3596, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 1657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 9, 'playtime_at_review': 1494, 'last_played': 1711627426}
review:
A globally strong improvement over the previous entry, which already was a great game in itself.

- Gameplay/mechanics: more polished and varied
- Graphics: substantially better pixel art and VFX
- Music: as mind-blowingly good as the previous one
- Content: more and better, also with great replayability
- Dialogues/VA: so cringe they're actually hilarious

Recommended to anyone that enjoyed the first game and also to newcomers looking for a good sonic clone

Edit: nominated to the steam awards <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197975567669', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1706916042}
review:
Like its predecessor, it's hard not to be awestruck by the sheer passion and ambition of Freedom Planet 2, which introduces a bevy of smart, thoughtful additions and improvements to the core combat and platforming across a healthy variety of stages and situations.  That said, much of the first game's signature consistency, intensity, and precision feels somewhat lost in the exchange, with levels and bosses sometimes falling flat, and the otherwise superb pixel artwork appearing somewhat mangled by the dynamic camera.

There's also the questionable decision to lock the story-free Classic mode away, but thankfully the writing, voice work, tone, and overall pacing have been significantly improved from the original (and you can still skip any and all cutscenes if you prefer).  More problematic is the non-linear progression of levels, which results in a scattershot difficulty curve that squanders one of the core strengths of Freedom Planet.  Conversely, improvements to Carol and Milla's movesets, as well as the addition of newcomer Nerra, ensure each campaign is as much a delight to traverse as Lilac's. 

Despite a lukewarm opening act, Freedom Planet 2 at last provides a definitively superior experience over the first game, although which one you'll prefer likely comes down to what drew you to the series in the first place.  If it was the Sonic-like traversal and platforming, as well as the callous difficulty curve, then you'll probably gravitate back to the original.  If it was the Gunstar Heroes-esque combat, stage variety, and cathartic boss fights, then the sequel achieves the fullest aspirations of that gameplay loop.  

Whatever the case, Freedom Planet 2 is an absolutely superb, polished, unique, elbows-out platformer that shouldn't be missed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157555271', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2010, 'last_played': 1703137788}
review:
words simply cannot describe how incredible this game is.

freedom planet was already an amazing game for putting its own spin on the sonic formula, but this is simply next level! the gameplay is just like the first game but with much more freedom (no pun intended) of movement, like with lilac's boost breaker and carol's aerial hatchet kick, the art is beautiful and does not ever disappoint (with the exception of a handful of unfinished sprites, most notably spade's idle), the music, while not as memorable as the one from the first game in my opinion, still holds up really well... it's as close as you can get to a perfect sonic/megaman zero hybrid game

there are a few bugs here and there but they're nowhere near as game breaking as some of the negative reviews here make them out to be, the only one that actually had me restart to a checkpoint was when i clipped underneath airship sigwada and couldn't leave lol (plus some of them are pretty funny, like a missing ceiling under a platform in shenlin park, which unfortunately got patched in 1.1.0)

would recommend this to anyone that enjoys the likes of megaman zero, sonic or even platform fighters

author: {'steamid': '76561198060619197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1405, 'last_played': 1702448265}
review:
3년 전에 이 게임 전작을 처음 알고 나름 재밌게 해서 이번 작품도 기대하고 있었는데
기다린 보람이 있을 정도로 기대 이상이었습니다.

다만, 아직 버그나 자잘한 렉 같은게 있지만 향후 패치로 해결이 될 거라 믿네요.

라일락과 캐롤, 밀라로는 엔딩까지 봤고 신캐인 니라로도 달려봐야겠습니다.

지금은 영어로만 플레이 가능한데 나중엔 전작처럼 언어 설정 생겨서 한국어와 일본어도 지원해줬으면..

author: {'steamid': '76561197978459575', 'num_games_owned': 672, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1664408762}
review:
It's a trite comment at this point, but this is another case for "Steam should have a mixed recommendation option instead of just 'yes' and 'no'."

First of all, it's impossible not to be impressed by the amount of real content in this game. The game could feasibly take someone 10 hours to finish on a first playthrough and I expect most will be over 8 hours at least. For an indie 2D platformer with a breakneck pace that's a lot of level. The level design is more ambitious than the first game with long, complex, multi-route levels. There are many gimmicks and almost all levels have a good sense of individual identity both visually and in terms of gameplay.

This scope is impressive but it's clear that the developers had ambitions beyond reason, leading to both a lengthy development period and a really hit-and-miss quality to the levels and boss fights. Some levels, like the Ancestral Forge and Nalao Lake, are really bad, but there are also some great stages— Lightning Tower is my favourite, mixing in some very light puzzle elements with hazards that are activated as you turn on power, and generally a more calculated level design with a good sense of progress as you climb.

Sadly, most of the levels are at least a little chaotic, as there are enemies and stage hazards that seem unavoidable given the speed of the game. In one stage, there is a crushing block hazard that drops so fast that you actually can't avoid it if you're stood still, which you may be if you boosted forward and bopped off the wall where it comes down. Enemies are almost entirely not worth dealing with, as many of them have untelegraphed attacks and a tonne of HP, but you will still take plenty of damage from enemies that attack as you run past. The added guard mechanic seems useless but thankfully wasn't required for Lilac, whose dash has about a billion i-frames and does good damage.

In general, the difference between FP1 and 2 is that the former feels more restrained, with level design that guides you forward, whereas FP2 regularly makes it difficult to tell which way you're meant to be going. And unlike FP1, the core gameplay isn't quite as engaging, since besides some good platforming and gimmicks you're mostly just ignoring the enemies and taking random hits. It lacks that sense of connection. Doesn't help that when you do attack an enemy, there is no feeling of impact (unlike the player character who gets stunned by hits). The effect of this is that the game is quite exhausting to play at times and it took me a while to finish.

And those bad boss fights... man. The fights against really large bosses are usually fine, mid-sized bosses are mixed and the player-character-sized bosses are almost all complete dogshit. Why? Well, smaller foes are typically either off-screen, or close enough to instantly cause harm to you. Also, many of their attacks turn their bodies into instant hurtboxes, and often aren't well telegraphed. Some are less bad than others, but the absolute worst is [spoiler]Askal[/spoiler], who does half-screen jumps into ground-slams, and spends half his time surrounded by little projectiles. Also a dashing punch that comes from offscreen that you have to anticipate every time he stops slamming, because there is no other cue.

The writing for the first game was much maligned and if anything this sequel doubles down, but I can't bring myself to hate it. I love that the furry freaks behind these games put their all into making their fantasy about anthropomorphic cats & dogs, colonialism and historical revisionism come to life... sincerely, it's kind of wholesome. In terms of quality it's like some kid's TV show. Whatever. The lowest point is probably Captain Kalaw. He seems as if the writer played the Ratchet and Clank remake and though Captain Klark was sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo frickin funny. To be fair, that only jumps out to me because the writing is otherwise much less bad than that game. I also saw a reviewer compare it to YIIK which seems like a wildly unfair assessment. This is fine for small kids but also tedious to sit through for us because we are adults and we like to consume dense things rather than liquid slurry.

I know that this review comes across as negative, and that's largely because I can't help but compare it negatively to the previous game. It's really not all that bad though, just hit-and-miss. Some levels are fun and suffer less from the general design issues. There were points where I'd sit down to play the game, go through two 8-minute levels and be completely checked out afterwards. Other times I'd get hooked on a really good level or set of levels and find myself playing for a good while.

For a quick summary, if FP1 is an 8.5/10 than FP2 is like... a 6.5 or 7.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025177776', 'num_games_owned': 672, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 27, 'playtime_at_review': 1356, 'last_played': 1712416425}

author: {'steamid': '76561198083165006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 3861, 'last_played': 1712396740}
review:
我自己知道1代的時候大概是2016年，由看到2代消息大概也等了最少4~5年以上時間，也曾經想過會否因為疫情而沒緣面世，所以2代真的發售的當天，什麼都沒想 就直接買下去了，結果沒有令我失望。
跟1代一樣 (1代也是大推)，特別推薦給喜歡Sonic / 洛克人 的玩家，得到的遊戲體驗可能在這之上，單純喜歡動作遊戲的玩家也是十分推薦。

官網有Demo免費下載試玩，想玩的朋友可以去試一下手感(?) 但不論新手還是Action game老手，一律都推薦先用Lilac通關。

畫面:
比起1代有不少的改變及改良，主角Lilac感覺改變最大，能否接受很看個人(我自己OK)
而遊戲的流暢度還是保留該系列的特色，玩起來還是可以有1代的速度感。

音樂:
很優秀，不少關卡的BGM 我自己十分喜歡，但也有覺得不完美的地方，總覺得不少boss戰BGM 魄力不足(我自己只有1~2首印象比較深)，之前1代boss 戰的BGM 好像比較有緊張感/激昂。

Speed run / RTA:
其實也十分推薦會玩RTA的玩家，本身此遊戲給玩家有一個感覺就是設計上是為speed run而設，目前發售後只是2週左右，已經有人在研究個別關卡的speed run 路線(Lilac用2分16 跑完關卡"Airship Sigwada")，各種巫術/ skip boss / 強行空衝跳躍等等，但能否爽快地一口氣跑完全場(?) 則可能還要再觀望。

中文版:
並沒有，連1代都沒有，想知道劇情需要英文能力www
但作為動作遊戲，你不一定需要知道劇情(應該是吧www)



其實想寫嘅野可以好多，例如New Milla超可愛啦; 例如想佢出DLC角色Spade之類，但你地自己體會啦，我唔寫啦。 
總之! 我好鐘意呢隻game!!!!  真心推!!!! (HK人上)

author: {'steamid': '76561199060931979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 23, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1712276749}
review: Lilac My Beloved

author: {'steamid': '76561199231719835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1664203448}
review:
Freedom Planet, while a fun and enjoyable game in it's own right, had much holding it back.
Freedom Planet 2, I'm happy to say, not only returns us to the fast-paced, action platforming of the first game, but surpasses it in every conceivable way. With a new art style to allow it to stand out from it's inspiration, but refined game play, an awesome new playable character and some of the most fine-tuned level designs and themes, as well as an proved story with top-notch voice acting, Freedom Planet 2 has both surprised and impressed me. It is a very worthwhile investment if you love fast-paced action platfromers like Sonic, Gunstar Heroes, or Mega Man X. Highly recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198151238283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2923, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1029, 'last_played': 1671152451}
review:
So glad it's finally here!

It's got everything a sequel SHOULD have! Updated Graphics, Reworked Mechanics, and tons of extra content and stuff (to say nothing of the story and characters which can get pretty DEEP at times). The first game while STILL good had a Very clear inspiration from a certain Blue Hedgehog, whereas this one is super ambitious to the point of almost feeling like its own identity.

THE ONLY REAL PROBLEM I noticed so far is this Frog Fist mini-game you can access at one point. A Fun inclusion for sure, but EVERY Time I wanna quit the game, I have to do it from the keyboard because the controller doesn't work for some reason.

If you were a fan of the first game, DEFINITELY Pick this one up.


EDIT: Turns out the Frog Game has been fixed shortly after I wrote the review. Once again, the day is saved! Thanks to... CONSTRUCTIVE FEEDBACK!

author: {'steamid': '76561198267698650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 908, 'last_played': 1665621028}
review:
I remember playing the first Freedom Planet back in around 2016 or 2017. It was one of several games that helped me get through the stressfulness that was high school and college. I followed the development of FP2 for quite a while and when I got around to launch day, it surpassed my expectations and brought me back to those much simpler times. I love the story, the extra flare of the animations, the fast paced gameplay, the oodles of secrets to find, and characters, both old and new, who whisk our heroes into another heartpounding, exciting journey.

All this to say is that Freedom Planet 2 is absolutely worth picking up, as well as the first one. It's sure to bring a smile to any gamer of any age. To Sabrina DiDuro and everyone at GalaxyTrail, congratulations on this amazing masterpiece; I look to forward to more titles in the future. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198287437999', 'num_games_owned': 60, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1686982218}

author: {'steamid': '76561199014464220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4932, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3194, 'last_played': 1685075152}
review: Whether if you're a fan of the Sega Mega Drive/SNES era, a casual gamer seeking a challenge, someone who digs amazing art, likable characters and fun game play or all of the above, Freedom Planet II is the game that you'll most definitely want to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983624763', 'num_games_owned': 1382, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1664336542}
review:
Freedom Planet foi um achado inesperado na época. Fiquei fã instantâneo desse jogo, de como ele é tudo que eu sempre quis num Sonic 2D: ele é focado na velocidade, mas também consegue ter exploração, tem um combate legal, tem uma história surpreendentemente boa, tem um fator replay absurdo, tem level design fenomenal, chefões complexos e desafiadores, enfim. Assim que eu terminei eles anunciaram que estavam fazendo um segundo jogo, e o hype foi instantâneo também. Era pra ele ter sido lançado em 2017... 2018... depois adiado pra 2021... e agora finalmente lançou. E a espera valeu MUITO a pena.

É uma evolução em todos os quesitos, além de ser gigantesco. O primeiro acho que tinha umas ~10 fases, esse tem umas ~25, fora as coisas extras pra explorar. Eu terminei a campanha da Lilac, mas além das 3 personagens do original (Lilac, Carol e Milla) agora existe mais uma campanha com a Neera. O gameplay ficou muito mais fluído que o primeiro, e o moveset foi melhorado também: agora tem como cancelar o dragon boost no ar e ele vai gerar uma explosão que dá dano nos inimigos por um tempo, e o shield, que antes era um assist e agora é uma habilidade pra se defender de ataques no estilo parry. Além disso, algumas melhorias na movimentação deixou tudo muito mais dinâmico (a que eu mais gostei foi poder cancelar o ciclone com o boost, por exemplo).
O level design continua excelente, e a diversidade das fases está ainda melhor. Tem muito mais set-pieces também, que pra mim é um ponto forte em plataformers. A música continua boa como o primeiro, porém achei que alguns sons do primeiro tem um charme que esse infelizmente não pegou bem. Muito efeito sonoro é reciclado do primeiro, lógico, mas tem alguns do primeiro que eu gostava demais e não veio pro segundo :(. O hud/mapa principal é uma adição legal e dá um dinamismo pra jogatina também. Agora tem um sistema de itens que podem ser adquiridos com alguns NPCs ou com a Milla, que na verdade são modificadores que pode deixar o jogo mais fácil ou mais difícil. Dá pra ignorar completamente esse sistema, mas ainda assim é uma adição legal. Por conta do mapa, ficou mais fácil explorar e refazer as fases também.

Agora em questão de história... Apesar de eu ter gostado, e de ter muitos pontos positivos e ser mais bem escrito em comparação, eu ainda prefiro a do primeiro jogo. A vilã desse é muito mais complexa que o Brendon e isso é excelente, os acontecimentos são memoráveis e o pacing é ótimo, mas ainda assim acho a história do primeiro com um charme a mais. Tem acontecimentos igualmente marcantes nos dois, porém o do primeiro é mais impactante na minha opinião. O que não tira mérito nenhum da história deste segundo, aliás. Inclusive acho que eles conseguiram fazer algo realmente muito interessante e expandir o próprio mundo de Avalice sem apelar pra (talvez spoiler se você tem expectativas em relação a história do 1, mas é spoiler leve)[spoiler]um segundo vilão vindo de outro planeta, por exemplo, ou "reciclar" o Brendon[/spoiler]. Foi um bom direcionamento e enriqueceu o universo e os personagens atuais.

Na dificuldade vi alguns falando que está mais difícil que o primeiro, e eu na verdade achei o contrário. Alguns chefões tem uma curva alta de dificuldade meio inexplicável mas, como sempre, é só questão de aprender o padrão. O gameplay mais fluído ajuda muito também. Os que achei mais difíceis em si foram as lutas mano-a-mano em si, pq os chefões robôs/gigantes, por exemplo, achei todos bem tranquilos. Porém não espere um jogo fácil, assim como o primeiro, esse é um plataformer mais desafiador. Além disso, o sistema de vidas foi descartado, e agora toda vez que você morre tem a opção de continuar exatamente de onde está (porém com ao HP totalmente reduzido) ou voltar no último checkpoint (como se fosse perder uma vida igual no primeiro). Continuar de onde parou é limitado porém, como se fossem vidas. Mas assim que perder todas, a única coisa é que vc vai voltar do último checkpoint.

Em resumo, Freedom Planet 2 é um sucessor excelente e eu não poderia estar mais feliz com o resultado. Superou minhas expectativas e recomendo fortemente pra quem gosta de plataformer fast-paced. Espero ver mais jogos desse estúdio e continuar me surpreendendo positivamente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151513992', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1665961746}
review:
Absolutely amazing. That's what the game is summarized in two words.

The more I play, the more I like it. 

Is the dialogue cringe at times? Sure. 
(Update: Got further into the game. This dialogue and story writing is amazing!)
Are some of the bosses jank or weird sometimes? Yes.

But despite its flaws, I see so many major improvements over the first game. (A game which, by the way, I've finished at a 100% on the Nintendo Switch)

The writing, the gameplay, and even the music are all better than they have ever been... and I love it. I'm so immensely surprised by it.

At the time I write this review I'll have around 9 hours, but believe me when I say that it might go up to 40 or more when I'm done finishing this game at a 100%. Having a blast with it, even if the battlesphere's a bit wack.

Heavily recommended if you like platforming games in general.

Update #1: After exactly 17 hours, I have 100%'d the game with Carol (except for the museum, still gotta repair that). And my opinion of the game's... not changed much! It's still really good, I loved a lot of aspects of it. Some of the hub songs don't loop, and a lot of the voices sound quieter than others, but I'm sure they're working on fixing them, so I didn't mind that too much.

Story-wise though, damn. I actually got engaged with it at the end, was pretty fun.

---

Update #2: I have 100%'d the game, having obtained every badge/achievement available, which also means having cleared all characters, obtained all S Ranks, Items and Vinyls.

Gonna miss this game. It's been a ride. 

Sadly, after your second playthrough, the story begins to lose some of its charm however.

While I did heavily appreciate the added cutscenes for Milla and Neera, they really felt shoehorned into the early conversations, ending up with some of their dialogues just straight up being ignored (mostly in Milla's case).

But again, the added cutscenes made up for it quite well. I didn't think Neera would even have one at first! Ended up pleasantly surprised about that.

Overall... I still heavily recommend the game! It's great! And the soundtrack's great too!

Gonna be waiting for Freedom Planet 3, if that ever becomes a thing.

Once that day comes, I will buy it on day one, and play it through and through as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999215652', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1663972722}
review: This game is a major and heavy improvement from the 2nd installment of the series. While some bugs present (Which were being patched) the game is still great. The story is enthralling from start to finish, it brings you on a wild ride wanting more. The jokes and humor add an extra level of charm which give each dialogue with the varies cast and NPC a lovable charm and delight. Heavily recommend if your a fan of the first one, will need to play the other characters at a future point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198425640053', 'num_games_owned': 66, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3016, 'last_played': 1664139629}
review: Прошёл игру за всех персонажей с экспертными модификаторами сложности, открыл секретного босса на всех персонажах, восстановил музей на всех персонажах. Замечательный сиквел, изъянов много, но замечаются они только через несколько прохождений. Решение отойти от сониковского стиля я считаю было успешным, дизайнерам это сильно развязывает руки и это видно, актеры иногда переигрывают или недоигрывают, механика игры, по моему мнению, не рассчитана на прохождение на легком уровне или с сильно упрощающими предметами, так как мастерить способности персонажей не приходится, а следовательно боевая система становится затыкиванием, системой предметов я не пользовался, не было необходимости. Рекомендую к ознакомлению, а так же постарайтесь разобраться в лоре, он тут есть, не скрыт в заднице и обещает быть интересным, новый злодей это тоже своего рода рояль в кустах что и Бревон, но в этот раз злодейка прописана с душой, а не злой потому что злой. Жду третью часть.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075941303', 'num_games_owned': 865, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 55, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1712261253}
review:
Freedom Planet was one of those games I shaped a lot of my interests around, and it heavily influenced what circles I've come to hang around with to this day. However, I slowly fell off of the series over time, since I began to kinda see the cracks in the game. When FP2's release date was confirmed, I can't really say I was excited, but I did want to see how it came along. When it finally came out, I bought it, but to me, it felt like it was more out of obligation. Eventually I played it, and, well...

My philosophy is that if you go in with no expectations, even the mediocre games are enjoyable. Despite having no expectations, FP2 was the biggest surprise hit of the year for me. So far, I've only cleared Lilac's story, but I went for all the Time Capsules too, and it's been a really fun ride.

Here's what I'd consider the biggest pros:
- Selectable story arcs. I like how you can not only set your own path through the story, but play with the difficulty in a way that still keeps every story beat intact.
- The original game's levels felt like they dragged on a lot. However, this one's levels lean a bit more into the speed-based gameplay, likely a result of Christian Whitehead's assistance on programming and level design. A typical level in this can take 6 minutes to complete, which works perfectly for stages that combine a Sonic stage's two acts into one.
- The voice acting is very much improved. In FP1, a good amount of the VAs were relatively new to the scene, or had come from the Internet. Dawn M. Bennett was a particular example, having no experience prior. However, in FP2, a lot more professional VAs were cast, and the VAs from the original game have hit the big time, having gotten a lot of training and more roles under their belt.
- The story feels a bit more... direct now? The first game's story had a number of things that just felt unnecessary, and didn't do much other than show characters' personalities. This one still gives them plenty of character, but shows it more in how they react to situations in the story, and there's less that could be considered unnecessary. Even the Battlesphere episode, which seems a bit disconnected at first, turns out to be important to the story as it introduces Captain Kalaw.
- All the characters feel far better to play as. Carol's Jump Disc is a brilliant way to give her a new ability on the level of Lilac's boost, Milla's combat has been heavily reworked while still keeping her primary gimmick, and Neera is great for the players who want to focus more on combat. Lilac has been changed the least, but the boost cancel ability is incredibly satisfying to pull off against a boss.
- The items are fun to mess with, allowing you to create your own gameplay experience. While I haven't played around with them much, there's a lot of potential combinations I've seen.
- Unlocking the extra final stage involves just playing through a set of short levels that play like the normal game. While things like Sonic's Special Stages can be a fun change of pace, they can sometimes be infuriating if you're not good at them. This method ensures that as long as you can play the main game well enough, you can unlock the extra final stage.
- I enjoyed the extra final stage's aesthetic. That's all I'll say because of spoilers.


While the game is fun, there are also some other things I want to point out. While they aren't necessarily bad, some may see them as such.

- Some bosses, particularly in the late game, have too much HP, and can be hard for those who want to just play something Sonic-like.
- The ranking system relies entirely on the crystal bonus percentage you get at the end of a stage. If you want to get a high rank, you need to use items to get a high bonus, instead of just going for a high crystal score.
- The storyline feels like a lot was taken from Sonic Adventure 2. While this necessarily isn't a bad thing, it still comes across as somewhat unoriginal.
- In a later level, a boss enemy appears as a normal enemy. However, its HP remains the same. If I were designing a game like this, I'd reduce the HP quite a bit. That's what makes it work in games like Space Invaders Infinity Gene: bosses appearing as normal enemies have less HP so that shooting them down makes you feel strong.
- It can be easy to not realize the Time Capsules exist on your first run. I definitely wasn't aware myself. I'd probably add a post-credits scene showing the museum in Parusa where you can find the only non-Battlesphere one.
- The museum side quest is fun, but it can be hard to get all the cores you need to complete the exhibits.
- The game ends on a bit of a cliffhanger, and we don't know if it's going to be resolved or not. This is kind of unfortunate, especially after seven years of development.
- One of my friends mentioned this, but I don't see it as much of an issue: the game's visual identity was made to set it apart from Sonic, but the levels and story still feel very Sonic-esque.

All in all, I firmly believe the positives outweigh the negatives. No matter what, no matter how hard a boss was or how much trouble an enemy gave me, I kept going because it was an enjoyable time, far better than I thought it would be. Seven years of development may have killed my interest originally, but it's clear that instead of sitting and doing nothing the whole time, Sabrina spent a lot of time making the game fun and enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973614049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1113, 'last_played': 1663554819}
review: I am a huge fan of the first Freedom Planet, considering it to be the best of the Sonic clones we have seen in the decades since the original Sonic. The gameplay is great, but the game goes above and beyond by giving us an excellent story, characters, voice acting, music, and script that elevates it to just another fun Sonic clone. Freedom Planet 2 takes what isn't broken and adds to it with an even better story and some gameplay additions that enhance the experience, including a longer length. Those who liked the first one will find much more here to enjoy. I hope this franchise continues as it has delivered two great experiences and I am ready for more.
