author: {'steamid': '76561198275427433', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 209, 'playtime_forever': 10563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5079, 'last_played': 1708875983}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is a pretty fun platformer on its own for sure but if you would compare it to FP1 then its more of a cup of tea which one you prefer more:

Pros:
+ 4 playable characters
+ good level design (i would say it beats FP1)
+ 38 boss fights (mixed i would say half better than FP1 and half worse)
+ a lot of stages (themes are very well)
+ story is very well  i prefer the character interactions and comedy in this one more but i prefer Brevon as villian a lot more which makes the story more interesting and not like a circus joke how Merga kind of are
+ Battlesphere challenges are fun and i say a neat idea also every single boss can be played there too
+ soundtrack to be honest is alright too but if would compare it with FP1 then it dont look so good but on its own its alright (Menu Theme, Shade Armory, Zao Land and Globe Opera 2 are still reallly good examples for worthy FP music)
+ art style is really the best thing about the game (very detailed pixels)
+ World map is alright i like it also the Gallery room is a nice idea
+ Mini game playable "Fish Frog" some training challenges and 1vs1 against the FP crew
+ 2 bosses only for battlesphere which shows how much effort but into the game
+ voice acting is a big improvment compared to FP1 and very well on its own too

Cons:
- what a wonder no Time Attack mode that really suprised me the same with your highest crystal score isnt here anymore too
- Merga and Weapons Core are the only stages i dont like and they are the last two and the main reason are those little swords they are way to fast (BUT NOT FOR LILAC I THINK THIS TWO BOSSES ARE MORE DESIGNED EXCLUSIV FOR HERE BECAUSE THE OTHER ONES ARE TO SLOW FOR BOTH)
- Neera is a little boring to play as also her movement fighting mechanics arent the best (Torque from FP1 even was a lot more fun than Neera in this game)
- the final boss Merga is kind of a little boring compared to Brevon (brevon had unique 3 fights, space ship, robot and himself without much projectile crap and Merga on the other side did almost only projectile stuff and dont had some unique in there)
- boss theme soundtracks are not memorable to be suprised they dont have this engergy from the first one they are way to soft (the final stages also are to soft for an finale atleast for me)

Even with a lot of cons but its more small stuff nothing to serious. I really enjoy the game for an Sequel its well made!

author: {'steamid': '76561198991024689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1666843864}
review:
Freedom Planet 1 was a good homage to Sonic games, with more than enough to set itself apart from its inspirational source. With its 16-bit styled graphics but refined controls, the game handled well and presented a high difficulty challenge, even on Normal mode. It had a good, compelling story, interesting world-building, fluid controls, excellent soundtrack and decent characters all around (albeit not perfect in this regard). What's most impressive about this game was that it was a passion project, made by a few fans from their homes, and still turned out as well as it did.

Freedom Planet 2, which came out a full seven years later, proves that this new world of Avalice (the planet that Freedom Planet's series takes place on) can pull its weight, and then some. Everything that was present in Freedom Planet 1 has been taken and elevated to a new standard of quality:
- The combat and controls are polished to a sliver sheen, with each character now having even more setting them apart than its predecessor allowed. Special mention goes to the new Guard feature, which allows you to precisely defend against and defeat tougher, more powerful opponents than what came in the previous game. This game does not pull its punches: you WILL learn how to fight, and fight well. Good thing this game's combat flows like a river of pure water and is a joy to figure out.
- The level layouts show the series' homage to Sonic the most, being multi-layered and easily speedrunnable for those that have mastered the quick, responsive controls.
- True to the generational shift, Freedom Planet 2 now emulates the 32-bit style found on the old Playstation systems, but still shows a serious upgrade to Galaxy Trail's budget and skills as developers and presents a wonderful charm to the world it depicts.
- With Freedom Planet 1 laying the groundwork for its world-building, this game can now take the runway and fly high, telling compelling stories while digging deep into the world's lore--shaking up a few things along the way.
- The next most notable upgrade comes from the characterizations and voice acting: everyone has improved from their record-from-home days with a bona-fide voice recording studio, courtesy of one Christopher Sabat (and yes, he too voices a prominent character in the game; bonus!). The characters truly have a chance to grow into their own as the story explores each of their backstories and personalities more.
- Somehow, the soundtrack is even better than its predecessors' was. As of writing this, there is no immediate means to purchase it; this review waits (im)patiently for its release, so he can buy it post-haste.

Overall, this game is absolutely solid and is a must-play for any Sonic fans, or any platformer fans out there. (And I recommend playing the first game so you can get a good idea of what to expect.) The seven-year wait was more than worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996055627', 'num_games_owned': 1247, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1982, 'last_played': 1666940345}
review:
Before I begin, a foreword is necessary. The furry/sonic fandom is strange and terrifying. Wariness of any title featuring anthropomorphic animals doing sidescrolling is wisdom.

With that out of the way, the game is fantastic. After playing the original Freedom Planet this was at the top of my wishlist, and the game hasn’t disappointed in the least. Gameplay is top notch and each of the four characters is worthy of a full playthrough. The game also does a good job of balancing the tone for the kind of game it is. The game goes from funny/derpy moments most of the time to discussing genocide, but somehow manages to stick the landing. The story was consistently fun, and the serious bits felt dramatic/heartfelt. A lot of it doesn’t quite make sense if you examine it critically, but if you don’t think too hard on it and you’ll have a fun time. 

A few other game highlights, some already mentioned above:

• Really nice sprite work with a lot of love to characterization. Unnecessary touches like special animations when your characters talk to smaller animals abound

• Great music throughout. In other reviews you will see people note boss themes hit harder in the first game (and I agree), but the music is still awesome. If Magma Starscape doesn’t get your blood pumping, you might be clinically dead

• Good challenge baseline with options for both those seeking mastery and those who are bad at videogames

• One of the characters is voice acted by the guy who does Piccolo

It is just a really fun game and worthy of the “Overwhelming Positive” status you will see once it hits 500 reviews.

On the downside, your steam recommendations will have suggestions like Fur Affinity 4: Beasts in Heat for a while after you buy this. Ignore those suggestions for a few days and eventually your queue will go back to normal. Probably. Hopefully.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134007125', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1088, 'last_played': 1700158254}
review:
So i've beaten the game last night, and Imma go ahead and give the game a strong 8/10 in case folks wanna just see the score. Imma be as fair as possible here, because while i really like the game and it feel like the pros significantly outweigh the cons, expect some of the cons to be some real stinkers or just flatout be disappointments. This is largely based off my run of Lilac's story, which i poured 18hrs into the game. Maybe this will change later on in the other runs, we'll see. There were some weird decisions i've seen for this game Just to list a few: Only Neera is a new playable character (who was available in the demo..), few demo updates, no Patreon for better support, No DLC plans, and Classic mode is post-game. We'll actually begin with the weakest aspect of the game.

Story:
It's not nonexistent, just has some amateur writing. It's not bad to where i regret playing & beating the game, but it's sorta obvious that the writer lacks writing experience and deficient in exposure to stories of sustenance. Even character bias occurs. So the beginning feels a bit off even, because they're saying Merga was encased in a crystal prison underwater. Later on you find out that this was due to the Kingdom Stone, which provides tons of power but they didnt establish that it can even do anything. I believe the Earth dragons got use out of it like this due to their tech, but it would've really helped if we were shown that, which brings me to a big fundamental point both games suffer from. The writing sin of "Tell, Dont Show" and the game is a repeat offender of this. It's disappointing in a way too, cuz they had YEARS to make this game, but couldn't show us even half of what's going on in the story? When this happens, there's an even bigger chance that ppl can easily miss something. So this much is bad because it easily turned into massive missed opportunities. Back to the story, they find out later a piloted mechaniliod gorilla destroyed their treehouse. It was offscreen and i forgot this even happened. If they SHOWED it, probably would've re-enforced my memory, but feels like even they forgot this later on. They also didnt show when the hell Milla became a scientist AND when she got herself a lab. Even weirder that she had no interest in this in the first game so that was pulled out of the aether (yet she, a fan-favorite & main character, still has 0 character development??). The girls find out that the attacks were behind Carol's sister (not mentioned in the first game), & a screaming monkey boy, who were aiding the main villain of the story: Merga. While she was the most imposing thing in the game, and was able to be on a similar threat level as Brevon, her M.O. could've been better. Basically i kept waiting for her M.O to be more explained cuz i kept thinking "Ok, i get why you're mad, but you're hung up on past bs". She was really hardheaded about it all too. Like how is it that you're not willing to negotiate with people who've had 0 interaction with you? It could be racism and revenge for how she was literally engineered to be the ideal war machine, but even then she's shown to be very smart. Cerebral enough to be the mastermind of this major plan that involved the help of others, gathering needed components to operate a big azz, planet-destroying, dragon spacecraft. Given her backstory, she should've stopped what she was doing long ago. Sorta odd that we dont know if this whole plan or it's process took 3 years or a few months, but she can get alot done in a day, even within an hour. 
Anyways, without going through this beat by beat, once Merga is brought into the swing of things, you, the player, are safe with the thought of "Ok we gotta beat down Merga". "Now is the story comprehensive?" Well what saps the quality out of it is the lack of character development across the board, big stakes but little impact since SPOILER...NO ONE DIES. How do you have a really dangerous villain if everything's virtually the dam same from start to finish? Then you dont even do it well...CUZ THE STORY IS INCONCLUSIVE!! Do these guys know how unsatisfying that is? ALSO how're you gonna give us Serpentine...BUT ZERO FOR BREVON? DONUT! Then the girls were stupid for trusting him & not have someone like Neera constantly shadowing over him (the same girl that's THE skeptic one of her own group). Lemme just go into positives before I just end up dumping negatives. The ideas for the locales are there, and really fleshes out the world you're playing. Trying to prevent a volcano erupting, flying thru a planet-destroying 3D ship, traversing sky islands that have a beach-esque setting. Merga provides good M.Os for her subjects, be it money, fame or tech. She was also almost even Successful with her plan. Had she fired her laser a quarter closer, that moon would've been gone. I might've missed a detail on why she fired it at the moon, but i think she wanted to test it, which makes sense. They also give you lore dumps in the form of time capsules and a library section...Which yeah, would've been soooooo helpful for the frist game, cuz no one knew what to expect when picking the game up, so some actual establishments can occur, and an obvious way to go about that is with flashbacks. If there's a reason why they couldnt, i wouldnt know. 
To wrap this off...If telling instead of showing....If it isnt the story lacking closure....The lack of info on Lilac's parents....Or even Brevon's absense...Why is it that when you get all the time capsules...This Earth dragon girl is hosting most of them...And she has a RELATIONSHIP with MERGA?....AND IT MAKES LITTLE SENSE?!! This opens up a can of worms on it's own, but the biggest thing about this is that it's biased AF towards since she's also Magister's daughter, is in hiding....BUT the devs dont even commit to this??? Unheard of. Merga never mentions her, even tho she considers her as "one of the good ones" among her race, she sees her an afterthought or she flatout hates her relationship with her. If she really is in love with her...Uh...You wouldnt destroy the race of the one you're in love with. Also i thought she wanted revenge for her race. Is her love repressed or did she actually forget about her? Oh well, IT'S UNEXPLORED :D! Then Merga's helpers get off with months of community service.....FOR AIDING WORLD DESTRUCTION?? This major aspect of the game, which it even tries to focus on alot, just falls short in the grand scheme of things, to where it makes DBZ's story look good. The pacing is a bit fast too and leaves little air to breathe and process what's said. Since things didnt really conclude, even with the "true ending" (counter-intuitive much?), this leaves us with sequel material. Im not giving the next game's story my time unless im part of the writing staff. This was just so bumpy, especially for a game like this.

Gameplay:
Now then...Coming off of the muddiness and the filth that was plaguing the story, we have the strongest part of the game by leaps and bounds: The gameplay itself. Even if i still have some gripes here, everyone and their mama looked forward to the gameplay. We have a layered equipment system, with a potion system & two bonuses you can give yourself either oriented to crystals or something to just get you ahead. The Elemental Burst can really shave off some health and you can even heal when hits land. They even allow you to control a big mech bunny boss in the challenges. It's sick. I have better platforming with everyone else compared to Lilac but she's still worth mastering. Only things I hate are a few enemies, bosses, and stages. The game gives alot of opportunities to spend and gain currency this time. Thankfully the devs are constantly updating the game. The hidden stage can screw right off tho.

Music:
I feel like the previous game's OST is better, at least as far as instrumentation. This game still has some bangers that I cant wait to get back to. Still keeping some chinese tunes to the tracks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971794367', 'num_games_owned': 1021, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1701185958}

author: {'steamid': '76561198354469532', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1677718297}
review:
This game is my favorite game of all time, it fixed all the issues I had with the first Freedom Planet (Torque) while also completely exceeding my expectations. It's beautiful, the voice acting is perfect, the Story is immersive, the gameplay is the most fun I've ever had in my gamer life. It has so much content I'm not even half done with this game yet.

I can only insist and say you must play this game if you haven't. You won't regret it.
Thanks GalaxyTrail Team.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087789413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1474, 'last_played': 1707781785}
review: It somehow improves so much on everything that was already great in the first one, the visuals , the gameplay, the boss fights, the level design, the music ...  one of the best platformers out there, just amazing all around!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198271932324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3128, 'last_played': 1668446893}
review:
This is one of the best indie platformers ever made and I'm very glad these past 8 years were well worth the wait. 

The bosses are challenging, the mechanics are smooth, and the post game content is exciting. No spoilers, but there's a ton more to do compared to the first game; hunting those achievements never felt so fun. 

If you love indie platformers and love to complete games, I wholly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031003812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 2592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1560, 'last_played': 1666036190}
review:
EDIT: Finished all characters and achievements. Gotta say that once you kinda know the layout of the levels and bosses, it gets a little better. But for a newcomer it's still confusing. Milla is obviously (again) the best original character, however it didn't save this game from my negative review :) Altough - maybe take it on discount?

As quite a fan of the first game, I was sort of looking forward to this one. While the game does deliver somewhat of an experience not different from the first game, it's overall less effective for various reasons.

First game featured small handful of levels with interesting biomes where each boss felt unique and thought through (some more than others, but still). This one offers you a s**tload of levels and about 40 bosses, where majority of them feel like a joke. Most of them only have three attacks and their animation is very static, it's clear devs love did not quite pour into these sprites. Same can be said about levels - they, unfortunately, follow same formula of the first game, which was already annoying, but they went bigger with this one, levels are larger and collectibles harder to find. There are also 40 of them, which makes biome specificity easier to overlook. They did have some interesting ideas, sure, but I found most of them annoying anyway and thats mostly due to inability to have the game zoomed out permanently, or at least, when you pick up speed. Its always just a blunt background and bunch of platforms. During the entire game not a one moment would come when I would think "damn, now the background really blends well with the foreground". It always seems like the background is there just so there isn't pitch black or something.

Introducing hub mechanics to game was totally unneccesary and cities where you would buy items as well as items themselves samewise. I literally finished half of the game using no items, because I didn't know it was there (i knew there were potions, but I was saving them for when they will be needed - turns out they act as items, you can use them indefinitelly once you buy them - who knew...?).

Photomode - wow, I mean... WOW. It must be first sidescrolling game where I've seen this feature. Saddest thing is that there is a visible amount of time that went into developing this... why? Why? It's not like this is a Horizon or God of War. The game doesn't look very good really, why would you put such thing in there?

Ok so now that I estabilished what game did wrong, lets talk about the good part. Animations of main characters. I liked how they expanded upon sprites for all main characters and also I appretiated slightly more detailed models with introduced shadows and such. New guard blocking system was definitelly a missing feature in the first game, so nice job here. Bosses also look less like gunstar heroes/sonic bosses, but they paid heavy price for having detailed but overall static models.

I have yet to finish game for other characters apart from Lilac, for which I unlocked everything that was unlockable in terms of collectibles and achievements including par times challenges and S rank in every level. I might change my mind, but right now - 7 years long work of a group of people seem like a lot for a result like this. Even if it was made by a single person over this span of time, I would still consider it a poor result. Other than that, fine addition to first game, except the first game was just better in terms of mechanics and redundant complexicity.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996678745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1154, 'last_played': 1677568093}
review: After seven years of planning, crafting and the struggles along the way, Galaxy Trail's second entry to the hit Indie Game has been released. And believe me as you read, It was well worth the wait! New levels. Awesome soundtrack that fits every situation that's worth searching for vinyls, Definitely replay ability with lots of twists, especially from different character perspectives. A fresh way to play each heroine and if you're into the lore like me, there is plenty to uncover leaving you to wonder more.  Vloggers, Streamers and Speedrunners will be in for an interesting challenge. Please support this game and it's creators. You won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198400115333', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 222, 'playtime_at_review': 2336, 'last_played': 1712268344}
review:
Its Sonic Adventure 1 + 2 but in 2D and with a ton of Gunstar Heroes bosses. If you know any of those well, you'll notice a ton of references.

Much longer and more difficult than the first, but also has much more difficulty options and items to make it easier or harder. Not that you need them to get through anything if you're good enough

author: {'steamid': '76561198124065493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2053, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1696480372}
review:
I waited 7 years for this sequel and it has been everything I've wanted and more!  

-The movement is immaculate, it flows insanely well, using most movement options allows you to glide and slide, keeping the momentum you've earned, redirecting and adding to it

-The level design has a beautiful, seemless flow, and they've solved the frustrations of 2d sonic games by making the game based on health rather than the danger being falling in frustrating random pits.  

-The combat system allows for creative combinations of moves depending on the situation, and all of them keep your movement flowing and feeling natural.  The combat feels built into the game, rather than tacked on, and works well with the boss section after every stage

-The art is BEAUTIFUL, the whole game looks amazing and I feel kind of bad for speeding through it when there's so much detail everywhere.  The game gives sections of time to just look at the world and appreciate it though, I love it

-The story has gone further with themes and writing than the first game, and its really engaging and interesting to see where they go with it.  I haven't finished all of the stories yet, but though the story goes through the same flow it seems, each character has differing dialogues and situations explored in their story, and it seems you explore the whole story by playing all of them

I can tell this game will be a long-term favorite of mine, it really encapsulates a lot about what I love about games

author: {'steamid': '76561198011578813', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1671065421}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is a turbo version of Freedom Planet 1, with almost all parts of it being tuned up to be even better than the first one.

While in the first game you would choose between Lilac and Carol (with Milla being a bonus character unlocked later on), here you have the option of the first three character plus Neera, one of the antagonists turned hero in this one.
Not only that but the moveset for all characters were overhauled and added to, giving you way more tools to glide, fight and explore the stages, both at your own pace and on breakneck speedrunning speeds.
The game plays really fluid and i had no problems at all on that department, the game does ask focus of the player and don't hold your hand at all in any way, if you don't up your own game, you gonna have trouble, even more so on bosses where they can very well drain your entire life bar in seconds if you don't focus.
There are some hiccups here and there but they in no way get in front of the fun so i would give it a 9/10.

Stage wise the game has more or less 30 stages i think, it's not a giant game, but it gives you enough content to deal with to not feel short, and that is not adding in the the campaigns of all 4 characters, since they all play different enough that you will have different problems to solve with each one. While i just finished the game i really want to get on the other characters to play through all the stages again from their perspectives, 10/10.

Music is a blast just like the first one, even more so in some places, it's as close to perfection as i think a human made work can be, props to the musicians and sound design guys, they did one hell of a job here! 10/10!

graphics are also amazing, everything is conveyed really well and danger is really easy to spot. Though the danger sign for projectiles outside of the screen does feel like a place holder and breaks alway from the game overall aesthetic, hope they fix that. 8/10.

Now, story... that's where i think this game kinda fails, HARD.
first, from a gameplay perspective, forcing people to play the game in story mode first before giving them the option to play classic mode (a mode more akin to old games where you just go from stage to stage without cutscenes or anything) is a step back from FP1, it reeks of writers throwing a hissy fit at the though that someone might not care about their work, and forcing them to it as an act of rebelion.
Now, if the story was at least on par with the first game, where it was not good, but did things interestingly enough, i think it would be ok to suffer through it once, but holy shit FP2 story drops the ball way too many times to be passable.
The main villain is a walking cliché of rebel without a cause and the writers trying to much at making you want to like her, most actions of Merga in the game comes off as a child throwing a tantrum, and basically boils down to "bad people did bad things so i will destroy the world, even tho the bad people don't even exist anymore".
Then you have the plot points that only serve to futher themselves instead of fleshing up the world, and to be honest, just feels like the writers are spending way too much time on twitter.
At no point in the first or second game we see any sign of slavery, yet somehow the story talk about it as if it was the most important part of the entire history of the world, the first game makes no distinction between dragon races, but now they have to because they need to push the story forward.
In the first game we had a completely ruthless warlord that would get things done and had no time for bullshit, here we have a child-like snowflake taking her problems on the rest of the world because it hurt her feefees.
And again, the story would have zero importance... IF they didn't held classic mode hostage so people would be forced to play through it.
Galaxy Trail dropped the ball HARD here, there are some funny conversations and cool secondary characters in it, so it's not all lost, but still a 4/10.

So yeah, gameplay, amazing, sound/music, amazing, graphics also amazing, if you can suffer through the garbage story, go for it, i hope they just give us the option to start on classic mode from the get go.
all in all, i will still give the game a 8/10, would be a 9/10 if it didn't had any story/if you're playing through classic mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994183048', 'num_games_owned': 1444, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1663808378}

author: {'steamid': '76561198093540693', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 1053, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 743, 'last_played': 1706915010}
review:
This game is good in the gameplay department. So, why the "no"? Well, it is because it crapped the metaphorical bed. Even thought this pushes the limits far above what was in FP1, by the end of this review, I will have either convinced you to never purchase this game or ignore my warnings because they don't matter to you. Sorry in advance for the angry late night ranting in this review that is half delirious. 

Here are some basic problems:
1: The game is too darn long in the levels. Honestly, they should have split every level into two sections for ease of play. This is made worse by lazy level design in some cases. Not only did they reuse certain story moments involving villains from FP2, such as them appearing on the screens to alert their minions late game, but also various other bits. While there is definitely a ton of heart to it, the problem is that the former game also did these reused moments and their mechanics much better.

2: The OST. Too many reused tracks, which normally is not a problem because I like listening to remakes of classic tracks in a series as everyone knows how many Sega has reused. However, what crosses the line is that a couple tracks seem plagiarized. The latter of these was an issue that even showed up in the demo way back, and clearly they did not care to fix it.

3: Despite the gameplay generally being improved, they messed up by making the new dodge button mandatory. The fact is, the first game had issues because only Lilac was ever worth playing as, mostly because the others were a pain to play as. This was because Lilac was the only character who got enough iFrames out of her moves, specifically her dash attack, while the cat spent too much on their kick and the dog had less health and only that shield. In FP2, they added dodges, which grant you a blink of invulnerability to characters. Why is this bad? Because they also made it 100% necessary to use due to how certain boss fights work. What this means is that you have to dodge, and you have to learn to be good at it, despite it breaking the fun of the momentum in gameplay. If they just toned down some of the more insane boss attacks, then I could have gotten through without it, and honestly I hate this new mechanic as, again, it breaks the fun of the momentum and flow of a highly kinetic platformer game.

4: The story....
Here are the nitty gritty story sucking problems with as mild spoilers as I can:
Okay, so let's talk about the first Freedom Planet game. Why? Because believe me, this is very relevant, and retroactively I must give FP1 a bad review because of what was in FP2.... So, in FP1, there were two characters intended to be playable that were cut; Spade and Torque, of those, Spade has a very important story that was clearly cut in FP1, and I know this because I have played FP2 and there is tons of backstory relevant to the character that would have really been important to him in 2. So, why the cut of this promised character? Well, I personally theorize the main dev of these games suffers from extreme selfhatred, which would not be an issue except that he/she clearly has other related issues often associated with selfhatred and suicide which I will not address here because IRL drama, which normally would not be relevant except it impacts writing and game variety. I wish them well, but honestly they are clearly psychologically unhealthy and I fear them projecting is partially responsible for the bad writing in FP2. In the case of variety, both cut characters from FP1 were male, and in the case of FP2..... 

....yeah, there is another case of "lipstick lesbian couple" afoot in this game. It's just bad. It is not simply that it is cliche, but in all honestly, it's a bad cliche when done bad. This type of crap writing is why Dragon Prince season 3 was so bad, although admittedly that case was much worse than this one, until you get to the "relevant history of racism" subplot, because of course this game pulls that dumpster of a plot point out. The fact is, this alone does not make a bad story, but the way it is told is terrible. I enjoyed the way Star Versus the Forces of Evil handled this story concept, even if that cartoon was flawed about it, but FP2 fumbles the ball down the stairs and it hits every step on the way down to the ground floor. Of course, explaining this requires spoiling things, so I won't, but let's just say "and nothing of value was learned and everyone got off scot free because hate crimes from generations ago that nobody in the current day was involved with" sorta bullcrap happens. It's trite hacky writing. "Character X burnt a whole forest down after the kidnap scenario, and yep because some of my ancestors were bad, your war crimes are nothing so you get a couple months of community service". I was the guy calling bullcrap when Orochimaru survived he end of Naruto and did not get blown up for his Doctor Mengele level evil, so seriously don't handwave this stuff with "oh, but they meant well when they did evil, so it does not count"; trust me, when you kidnap people who have no involvement with the situation, it ain't meaning well, and this happened in FP2. You could have skipped this awful story, but the casual mode is unlocked after the game ends.

Funny little detail about the "Battlesphere" area of the game. The things you unlock in that arena, at first I thought they were going to be neat accessories like those you find in shops. NOPE. They are the items that unlock the holorecords to the dang backstory involving the lesbian couple. Because, OF COURSE THEY GODDAMNED ARE! Imagine saying "yeah, work hard for that unlock", only to unlock a heaping pile of crap. At least the turd quest from Breath of the Wild was not trying to pander towards me.

This is supposed to be a game about a goddamned purple dragon speeding around and fighting robots; what the heck is wrong with you people?! Just let it be that, or make the writing not bad cliches of current day writing! I can read preachy writing and not have a problem, even if I disagree with it, if the writing does not suck, case in point all of my favorite RPGs which are filled to the brim with Japanese environmental messages and really oddball treatises on religious views both local and foreign to me; those RPGs actually conveyed these issues well, but FP2's writing is weak and seems only to suit the fetishes of the people who made it. Heck, I have even loved games with LGB characters and couple in them, including Undertale, which was amazing, and the reason that game's lesbian couple is not hated is because it meshes well with the absurd nature of that story, which also included a Tsundere Airplane, but also did not break the flow of the game. 

Also, just FYI, there are many people who would have not purchased this product if they knew the entire game's story was going to hinge and center around one lesbian couple in it. Like it or not, people have beliefs on that issue, and they also like to make sure their kids don't buy things that have that content either. I will argue that this is not a deception by omission, as the game pretends to be child friendly, but engages in both pandering and terrible story writing that makes it all about people paying for crimes based on their racial ancestry and not whether they were involved in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198304075469', 'num_games_owned': 42, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1664372296}
review:
It's been almost two years now since I played the first one and if you remember my review to FP1, you may remember that I really loved this game. Meanwhile, the awesome team at GalaxyTrail was cooking the second game of this young franchise. And after years of waiting (like, the game was announced in 2015), September 13, 2022 rolled around and the floodgates opened. Ladies and gentlemen - Freedom Planet 2.

And...with the nearly 11 hours (by the time I write this) invested and the Lilac story finished (complete with all time capsules. Trust me, you want to collect them!), I came to my conclusion rather quickly. FP2 is not just a sequel, no, it feels like an entire revival of the series. While the first game was more on the lines of a 2D quick paced Sonic like game, FP2 feels unique. There is right now no other indie game with that feeling. There's so much you can do - you can do challenges, you can just talk to NPCs, unlock neat Easter Eggs, on top of the core gameplay that remained mostly the same. And yet, it feels refined. You can fight the way you want, you can cyclone into enemies (which no longer uses energy), you can dragon boost into them - or just combine these to deal massive amounts of damage. And that is just Lilac's gameplay, as you can also play with series staples Carol and Milla, as well as the fourth playable character, Neera.

Story wise...oh boy. I don't want to spoiler anything, but Merga and the Bakunawa situation were perfectly set up and after the story is done, you are satisfied. There are even some questions you may have from FP1 that are answered in FP2. If you would force me to choose between FP1 and FP2's story, it'd be latter anytime. And Merga is a fantastic and understandable villain. But that, explore for yourselves. Even the length is perfect - with Lilac, I took around 9 hours to finish the game. If you want to go for all characters, expect around 35+ hours. Not even counting the challenges.

Ultimately, Freedom Planet 2 takes what made FP1 so cool and does it much better. I don't regret my Day One buy at all, as for me personally, this is the one of the best indie games that ever graced this platform. Absolute recommendation if you are a fan of 2D high speed adventures in the vein of the older Sonic games. And fans of the first game can get this one without doubt. Trust me, you will not be disappointed.

Freedom Planet 3, whenever it comes out, will also be a Day One buy. Because if I learned one thing with Freedom Planet 1 and 2, it's that GalaxyTrail know their stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003415677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1666135369}
review:
If you want a momentum-based platformer that's a zany blend of Sonic, Megaman Zero, with a ton of other unusual spicy additions, you're gonna get your money's worth with Freedom Planet 2.

While it takes a little while to get used to the game (the start of the game doesn't feel quite as tight as the first one), once it hits its stride, it's phenomenal.

There is a also an unbelievable amount of content here for a platformer.  Around 30 levels, with 4 characters who play VERY differently, which gives it a shocking amount of replay value.

author: {'steamid': '76561199035889071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1704648737}
review:
Долгожданный сиквел, который ждали почти 8 лет! И он превзошел все ожидания. Вот, с кого надо брать пример Sega со своим Соником. Однозначно игра года. Играется свежо. Обновления выходят регулярно. Сразу видно, что к этому проекту отнеслись, как к своему детищу.
Будем ждать третью часть или какое-нибудь продолжение франшизы.
Из минусов отмечу отсутствие Бревона и Торка, причем Торка вообще никто не вспомнил. А Бревон был крутым злодеем, чем Мерга.
А так все зашло.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313880524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1549, 'last_played': 1669341370}
review:
Freedom Planet and Freedom Planet 2 are a masterpiece of platforming. This game offers more hours of exciting meticulously crafted game play from every last pixel to the entire humongous soundtrack. You cannot find a better $ to entertainment value in any other game of it's like.

 The story and voice actors are absolutely amazing, there will be moments you laugh, and others where you feel the tingling emotions and butterflies. These games are instantly in the all time hall of fame for me when it comes to expressing the pure passion of a development team it shines through in the game as you play it. 

 There is plenty of replayability, again more than any other games in the genre. I cannot stress enough to anyone reading this right now considering this game that you are missing out on a gem of a game that in my strong opinion is leading the entire platformer genre even with the small development team and funding they have to work with, this game is more than all Sonic games ever were to me, and I used to be a Sonic die hard growing up. This game series has easily replaced Sonic for me.

Thank you GalaxyTrail, I love you all!

author: {'steamid': '76561198097714525', 'num_games_owned': 1858, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1672512911}

author: {'steamid': '76561198416324509', 'num_games_owned': 68, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1708715928}
review:
So, I've beaten the game with one of the four characters, and here's my summary:

Fun levels, rich and colorful pixelart AND a great story!

But on a longer note, this is one of the best fast-pacing, action 2D games your money can buy. You have over 20 great levels. Some are fast-pasted, few are puzzle-oriented and they are greatly made. After that, you can spend your time to master these levels and get an S-rank if you dare, especially when it all compliments the four characters' abilities, Lilac, Carol, Milla and the new playable character, Neera Li. They all got their own stories to unfold on this adventure, (I do recommend playing as Lilac on your first playthrough just for the sake of the story).

You can also tell that GalaxyTrail got the experience on their belt when making this sequel. The pixelart for starters is amazing! So much so, you might get your eyes glued on it 0.0. Not just the levels, but even a handful of hub worlds you can explore. They are pretty distinctive too, depending on their themes and culture. You even get a whole lot of NPCs to talk to. Some have funny quirks, some are even making references you might or might not get. The whole world is just inspiring to see.

And then the story. I won't do a spoiler, but I will say it's consistently told and got a tone that is more balanced out. You got some villains that you gotta stop or else we are all doomed and all that jazz, but you might like them too just for their characteristics, and all this will also impact the characters you play as and the ones they are allies with. Still, gotta play the game for yourself to know what it's all about.

 I bought it day one to support the indie team that worked 7 years on this 
and I promise you: You will get a heck of a time with this game! I highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051439310', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1664580727}
review:
It's a much more fleshed out sonic game, that lets you go faster faster, with more flexibility.  Sonic was honestly always held back by its desire to keep things simple, and a bit of level design and screen size, sonic mania showed what really good level design and even a slightly bigger screen can do for the game.  Freedom Planet 2's addition of a screen that can zoom out really highlights how nice more information is in these games, though it's unfortunate that the pixel count doesn't increase as the game zooms out, as it makes some sprites look a little wonkier, but it's not too bad.  The addition of attacks, guards and some special abilities makes their characters feel unique and increases the things a character can do, at the exchange of having to use more than one or two buttons.  

Playing as Lilac, you can use her Dragon Boost ability to speed up from a standstill, like sonic's spindash, but since it's assigned to a single button, seperate from the jump button, rather than a combination of down and the jump button you can use this ability much quicker, in addition in being able to do it while still in movement, even using it in the air and angling to fly through the air.  It results in a more flexible move, which will make obstacles easier to by pass, but,the move itself is insanely fun to use.  The invincibility on the move does have the potential to make it kinda OP, but the short cool down and direction lock on it is usually enough to keep you from spamming it and just never dying.

The other 3 characters all offer their own unique play styles, though I haven't played much of them.  A big portion of this review is coming from my experience with the previous game, and finding this game to be a big upgrade to what they did previously.  The voice acting and story are a bit too anime and cutesy at time, but there is plenty of charm and the voice actors are actually quite good, just know if you're some hardcore cool guy you might feel like a bit of a weirdo showing it to friends.  I know playing it in front of my D&D nerd friends resulted in a bit of joking about the story and characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198341224625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2185, 'last_played': 1678863158}
review: I'll put a more detailed review eventually, but for now I just want to help boost the ratings. This game was absolutely worth the wait and is great for anyone who loves storybound, 2D action platformers, and for speedrunning enthusiasts. The graphics are gorgeous and have so much love poured into them, and the soundtrack does an amazing job at immersing you in the story and gameplay. The voice acting and handling has improved exponentially since the first game, and the dev team is very friendly and is constantly cracking down on any game issues. I implore everyone to give FP2 a shot!

author: {'steamid': '76561198061487775', 'num_games_owned': 320, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1666508693}
review:
This game is absolutely fantastic. I can't believe how many details they put in this game:

- 4 playable characters
- Towns with lots of fun dialogues and mini-games
- Every stage is big, have multiple paths and one or two secrets
- Unique enemies and gimmicks per stage (and there are a lot of stages)
- Fully voice acted, expressive and charismatic characters
- Story is simple, but interesting
- GORGEOUS VISUALS
- AWESOME SOUNDTRACK with a jukebox of collectible music
- Items that can make your life easier for less bonus cristals, or harder for a higher reward, the game can be as easy or challenging as you like
- Very high replayability
- Solid game, there have been some softlock issues but the devs are quickly patching those and gameplay wise it seems great so far

11/10 please try it if you liked the first one, are a Sonic fan or just like a good fast platformer.

SEGA should hire Galaxy Trail, if they can do something this amazing with limited resources and fan donations, I can't imagine what they would achieve with proper investiment. I hope the success of this game makes Freedom Planet 3 a reality, and wish it got far more attention than it has now, the devs deserve it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111276286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1618, 'last_played': 1663972656}
review:
So i picked this game up a few days ago and well now i got 27 hrs in it.
but for a more detailed review-
(at the time of the review, I only have completed lilac's story, plan to do the others soon)
First up, negatives. Weird start but its short so who cares-
The only true thing that id say could use a look outside of the odd glitch or two is specifically the world map. Now I like the idea of the map, making the world flow better and giving you a break in between stages and cutscenes. However later on, once I want to practice stages to get better the walking can get tedious. A quick solution would be a fast travel option through the details menu, where you could select a stage to automatically start.

Now onto the things that I dont exactly feel strongly about:
Story-
 all the subtlety of a sledgehammer, but honestly, Im no writer so I feel a  bit unqualified to give a detailed critique here

Music-
 Now part of this is the hype I had going into the game and honestly, I think the music will grow on me over time. But as of writing, I feel the first game had a slight edge in the soundtrack department

And now the positives-
Level Design-
 Holy mother of something this is good level design. Each level sticks out in a way, and none of the level mechanics are quite what I'd call "gimmicks" as they are fleshed out enough within the level to make it feel right. As well, the level design quite encourages exploration, which is always fun in these 2d games that give you great movement options. The amount of goodies scattered around is insane and I love searching each nook and cranny of a level and getting rewarded for it.

Physics-
 Now most of the time its not worth mentioning, but since the game focuses on speed, it is worth mentioning that the momentum feels great, but still feels very controllable. As well, gaining speed is easy to do, but keeping top speed is difficult, and the physics play into this with how everything just feels. Just feels right, yknow?

Combat-
 Now the first game has some issues with combat imo, with some enemies just feeling far too bulky, especially in the endgame. It didnt help that bosses did not have health bars so it was totally up to you to track it. Now with healthbars for bosses and enemies feeling less tanky (or your attacks dealing more, idk it has the same effect in the end), combat feels satisfying enough to learn and try to get better at, especially since bosses are almost always vulnerable to attacks meaning you can really shred them if you know how to. And finally some attacks have utility during platforming which always helps things feel cohesive.

NPC dialogue- 
the game made me spit out my drink laughing. Don't know if that means my humor is just bad or if the dialogue is good but I frankly do not care. 

Art-
Every single sprite is super detailed and looks great. Special shoutouts to the bosses being made of multiple stitched together parts by how it looks, letting the bosses feel alive, and letting them do expressive movements with them.

If you liked the first game, you will probably like the second game is all I have to finish this review

author: {'steamid': '76561198149600994', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1665718559}
review:
I was definitely hyped for this game when it was announced on Christmas 2015. I had played the first game about 4-5 months beforehand and considered it among my favorite games of all time (and would at least place it somewhere in my Top 10 even now). Unfortunately this game did take longer to release than I was initially hoping (not that I was thinking it would come out the following year but I at least expected it around 2018-2020 lol), but now that the game released... I can safely say it was worth the wait.

In a nutshell, everything that the first game did really well, the sequel does even better. Gameplay and level design is even more interesting and fast-paced, the characters feel even better to play as (though I've only completed the game as Lilac but, whatever), the story is more in-depth and the art style looks even nicer. Presentation-wise, if Sonic Mania felt like a long lost Sonic game on the Saturn, this game basically feels like a hidden gem platformer on the same system, to put it the best I can. There's a lot more detail in the pixel art between the character sprites, environments and backgrounds in a way that still stays true to the first game's general art style. I will say that I didn't quite like Lilac's redesign at first, but it's definitely grown on me.

The plot is also a lot more in-depth than the first game. FP1 was pretty good for what it needed to do, but it didn't really go very far with things like character development or lore, in which this game... well, it does a lot more of. Not going to spoil it for those who haven't played it, but it adds a lot of worldbuilding, lore and history to Avalice with events that unfold in a way that helps the characters feel more fleshed out. On top of that I feel like this game does a better job of incentivizing playing through the game multiple times with the different characters - which I already touched upon but with how some characters go in and out of the story it does make me want to replay the game to see how those events unfold (on top of seeing if there were any levels I might have missed by just playing as Lilac). Plus it also feels a lot better paced in which the first did have an issue of overly long cutscenes that... really didn't do much to further the story (to the point where some of the original cutscenes were trimmed in an update lol).

Gameplay-wise, there's a lot that Freedom Planet 2 does to build off and add depth to what the first game brought. The new potion and upgrade system is one thing which, while optional, does add a level of personalization to each person's playthrough and may offer extra assistance to those who need it or even offer extra challenge with some items that you can receive that limit your abilities, life or revivals - which also come with the benefit of extra bonus. That last point brings me to another thing - this game also adds a rank system similar to what the Sonic series has since Sonic Adventure 2, which further incentivizes repeat playthroughs to get the best rank in each level. Plus the lives/continue system isn't meaningless like it was in the first game - you are given continues but they come at a penalty of the amount of crystal shards you've collected, and when you die you're also given the option to continue right where you left off but with only 1 life petal, or continue from a checkpoint with a full life bar. You are given difficult options to choose from in the game's assist settings though in case you have trouble with the game.

The game's also much longer than the first - containing 24 levels and according to HowLongToBeat clocks in at around 10 hours for a normal playthrough (albeit my first playthrough as Lilac clocked in at almost 12) compared to 4.5 hours for the first game - more than double the length. And if you think the amount of levels might diminish the quality of each individual one, you'd be wrong. Each level feels extremely well designed around the smooth, fast-paced controls, and each of them stand out with their themes, gimmicks, tempo and challenge. The game further builds off the Sonic-y level design from the first game combined with some added depth to the combat system, and overall creative, fun levels that reward replayability through the game's rank system and general mastery of the game's mechanics and controls, plus a few alternate pathways here and there.

The only real negative I can think of is that I did experience a few bugs here and there - a couple of which that did require me to restart from the last checkpoint. First one was during the first Serpentine boss in which during the 'falling' section after the first phase I ended up somewhere offscreen and got stuck somewhere I couldn't recover my character from, and the second one I clipped into the floor when falling down after being blown upwards by a giant fan thing. Nothing too big of a deal, but did cause some slight annoyance. I guess also that some of the later levels went on for a bit too long but considering how much I enjoyed playing through the game it really didn't become much of an issue lol.

Truth be told this game might be my Game of the Year so far, and depending on how Sonic Frontiers turns out, may even hold onto that title. I pretty much had a good time throughout it - never really feeling tired or burned out - and I can definitely recommend it especially if you liked the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098638522', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 6501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 15, 'playtime_at_review': 1498, 'last_played': 1712365750}
review:
[h1] Freedom Planet 2: One of the best games ever released! [/h1]

I remember when I first played the original Freedom Planet way back in late 2015. I was bored one day on the weekend after school, and decided to give it a try. I was absolutely blown away, and loved every aspect of it! Even after dozens of game overs, I beat the entire game in one day! Something I can only do for very few games. Somehow, Freedom Planet spoke to me in a way that no other game at the time did. But things were about to get even more exciting! very soon after beating it, something big dropped on Youtube. The trailer for this very game: Freedom Planet 2!
This was the most excited I had ever been for an upcoming release EVER! Years passed, I grew up, went through phases, started jobs, ended jobs, survived a dreadful pandemic, started questioning my gender, but through that entire time, I never forgot about Freedom Planet 2.  

Eventually, in September of 2022, it finally released, and I was HYPED! I bought it ASAP, on itch.io for ten extra dollars! But you know how hype works. It gives us impossibly high standards, and inevitably leads to disappointment...
...At least for games that aren't Freedom Planet 2! Seriously! This is easily the shining example of how to do a sequel right! Every aspect about Freedom Planet 1 has been improved! The music, for instance, is much more diverse! I'll admit that it needed time to grow on me, but this is one absolutely phenomenal OST! Leilani Wilson (AKA 'Woofle') did an amazing job here, and you should check out her Bandcamp albums, and her Novel series 'Elancia Chronicles' (The protagonist from that series also has a fun little cameo appearance in FP2)
The voice acting here is also incredible! FP1 had some great acting that brought the cast of characters to life brilliantly, but this sequel saw a BIG improvement to the quality! Being recorded at Christopher Sabat's  (Voice of Kazuma Kuwabara from Yu Yu Hakusho, Vegeta from Dragonball, and probably a whole host of other anime tough-guys) Studio, the voice work is a whole lot more professional. Every line is delivered so perfectly, which is elevated by the more complex, mature story! The first game had the classic story of a rag-tag band of heroes uniting the nations to repel an evil alien warlord. Simple, but it's delivery was very ambitious and passionate! You can really see how much GalaxyTrail have grown since then, as Freedom Planet 2's story is much more mature and well realized! The antagonist of the game: Merga is a much more complex, and tragic character than Lord Brevon. The game has a much better balance between dramatic and light-hearted moments, a more fleshed-out cast of characters, more mature themes, and loads of lore delivered through the game's several hub-worlds. 
The art of FP2 is also simply magnificent! The resolution is very high for an indie pixel-art platformer, and they used this extra screen size to incredible effect, having vastly more detailed sprites than it's predecessor, while also being super expressive, fluid, and easily readable in the heat of the action! Big shout out to Tyson Tan who volunteered an incredible amount of work to give this game it's beautiful art-style!
And now the gameplay: 
Yeah, it's also a massive improvement! Every playable character has a much more balanced, and powerful arsenal of abilities, while all still having their own strengths and weaknesses. Milla and Carol especially have seen a drastic improvement to their move-sets! Carol now has a proper ranged attack, which doubles as a great & super satisfying movement option, while Milla's Phantom cubes are now spawned instantly, and she's also picked up some new Kung-Fu tricks! The newcomer to the game's playable cast: Neera Li is also an excellent addition, sacrificing easy movement abilities for rawr strength, and a wide variety of ways to bust your enemies up good! The levels have also seen an astonishing improvement in Quality, Quantity and Diversity! From the journey through Dragon valley, to the daring raid on Airship Sigwada, to the visceral carnage of Zulon Jungle & Naolo Lake, and the dark, ominous depths of Ancestral Forge. There is something here for everybody!
My favourite addition to the game is it's Hub worlds. Each one is packed full of so many unique, and colourful characters, who all have so much personality, and really bring the world of Avalice alive! Some of the game's best humour and lore comes from these NPCs! 

In conclusion, Freedom Planet 2 is an absolutely incredible hidden gem of a game that gets nowhere near as much discussion as it should, and you should definetely not miss it! I'm just as in love with this game that I'm playing as a proud 24 year-old lady as I was with the first game as an awkward 16 year old boy. This has to be one of the most ambitious, and beautifully executed games I have ever seen! No wonder it's among my all-time favourites. And I certainly don't expect any other games to surpass it any time soon (Unless GalaxyTrail blesses us with another sequel, that is...). Thank you Sabrina DiDuro, and your incredibly talented team for bringing this incredible game to life! Your games have made a huge impact on my life, and spoken to me in a special way that no other has! (By the way, Sabrina is now a V-tuber named 'Spacey Batotelli'. Be sure to drop in to her streams and say Hi). 

TL:DR
Freedom Planet 2 surpasses the first game in just about every aspect. It has loads of incredible content, and is sincerely one of the best platformers ever made! You can feel the development team's love and passion all throughout this game! Buy it! Play it! Love it! Now!

author: {'steamid': '76561198823549388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 1404, 'last_played': 1712305105}
review: If you're looking for an action game, a speedy rush, or a good time overall, this game is quite the buy. I played the original game in 2017, and have been anticipating this game since. Freedom Planet 2 manages to iron out many kinks the first game is notorious for, while still keeping the game's identity intact. The story can be a *little* thin at times, but overall is a good experience. Presentation is overall waaaay better than the first entry, and the core gameplay is still killer. For $25, I must recommend Freedom Planet 2 to anyone interested in 2D platformers or action games.

author: {'steamid': '76561199038887041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 723, 'last_played': 1666119962}
review:
I wish Steam had a sideways thumb button to check. As much as I love the Freedom Planet universe, and with as far as I've gotten with the second game, I have a few problems to point out first.

The gameplay is alright. Doesn't change much than the first game, at least for Lilac and Milla. Having played the demo recently, Neera and Carol feel alright as well. Every character is enjoyable on their own. Only thing is, is that I just can't get through the game while forgetting to guard. I'm glad Auto-Guard is an option though... But I can never get used to doing it manually.

The problem mainly lies in the fact that the game no longer feels... fluid in it's progression. [SPOILERS AHEAD.]



The first game was simple: Get through a stage, get a few cutscenes showing the transition between one stage to the other, then progress.
Here... We have a lot to do to get from one stage to the other. The map feels disorienting, and it's annoying that you have to go by feet to a certain spot to advance the story. The world doesn't feel very organic this way.
[spoiler] Take Prince Dail's hallway to his throne... I am aware there is a shortcut to him underground, but it's neatly hidden, and I found it accidentally after speaking with him. [/spoiler]
Either way, the map and hub system doesn't stick to me well.

And if it isn't the map, the episode system is pretty slow. When I got to the first episode selection, I was somewhat fine with it. I get that all of them link back to each of [spoiler] Merga's peeps [/spoiler] but... when I got through it all up to the second episode selection... It quickly drove me away. I just don't like it. I know I'm gonna have to finish the game by forcing through all 3 of them though...

Aside from all this, this game is still very solid. The level design is very good, not as good as FP1, but still decent. Music bangs (but hits a bit less than FP1). Art direction is chef's kiss. I just wish they kept some ideas from the first game like the text font and textbox. It looked way nicer back then.

I guess I'm too much of a nostalgic person but FP1 stays my favorite of the two up to this day. I have yet to finish the game but, so far, this is my opinion.

So if you want to buy this game, go ahead. Playing the first game is essential to understanding this game's plot though. So get that controller workin!

author: {'steamid': '76561199064580084', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 8, 'playtime_at_review': 1148, 'last_played': 1712370827}
review: FP2 is super immersive. There are several points in the game where the extra effort put in by the developers helps players to feel more fully integrated into the world of Avalice while also enhancing the game-play experience as a whole. It's a long game, (for a platformer,) with lots of surprises, a fully realized story mode a nice soundtrack and content for days. Definitely a worthy follow up to the original game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198283655405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1829, 'last_played': 1671272764}
review:
[h1]Okay Gameplay. Saturday Morning Cartoon Writing. Topped off with a Killer Soundtrack.[/h1]

I'm prefixing this with the fact that I WILL be getting into Spoilers, nothing heavy like outright revealing something at the very end of the game, but I will be discussing parts of the story.

To start off with a generally good note.
The gameplay isn't terrible. There's some glitches, which definitely pulls me out of the experience if the glitches in question get intrusive.
But otherwise, aside from some general gripes I have with the gameplay, mostly with the overly robust combat options paired with momentum that feels slippery on occasion, I say the game plays alright.
Not great, not exactly good, but far from bad, and definitely not the worst it could be.
[b]EDIT[/b]: I believe some of the bugs I experienced could be fixed by now, I hope so anyways, I can't bring myself to play this game again.

Now, onto the big piece of this that caused me to really dislike this game.
The story.

Between the touchy subject matter it gets its hands on, and the characters it has at its disposal, the big story beats end up being horrendously cheesy, what with a reveal with Askal, and a story beat between Lilac Neera and Milla.
Askal's reveal as a villain was something I heard making the rounds literal years before release, which is just lovely considering it's an actual story beat that's meant to have impact.
As for the scene between three of the four main characters, I get a character being angry, really, I do, but does that scene have to have what's essentially a gun pointed at one of the characters?

And now, for the real part with the story that I personally feel is too much.
The Time Capsules, and the lore contained within.
Granted you care to try the Battlesphere, which is a side mode I believe you're encouraged to play, you get all but one of the Capsules for finishing select challenges.
Don't bother looking for them anywhere else say for the hub world of Parusa, because all of them are shoved off into Battlesphere Challenges as I mentioned.
They end up detailing what happened in the past, specifically with Princess Cordelia.
As great as this would be, if it was handled correctly, I feel like them ham-fisting in Colonialism, and dealing with the aftermath both of that, actual species genocide, the uprising from those affected by it, and what reads to me as racial tension masked through different species was handled very poorly, to the point that it comes off as Tone Deaf, or worse, Insensitive.

There is some genuinely nice things in the story, as well as things that made me feel a bit bad, for a good reason, like some lore reveals for a character and such.
The reveal for Milla's backstory, and Cory reasoning with Carol are two examples.
But the lore included in the Time Capsules, and the lore included after collecting all of them just ends up being like Cheetos, Dangerously Cheesy.

To cap that section off, I believe Creative Freedom is a thing, but Creative Freedom and Proper Execution need to go hand-and-hand to create a story that's both cohesive, and create a story that handles topics as sensitive as race relations in a way that ends up being respectful.

As for the other good thing with this game.
The soundtrack.
Now don't get me wrong here either, some tracks in here aren't exactly perfect, and some I won't see myself listening to regularly, if at all outside of the select times they appear in the game.
But the game's soundtrack, as a collective whole, is genuinely really, REALLY good.
By no means is the soundtrack enough to save the game's reputation for me, but the soundtrack itself takes the game from a tolerable experience, to one that I ended up enjoying on a few occasions, specifically with Robot Graveyard, Shade Armory, and Airship Sigwada.
The only thing of note that I have to mention, at all, is the fact that the soundtrack leaked actual years before the game properly released, which ended up making the game's soundtrack, for me, feel a tiny, tiny bit repetitive in some select points, (Specifically with the end-game level themes, and Magma Starscape.)
There's also the disappointment that some of the tracks that got distributed didn't change in the final, or got cut as a whole. Some of these tracks sounding genuinely good.
[b]EDIT[/b]: As ironic as this is, what with the soundtrack not being purchasable at the time of writing this, it's one of the few things tied to this game that I can actually come back to, as some select tracks are genuinely good. Ones to note are Cory's Theme, Shenlin Park, Ancestral Forge, and the removed track JC101A, as they're ones I keep coming back to.

Overall.
4/10, 5.5/10 for the soundtrack quality alone.
The gameplay is alright, passable at its worst and actual fun in some rare scenarios, the story and its subject matter are written and handled very poorly where it matters, and the soundtrack is a shining jewel that lifts the game up even if only slightly.
Even through editing this review my standing with the game and its intricacies stand.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160574125', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1697522889}
review:
[b]This review hurts to make.[/b]
I really, really wanted to enjoy this game. If there were ever a game to convince me Steam needs an "in the middle" rating, this would be it. I was given FP2 as a gift and I am thankful for it, but ultimately this game just did not click with me at all.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Game feels very good to play
+Beautiful graphics
+Creative stages and bosses

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Level design is cluttered and long
-In desperate need of polish
-Marvel-tier writing
-the music 

[hr][/hr]

For all that I disliked, there is a lot that I did enjoy.
The game feels [b]great[/b] to control and play; everything just feels so right when you do things, and it is fun to run around and attack and smash enemies. It is fun! But then a nasty bug might show up and ruin your day, getting you stuck in a wall and now you have to restart to the last checkpoint.
This game looks beautiful and has some absolutely brimming art. The scenery is pretty, characters and enemies alike are well-animated, and the "segmented" bosses are very impressive (major shoutout to Lemon Bread there especially) - everyone on the team did a great job on the project. However, there are moments - especially in the Shuigang hub - where things just look unfinished. NPCs missing shading, heavy sprite clash between the pixel art of Sabrina and Pixy versus TysonTan's binary art scenery, and some off-model art (Lilac's "shocked" portrait being the biggest offender). This game was in development for 7 years, and it's jarring as a result.
There is a lot of creativity brimming with each stage; every level looks and feels unique from one another. Some of my favorite levels were the ones where you had to slow down and either engage or do some puzzle work. Shade Armory and Lightning Tower are two notable highlights in the pool of stages I really enjoyed - more of those levels, please! Unfortunately, the better stages come later in the game with some of the downright weakest stages coming closer to the start of things. If you're willing to get through the less interesting levels (and deal with the story, more on that later) then you'll probably have fun with some of the more intense stages.

Alright. Now into the things I downright disliked.

Levels overstay their welcome. I think everyone who has gotten to Ancestral Forge knows about it taking 20 minutes or more to complete... But other levels in the game take upwards of 8 minutes, at which point you start to wonder when it's going to end. Sonic games had their levels split into 2 acts to break up the stages, and notably in later entries, allow the 2nd act to throw new things at you instead of continuing to be the same level for 10 minutes. People complained about Battle Glacier for this reason but it seems that stage length is being doubled down on here.

The writing is not good at all. The story's premise seems serviceable at first... Dragon warrior from the past that was sealed away is now free, and is out for the Magister's blood because of something that happened long ago... But then you get to the dialogue. Maybe it's because I just finished Xenoblade 3, but the dialogue gave me immense whiplash. Like, I'd compare some of this game's writing to the original "Golden Alpaca" scene from YIIK - going from absolutely serious to trying to shove in humor where there really, really ought to not be any. Characters ironically don't feel like themselves at moments. Simply put, it is not easy to get through.
The worst part of it all is that you cannot skip the story; you are forced to play through the Story Mode on your first playthrough, which seems like a complete backstep from FP1 allowing you to play Classic Mode from the start. Weirder still, you can skip the cutscenes... But can't cycle through text? I read far faster than I listen, and even in games where the text is being spoken to me, eventually I just want to read it. It's really annoying and it makes the dialogue issue worse when you aren't able to skip through the parts that dampen the experience without sacrificing the entire cutscene in return.

And the music... What happened here? Freedom Planet 1's OST is absolutely wonderful on the ears with music that gets your blood pumping and ready to roll - Sky Battalion, Thermal Base, Major Boss Theme... There is almost no bad music in the entirety of FP1.
I cannot remember a single song outside of Globe Opera 1 in this game. The music here is just not memorable in the slightest - I genuinely have tried to remember other tracks and I just cannot, only bits and pieces. The music in FP2 is not strong and I do not know if it's a mixing issue or the composing being weak. I know Woofle can do some amazing work, not even including FP1 but also her arrangements for Bunny Must Die! were strong as well. But then you get to tracks like "Boss (Mega)" that are just... not good. 

[hr][/hr]

But of course, I am just a dragon on the internet. Your opinion is your own, and mine is my own - just because I did not enjoy the game does not mean you will not. Again, this game does [i]not[/i] do everything wrong, and I will reiterate that this game is an argument for Steam adding an "in the middle" ranking for games. It is not so awful that I hate it, but it is not a game I would recommend.
If you're curious... Well, Steam has a 2-hour refund policy for a reason. Try it out. Maybe we'll get Spade DLC this time for real and it'll change my point of view.

[h1]I am grading this game at a C ranking.[/h1]
