author: {'steamid': '76561198028723758', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 2917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1682480907}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 expands on everything in the original game and mostly upgrades it, gameplay is even smoother, abilities chain into each other or have new capabilities. 

The music is fantastic like the first game, but with some added variety. 

The storyline was probably the biggest surprise, considering how some people didn't like the darker tone of aspects with the original, they doubled down here but balanced the darker stuff and comedy in a much better way than the original. Aspects from the first game play a big role here, and i'm all there for that. This game also has room for a sequel which I hope happens now.

There's a massive amount of stages and collectables here, it's overall just a really magical experience. My only negatives are I feel some of the bosses are a little too awkward, the fact you have to unlock Classic Mode this time, not that I didn't like the story, but I feel some folks aren't going to care and gating Classic Mode behind a first run feels kind of strange. Also where's my mahjong? 

Full thumbs up though, fantastic followup.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978481486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1663724664}
review:
I've hit 10 hours into this and I still don't feel I'm near the end (let alone other character playthroughs for unique story). Visuals are gorgeous, the characters are charming, music is great but ultimately it just plays like a dream. It's SO smooth. Absolutely worth the wait and a solid upgrade on game 1.

Voice acting is a little inconsistent. But it's Freedom Planet, did you expect anything else?

author: {'steamid': '76561198042478352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1664491405}
review: I thoroughly enjoyed the first Freedom Planet (even platinum'ed it), and this one goes beyond FP1 in all directions: the art has now moved to more or a 32/64-bit look (Saturn/Dreamcast-era), and the scope of the game is much larger. There is a great variety in stages, each with its own quirks, and all the characters seem to have had some new techs added. I'm still playing through my first character as Lilac, but so far it has been a blast. Highly recomended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198091162661', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1728, 'last_played': 1663810384}
review:
I have not beaten this game yet(the play time is from leaving it on overnight) but overall I'm not thrilled with my purchase.

Pros
Alright Music(I like some tracks)
Alright controls
The writing can be funny...occasionally 
It's pretty long(which is good if you somehow like the level design)

Cons:
-Story is nothing to write home about, and the characters are pretty annoying most of the time. Apparently if you want to play the classic mode(which skips all the cutscenes and hub world crap) you have to beat the game first...soo
-While the game is LONG for a platformer, it is BLOATED. The vast vast majority of the levels are all tedious slogs with set pieces and ideas that seem like they should be in one of the Klonoa gba games instead of a sonic inspired action plat. Like there's one stage where you move fish keys around to altars that cause various effects (changing gravity, raising water level, cooling lava). It's like I could imagine it being fine in Klonoa GBA since that game has small sectioned rooms (and better control...), but in these huge nothing burger snail maze type levels you just get lost. No clue why the devs made levels with no flow in a SONIC INSPIRED game.
-Bosses are...not great, there's a block button now which is nice but the boss design and the combat is just not satisfying. You could write a whole essay on why the camera is wack in some fights or why the combat is unsatisfying or why the boss movesets are weak and then make comparisons to other action plat boss fights like say Mega Man's but i'm not in the mood for that

So overall, not satisfied. I was hoping after Spark 3 we could also have a great 2D entry to play but this is not it. Guess I'll go back to my Mega Man Retrospective after I beat this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245632364', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1692643598}

author: {'steamid': '76561198095635925', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 2834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 25, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1711809668}
review:
Loved the first game, this has practically blew it out of the water (pun 100% intended)

I love all the little citizens you can talk to and all the extra stuff you can do after you finish the game, and by the looks of it, the different characters perspectives are more fleshed out this time around! (i only have a little bit of millas story to go off of rn)

The gameplay of everyone feels great too, it was already great in the first game but this one adds some new things (as well as a completely new playable character, Neera, which btw had the biggest glowup of the century with the new and improved art style, shes so pretty!!!)

The voice acting is for sure leagues better than the first (but i still loved the first games voices despite that) and the humor of this game is on point, I especially adore the little mascot otter in purusa!

All in all, even if you DIDN'T play the first game, this is well worth the play! I beat the main story as lilac in 10 hours, and there are 4 total characters and many things to do after the story, do the math, the experience is well worth the 20 something dollars!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197986132304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 811, 'last_played': 1663524481}
review:
[h1] It was hard to "down vote" this game, but I had too... [/h1]

As someone who not only enjoyed the first Freedom Planet game, but also gave it a [b] 10/10 [/b] and considered it one of the BEST 2D Platforming games EVER, I was "beyond hyped" going into Freedom Planet 2 and had such high expectations for this sequel to be as good (if not BETTER) than the first game, but unfortunately, it truly saddens me to say that this sequel, in my opinion, is [b] inferior [/b] compared to the first game in almost every way possible. The following points lists my main issues with this sequel:

[b] 1) New re-designs are NOT good: [/b] This is especially true for [b] Lilac [/b] who had such a GREAT design in first Freedom Planet (she truly looked like a character from the "Sonic the Hedgehog" universe), but in this sequel her re-design looks [b] so generic/weird [/b] and uninspiring whatsoever. What's worse is that another character, [b] Spade, [/b] who was my FAVORITE character in the first game both for his design and his "Shadow the Hedgehog-like" edgy personality, was COMPLETELY RUINED in this sequel with an AWFUL new re-design AND attitude that made him SO BORING that I lost all the love I had for him from the first game (I'm truly baffled by the developer's decision to change/ruin the cool personality that Spade had in the first game rather than building upon it).

[b] 2) General art direction in this game NOT as good: [/b] Much like the 1st point, the graphical look of this game as a whole is not as good as the original game which had WAY BETTER-LOOKING stages/backgrounds than this game. As a result, the stages looked (and felt) bland and weren't as memorable to me as the stages from the first game (the "16-bit" look of the first game was magnificent IMO).

[b] 3) Zone Music: [/b] With maybe 2-3 music exceptions, the zones music in this game as a whole weren't memorable at all and most of them were "all over the place" in terms of how they play and none of them felt "catchy" at all. In fact, some of the remixes (e.g. Dragon Valley) were COMPLETELY RUINED in this game and nowhere near as good as they were in the first game.

[b] 4) Boss Music: [/b] THIS point right here is, by far, the [b] most disappointing [/b] part of this game for me personally. You see, I'm someone who always looks forward to boss battles not just for the fight itself but also the BOSS MUSIC that makes those moments so INTENSE/EPIC/MEMORABLE. And so, whereas the first Freedom Planet game which had EPIC boss music that [b] popped-up, [/b] were [b] very fast-paced/intense [/b] and gave you a sense of [b] hype/excitement [/b] as they play ("Prince Dail's" boss theme from the first game was in my "Top 15 all time favorite boss themes" too), the majority of the boss themes in Freedom Planet 2 however sounded [b] very subtle/soft/low-key, dead and did NOT give those hype/excitement/sense of threat vibes [/b] that you would expect in a boss battle and sounded more like "regular zone themes" than anything else. I am still beyond shocked at how the developer "okay-ed" these GARBAGE boss themes/remixes that were absolutely NOTHING in comparison to the AWESOME boss themes from the first game. (My rating for the boss themes alone in this sequel is [b] 0/10 [/b], sorry to say)

[b] 5) Longer stages + No in-stage map: [/b] While having longer stages (compared to the 1st game) may sound like a good thing at first, the stages in this sequel are SO LONG that it feels [b] tedious to go back to again, [/b] especially if you want to achieve a better stage completion rating or find hidden chests that you missed. It's even worse that there isn't an "in-stage map" and thus trying to find hidden chests in stages that take [b] +15 minutes [/b] to complete is just HORRENDOUS and very de-motivating to do honestly.

[b] 6) No accumulated lives: [/b] While I never got a "Game Over" in this game, the fact that the lives counter RESITS every stage to "2 lives" and does NOT accumulate like in the first game felt like an unnecessary [b] punishment [/b] to the player and many times I felt [b] pressured to play very safe/defensive (especially against bosses) [/b] so that I don't get a Game Over. I really think this was a BAD DECISION on the developer's side and feel that this should have been kept as a "Hard difficulty-only" feature (I played on "Normal" difficulty for the record). Additionally, I did NOT use those "helping items" that you can equip before entering a stage because it felt like a "cheap" way to make the level easier and I didn't want to feel "forced" to use them just because of this "always 2 lives starting" system. (And no, I never used that "instant revive" option when you die because that too felt like a "cheap" way to finish a level and so I always preferred to restart from the "last checkpoint" instead)

[b] 7) Hub zones are annoying: [/b] Unlike the first game (which DIRECTLY took you to where you are supposed to go next), the so called "Hub" zones in this game felt like a CHORE to explore to progress the story. I didn't care about the characters there who provided USELESS text and the shops in there were also useless because I had no intention of using any of those items in-stage.

[b] 8) Not knowing where to go next: [/b] There were many instances where I honestly did NOT know where to go next in order to progress the story. For example, after beating "Merga" the first time, not only did that battle end very awkwardly (i.e. without any subsequent cutscene to explain post-battle events), but also the game did NOT tell me where I'm supposed to go to next and there wasn't even an "!" mark to highlight the place where I was supposed to go to next. Needless to say, I much prefer the "directly taken to the next area" approach the first game had than this game's "hub approach" IMO.

[b] 9) Merging Guard + Dash buttons: [/b] Many times I ended-up taking unnecessary damage (especially against bosses) because the "regular guard" and "dash" buttons were merged, which led to many instances where my character "dashed into an enemy/projectile" even though I did NOT intend for them to perform a "dash" command. The solution to this is to simply [b] split the regular guard button and dash button into separate buttons [/b] through a future patch and that should significantly help in reducing unintended character inputs.

[b] 10) Main villain was boring: [/b] Initially, when I saw the animated short video for this sequel when it was announced, I had high hopes for the main villain of this game, but sadly I was so underwhelmed by the main villain who was very uninspiring, all talk and nowhere near as VICIOUS/MENACING as the AWESOME [b] "Lord Brevon" [/b] from the first game. I couldn't take the main villain seriously and was bored every time she appeared throughout this game (even the final boss battle was "meh" at best IMO).

[h1] Final Ratings: [/h1]

[b] Freedom Planet 1: [/b] A [b] 10/10 masterpiece [/b] that was a blast to play and had awesome character designs/personalities, story, stages, visuals and ESPECIALLY boss battles/music, all of which should've been preserved going into the sequel.

[b] Freedom Planet 2: [/b] A [b] 6/10 underwhelming game [/b] that opted to "try something new" rather than build upon the strengths it had established from its predecessor and thus resulting in a sequel that fell short in almost all comparable areas and was nowhere near as memorable (or worth re-playing) as the first game in the franchise.

P.S: When the development for the inevitable [b] Freedom Planet 3 [/b] begins, I hope the developer goes back to their roots and takes inspiration from the [b] original Freedom Planet [/b] in making the next entry in franchise and focuses on what made the 1st Freedom Planet game so awesome while developing the next game, in particular the [b] INTENSE/FAST-PACE BOSS MUSIC [/b] that made the boss fights in the first game (especially the [b] Prince Dail fights) [/b] so epic/memorable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198795895886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1250, 'last_played': 1710040030}

author: {'steamid': '76561198251827046', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1665188600}
review:
First thing I want to say before I get into this review, I thought this was a fine game. Yes I know its a negative review but that will be explained later.

Freedom Planet 2 was a game I was waiting to play for several years after I played and enjoyed the hell out of Freedom Planet. While I enjoyed this game, I feel like it completely failed to live up to its predecessor's legacy. 

Pros:
-The platforming is really good. The momentum, speed and physics are very fun and it feels/plays similar to the original game which is great. I was very glad it was like this for this game.
-The updated sprites look really good, lots of characters got huge visual upgrades and the backgrounds within the game look great.
-The hub worlds which I thought would be pretty bad addition to this game, were surprisingly nice to have. They felt like needed breaks in-between the story and game play.
-Character interactions were great, there was a lot of comedy that got me laughing (especially mayor zao, phenomenal job on his part).

Cons:
This is going to be a long one, I really wish I had less complaints with these games
-Combat. I didn't like how this game wanted to become more of an action platformer. In the original, bosses took damage when you hit their weakpoint. In this game you have to hit the weakpoint multiple times just to remove one bar of health (I beat the game with lilac so it might be easier with other characters). I think adding hp bars to the bosses was dumb as it felt more annoying to deal with bosses compared to its predecessor. It also makes me feel as if I'm playing a megaman zero or megaman x game instead of something like sonic. I understand why they did it as they wanted to move the series away from being a sonic clone, but I believe they perfected it in the original. 
-Backgrounds. While I do love the backgrounds, it really makes it hard to tell what I can and cannot jump on and this has lead me to die several times within the game.
-Sprites. The only sprite change that I didn't like was Lilac's. I was always a fan of her original design, other than that everyone else's sprites are very good.
-Story. While I don't think the story is too bad or too good, there definitely felt like various moments were shoehorned in to add more of a dramatic tone shift. That mixed with the limited sprites for the characters made some of those moments feel awkward or failed to get my attention.
-Guarding. Guarding is super awkward to the point where I don't know if I'm actually guarding properly or it just doesn't work because I still end up taking damage.
-Level design. While some of the levels in the design are really fun to play through, a lot of levels later on feel really poorly designed. The puzzle levels were obviously very annoying because they're puzzles. There were times where I would get hit by projectiles that were off screen or I was completely unable to dodge an enemies attack at all because I was simply unable to see them. The inclusion of guard is only because they couldn't properly design levels without you taking a shitload of damage. I don't understand why the level design ended up this way because they did a great job with levels in the first game.
-Music. There were a few songs in this game that were pretty good, but for the most part it is all super forgettable. The first game had some of the best tracks I've heard in a video game and when compared to this its just very sad to see.
-Spoiler [spoiler] Getting the true ending. Finding the first memory/log was really cool and I thought finding the other would be that way. Nope just do like 13 levels of the battlesphere and you're done. It just didn't make sense to me at all. Why not try hiding them in the hub world or maybe hide some in the stages. This was just handled poorly. Also, many of the battlesphere levels were very tedious as they felt like the same thing being done over and over again with minute changes or they had broken mechanics that made me unable to progress unless i restarted.  [/spoiler]
- Another spoiler [spoiler] The whole final level against syntax was also pretty poorly designed. I don't know why the game didn't show you the amount of lives you had or the timer which just confused me. The search light mechanic was also dumb because it guaranteed that if this was your first time in the level you would die. Hiding should have at least lowered the security alarm for syntax but it didn't and I have no idea why [/spoiler]
-Glitches. I had gotten "softlocked" on 3 separate occasions during this game and they were all when I had gotten pretty far into a stage. It felt annoying that I had to keep restarting/reloading to a prior checkpoint because I was "too fast" for the game.

Overall, I really wanted this game to be just as great as the original. When I played that first demo, I definitely knew something was up with this game and I tempered my expectations. While I've only done a run of one character, that being lilac, I do plan on playing as the rest of them and seeing how their respective playthroughs work. This is a good game and I don't hate it, but in good faith I cannot recommend this to someone who's played and loved freedom planet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254606191', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1674304638}
review:
Что же, это свершилось, игра наконец-то вышла в свет спустя 7 лет. Поначалу я решался её не покупать вдоль до выхода проекта DragonBorn от FLEX_CREATOR(Если что это я), так как я начал его смотреть еще до выхода каноничной версии Galaxtrail, но игре я решил дать шанс не смотря на халтурщину со стороны от разработчиков к игрокам, ведь 2Д игра не может столько разрабатываться, но не суть. Хочу сразу подметить еще одну дерзость со стороны ДиДуро это циник в 25$ или же 600 р. Как заявлял сам издатель, ценик подняли из-за якобы упорной разработкой, что я сказал выше сказано по прежнему считаю бредом. 

С минусами разобрались, теперь пришла пора разбирать саму игру, ох уж этот главный Саундтрек  темы игры, мне всегда казалось что Фридому не хватает серьёзной музыки, но в первой части он тоже был флагменным, но тут плюс\минус все композиции это рок, 
За дизайн персонажей и уровней отвечал Tyson tan так же известен по своей программе Krita, где он собственно на ней и делал дизайн всё и вся
Озвучка выросла в качестве, английский я знаю так себе но мне не составила труда понять лор второй части, даже на их блогах в Твиттер сильно хвалили игру, яркий пример голос Лайлака Dawn M. Bennett
Боссы в серии FP были один из ключевых фичей, но в этой части они стали красочные и местами даже сложные, [spoiler] всего за игру вы их встретите 29-30 штук, смотря на какую концовку в играете, на обычную или на истинную[/spoiler]
Свобода действии и HUB просто приятная мелочь
Battelsphere режим который заставит застрять на несколько часов с битвами боссов и хом ранов [spoiler] В основном вы там застрянете из-за временных капсул, для получение истинной концовки[/spoiler]
Графон стал красочнее, что вы итоге и затянуло в этот мир.
В общем не пожалеете что вы купили эту игру 

Еще от себя скажу очень странную вещь, но очень депрессивную, не знаю у меня только такое случилось, или это просто ревность к конкуренции, вообщем после прохождении Лайлака, на следующий день у меня появилась депрессия, я не шучу у меня правда такое случалось, мысли у меня были какие то смешанные, толи из-за халтуры (У DragonBorn вышло три эпизода, но уже вот как год я не делаю 4 серию) толи из-за того что вышла каноничная версия вышла, DragonBorn будет отличаться так называемой контрастностью, депрессия начинает уходить, но не полностью,  в любом случаи игра дала мне мотивации на продолжение, огромное ей за это спасибо, надеюсь продолжение не заставят так долго ждать

author: {'steamid': '76561198389997557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 811, 'last_played': 1707996771}
review:
The sequel is amazing! 
The story is really interesting and gets some really unexpected twists, that helps reveal the characters. 
The graphics are good, It's very smooth and colorful. There are some NPCs and other characters that don't have completed shading, but I hope it will be fixed in the future.
The music keeps the quality bar, it's pretty good as in FP1.
The gameplay is very dynamic and characters have their unique moves. Well, some moments are pretty hard to beat in first try, just like in the first part.
There are some minor bugs, but they don't affect the walkthrough, and I'm pretty sure they will be fixed soon.
Highly recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994904389', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 3562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1712353876}
review:
Look at this absolute unit of an action platforming game.
Look at this enormous chunker-on-a-bone with over 25 fully-fledged levels. Each different than the last.
Look at this thick behemoth of a production values, outclassing everything in its genre.

Yep! That’s Freedom Planet: The Second: Electric Boogaloo baby. First game is still to this day an incredible benchmark of quality for 2D action platformers and straight out of the gate I can say that most of the good qualities you could attribute to that game, apply to the sequel 1:1. 

Sequel retained it's identity as a high-speed joyride: mixing gameplay mechanics from multiple sources (mostly Sonic, Mega Man X and Gunstar Heroes), that are delivered with excellent feeling controls, creative gimmicks and stages, jaw-dropping setpieces and multiple characters to choose from with vastly different playstyles.

Freedom Planet 2 never ever drops down from a set baseline of quality at any given moment and despite few minor flaws or disappointments (in comparison to the first game), it maintains a package of speed and solid quality that could go through military grade blast doors.

Improvements over the first game include a higher fidelity graphics which exchange Genesis charm of the first game for the gorgeous details and colors of Hi-Bit aesthetics, which is awe inducing in multiple places. All playable girls each got themselves major or minor changes to streamline their gameplay plus new 4th hero joins the fray with difficult but definitely unique playstyle.

Game also addresses most of the common complaints from the first game. Bosses are still tough as nails, but this time not only I didn’t encounter any mishaps with missing telegraphs or unfair moves, but also a new item system was put in place that helps you modulate the amount of pain you can induce on yourself. This system is incredibly flexible and shall you look for either smooth sailing or ultra-nightmare experience, you can set up those pretty easily.

Story is also a good improvement over the first game, especially when it comes to pacing. There are no longer 20 minute cutscenes between levels. Odd tone shifts are gone as well. Plot still isn’t noticeably unique and themes lack subtlety, but great character interactions never left and it is a joy to hear and see. Highlight goes to some minor villains that do often steal the show because how entertaining they are. It’s just a little shame that the main antagonist isn’t as memorable this time around. She is not Lord Brevon unfortunately and she doesn’t have the impact on narrative and gameplay his shenanigans brought.

I also need to bring up, that while there are absolutely truckton amount of levels, those are a little less dense and evolving this time around. I do miss the two act structure of the first game quite a bit. I believe this was made to keep the game’s scope in check (which you can also see by some enemy recycling mid-game).

However as I say that, the individual levels themselves are designed with no major flaws and they are still as fun, creative, fast, unique, colorful and expertly designed as in the first game. Again, nothing goes here below that baseline.

The only thing that sadly could be considered below that aformentioned baseline is the OST. It's a big shame, since first game was all bangers all the time and it's a big part of first game's charm. FP2 delivers a lot of great stage themes and character motifs but boss themes mostly lack that excitement pill that elevated the first game. I wouldn’t be honest to myself if I didn’t mention this small disappointment.

But that’s the end of downers. Most of other users mention the 7 year wait for the game and if it was worth it or not. I’m biased here – I’m a fan of a first game and of course I could weigh in on this question. However, I do consider this a bad metric to actually answer what does Steam ask you. [i]Do you recommend this game?[/i] - to a random Joe that might stumble over this game an wonder if it’s worth their hard earned cash.

To those people I will first say, Have a nice day! And secondly… It is a bit expensive, but Freedom Planet 2 seriously blows away all the competition out of the water with sheer amount of quality content that will occupy you for hours on end. First playthrough took me 9 hours which is double of the first game! With ONE character and NO side objectives! We are talking about Hollow Knight levels of measuring contest and everybody knows how that game was severely underpriced at launch.

Freedom Planet 2 deliver top-of-the-line 2D action gameplay nowhere to be seen on the market, despite few flaws here and there. I’m still fresh of finishing the game. I might change my stance on few things later, but at the end of the day, like its predecessor, it’s a top tier gem waiting to be discovered and cherished by you and your friends. I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116205839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1663951601}
review:
Первую часть я играл много, очень много, она действительно крайне мне понравилась, если бы не баг, из-за которого мои ачивки в игре не получились в стиме, у меня было бы их 100 %, потому вторую часть я ждал с нетерпением 4 года (в первую я сыграл только 2018 году и тогда же узнал о сиквеле), расстраивался каждый перенос но терпеливо ждал, и вот, она вышла.
Пока что я прошел игру только за Лайлак, потому буду судить с точки зрения только ее геймплея, но что я увидел меня крайне... озадачило:
С одной стороны имеется действительно неплохой левелдизайн с кучей развилок, а с другой очень часто сталкиваешься с проблемой, что ты не можешь просто бежать и уклоняться за СКОРОСТНОГО персонажа, тебе нужно сбрасывать скорость, а защита, которая могла бы быть неплохим дополнением, местами превращается в обязательное условие для прохождения.
Имеется возможность какой то прокачки и покупки зелий и итемов, но в то же время штраф очками за их использование (что особенно забавно, если учесть, что никакого штрафа за активацию различной помощи из настроек нет)
Обилие боссов, но многие из них не то, что плохо сделаны, а сделаны невероятно жирными, больно бьющими имеющими УЖАСНУЮ арену и просто раздражающе душными.
Система жизней так же довольно странная, если в первой части ты копил жизни на протяжении всей игры, что позволяло тебе их накопить перед сложным боссом (привет Брейвон и мои потерянные 30+ жизней на нем при первой встрече), здесь же тебе дают по умолчанию их 3 и еще где то одну-две можно заработать за сбор очков, потерял все жизни - покупай за 500 кристаллов продолжение или начинай сначала (что выглядит просто издевательски на водном уровне, который я и так проходил минут 30, после чего еще и встретился с худшим боссом игры, который сочетал все проблемы прошлого абзаца).
Сюжет очень сильно расширяет лор, но в тоже время не имеет никакой глубины за собой и мне было намного менее интереснее за ним наблюдать, чем было в первой части.
Хаб позволяет поговорить с фоновыми персонажами (что на самом деле мне к третьему разу уже надоело), но довольно сильно сбивает темп и скорее мешает, а классик мод недосупен при первом прохождении.
Музыка неплоха, но кроме темы главгада особо не запомнился ни один трек, по сравнению с первой явно слабее.
Стилистика потеряла часть своей приятной атмосферы, став более детализированной, но это уже скорее моя вкусовщина, а вот странности с камерой, когда автозум приходится выкручивать на максимум что бы просто иметь возможность видеть и драться с боссом это действительно странно, иначе он прыгает за камерой.
Как итог, игра мне в целом понравилась, иначе бы я ее не прошел даже, но, к сожалению, намного меньше чем первую часть. Скорее всего я пройду ее за остальных персонажей и заброшу, в то время как к первой я все еще буду возвращаться временами.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050749385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 4170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 992, 'last_played': 1712238931}
review:
Ever wonder what games would look like if 3D didn't happen and major studios kept pouring the lion's share of their effort and resources into 2D games? Well you can stop wondering, cause Freedom Planet 2 is what that timeline looks like. Bigger, better, faster, stronger, everything about it screams "Extra."

The most immediate and striking improvement you'll notice is the pixel art. It is [b][i]ludicrously[/i][/b] detailed. On everything, from playable characters and stages down to each individual NPC and bossfight. You jaw will drop the first time you fight one of the larger bosses. Then it will keep going through the floor when you realize there's 39(!) of them. You'll also notice that almost everything has a unique track on the OST - each level, hub area, and subsection of the map has a unique, certified-GalaxyTrail-quality musical piece attached to it.

On the gameplay side of things, the addition of items and the guard button makes for combat that's easy to get into (just like the original) but satisfying to master for the game's later, more complex fights. And you'll have plenty of time to master it as well, on the whopping 24(!) levels that you'll be traversing. Their count does not diminish their quality - each one is tightly designed, with different tempo and memorable gimmicks to make them stand out. It also does not diminish the storytelling. Quite the opposite - the new episodic chapter approach makes it so the plot advances at a brisk pace, whilst also finding plenty of time to develop each character's personal stakes.

Throw in high replayability in the form of 4 playable characters, the ability to talk to over 100 NPCs (who all have unique sprites!), tons of extra challenges, and an effin' museum for the spritework, and you get a dizzyingly rich package for the asking price. The only possible flaw that I can think of is how that sheer size makes for less cohesive narration: The episodic format means that the player characters get a lot of air time, but the main conflict and villain do not. This can often leave you feeling like the story is... unfocused, that certain levels are unrelated side-quests at best, even though they are still mandatory. Other than that, though? Practically flawless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077776105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1663778873}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is 50% a great time 50% unnecessary additions and bloat. It's clear that a lot of passion and time went into a dream game but the developer was never told what ideas might be working and what would have been better to cut.

The template is the same as the first game. It's a heavily Sonic platforming game with some light combat elements. The core Sonic platforming is the strongest part and though the physics aren't quite as well tuned that's probably more of a consequence of more moving environment parts and it never broke in any significant way. There's a huge variety of levels with unique stage mechanics: one of my favourites being a giant bat that shoots you off a baseball miles across the stage. The main issue is everything else.

There are some stages that have more of a puzzle element, collecting machine parts or keys etc and sometimes these are interesting diversions and other times tedious chores. My main contention is the bosses which are memorable artistically and often conceptually but just aren't fun to play. It's like you are playing Megaman Zero bosses but without the deliberate and tight movement akin to that series (point stolen from Stu Gipp). It doesn't help that boss stages are often so large the enemy moves offscreen, potentially throwing 
attacks at the same time. I think I enjoyed only one or two bosses throughout my entire playthrough.

I should also touch on the story. It's very much bunk but unlike the first game which has a classic mode to skip through it, this one makes you play through the whole story first. I'm assuming you get classic mode after finishing the story. There is no option to fast forward the dialogue so you if the voices are driving you nuts, or you just read the text as quick as I do your options are either sit through or skip. I honestly don't think this games has a subtle enough touch to be talking about species genocide: maybe don't have the antagonist sporting Dr. Wily skull mechs as a minimum??

I've played about 7 hours of the game with one character, Lilac. In terms of content that's impressive because there's still three other characters with unique gimmiks. This would be great if I wasn't dreading taking those characters through the aforementioned aggravating parts. I didn't enjoy taking Lilac through the mecha piece hunt, getting dogpilled with enemies and walls/ground of spikes; why would I enjoy it with Milla?

There's some other issues to briefly touch on. The music is good but I don't think it's a cut on the original game. The pixel art is very detailed with wonderful animations but the background art can often be so cluttered that it's hard to tell what's foreground or not. 

It feels like GalaxyTrail is equally committed to undercutting it's great ideas as it to passionately crafting an engaging game. I really don't want to mark this down because it has so many fun ideas and level mechanics so I would say pick this up on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005558616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1677641365}

author: {'steamid': '76561198376337971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1706557900}
review:
At the time of writing this review before, I had not finished the game. I am updating it now to show that I have finished it on at least one character. I will say this: It isn't a perfect game, but the passion OOZES out of it. It plays incredibly smoothly and really pushes the player to get good. It does well to recapture the feel of the SNES and SEGA Genesis days, and some of their difficulty. I played it on the hardest difficulty to start with, and it was a painful journey, but it was worthwhile, as it really helped me improve my play. The Normal difficulty will be accessible to people starting the game off or just picking up the genre. The bosses are far more lenient without Hard Mode's doubled damage.

The Character designs are even better than they were in the first one, and it really feels like the voice-actors not only enjoyed voicing the characters but had genuine passion for the project. I can only really remark on playstyles I'm proficient with, and I have to say that I am bad at Lilac and Milla, though players good with them in the previous game will have an easy time using them in this one. Carol is a titanic step up from what she was in Freedom Planet 1. Her DPS is much higher, and her gameplay is more streamlined and intuitive. I cannot speak for fans of Carol with the Motorcycle, as I barely used it. To me, it feels and plays worse than without the Motorcycle, but I grew up playing Megaman X and Zero. Since Carol reminds me so much of Zero (Zero series on GBA) in gameplay, I really meshed well with it and it felt amazing to play as. Her kit is excellent, and, once an opening is found, she can eviscerate Boss' health bars with stunning ease. She really plays like a cat.

Neera is more sluggish, but she is a precision powerhouse. She is less agile but still quick, more relying on careful positioning than merely blasting through a stage with invincibility (though she is still capable in that regard). Players that like being close to enemies will like her, especially once they really get good with her slower attacks and utilizing her "Focus" self-buff.

The Guard System can be thought of as more of a Street Fighter Parry with massively lenient timing. It is required for some Boss fights, and makes some stages much easier, and it is very easy to use (I'm bad at parrying in Street Fighter but I got pretty good with it in this game. It's not hard).

The stage design is imperfect but pretty smooth for the most part. There were times where I got lost and questioned which way I was supposed to go, but a little exploration and a lot of going this way and that sorted it out. The terrain is a little frustrating in some places, as surfaces meant to be walked up vertically will throw the character at a sharp angle if a jump is done while running on the wall. Since some terrain behaves in such a way in Boss fights, it makes them unnecessarily difficult, and makes the losses inflicted by them feel unfair. That said, It's all very smooth barring that one hiccup and it will not stop me from recommending the game because it can be played around with even the barest amount of experience. Some enemy placement is annoying, though. On-screening an enemy and then feeling like there is no time to react as one takes damage from something one couldn't have possibly seen feels bad, though, again, it's not game-breaking and these instances don't occur often. The warning markers are a bit large, and, at one time, prevented me from seeing something I was supposed to be avoiding. Not perfect, but still able to be played around and still tons of fun.

The story is actually pretty decent for what this game is. The team respected the characters. They expanded on them and leaned into their personalities pretty hard. Carol was already my favorite, and, as a Carol fan, I was exceedingly well-pleased. I'd heard the same for Milla. I'm sure Lilac and Neera's characters are just as well-represented. As a bonus, Neera is actually likable in this game. Hints are dropped of developments in the other parts of the stories, so it really encourages the player to play through with all characters.

Merga is a villain that was done well with the narrative and "show, don't tell" techniques used. She was done far better than Brevon, but still, somehow, lacks his innate menace. That said, I really have very few complaints, if any, about the direction the story took. This is how a sequel should be done.

The music is excellent, by the way. Maybe not as punchy as some of the first Freedom Planet's tracks in some spots but definitely, DEFINITELY amazing. This OST is a whole lot better than the first Freedom Planet's. I only found a few of the themes not hitting as hard, and that was rare. I also was concentrating on tough boss patterns and trying not to die so I will have time now to appreciate the OST more since I'm not trying to survive something that will delete my health bar.

Games like this don't come along too often. Makers rarely have this kind of passion anymore and they rarely execute it even half as well. This is a sequel done right. This is what the Triple A industry can't seem to get right, and yet this little team of developers with gobs of passion and a fraction of the budget did amazingly well. This game is worth every penny and I am glad I could support it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031485109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 916, 'last_played': 1663982375}
review:
I had fun with the first game, but with Freedom Planet 2 I reached a point very quickly where I just wanted it to end, because it was getting so tiring.

The level design often gets confusing and doesn't convey well where you're supposed to head next contrary to the first game.
A lot of times the levels are littered with enemies and traps, which make it impossible to not take a hit. You can also see the developers acknowledge this will happen by adding health petals close to those spots so the player can compensate for the hits taken. This is not good level design.
The level design after a few stages feels flat out lazy and re-using gimmicks and enemies from older stages while the layouts get even more confusing, and the stages drag themselves to 10+ minutes each.
I'd rather have less stages that feel unique, shorter and fun than a lot of stages that feel like padding and filler.

The pixel art and animations are cute but the background gets overly detailed at times making hard to distinguish the characters from the backdrop elements.

I don't know why they changed Lilac's model so much from the first game, especially when all other characters only got slight updates, she looks weird to me now, like if she's wearing a wig. Lilac's appearance was already established with FP1 and all the other indie projects the character is in, so what gives?

Not fan of the bosses in the first game and seems they are even worse here.
Bosses have very erratic patterns, spam the screen with projectiles, barely announce their actions and often jump offscreen making the battle a chore.
I know there's a guard mechanic, but it's very finnicky and often results in you getting hit anyway, perhaps if they added a freeze-frame or a parry/counter mechanic then the guarding would make more sense.

For the music, I don't know what happened here. The first game had some really nice themes, especially boss battle ones. Minus a few tracks, this soundtrack feels too "soft" and afraid to push the bar. Very disappointed with the music.
The voice acting is better than the first game, but the cutscenes that they are used in are not very entertaining. Sometimes the voice clip quality sounds lower and more muffled for some reason.

There needs to be a fix for the gamepad. Perhaps add some profiles for it to support DPAD as well etc. I had to wrestle around with fixing the controls when I first launched the game. Not a good experience, especially when the icons do not really reflect the controller buttons.

Finally I got a few collision bugs, especially stuck when moving through loops or jump-through platforms. There's some instances where the collision area of some objects is larger than it should be and the character looks like they are standing on thin air. The game softlocked as well when I tried to pick the "Food" option in the inn at the palace area. I encountered a few audio glitches as well where a lot of sound effects were playing at the same time really loud. And in the final stages with the light on/off system the game lagged a lot and experienced graphical glitches (Had to restart the stage a couple times for them to be fixed).

The game might scratch the "classic Sonic platformer" itch for a little bit, but I wouldn't recommend this game over the first one, that's for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071387892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1671019152}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198296573903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1711150957}
review:
An ambitious, dense follow-up to Freedom Planet, which doubles down on every element that makes the original game great. For reference, I finished the game as Lilac. 

Pros:
[list]
[*] The level design has been turned up to 11. There's so much variety in level-specific mechanics. 
[*] Engaging story, supported by high-quality performances. I particularly loved Lilac's voice. This comes from someone who only played 1 on Classic mode. 
[*] Movement and combat is as great as before. The new thing here is the guard move, which serves to enhance the game's flow, by letting you i-frame through a lot of obstacles. 
[*] ~10 hours for one playthrough, which is far more than what most Sonic games offers. I haven't touched the other characters yet, but there seems to be more content / story hidden in these other paths, as well as true ending path. 
[*] The visual presentation is fantastic. Backgrounds look incredible, and animations are smoother than before. 
[*] The bosses are all well designed and fun, and none felt annoying / gimmicky to fight. 
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] World map is confusing to move through, since it's split into separate areas. 
[*] Hub levels felt a little hollow (just some NPCs and shops). 
[*] Some pacing issues in the 2nd act. Story just kinda stops for a while, and the levels seemed to have a higher focus on puzzles than speed. 
[*] The non-stop bosses were exhausting. I think they should have reserved bosses for the end of each "episode", as I got tired of fighting them in every single level. 
[/list]

Rating: 9/10, easily one of my favourite games of 2022.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009312125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1687054345}
review: This game is exactly what it looks like on the tin. It's a spiritual successor to Sonic 3 & Knuckles with a smattering of the Megaman X series thrown in. If you love old-school Sonic and are willing to swap a bit of speed for more platforming, this game is 100% it.

Sabrina, you and your team gave us a work of art that I'm going to remember for a long time, and one I'm DEFINITELY going to replay and recommend to others. author: {'steamid': '76561197992776583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 334, 'playtime_forever': 2688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 894, 'last_played': 1703894583}
review:
Fantastic sequel. Takes the first game, makes it bigger, and INJECTS IT WITH DRAGON STEROIDS!

The new:
- World map
- Hub levels (First game was supposed to have them, but were cut, and I see why, because they are HILARIOUSLY glitchy)
- Equippable accessories and passive potion charges that alter various stats/effects (but appear to degrade your rank, because REAL MEN DON'T EQUIP RPG TRINKETS TO MAKE THE GAME EASIER (I am not a real man apparently)
- 1 new playable character (Neera)
- Generally improved combat, as well as a new Dodge/dash function. It works pretty well. I am now going to go back to the first game and try pressing the nonexistent dodge button in vain.
- And a bunch more.

I'd say the difficulty of bosses are overall a bit harder than the first game's (minus pre-nerf steroido Brevon of FP1), but the ability to dodge-dash makes bosses more tight. Most bosses are fought in the middle or end of a stage, but every now and then it pulls a Klonoa 2, and puts a boss only stage on the map, which is neat, more games like that should do this, at least at times. Speaking of Klonoa 2, just like FP1, some levels do indeed drag on for quite a bit, which I'm fine with, but some people like their bite sized levels. Good old Klonoa 2/Freedom Planet level syndrome.

In the hub levels, there's tons of charming characters to talk to for lots of optional dialogue. Soooo many npcs.

[spoiler] Lilibeth's abs are ROCK HARD, I wanna SKATE ON THOSE ABSOLUTELY DENSE BOAR ABS OOOOOOOOOOH! [/spoiler] 

Some of the characters are designed by Tyson Tan, which I somewhat know from DA eons ago, his artstyle is cool and all, but sometimes its "Hyper cute", whereas I prefer the more consistent artstyle of the first game (Although, I'd say the artstyle of this game is generally better, and certainly more detailed). Whenever I saw something that looked overly Tyson-Tan-y, it kind of took me out of it (both in a good and bad way). Especially that one mech fight. I'm like "Oh no, it's The Tyson Tan Mech" weirdly enough, it's the boss I had the most trouble with, needed like 2-3 continues, didn't think I needed even 1 continue for every other boss. I feel kinda funny now for getting my ass handed to me by something so cute.


[spoiler] Snake: I didn't think you'd be so... cute. [/spoiler] 

Speaking of lives, you can't horde them like you could in the first game, but on the flip side, you always start with a few every level (can be increased with a potion effect), as well as having the choice of using a life to start from last checkpoint with full health, or start off exactly where you died, but with low hp (hp recovery can also be increased with a potion effect).

How the potions work is that they are passive, you do not actively drink them. There are 5 slots to put whatever potion effect you want, you could have 1 charge of 5 different effects, or 2/3 charges of 2 different effects, or 5 charges with 1 effect, if you want to focus on your favored effect. Makes me feel like a Witcher mixing these potion charges into the bottle. Milla is a Witcher confirmed.

You can buy potions/accessories/music from various shops in various towns, by spending either gems, as found in the first game, or enemy cores, dropped by most enemies, or gold pieces, which can be bought with gems/cores, and sometimes found in chests. Several accessories can also be found in chests, but most of them make the game harder in exchange for a bigger gem bonus (reminds me of Supergiant difficulty gimmicks)

The music is superb as usual, the levels are fairly similar to FP1's in structure, you have your normal/action stages, puzzle stages, some key item hunty stages, and sometimes a mix of the above. As well as a few SCHMUP stages, just like the first game. That one mech schut stage was pretty ridiculous/chaotic and kind of glitchy. Loved it.

The voiceacting is as good as the first's, there's a good lot more of it, and the main villain is likeable and sympathetic [spoiler] and very hot [/spoiler]. Unlike the first game's villain which was just SCUMSCUMSCUM that you love to hate. I like me a good hateable villain (Brevon), but I usually prefer the more likeable ones that you can sympathize with.

There's also some neat twists in the story. Such as the Magister revealing his face 
[spoiler] Oh no, he's hot. [/spoiler]

review: This game is incredible. It's been in dev hell for ages and honestly I was iffy about it just from that, but it blew me away - dev hell does not seem to have hurt it, if anything it's *incredibly* polished, great ost. Everything that made FP1 amazing is here, *with some actual improvements too*. The extra effort on world building is great. The sprite animations and spritework are ridiculously fluid and it feels so satisfying to play. Also Lilac is gorgeous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162960171', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 102, 'playtime_at_review': 1156, 'last_played': 1712455361}
review:
110% worth the wait. Little sis and I loved the first minus some corny dialogue; what an upgrade GalaxyTrail delivers the writing department. Planet 1 ran so Planet 2 rocketed to the moon in identity and charm. So smooth can see Planet 1 fans who struggled or didn't like could pick up Planet 2 no problem, big respect the Planet franchise-fanbase.

Planet 2's community and Avalice's world feels ever more complete. Cheers Planet 3 the future or whatever magic Trail brings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977884236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1679101381}
review:
A modern masterpiece. This game should set the standard for all other games in its devotion to just [u]letting players have fun[/u] in whatever ways they want to.

There is an insane amount of quality and polish to the game, even on day 1 of release. It is obviously a labor of love and that is felt through the way its design meets players at whatever level they want to engage with it. Do you just like platforming? Here's ~30 stages for you to run through with unique set pieces like low gravity, air bubbles, boosters, darkness, etc. Quick-reflex combat? Got tons of that with a huge variety of bosses. Story? Dive in or just skip it if you want. Achievements and challenge modes? Go wild. Favor different play styles? There's 4 unique characters you can be. Find the game too easy or difficult? There's assist options and items which augment the difficulty. Speedrunning? Plenty of in-game timers and record trackers available. 

It's just.... overwhelming. There's [i]so much[/i] here. There's a museum of collectibles to fill up. There's a photo mode that I don't know who asked for but it's in here! There's hidden collectibles that unlock multiple endings. There's a jukebox. There's dozens of unique fully animated NPCs with distinct character. Basically every single thing from the previous game has been refined and improved to make gameplay more fun and dynamic: cancelable dragon boosts, instant Milla cubes, a guard / instashield button, a broader moveset in general like Lilac's up-slash, Carol's Jump Disc and bike stashing... and also she's actually fun to play as now ( :-P ). Neera adds yet another playstyle to the mix. Bosses do that thing I love where they're actually involved in the course of the whole level and not just showing up out of nowhere at the end. For the most part their fights are fun (maybe just a bit pattern-heavy) but there are a few stinkers (pretty much any water-based boss...) Those are balanced out by the few that had really unique mechanics or were just eye-popping WOWZA the whole way through.

There's a lot more I can say about specific things but I want to keep this somewhat brief. Freedom Planet 2 is an easy Game of the Year 2022 for me, and if you ask me in a few months I will probably agree it is one of the finest games I have played in my life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198812870813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 856, 'last_played': 1676777779}
review:
Just finished it as Lilac. The game absolutely blew me away on multiple occasions. The levels are many but are fun, unique, and varied. Combat mechanics are refined, so many bosses and yet they're all unique and fun to fight. 

There were so many times where I truly felt like "now I can see why this game took so long!" I really think GalaxyTrail went above and beyond with this game!

My biggest gripe would have to be the last two levels. Just like FP1, the last couple of levels feel unfairly difficult. It throws so many enemies your way and traps (like spikes on grind rails while you're going super fast so barely any time to avoid them). These levels did have unique mechanics just like the rest of the game which is very impressive considering the high level count in this game but yeah I think the last two could've been a bit more polished.

There were also a few levels where I couldn't figure out how to progress for some time due to unclear objective/path so I think that could've been made a bit more clear.

The story won't blow your socks off but as someone who isn't crazily obsessed with finding the best writing ever in video games (like so many gamers tend to be...) I very much enjoyed it. Lots of high stakes and emotional moments. The dialogue is heavily refined from the first game and there are lots of really neat reveals about the characters we know and love from the first game. 

The music was, as usual, really good but unfortunately nothing really stuck out to me as much as FP1's soundtrack. Still the composer did an excellent job.

I hear lots of people have ran into bugs and personally I haven't experienced anything too bad or annoying. I did have trouble setting up my PS3 controller using the Playstation button icons. Lots of the buttons displayed in the game did not match what I pressed on my controller. However, setting the icons back to the default "numbers" made everything a non-issue. I think its worth bringing up to people reading this that, for now as of writing this review on 9/16/2022, you shouldn't bother trying to change icons. Just stick to the numbers!

All in all, I think the game was very much worth the wait. Definitely one of my favorite 2D platformers of all time now. I replayed FP1 many times because it's just really fun to play but now I don't think I ever see myself going back to it and instead probably going to replay this game a whole bunch from now on! Thanks GalaxyTrail!

author: {'steamid': '76561198083997754', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2494, 'last_played': 1709845961}
review: After beating the game with all 4 characters and unlocking the true ending. I can confirm that after 7 years in the making, GalaxyTrail have pulled off EXACTLY what a 2D fast paced platformer and what a squeal are supposed to be. Freedom Planet 2 Expands HEAVILY on what the first game brought to the table and as a result, This is hands down the best platformer I've ever played. The same fast paced action is back along with the lovable and memorable characters from the 1st game plus some new faces as well. Freedom Planet 2 adds so much more to the franchise while making sure to still feel as amazing to play as the 1st game if not completely better. I wrote on my review of the first game that I would recommend freedom planet 1 over most Sonic games and the same applies here. Freedom Planet 2 is a game made by a team who wanted to make the best game they possibly could and they damn well delivered. It feels so amazing and nostalgic to finally return to the world of Avalice with such a bang! My hat goes off to everyone at GalaxyTrail. Thanks to you guys, Freedom Planet has easily become one of my favourite franchises and both games have become some of my favourite games of all time. There isn't and probably never will be anything else like Freedom Planet 2. It truly is a masterpiece. Round of applause for everyone involved. Now go take one hellva holiday. You guys have earned it. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198057055911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1893, 'last_played': 1663805047}
review:
An amazing masterpiece of a sequel to one of my favorite speedy action platformers of all time. I played the original Freedom Planet, and waited 7 long years for Freedom Planet 2. 

I appreciate the transition from linear classic story progression to branching adventure quests that meet back together into a main path after completion, while exploring various maps with town hubs in between...There are also plenty of items that you can alter gameplay with as you unlock more shops, whether to aid you or to make the game much more challenging which is sometimes required to get the highest ranks.

Boss battles are notably memorable and numerous as well in Freedom Planet 2. Many bosses follow a changing pattern, however the boss 'characters' that you can battle are surprisingly responsive and certainly provide that spike in difficulty when a change of pace is needed. Not only that, you can fight the bosses again later after a certain amount of progression.

All four main characters are unique and dynamic from everything I've tested. The only things I can say I find lacking, is that I want more playable characters if there aren't any or some kind of online or local PVP character fighting arena...

Regardless, the swath of gameplay additions and improvements to Freedom Planet 2 enrich the experience enough as is. The upgrade in graphics certainly has done wonders in the sprites and artwork too. 

10/10 I will be taking my time playing this game, that way I can enjoy it for long as I can.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992898485', 'num_games_owned': 1865, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1663530256}
review:
Después de seis años de espera, por fin llega la secuela del estupendo Freedom Planet.

[hr][/hr]
El juego no se basa solo en velocidad, en algunas fases toca explorar, saber por dónde ir y también hay que pelear contra los enemigos. Este no es como el juego del famoso erizo azul, aquí los enemigos aguantan un par de golpes, así que ya puedes atacarles con garras, armas o lo que use tu personaje. Arrollarlos también sirve (y es muy satisfactorio). De hecho, el juego se parece más a los juegos de TREASURE (como Gunstar Heroes o Alien Soldier) que a los del erizo azul, y esto se nota mucho más en las batallas contra los jefes, que son auténticas batallas y no saltar rodando encima de los robots de un científico.
[hr][/hr]
Para cada fase tienes dos vidas, da igual cómo acabases la fase anterior, siempre empiezas con dos vidas y cada 250 cristales te dan una extra. Esto influye en la puntuación, pero también influye cuando te derrotan, ya que tienes la opción de volver al último punto de control o de revivir al momento con muy poca vida (se pueden usar objetos para revivir con más vida). Ideal para cuando un jefe te derrota cuando le queda solo un golpe.
[hr][/hr]
Tienes cuatro personajes a elegir, cada uno con sus habilidades y movimientos propios. No es lo mismo jugar una fase con uno o con otro:
  - Lilac es la más rápida y puede impulsarse en cualquier dirección, incluso desde el aire.
  - Carol utiliza un yoyó para impulsarse al estilo ninja, puede usar unas plataformas especiales para moverse, puede escalar paredes como Megaman X y tiene una moto que desafía las leyes de la física.
  - Milla utiliza sus poderes psíquicos para protegerse, atacar e incluso impulsarse. También es super adorable.
  - Neera tiene una lanza y problemas controlando su ira. También controla el hielo.
[hr][/hr]
El juego tiene una historia que no te esperas, la historia de la anterior entrega estaba bastante bien ya que ofrecía más de lo que esperarías en una historia para un plataformas. No obstante esta secuela va más allá, continúa la historia y no deja de darte sorpresas. También puedes investigar el trasfondo del universo del juego, y es bastante rico.
[hr][/hr]
Los personajes no jugables también son super carismáticos y los principales están doblados, dándoles mucha personalidad.
[hr][/hr]
Puedes personalizar tu estilo de juego con objetos y pociones. Renuncias a bonus de puntuación pero desarrollas tu estilo de juego, a menos que sean objetos que suban la dificultad.
[hr][/hr]
Si tu primera partida te puede durar alrededor de diez horas con un solo personaje, te puedes hacer a la idea de lo que te puede durar con los cuatro. Tómatelo con calma.
[hr][/hr]

Si no sabes si darle una oportunidad, juega a la primera entrega, que cuesta menos, juégalo, disfrútalo (dura algo más de cuatro horas con un personaje, y ese tiene tres) y luego lánzate a por este.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094655342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1664130034}

author: {'steamid': '76561198117953718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 902, 'last_played': 1689358563}
review:
Well, the game was worth the wait. But did it live up to my personal expectations?
Not quite sadly. It's still quite good but there are some issues that sadly soured my experience with the game especially nearing the end and prevented it from being great to me.

Well let's start with some of the good:
- The story is quite good, the comedic scenes made me laugh sometimes (otherwise atleast grin) but the serious parts were more earned than the first game
- The presentation of the game is quite good, the artstyle is unique and really colorful
- The game has loads of fun gimmicks that kept each level fresh
- The hubworlds were a welcome addition which made the world of Avalice feel more alive
- The game has a big cast of main characters and more minor characters

Now for the bad:
- I like the new artstyle but it made it really hard to see what was in the foreground and in the background in some levels. Causing me to get stuck, not understand where I could land or even die
- I ran into quite some bugs that usually were to my disadvantage (once it helped me beat a boss though) - though with all the patches coming out this should get better with time
- The music clearly does not loop, which is very noticeable in some levels
- Most of the hubworlds were fun but I wish there were some more things to do
- Some parts of the story felt "off" to me (one choice seemed to lessen the impact of the main villain to me)
- Some levels were kinda annoying to beat (the puzzle based levels mostly)

Back to some great stuff to finish this review:
- That title screen is just amazing, when a game opens up like that you know if will be good
- The game is very well balanced each boss encounter felt like a threat but not straight up impossible (Playing as Lilac)
- 80% of the levels were very fun to play and had loads of very cool features
- The game has tons of moments where the WOW factor really was present (elevating it the best 2D platformer game you can find gameplay wise)
- I like the episode format, gives more choice and personality to the world
- There are loads of nice little references for long time fans, which felt very earned after replaying the first game
- There are loads of fun levels making the game really worth the asking price (heck it may even be too cheap for what you are getting)

If I would give this game a grade... I would give it around 7.5/10
Definitely recommended

review: I LOVED this game! Even though I spent 10 hours just to beat it, I was still OVERJOYED for this game to come out! When it came out, tears came to my eyes, and I immediately bought it. I was crying in happiness when I first played it, since the graphics were so great, and the music was so great, and absolutely EVERYTHING was great about this game. I cannot express how happy I was for this game to come out. People might assume I'm a simp for some of the characters, but really, I'm not! I'm a simp for the music. Really, this game is an absolute freaking M A S T E R P I E C E. I highly recommend this game to all of you who loved the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042438869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1684550270}
review:
It's Freedom Planet 1, one of my favorite platformers I've ever played, but turned up to 11.
It's super polished, full of depth, replayable, full of groovy music...
My only criticism so far is that the difficulty can be a little spiky sometimes. But there are a ton of options to make the game easier.

author: {'steamid': '76561199101253156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1664865976}
review:
Going into this, already being a massive fan of the first game, it would have taken something truly special to blow me away like the first game did. But, not only did Freedom Planet 2 live up to the first game, it surpassed it in every conceivable way. No, it went even beyond that.
The genuine surprise and joy of playing Freedom Planet 2 doesn't come from saying "Wow! This is like if Treasure made a Sonic game" it comes from the realization that this game is BETTER than that hypothetical game! Every element comes at you with the energy of what had to be the happiest game makers on the planet. There's ALWAYS something new coming at you, and with the quality of the art, music, level design, enemies, and game feel, you'll be surprised to know the amount of content this game has. 

Freedom Planet to just about triples the amount of content from the first game, and that's not counting the fact that there's 1 more character, and 2 more adventure campaign stories than last time. This could have easily been a $40.00 price tag, but at it's current price, it's more than a steal.

This game puts FREEDOM in Freedom Planet. The movement options and level design go together so well, you'll find yourself in a constant loop of speed, exploration, discovery, and combat ALL AT THE SAME TIME!

To all video game fans out there, this is a genuine victory for the industry, and not something you should pass up. In a year with Sifu, Bayonetta 3, and God of War Ragnarok, Freedom Planet 2 will still probably speed away with my game of the year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198349646141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1665928686}
review: 直接玩的2，感觉还可以，高速移动的时候挺爽

author: {'steamid': '76561197985286690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1663523752}
review:
Great! Better Sonic Game than Sonic games!
Im being serious!

Cleared the game first time as Milla.
Anyways, the worst parts of the game in my opinion is still the camera not zooming out enough normally. I know what that does to the sprites, but I feel like the game could have had the camera out a little more without the sprites going nuts. I feel like I get hit by offscreen bullets and enemies very often.

Some levels are just so big I cant wrap my head around memorizing them. Some parts feel the same in the same level, making it difficult to properly have the levels be recognizable and have a signature. Well, its great in the art department. But the largeness really make them slightly hard to put in mind. The water levels are actually pretty damn good I must say.

The story is also much better. I cringed a lot in the first one, but this time I can forgive it because its actually not too linear of a story.

I feel as if the music is not as memorable but that could be me.

The art is absolutely great tho! Cute animations! Awesome characters! Even just random npcs look pretty fleshed out. Its great!

Pretty lengthy story mode. As you can see, I beat the game in about... 8-9 hours. Is this normal? Was I slow? Regardless, I hope to try beating the game several times as the different characters. Carol was my favourite in the first and from what I tried shes still incredibly good. Although I do think Milla is still the advanced cheater character hehe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025417603', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 2216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1691712112}
review:
This game is just as incredible as the first one. From its ridiculously detailed sprite work to its optimistic, sincerely-told story, the whole package drips with dedication to and reverence for a special era of video games. My experience playing Freedom Planet 2 is additionally elevated by its grounding in Chinese mythology, which lends the game a familiar vibe that I have always wished more games would employ.

I think this game is worth far more than its full asking price. It consistently punches above its weight class is basically every aspect, from aesthetics to mechanics to level design to music. I highly recommend playing this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198387121965', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1668174199}
review: El mejor sucesor de Sonic! Exelente historia, dialogos, jugabilidad, animacion y por supuesto LA BANDA SONORA!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198972146385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1664509781}
review:
A Spectacular Sequel to one of my favorite 2D Platformer games of all time, the writing and voice acting is as top notch as ever. Amazing gameplay improvements and the story is more ambitious and exciting. the 7 Year wait has really paid off. it's got much more replay value, and gets you in with every second. from the stunning visuals and cute sprite work. I totally recommend this to anyone who loves the first one, and wants a good story to go along with it.

best advice is to start off on beginner difficulty if you want to have a fun experience for your first playthrough.

Thank You, Sabrina & Galaxy Trail. you have made this GOTY for me. cannot wait to see what the future awaits for this series, I be down for a 3rd game if it ever were to happen.

10/10
