author: {'steamid': '76561198329980672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 10913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 574, 'playtime_at_review': 10338, 'last_played': 1712292998}
review:
This is everything i could ever want in a video game. Cute/likable characters, fun levels, fantastic music (like the first game), did i mention a WHOLE lot of charm and cuteness, and the most satisfying momentum I've ever had the pleasure of playing with.

 I want to start first with the levels, because the levels in this game are UNMATCHED with how creative and fun each one is. For example one of my personal favorite stages is lightning tower cause the whole gimmick is its COMPLETELY vertical which doesn't sound fun at first but combined with the games excellent flow and the wonderful level design it ends up playing like a dream, and ancestral forge is super fun as well because it has very neat puzzle gimmicks and it pulls it off in a PLATFORMER its not what you would expect to be fun but it just clicks and that flow that i mentioned earlier is still present here too.  despite there being around 30 levels. 30 is kinda an exaggeration because there is some boss levels (6 or 5 i think) which take up some of the level slots but there is still alot of content to chew through if you just want to flow through the game YET it still takes me just under 2 hours to finish the game even with experience and some knowledge relating to skips and whatnot.

 Now to continue i want to talk about the main cast and how they feel to play as, starting with the main gal herself LILAC. Lilac retains all of her moveset  from the 1st game and gains 2 new abilites which includes: Dragon boost, upward and downward air attacks, and her crouch attacks. But also now has the ability to cancel her dragon boost called the boost breaker to create a area/cloud that does ALOT of damage when you use it on bosses its also really nice you dont have to go through the whole duration of the boost if you use it at the wrong time or bump a wall. But for my own take i personally think her move set is  a bit too weighty and sluggish to use in this game despite it being nearly exactly the same compared to her FP1 counterpart, but i think the reason why i feel this way is cause the levels expanded to compensate for the faster and floater gameplay and sadly Lilacs move set just doesn't cut it for me. doesn't mean i hate it though it still gets a solid 3rd place when compared to the others.

 Next we got Carol....... CAROLS MOVESET IS BATSHIT INSANE WHAT I MEAN BY THAT IS HER JUMP DISK AND HER UPWARD AND DOWNWARD ATTACKS ARE SO BUSTED, SHE IS BY FAR THE BEST AND MOST FUN CHARACTER TO PLAY OUT OF THE CAST. FOR EXAMPLE HER WALL JUMPS TRIVIALIZE LIGHTNING TOWER AND ANCESTRAL FORGE ITS SO NUTS... ahem sorry i was a little carried away but you get my point I easily give Carol the gold motor bike and 1st place as my favorite character to play, and shes always my pick when returning to the game to play some levels or to just have fun with the story and shes the most funny tbh. 

NEXT we have Milla. Im just gonna say this now im not sure if i like her unique style of fighting or dislike it sometimes it can feel finicky to use but its still faster than Lilacs moveset so ill take less traditional fighting and movement style over Lilacs. But hey her move set (and health) now is leagues better than the 1st game where it was nightmare to play any level but aqua tunnel or relic maze. Which is why im giving Milla the 2nd place spot for the me having fun tier list.

 Lastly Neera. I know shes a newcomer but overall her moves arent bad per say but she feels the most restrictive to play as i think a lot of that has to with the fact even though she has a built in double jump she practically has NO way of gaining vertical height. She has everything else though like great attack potential and how fast she can go on horizontal paths is breath taking but its the fact she has no vertical and something i failed to mention but i will now is she has to get super close to targets in order to deal damage with some exceptions being her ice shoot attack (Sniper Drive), and the upward special attack (Tundra Ray). Even with those few rare attacks its not enough to make her that fun to play, she just kinda feels awkward which sucks to say cause she has CRAZY potential, imagine her with carols wall jumps.

Well thats about it i know i didn't talk about some things in this review but i wanted to get the REALLY important thoughts and feelings out on this review TL;DR Level design is good (Lightning Tower) Ancestral Forge) and Carol is my favorite Milla is 2nd Lilac is 3rd and Neera needs to be improved.

author: {'steamid': '76561198998802539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1673023690}
review:
前作よりもテンポがよく、程よく初見殺し要素もあって楽しめる

author: {'steamid': '76561198074876127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1712239269}
review:
It's better polished, larger and more ambitious in scope, has even more gorgeous pixel art, has even more clever level design, and is better written to boot.

Controller support upon first booting up is... baffling but won't take more than 5 to 10 minutes to fix. Some sounds are way too loud because they're actually 12 instances of the same sound playing at once. One specific level is just a tad clunky to play at a certain setpiece. There are a few minor bugs here and there.

Those are all of the outstanding negatives. And most of them are already known of by the developers and being addressed in extant or coming patches.

All in all this is a textbook sequel in all the ways that matter. If you like classic Sonic, classic Genesis platformers, or just the first Freedom Planet, this is a must-get. The seven years of development were very well spent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141530668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 756, 'last_played': 1666919288}
review:
So I flipped it with Carol, Lilac and Milla (halfway with Milla). And got both endings with Carol just today, since I got most of the stuff with her. This is a complete update on my rating now that I've flipped the game completely so I will just put it with a sentence, Pros and Cons.

So visuals are great, music may be mostly remixes of the first game (very subtle Sonic vibes on some stages, but I still like the soundtrack regardless. There are still some bangers here; The volcanic caves (Boss is that whale on a ball) being my most favorite stage/ song track. Gameplay is ok, started off terrible when the game first launched but the current patches have helped alot. I don't know what it is about this game, but Lilac is kind of Un-Lilackable. That part with the mouse bomb.... omg


PROS

Graphics/visuals - The graphics have improved very much from the first one and separates clearly from FP1. 9/10

Music - As stated earlier, songs are mostly remixes from the first game, but I say those remixes were still great to hear in the game. 10/10

Gameplay - Pretty decent gameplay 5/10 (will be explained in Cons for low rating)

Boss fights (some) - Some boss fights were kind creative and I enjoyed the creativity/ 6/10

Hub/town interactions - pretty cool on the first gameplay, something new to the whole thing, I guess. 4/10

Carol Tea - I only used Carol to get everything: Game startoff, Battlesphere, flipping game twice (normal and true route) hey, Team Carol all the way. 10/10.


CONS

Bugs/glitches - I understand the team poured their heart and soul into this sequel and I thank you guys from the bottom of my heart, but for a game that was pushed back for 7 years, I truly expected to see very little to no glitches/bugs in the game. Before my re-edit of this post I mentioned that it killed the game for me: it still does. Patches are being done, but not completely in the right spots. I honestly before the patch could not clear Mach Madness because of some bug that didn't allow the enemies to respond during the waves. This part alone has made me dub this the Cyberpunk of 2D scrollers and I'm giving this section a 2/10.

Gameplay - The cons of gameplay was the launch day; inputs were so weird on ps4 controller ( 1,2,3, etc.) it was awful, Changing the controls to how I wanted the buttons (Jump, action,special, etc) mapped in a certain way somehow mapped right to up and left to down. I haven't been complaining about guard since I always used assist, but from the beta before the game ever came out it's really out of place for this type of platform game. It was more fluent in FP1 1/10

Level Design - Most of the levels had decent design, but some of them, the Bakunawa stage with the warps was probably the worst. The catchy song could not save the design even if it tried. 2/10

Hub/town - After Flipping game with one character, it gets very tedious and boring to keep talking to these people. I think it would've been cool characters with lightbulbs gave side missions to reward player with time capsules, instead of shoving them all in battle sphere. 1/10

Battlesphere - As mentioned above, I hated how all the time capsules were shoved into battlesphere, its like all the development went solely into the battlesphere, which is probably why it took 7 years to kind of complete the game. So Cordelia just spent all her time leaving messages in the battlesphere for anyone to find?? That's what it felt like to me. 2/10

Time capsules (SPOILER ALERT!!!!!) - I'm really mixed about this... I think it would've been better to have side missions with NPCs with light bulbs to get the other time capsules. On top of that, The log entries themselves felt pointless; True ending still felt pretty empty, as there are still some questions that are left unanswered within this game's lore. I've seen some other reviews, they say it's optional. It's not, its mandatory LGBT. I have nothing against it, but all of year 2022 Hollywood has been shoving it down my throat in their movies, even game companies. It has gotten to the point that I am just tired of seeing it... I have to give this part a 1/10


VERDICT

Now This is not a bad game, I would recommend it after a few more patches, because the best review is your own. The reason It still has a downvote for me is because of all the cons I mentioned; They just urked me to Avalice Kingom come... I really didn't want to downvote this game, honest. But it's just so many flaws that's not balanced out well.

I guess my rating still stands from before, as it's how it feels to me: 5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146436345', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1695196878}
review:
10小时通关了Carol的普通结局，还有隐藏结局未打，总体来说非常棒！
（后面开了游戏内的无限续关，因为太难了，最终关我甚至续了9次币）

给出的评价是推荐买，人物都画得很好（不只是主角和几个主要配角，还包括NPC），其次是比起一代，本作多了相当多的剧情展开，除了战斗场景，还有不少的和平场景供探索和浏览，而不只是像一代那样单纯走过场动画，同时，每个场景都画得相当精良，可以看得出本作是非常用心的作品，得益于上述三点，这个游戏能够非常充分地展现FP2的世界观。

从关卡设计上来看，本作总体关卡长度比1代长了不少，还多了很多以前都没有尝试过的新元素，本作最值得说的就是解谜（同时也是最让人头疼的），例如某关要在水中反复调整水位，不断插拔钥匙，还要对付难缠的敌人，这可以说是令人感觉十分新颖，也可以说是非常头疼，因为以前从没有这样的玩法设计，也不需要一边打一边解谜，如果你不喜欢，后面几关势必会让你十分头疼，因为或多或少包含了一些解谜元素，而如果你喜欢，你肯定会感觉十分有趣，毕竟有不少关卡是要边打边解谜的。
另外，本作还加了一些新的关卡类型，例如竞技场（没怎么打过）还有训练场，训练场让你能够与不同的角色进行对抗，这是1代所没有的玩法，竞技场没咋玩过，不太确定是什么样的。

除了上述的关卡设计，本作还在玩法上多了一个很大的不同，加了一个无敌护盾，这是你无伤通过某些关卡的重要打法，有的弹幕十分密集，如果不借助护盾，要想无伤会非常困难，而护盾则降低了通过的难度，但是护盾也不意味着无敌，因为护盾是瞬时释放，极短持续时间和一定的CD。Carol的大招方式也有所修改（相对于FP1），体验上肯定是与1代完全不一样的了。

如果你确实十分喜欢这个游戏而又担心自己能否玩通关，那么你可以放心了，因为本作修改了一些设定，例如生命条耗尽后可以选择从检查点满血复活或者原地丝血复活，释放无敌护盾的设定，额外加了4个辅助设定，其中就有最重要的，无限原地复活，即便是手残党（比如我）也是绝对可以通关的。

总的来说，是一个质量上乘的作品，值得票价。

author: {'steamid': '76561198065677162', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1663713644}
review:
If you're new to the series I would recommend playing the first game, it's not needed per se but it's not too long and still very good.

Overall this sequel is really good. The creativity is off the charts, every single level you're facing several new mechanics and ways to move around the map. I would say the level flow is slightly worse than the first game, a few times I got a little lost in my first playthrough. The art is exceptional, the first game wasn't bad but this is about as good as it can get in this style. Overall though I waited 7 years for this to release and I was not disappointed. Will probably try to 100% this game eventually

review:
Freedom Planet 2 is one of the best games i have ever played, 9.5/10 easily
Freedom Planet 1 was already great, but in Freedom Planet 2, the music, the artstyle, the graphics, the gameplay, the story, the level design, it has all gotten better, it was worth the wait, and i had more fun with this game than any other game released this year so far as of the moment i'm writing this
Of course it's not for everyone, but if you love fast platformers and cheesy but endearing stories, you'll love this

author: {'steamid': '76561199004546959', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1700345221}
review:
Já Início esta analise com isso: 7 ANOS DE ESPERA QUE VALERAM A PENA

Vamos lá Freedom Planet 2, um dos jogos mais esperados por mim e cara embora tenha demorado muito valeu a pena, bom nesta analise vou seguir os seguintes tópicos que são: Gráficos, Chefes, Personagens e a Dificuldade 

-Começando pelos Gráficos 

Os Gráficos estão muito bonitos se o primeiro já tinha uma pixel art bonita, então nesta sequência estão melhores ainda.

-Dificuldade 

Cara eu te falo mesmo no normal o jogo está bem desafiante e no momento que estou publicando está analise, ainda não joguei no expert, mas uma coisa e certa no normal o jogo já esta desafiante mesmo.

-Personagens 

Os personagens estão muito bons e queria detalhar uma coisa a dublagem do jogo está muito boa, dá pra sentir a emoção nas palavras de cada personagem e a nova vilã e muito boa também e além do mais os personagens ao decorrer do jogo amadurecem e muito.

-Chefes 

Olha os chefes estão bem desafiadores, tive dificuldade com muitos no normal, inclusive o chefe final foi um dos mais dificeis ou então o mais dificil tive que usar muitos cristais do jogo para conseguir zerar.

Olha pra mim o jogo vale o seu preço e a nota que eu dou é 10/10 realmente um jogo muito bom, e sim roda nessa sua batata computadorizada, kkkkk

Bom esta foi a analise e espero ter te convencido flw.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125951873', 'num_games_owned': 662, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1663274154}
review:
It's fun. I was kinda iffy on the voice acting in the first game, and I think its improved this time around. Pixel art is gorgeous, levels are sprawling albeit a little confusing, and gameplay is as fluid as ever.

Maybe I missed it but i would have liked a level only mode from the start though. I kinda don't care about the story and just want to blast through it like a genesis game, but I'm not gonna knock the game for that at all.

It's a very good game, and a good year for people who like sonic styled games. This year alone we got Spark the Electric Jester 3 and Freedom Planet 2, on top of some stuff from sega. I'm quite happy about that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198174155399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1669933049}
review:
Грех не оставить отзыв после такого длительного ожидания выхода 2 части >w<
Я редко во что либо играю, но FP это исключение. Игра изначально зацепила своей красочностью, персонажами и сюжетом. Возможно 2 часть чуть мягче чем была 1, если сравнивать по событиям и то что было с Лайлак и Миллой, но тем не менее стоила такого долгого ожидания ^w^ Единственное что местами смущает - это цветовая палитра некоторых локаций, в первой части цвета были более яркими и насыщенными кажется, но это не критично. Очень хочется верить что игра будет развиваться и дальше как и ее лор ♥ Прям вот запало в сердечко, готова ждать любого продолжения сколько угодно ~

author: {'steamid': '76561198167599299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 588, 'last_played': 1666738168}
review:
Not very good at this whole review thing, but let's just say the very long wait was definitely worth it and I plan to spend a lot of time beating the game with all the other characters (just beat it as Lilac) and getting all the badges/S ranks if possible. The only complaints I have are bug related and the developer is currently working hard at fixing them.
Anyways, just buy it and play it if you have any interest in side scrollers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262392865', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1693689294}
review: It's definitely more challenging and longer than the original game (in a good way of course), and the 7 year wait definitely paid off. This game just like it's predecessor has gorgeous pixel art and music, and fun dialogue too! Like the first game, I can highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of Classic Sonic or the Sonic Advance trilogy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971019883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1663686636}
review: The Freedom Planet trio are back!  The sequel to the original has made leaps in bounds of world-building, graphics, storytelling, and, of course, enjoyment.  Lilac, Carol, and Milla are back at it again, this time faster than before and full of wit with Neena tagging along.  Although it took years in the making, the wait paid off!  There's also great references and ester eggs hidden throughout the world (if you look hard enough).  Of course, it is much more challenging than the previous installment.  (i)Absolutely(/i) worth picking up since it is at an affordable price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198851846361', 'num_games_owned': 36, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 16, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1712255655}
review: 5 лет назад, в группе ВК по фан-играм посвященым по Сонику, увидел новость с подписью о разработке Freedom Planet 2. Решил посмотреть и понял, что "Я хочу в это поиграть!!!". Пока FP2 была в разработке, решил поиграть в первую часть, подарила много хороших эмоций и желания стать разработчиком и сделать свою игру. Сегодня целый день сижу и играю в FP2. Игра значительно изменилась после первой части: геймплей, графика, музыка, динамика, сюжет и много чего!!! Буд-то в детство вернулся, когда я целый день играл только в Sonic Adventure!!! Galaxy Trail не зря вы потели на игрой так долго, вы молодцы!!! На момент написания наиграл 4 часа, еще игру не прошел, но мне она очень нравится!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025308787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 22848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1675260581}
review:
[h1]■8年を経て続編登場のソニック風ハイスピード2Dアクション[/h1]
前作で侵略者から世界を救ったドラゴン族のライラック達が、新たな脅威に立ち向かいます。
アクションの爽快さはそのままにボリュームアップしており、
マップはより広大に、ステージギミックは更に種類豊かになりました。
フルボイスで軽快に掛け合うキャラクター達も健在です。

[h1]■前作からの変更点[/h1]
・前作の中ボスだった「ニーラ」がプレイアブルキャラに追加されました。
・前作の面クリア型からワールドマップからの面セレクト型へと変更され、
　マップ数が大幅に増加しています。（12マップ→約30マップ）
・様々な効果を持つサポートアイテムがステージ開始時に設定できるようになり、
　残機がある限りその場での復活が可能になったため、やや難易度が下がっています。
・キャラが若干小さくなり画面全体が見やすくなりました。
　またオートズーム機能や、画面外の敵へのアラートが実装され、
　前作の不満点だった「早すぎて画面外の敵や障害物に当たる」といった事が減りました。
・新アクションとしてガードが出来るようになりました。　

[h1]■ローカライズ[/h1]
発売時点（2022/09/15）日本語化はありません。
ほぼキャラクター同士の対話のため、英文自体は理解しやすいかと思います。
前作は有志の方による日本語化がされていたため、将来の日本語化は期待できそうです。

[h1]■満足点・不満点[/h1]
〇ハイスピードで爽快感のあるアクション
〇優れたレベルデザイン
〇前作のキャラが多数登場
〇美麗で動きのあるドット絵（NPCにまで固有グラがあります）
△一部ボスの難易度が高い
△マップ間のデモを手動送りできない（丸ごとカットは可能）

[h1]■こんな方にお勧め[/h1]
・前作をプレイした方
・90年代の2Dアクションが好きな方
・かわいいケモが好きな方

[h1]■クリア状況／プレイ時間[/h1]
ノーマルエンドクリア／約15時間

author: {'steamid': '76561198170288197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 147, 'playtime_at_review': 1102, 'last_played': 1712298550}
review:
Freedom Planet 2 is like Freedom Planet but with more Freedom. And more Planet. And more good.

It's good.

Go play it.

EDIT: I have fully completed Freedom Planet 2, so here's some more in-depth opinions.
The game is very fun, and the story is a wonderful improvement over the last game. It's also an improvement over the last one in basically every relevant fashion. But it's not perfect, and my criticisms mainly come in the form of two areas.

1. The S rank system. The way the HUD presents it is confusing, as it makes it appear that collecting gems is actually important for getting them when it's exclusively about that multiplier. In addition, the entire challenge is completely ruined by three bravestones - Expensive Stocks, No Revives, and No Stocks, as getting the S ranks requires not dying with two brave stones equipped (or not taking damage with one brave stone/no items equipped, but that's far more difficult as-is), and these brave stones quite literally only punish you for dying rather than actually making the run more difficult. I would suggest a rebalancing of the multiplier bonus you get from the various bravestones to make the others more appealing to use.

2. Neera. Lilac is fun to play and a surprising powerhouse, Carol is my favourite to play as and feels even better than FP1, and Milla remains an amazing character locked behind needing good skill to access, but Neera feels lacking in comparison. Her mobility options are poor as they require utilising enemies and the floor to make use of, making most of them completely unattractive to use, Focus conflicts with the intended purpose of Guard, forcing you to choose between avoiding damage or conserving your Energy for where you need it, and in actual combat her attacks are close range and precise but don't deal quite enough damage to make up for that finicky precision, despite being labelled as the brawler character.

That being said, this game is still absolutely amazing, and the 8 years of development have most definitely been worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198046594216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1700343401}
review:
A game genuinely worth the wait. Controls are solid and responsive, level design is quite good (with a few notable exceptions having weird stage flow in my opinion), the dialogue and overall humor genuinely made me laugh quite often (Carol's Battlesphere commercial cutscene is amazing), and the sprite work is beautiful. 

During my play time thus far, a few bugs have occurred, like checkpoints placing you in the floor (most egregious during a HARD spoiler level at the end of the game), dying on grabbables incurring a soft lock and some strange collision detection that may or may not also put you in the floor temporarily depending on how it feels on that moment.

My only genuine gripes thus far are related to Lilac's Blink Dash, which feels kind of sticky and unresponsive sometimes, not always activating when I press input and losing most of my momentum out of it, and the lack of a way to view seen cutscenes again. I recognize that it's totally possible this may be a me issue, so take these with a grain of salt.

Overall, I genuinely recommend this long awaited sequel to Freedom Planet, and the series as a whole. I truly hope many more will find it and have as much fun with these games as I have.

-----
EDIT: According to patches, the checkpoint misplacing your character has been fixed in most, if not all, cases. I have not gotten around to testing the ones I originally found except one which no longer occurs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974460705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1663714893}
review:
An astonishingly well-tuned game. Some of the levels in this shocked me with how good they were - Shade Armory, for example, might be a candidate for a classic of the genre. Rapidfire saturday morning action cartoon storytelling, anticipation and beats woven into almost every level, and really, really good control-feel.

Also when a vanishing block appears directly over you, you get stuck in it, making a funny face, until you get let out, instead of being pushed aside or damaged. The game is full of amazing touches like that.

And there's so many levels in it!

Also all the little town NPCs are adorable and I'm glad they're here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198442025358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 2130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1706702524}
review:
かわいいミラちゃんが前作以上にかわいすぎて萌え死にそうだ。キャラアイコンすらかわいい。
かわいいミラちゃんのかわいい仕草を見たいがために連打する。Hadesは連打しすぎて即飽きたというのに。
かわいいミラちゃんの被ダメ時のかわいい声を聴きたいがために故意に攻撃を食らう。残機はいくらあっても足りない。興奮と申し訳なさで早打つ心臓。俺の残機もすり減ってゆく。

[i]当たり前のように萌えていられる日々[/i]

かわいいミラちゃんは走っている姿もかわいいが、速すぎて目が追い付かないので俺は残機を振り絞り、寿命と引き換えに脳のリミッターを外して動体視力にブーストをかけた。だが立ち止まって呼吸しているだけのミラちゃんもかわいいのであまり意味は無かった。そんなことよりもミラちゃんのために寿命を削っただなんて、嬉しすぎて死にそうだ。走り出す前の早歩きミラちゃんもあまりにもかわいい。殺す気か？いや待つんだ、空中で犬かきするミラちゃんはそれすら上回るかわいさすぎる。かわいさというのは際限が無いものなのだな。
ぬいぐるみが欲しい。永遠に抱っこしていたい。

[i]明日もまた萌えていられる保障など無いのに[/i]

かわいいミラちゃんを愛でるために時間は過ぎてゆく。でも、この時間は決して無駄なんかじゃない。無駄どころか、全ての残機を賭ける価値がある！俺は最初に最もかわいいミラちゃんで始めたことを軽く後悔したが、2周目以降もまたミラちゃんで萌えれば何の問題も無いことに気付き、それ以上考えることをやめた。



・・・とある場所で超必殺[spoiler]椅子に座って内股で尻尾をフリフリ[/spoiler]するミラちゃんのかわいさには、完全屈服。ミラちゃんの全ての動きをGIFファイルにまとめて網膜に焼き付けたい。
我こそが犬となろう。君のために。

author: {'steamid': '76561198061615342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1712329774}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005222200', 'num_games_owned': 533, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 23, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1712267683}
review:
I'm not big on the 2D Sonic titles (or just in general), but the first Freedom Planet really enamored me and the sequel is no different.

The way you create speed and carry momentum in this game is so satisfying with your attacks generally having some sort of movement property. My favorite example being Milla's beam attack "Super Shield Burst" that's so strong, it blasts you in the opposite direction you shoot it. Learn to chain this attack together along with her Yoshi-like float that keeps your momentum, you'll be flying across the stage at mach speed if you're good enough. Legitimately some of the best movement mechanics and physics I've ever experienced in a platformer.

On top of that you have the absolutely gorgeous pixel art and incredible soundtrack. Even if you're not a fan of the Sonic titles like me, I'd still 100% give it a try.

review: This game has so much to offer in terms of replay value such as extra parts to the story for each character with stuff only seen for that character but also the normal and secret endings to the game itself and the post credits oh boy I am not spoiling it but accessing the secret ending is the same for all characters from what I gather but the boss fights are tough no matter what difficulty you play on and the 2nd chance in boss fights helps too. Despite 7 or 8 years waiting the game is worth the price and hoping that GT learned its lesson before when announcing too early, Now we wait 14 years for Freedom Planet 3.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978683845', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 4281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 27, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1712330807}
review:
There's a lot to this game, 
There's 4 characters with their own skills that completely change how you play the game. 
Lilac can pull a Rocket Knight and shoot in any of 8 directions with Dragon Boost and she has a double jump that has a slight hover with Cyclone. 
Carol has a variety of martial arts with a Wild claw for extra damage, wall jump like Mega Man X she can roll to damage enemies and gain speed, can get  a motorcycle to change her moveset entirely where she can backflip, boost and such. 
Neera has a wand to shoot ice projectiles from, she can cover enemies with ice and bounce off of them or shatter them and even skates at top speed.
Milla can build up murder cubes to either spam light attacks or shoot a big shot. She can flutter her limbs for a Yoshi style jump.

All characters also have basic attacks and this is my BIGGEST TIP when playing either Freedom Planet 1 or 2:
When attacking if you hit up or down will give you different attacks- and different attacks in the air. They're very, VERY useful and most people I've seen play ignore them and these are some of the more damaging attacks.

Lilac's up+attack is an uppercut that not only goes a bit higher than her jump, it does far more damage than her cyclone attack- and you can go right into a down+attack that is a stomp that also does a lot of damage.

Neera's attacks in the air are vital to her gaining speed, you can really, really make her go super fast and stay in the air a long while.  Carol's down attack is great for her gaining speed and her disc will help you get around the map or double team an enemy since you can attack while it's doing damage on it's own. 

I haven't played Mila but I know her changes are pretty big vs her in the first game. She can be more aggressive with more attacks for one and I think has more HP than she did previously. 



So the characters themselves have a ton to offer in terms of variety and replayabilty. 
The game itself (So far I'm only 4.6 hours in) is crazy just how much they packed in. Huge levels with tons of routes and spots for characters to use their skills to get around with. 
The game has much improved writing and  voice work over the first. That's not to knock what the VAs did in 1, I felt a lot of it was their equipment being so different - which isn't the case here. I wish I could explain that better, just know if you thought the story and dialog was a bit lacking in 1- 2 is does it all so much better. 


The game also has items to help or hinder your gameplay.
Hindering items are there to 1- challenge yourself and 2- get your bonus up for a higher rank. 
Potions & positive items will lower your bonus and your rank.
So if you have a item with a negative that boosts your bonus by 75% and you fill a potion to a full 5 you lose 25%. Tie that in with a no-hit bonus and you too can get the fancy rainbow S-Rank.

Or you can ignore all that because ranks don't really effect anything from what I can tell. 

The game feels, so good to play. I can tell I'm going to put a lot of time into this one over the years. 

The one gripe I think someone could leverage against the game is you have to play through the adventure mode once before unlocking classic mode. Classic mode being you just get the stages. But seeing how much work they put into this and how good it is? It's worth it. 


This is a heck of a game, they really upped everything in this, the art design and visuals are a big leap over the first game, the stages aren't cut into parts anymore and it's just one large stage with SO many routes to go through. They leave it up to you to explore or blitz through. 
The music is, so, good. 


Performance: 
What I really like is the game can run at over 60fps, I don't know all the numbers off hand but I know it can do over 144hz. 
Other good news the game can run on a potato, my laptop sporting a 5 year old i5 and a HD620 runs the game at 1080p/60fps just fine. 

Just make sure you have a good set of speakers, the music is worth it. 

Edit: 
The bugs I had in the review have been addressed & I beat the game as Lilac (I'm aware there's a 'true ending' but haven't done that. 

I think Freedom Planet 1 had better bosses & boss music  & FP2 has a level I'd equate to Sonic CD's Wacky Work Bench in terms of "Really bad level design" as it has teleporter walls that send you all over in a disorienting way. But that is just one bad level out of a ton of them and as a whole FP2 is a really great game with a lot of fun levels, great music & fun levels (except the 1). 
Tons of replayability and I'm sure in a few months I'll have a bunch of hours racked up & will be revisiting this like Sonic 3 & Knuckles since I first got that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141506931', 'num_games_owned': 5, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1663891956}
review: This is incredibly a major step forward from the first game in terms of story, characters, soundtrack, and game play. 40 hours of watching good cut scenes, battling different species even your own kind, collecting all Time Capsules for the true ending, playing four different characters with their unique set of skills and different paths, listening to some awesome music in the background that fits the tone. Loved it. I don't usually leave reviews on games but I had to with this one because it deserve more love. Best character: Carol

author: {'steamid': '76561198255595397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 3571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 202, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1712358455}

author: {'steamid': '76561198086418978', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 7672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 39, 'playtime_at_review': 4236, 'last_played': 1712345205}
review:
Like the wings on its logo, Freedom Planet 2 soars above the competition as an outstanding high-speed platformer that improves upon nearly every foundation set by it’s predecessor. It is without a doubt my personal game of the year and a shinning example of both indie development and how to craft a killer sequel. 

The game’s story is heavily involved, taking place 3 years after the invasion of Lord Brevon and the shattering of the Kingdom Stone. An ancient centurion of a dead race named Merga has awoken and seeks revenge against the world of Avalice due to the genocide of her people long ago. Returning animal heroines Sash Lilac, Carol Tea, Milla Basset and newcomer Nera Li must confront her plans as well as intercept remnants of the previous alien invasion and friends turned enemies. The center conflict deals with heavy themes like genocide, cultural erasure, and the ethics of warfare without coming off as cheesy or edgy while greatly expanding the mythos, lore, and fleshing out the culture and identify of Avalice. Merga comes across as a cunning yet broken person with actual motivations for what she does rather than simply being the evil big bad. Despite the serious tone, the game features a lot of funny jokes and witty comedy that never breaks pace and helps to round out the mood in between drama. Each playable character gets unique dialogue and cutscenes throughout their own playthroughs that frames a narrative for their struggles and motivations. Voice acting is thoroughly improved in both delivery and consistency; everyone sounds fantastic without a single instance of wince or cringe and cutscenes don’t overstay their welcome. This includes the previous VA’s and professional talent like Christopher Sabat of Dragon Ball fame. A plethora of new and returning characters help to add personality and charm to cutscenes. Every criticism of the first game’s story was taken to heart here and for repeat playthrough the story can be skipped with classic mode. 

Like it’s predecessor, the game offers a mix of highspeed platforming, exploration, and combat across 24 levels and 4 playable characters each with their own unique movesets. Movement feels more fluid and easier to keep due to a reworking of the skill meter and abilities that allow for greater vertical height. A new dodge button allows skilled users to avoid damage and parry damage back if timed right. Lilac remains speed oriented with her dragon boost now cancelable, Carol can climb walls and use a throwing disc while her bike doesn’t break apart, Milla has a normal health bar and can quickly summon alchemy cubes, and newcomer Nera is slower but uses frost arts and focus to freeze enemies and unleash powerful attacks. This gives each character their own utility and playstyle which gives each playthrough a fresh but familiar challenge. Stage design feels better adjusted to player momentum, physics, and abilities which gives each level a more polished feeling. Unique environments, platforming gimmicks, treasure boxes and boss encounters make for a lengthy campaign with enduring replay value. Once unlocked, the battle sphere allows for unique challenges and boss rematches, which help unlock a special ending and secret stage. 

Bosses remain a key focus of the game, with most stages having at least one encounter and some stages being entirely devoted to boss fights. Unlike the first game, these are more strategic in nature with better attack patterning and a greater focus on movement. This results in many fights acting less as slug fests and more like combat puzzles. These are still very challenging encounters with later bosses offering exceedingly difficult fights. For several fights this does equate to chasing down the boss to damage it and overall, I feel encounters are weaker compared to the first game. This is especially true for the final encounter against Merga, which lacks the fast-paced frenzy of Lord Brevon’s showdown. It should be noted that boss encounters are still a fun challenge, just different from how the first game offered them. The block button helps to make encounters feel fair. 

In Adventure mode, levels are accessed across an expanding tile map that also includes hubs housing shops and interactable NPCs. They feature new dialogue after clearing certain stages and help to make the world feel more interconnected and alive. Shops are connected to the new item  and ranking systems; trinkets found in stages or bought at shops can either ease difficulty or increase the challenge. Examples include items that can increase player health or kill the player upon taking damage. Aid will reduce the gem payout after clearing a level while challenging items increase the payout and award a higher rank upon completion. Rank is defined from C to S rank, which is determined by items, the number of deaths and continues used, and damage taken. Potions affect gameplay statuses like shield points given or player speed without affecting score. This system allows for more robust playing options for casual and competitive play. Upon beating the game, a Museum opens that allows players to spend gems on models of bosses fought and trivia on the game’s development. Progression is more linear in Classic mode, with a basic level select and universal store option between levels. Lives reset each stage, with continues bought using gems after lives are used up. A new reviving system lets players restart after dying with only a sliver of their health left to clean up mistakes in a pinch. Difficulty options allow for the rules to be customized, like adjusting how many gems are used to revive or turning off these options entirely. 

The game features gorgeously detailed pixel art reminiscent of the Sega Saturn with a lot of rich colors and highly animated sprites and occasional polygonal elements. Character sprites in particular are much more vibrant and expressive with a lot of personality. This is seen in the game’s photo mode, in which any paused frame can be turned into a photo with unique poses available. Levels and hubs feature rich backgrounds which blend Asian and Filipino architecture and science fiction. Some sprite scaling can become blurry when the stage scrolls out, which adds to the retro charm but can be distracting and should be optional. With a greater focus on melody and atmosphere, the soundtrack offers a less high octane score compared to the first game. This will be disappointing for those that enjoyed the first game’s OST, but this is largely down to preference. The game’s score is still impressive with over 90 original compositions that offer a rich sound. My only criticism would be that many boss themes lack the same intensity found in the first game but overall, the soundtrack is phenomenal with many call backs and leitmotifs to the previous game. Personal favorites include Shade Armory, Ancestral Forge, Lilac’s theme, and the boss themes for Magma Starscape and Clockwork Arboretum. 

At launch, the game featured few bugs and an overall astounding level of polish. Updates for the game have been constant, with continued tweaks and bug fixes. A few recommendations I have would be for additional rank and par times to be present when selecting a stage, for classic mode to be unlocked by default rather than rewarded for beating adventure mode, and for greater item customization. A late game use for gems and currency would be appreciated as well. DLC offering more playable characters and levels would be a godsend.

After nearly 7 years in development, Freedom Planet 2 acts as a near perfect sequel by expanding what worked and improving what didn’t in the first game. This title matures the franchise into its own unique identity that surpasses it’s own inspirations to become one of the best side scrolling platformers of all time. This game raises the bar for indie works and leaves high expectations for a potential Freedom Planet 3. Easily 9/10, please buy this game and support the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005816494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1663253563}
review:
This was worth the wait! The first Freedom Planet stole my heart with the possibilities it presented, and now after about 8 years, it delivered. I love that the level design adds so many unique elements to it, as that's honestly the most you can ask for in a platformer. It's surprisingly hefty, too; my first full run as Lilac was an impressive 10+ hours, which is over double the time it took me for a run in the first game. That's a lot of content, considering the other  character routes that await me someday! For now, though, I'm content after playing my heart out over two days.

Probably my only nitpick is that the action gets a little too chaotic when there's a ton of regular peons in your way, but everything else was fabulous. The team is quick to smooth out any launch day bugs, and personally I loved the fact I could learn the boss patterns as I went to overcome the challenges. The game is really flexible on your difficulty curve, and avoids a lot of problems afflicting certain Sonic level design tendencies. If you're either passing time until Frontiers comes out, or just want another experience on par with Mania, I think this will get you your fix!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011029626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1693677934}
review: Game is genuinely a lot of fun, hearkens back to a lot of the good about the old Sonic games.  There's a lot of challenges and things for completionists and hardcores to strive for, and minus a boss currently kicking my teeth in, the challenge is very fair thus far on normal difficulty.  Wholeheartedly recommended if you love fast paced platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064694439', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1702796855}
review:
Я настолько ждал эту игру, что удивлен от того факта, что при всем моем фиговом знания английского... Я понимаю в чем сюжет, и понимаю юмор и о чем речь. Наверное я настолько хочу пройти эту игру, что все извилины моего мозга напрягаются для того, чтобы понять смысл фраз персонажей. И это меня удивляет... У меня правда фиговое знание английского. Поэтому когда происходит катсцена, где фразы автоматически пропускаются когда заканчиваются (кстати), я офигиваю в духе "Нихрена себе... Я что только что все понял!?". Не знаю как это получается. Первую часть я тоже проходил на английском, но понял весь сюжет. В других играх я обычно нифига не понимаю. Магия какая-то. Возможно помогает озвучка, которая очень эмоциональная. Либо английский какой-то упрощенный. Не знаю. 
В любом случае это удивительно, что я понимаю смысл без русификатора. Что касается самой игры, - она шикарная. Столько впечатлений! Браво! 

Особенно радует то, как вырос левел-дизайн по сравнению с предыдущей частью. Каждый уровень в чем-то уникален и запоминается! Это вроде и геймплей Соника, но во многом впечатления схожи с тем, как я в детстве проходил Battletoads. Словами не передать насколько много всего в игре, и насколько круто продуманы уровни! Я как геймдизайнер удивляюсь тому, что впервые за долгое время не ощущаю искусственности во всем этом. То есть... Обычно я заранее могу предугадать геймплей игры и то как он будет раскрываться по ходу. Здесь такого не происходит! Я вижу много неожиданных решений и игра воспринимается очень естественно, как будто такими и должны быть игры. Уровни удивляют. Я люблю эту игру!

author: {'steamid': '76561199090248498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1666142588}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970512380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1663736858}
review:
So you take Sonic, and then you add 4 very different playable characters that mash up other Genesis greats like Rocket Knight, and then you swipe the guard mechanics from Smash Bros for good measure. And then you get a great mech artist to draw you a ton of screen-sized Mega Man X and Treasure bosses.

This game is unbelievably awesome and you need to play it immediately. It's the kind of over-the-top supergame that kids fantasized about making in the 90s, except they actually made it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046663265', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1663844208}
review:
I'm someone who always gets... worried when a game spends a little TOO long in the oven. While having the time to do game development responsibly and fill out features is good, this also costs a lot of money and can lead to things like game engine changes, a lack of direction clarity from leadership, or just a game coming out far after it's relevant star has shone.

I am overjoyed to say that Freedom Planet 2 is a game that was worth that long gestation period. 7 years of passion has lead to a game that by and large smooths over it's original's roughest points, fleshes out it's world, and comes out as a speedy platformer with excellent pacing as a first-time playthrough with plenty of reason to revisit the game thanks to the combination of it's various difficulty modifying item loadouts, levels that adopt the multi-tiered and routed style designs of it's inspirations, and the 4 different characters to take through what is a dense indie title.

I am very glad Freedom Planet 2 didn't shy away from narrative beats after the harsh criticism that the first game became bogged down in it's melodrama and overly long cutscenes. They still are here for Freedom Planet 2, and the much more brisk 'classic' mode is locked behind first-time game completion. However, I think that Freedom Planet 2 thrives in it's adventure mode now, with a narrative that is far less uneven than the first Freedom Planet, and one masterfully broken up between delivering lines through radio banter, having hub areas to fill out lore and character interactions that would have been a cutscene in the previous game, and keeping things brief save for the climaxes of Freedom Planet 2's 3 act structure. although so far I've only experienced Sash Lilac's path, I'm even more endeared to the characters here then I was in the original game, and I'm excited to delve into the other three girls' paths through the game, hoping that the likes of Milla and Neera get as much fleshing out as Lilac does here, given how... personal of a story this suddenly becomes to her. Also, it should be noted that there's clearly much more emphasis put into the quality of voice work, with much of the FP1 cast reprising their roles and feeling much more comfortable in them. Andi Sina in particular sounds much more comfortable in her role as Carol Tea and less like she's recording from a bathroom. Also, I need to give a special shout-out to Merga for being... so much better of a villain than Lord Brevon. while the intergalactic warmonger did his job and provided that fun gutteral growl, Merga is a tragic figure who provides some much needed pathos to the journey and also has some amazing moments of her own.

Freedom Planet 2's gameplay does much of what it's predicessor did; channeling the energy of Treasure co. ltd's seminal works in the 90's into a shell that is much more Sonic the Hedgehog like. I would say that Sonic Mania is a game that has since stolen some of Freedom Planet 2's thunder if not for the fact that Sonic Mania director Christian Whitehead contributed level design to FP2. The cast all has wildly different ways of traversing the multi-tiered, winding levels and dealing with the frantic but fair blasts of bullets, blades, bees, and bombs that tend to fill the screen in spectacular fashion, with Lilac being a speedster with a Rocket Knight Adventures inspired Dragon Boost to really get her going and offer her tons of invincibility while moving fast. Carol is a swift combatant with wall jumps and an acrobatic disc she can throw and teleport to and a motorcycle she can ride, while Milla shoots telekinetic projectiles and cubes that she can use to propel herself and flutter about like Yoshi, while (playable) newcomer Neera muscles her way through enemies and freezes them to use as platforms and the like.

I'm also happy to say that presentation-wise, Freedom Planet 2 feels SO much more cohesive, with chinese artist Tyson Tan's art style giving Avalice the glue that the original game was missing. seeing the variety in NPCs and the way Tyson's redesigns of the cast came together was a big joy, and I popped so hard seeing the likes of the director's dog (Sammi Diduro) working at the museum, or characters who are clearly fursonas or mascots of various devs throughout the adventure (Verse for example, is the composer's fursona, or Libbie being a mascot Tyson Tan designed to be... I think Huion's mascot?) 

There's so many cool and very... 90's sorts of graphical pops... things like line scrolling to create the illusion of 3D with the many, MANY layers of parallax, the zoom in and out of the camera as needed, the stage that clearly is meant to be a Super-scaler that made me think of afterburner... there's so much smooth pixel art animation and explosions and cool VFX going on at any given time and it's SO stimulating, but never overwhelming.

Of course, Audio is pitch-perfect too, with SO many numerous bangers or songs that use lietmotifs from Fredom Planet 1 to flavor them. I remember being super impressed with one of the levels in the Suigang arc having a bit of the Lord Brevon theme weved into the harmony of the piece JUST as I was getting to a part of the level that had remains of the invaders from the original Freedom Planet coming back. ALong with the frightened tone of Dawn Benett's delivery upon seeing it struck such a powerful chord of... what fighting a war like that must do to a hero seeing their nightmare come back.

Freedom Planet 2 has so much love and care put into it. it's why I felt it nesessary to put out this review and implore you all; PLEASE Play this game. yes, it came out a bit hot and maybe needs a couple of minor bugs fixed, but FP2 has SO much dang content and awesomeness in it. PLEASE play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199046651966', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1678745684}
review: bro 10 out of 10 game

author: {'steamid': '76561198087034805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1663202337}
review:
[b]A bad case of sequelitis.[/b]

Freedom Planet 1 is a game that is near and dear to my heart, so I'm going to be reviewing this primarily as a comparison to the first game. I've played 5 stages with Carol and tested out all the other characters within the tutorial and first level.

[b]Visuals:[/b] 👎 
The artstyle is very distinct from the first game. I can't really say that I appreciate it after playing the FP1 so much and associating all the characters and whatnot with the old artstyle. It doesn't feel like a natural progression for the series's artstyle in the same way that something like 2D Sonic games have evolved. I do think all of the new assets look great in a vacuum, but the first game's artstyle was so striking that this feels like a downgrade. It doesn't help that the higher pixel count sprites end up making the game blend in with other indie games going for a similar look. I get the impression that whoever made the decision on the new artstyle wanted to distance themselves from the Sonic and Megaman X inspired artstyle of the first game. I feel like it's kind of too late to do that though.

[b]Music:[/b] 👎 
The music is very much a mixed bag. Some of the songs sound really great like the new Dragon Valley remix and Shade Armory. Other songs though are either unmemorable or feel unfinished. The boss themes I heard in particular were quite a disappointment. Even with the songs that I like though they don't really have the same appeal as the FP1 OST. They end up feeling overly busy and not as cleanly mixed as the songs from the first game. It seems like some of the songs from the beta/alpha have remained unchanged in the final game as well like Bakunawa 3, which is still just a 46 second loop. The end result of all of this is that the music quality feels very inconsistent throughout the game. [i]Especially[/i] compared to FP1, which I felt maintained a very consistent level of quality throughout its OST.

[b]Mechanics:[/b] 👎
For the most part the entire cast controls really well. There's just a few mechanics that I personally disagree with. The game has a guard button. This was something that was in the demo I played a few years back and I hoped it was a placeholder mechanic but I'm sad to see that it's still here. I'm not a fan of "press button to negate damage" mechanics as I find them to be unengaging and promote a passive playstyle. And that's exactly what they do in this game. The timing for the block is [i]very lenient[/i] (despite NPCs dialogue's attempts to convince you otherwise). You can pretty much just stand in one spot and keep negating damage as long as your timing is half decent. I wouldn't have an issue with this so much if I could just ignore it like the bullet time in Katana ZERO, but it is ingrained into the game and so you will need to use it. FP1 did not have a block button (unless you were Milla, but that's a different kind of block), so all bosses were designed for you to avoid damage by moving out of the way or using invincibility frames. Not the case here. Boss design in this game is far more loose and cheap as a result of the guard mechanic existing. Pretty easy to design bosses that you can call fair when you give the player a get out of jail free button. I could harp on this mechanic for another paragraph, but I'll just say that I don't find it very interesting or engaging and leave it at that.

[b]Level Design:[/b] 👎
The levels don't feel as tight as the ones from FP1 from what I played, and you can feel it from the very outset of the game. They feel kind of empty and bloated sometimes, and convoluted and mazelike some other times. I think there was another review on here that echoed a similar sentiment. I do think the level design picks up after the first 3 levels, but I never really felt like it got as good as the first game's levels. The end level bosses also were pretty underwhelming from what I played. Apart from the boss of the 5th stage they all felt more like minibosses from the first game. Speaking of which this game doesn't have those. The structure from the first game of Act 1 --> Minor Boss --> Act 2 --> Major Boss is gone. You just have level and then boss here, and the bosses are generally just random big robot, while the bosses and minibosses from the first game often had a story reason for existing. Overall levels are shorter and more bite sized in this game, but they have a lot of empty space and glorified hallways.

[b]Camera:[/b] 👎
I like the idea of FP2's camera as a proof of concept. FP1 had a single viewframe for the whole game that never zoomed in or out. It could be kind of claustrophobic in a few places, but I didn't find myself minding it too much. FP2 attempts to fix this issue by implementing a camera that zooms out depending on how fast you're going, allowing you to see more of what's ahead. You can adjust how far the camera zooms out in the settings or turn off the feature completely. The downside of this is that it makes those pretty hi-pixel sprites look like total garbage, and you often can't hardly tell what something even is supposed to be because the pixels are so crunched when it's zoomed out. I really don't think it's a good idea to put control over the camera in the player's hands in a game like this. A better solution would have been to handcraft the camera according to the level design: zoom in during the slow and complicated sections and zoom out during the high speed sections where the player is expected to go fast. Instead what they've done is implemented is a clunky system that tries to automate the hard work of proper level and camera design away and fails at it.

[b]Polish:[/b] 👎
It's quite buggy. Within the first two hours I found more bad geometry that I was getting stuck on than in the entirety of FP1. There was also someone complaining about the controller glyphs, and yeah those are screwed up as of writing this. Game feels rushed despite taking so long to come out, and honestly that's what I was expecting. I'm not going to say it's Duke Nukem Forever levels of bad or anything but it feels like it's within that territory.

[b]Voice Acting:[/b] 👍
From what I played it seems like they got almost all of the original cast from FP1 back to work on this project. There are some replacements like Gong and Syntax, all of the major VAs still seem to be there. The VAs for the new characters sound good as well. I really liked the amateur VA cast from the first game and I'm very happy they've returned to work for this project. I think they do a pretty good job in their delivery for the most part. However I can't really say that the spritework always does the voiceovers justice. The original game had that problem from time to time as well, but I feel like it's exacerbated here because of the more zoomed out camera in most scenes. This segues into my next complaint which is...

[b]Presentation:[/b] 👎👎👎
The presentation in this game is a wreck when you compare it to FP1, and I think it mainly is due to the overambition of FP2. There are text only dialogue boxes now, which weren't a thing in the first game. In FP1 whenever a character opened their mouth you got voice acting, and they were able to pull that off because of the smaller scope. In FP1 you would go through a level and get a cutscene. Rinse and repeat until the credits. Here you also have towns segments (that feel completely pointless) and have NPCs to talk to. When major characters show up as NPCs to talk to they don't get voice acting either. You don't always get a cutscene after each level like in the first game, and some levels seem to have no place within the story of the game either (Tiger Falls is just a level you go through to get to another city). I can't make myself expect less when the first game set the bar for my expectations.

Would you look at that, I’m out of space. Can’t fit anymore. No conclusion segment, sorry. I’m going to try and refund this.
tl;dr go play Freedom Planet 1 if you didn't

author: {'steamid': '76561198097482576', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1698631129}
review:
Perspective: Just finished the game on Normal (middle difficulty) using Carol earlier today. Still intend to play the other characters. I also played a ton of the first game and considered it one of my favorite 2D platformers ever. If you haven't played the original then this may not be quite as good a review for you, but if you're at all a fan of fast, action focused 2D platformers and don't mind a challenge then definitely go for it.

Pros:
-Music slaps as expected
-Movesets of characters are expanded from the original, Carol's shuriken is very fun to use
-Love love LOVE the level aesthetics and variety, every level feels super distinct and always challenges you in new ways, and some just look amazing
-New interactivity with NPCs and world map is minor but helps make the game feel more grand
-Nice ways to customize your difficulty and character using handicaps or potion buffs
-Sprite work during story conversations are more expressive, and general dialogue is more enjoyable

Cons:
-The story did its job but I failed to get too invested in it. This may be due to the character I chose (Lilac seemed to be more integral than Carol). The main antagonist's motivation was more relatable than the OG game's Brevon, but from Carol's perspective she's very one note
-Main gameplay critique: your character's volatile moveset and the more intense levels backfire on the game a bit in that it makes the game very hectic. It's very easy to lose your bearings and struggle to find the exit to a level segment for a bit, or miss items like hidden collectibles or life flowers that you'll need to keep yourself alive.
-Limited view around your character can make some bosses annoying to keep track of. One boss in particular I found myself waiting until they entered my view because pouncing around the arena looking for them would put me at risk of taking a hit.
-This game is surprisingly difficult on Normal, partly for the reasons listed above. I would definitely recommend either playing on the easier mode or allowing yourself whatever buff items you can find on your first playthrough. The lives system is more strict this time as well so you may find yourself replaying some sections fairly often.

Overall worth the 7 year wait and I am definitely looking up the soundtrack later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198293720253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1670462413}
review:
Very early impressions

Great game so far. Worth the wait. My only problem so far is the button display issue. It shows the PlayStation icons just fine, but it displays 1,2,3,4 for Xbox and Nintendo. Not to mention, the icon says to press the right d-pad button to talk to NPCs when I have to press up instead.

Another issue is with menu navigation. Since I'm using an Xbox controller, I've mapped Lilac's standard attack to the X button and her Dragon Boost to B. Unfortunately, since these buttons are swapped at default, resulting in pressing X instead of B to go back in the menus. Other games have button mapping options for menu navigating, so there's potential to patch it. Not a large issue but not a nitpick either.

In the end, the wait was worth it! The characters and the world are charming and the controls are buttery smooth. Love the Full Metal Alchemist reference in it too.

Now if you excuse me, I need to continue playing this game. Thank you. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198040215556', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1688385476}
review:
Wow.

So, as a HUGE fan of the first game, I think about halfway in I can say this blows FP1 out of the water (dragon) and then some, while staying respectful to what was established in that one too. Everything has been refined, from huge gameplay additions like the guard, to world maps and hub towns, way more lore and information about Avalice and its history, whole character arcs, an interesting and an incredibly impactful local threat...

Phenomenal game so far, and an easy 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001703704', 'num_games_owned': 839, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1663537066}
review:
WARNING: Playing Freedom Planet 2 will reduce your enjoyment of the 2d Sonic titles by up to 98.5%

Seriously, the game is so far and above beyond Sonic, that they are hard to compare, except that everything Sonic does Freedom Planet does better, and the things Freedom Planet does Sonic doesn't even have in it. I used to love Sonic 2, now? Compared to Freedom Planet 2? It reminds me of picking up an unfinished 2 minute long sonic fangame on newgrounds that never figured out physics. Sonic feels like a bad unfinished clone of Freedom Planet, they've gone so far and above and beyond the source material that the fact I'm making this comparison at all feels insulting to Freedom Planet 2. I legitimately love this game.

Also, Milla best girl. Or should I say Allim the Masked Marauder, best girl.

author: {'steamid': '76561198831762740', 'num_games_owned': 68, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1663179813}
review:
[SPOILERS FOR THE STORY!!![

It's a great game, it really is. Gameplay is improved over the original, the accessibility options are great for people like me who forget to dodge and keep dying, music is very old-school 90s SEGA, and all the playable characters are fun to control... 

But in regards to the story, specifically near the end... I have a very personal gripe... 

They shoehorned some identity politics into the story (No, not talking about the playable characters all being girls. That doesn't bother me and has never bothered me about this series). And what's sad is that the story up until the very end was good... and then... they just... throw a curveball in regards to something we REALLY DID NOT NEED TO KNOW about the main villain.

I wouldn't be harsh about this normally, but I've been bullied by those exact kind of people, even to the point of breaking down mentally. Ever since that started with me a few years ago, I've not really been cool with a character all of the sudden and out of the blue just... "coming out", especially the way the main villain was after unlocking the true ending.

Again, the game is good. I'm not taking that away from the team who made it. However, because of IRL things revolving around identity politics, that one detail near the end soured the story for me. Unlike a series like Sonic, Freedom Planet is very story-heavy. You can't play the game classically untli you beat the story. So yeah, it just really bothered me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102084293', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1663186945}
review:
I see that Lilac can no longer roll and that makes the movement significantly more rigid then it used to be.
Unfortunately the game now seems to make the exact same kind of mistakes sonic started to do with level design even starting from Sonic 1. I expected to feel a bit of speed at least on the first level not constant walls. Yes, I need to get better, but this is also a terrible piece of motivation to do so.

These two are going to be the "not fluid" negative reviews.

I'm figuring out if I'll refund it for this, even knowing that Carol's bike is still exactly as dumb as I remembered it to be.

Edit: I'm keeping it as a positive because I can see the love that went into the game, but I also had it refunded. This is not fun for me.
The sprites are way too busy, and I think I can feel some "general purpose physics engine" under the hood instead of the more custom/fine tuned one the original seemed to have. It might just be Unity only being average/bad at doing 2D in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561199007382698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1697756522}
review:
So, I'm a big, BIG fan of high-speed action platformers. And yeah, I've heard of freedom planet, I bought it this year, fell in love with it, and It's probably my favourite next to Spark the Electric Jester.
So I heard that Freedom Planet was getting a sequel. 
Brilliant !! 
Bought it, 
but I couldn't even get into a few minutes into the game without really, REALLY bad screen flickering.
The vsync option doesn't help either, and the game won't even allow me to play with my dualsense controller, not even with a custom steam controller layout.

I'm playing on the latest build as of 14/09/2022, being 1.0.1r, so maybe later down the line, I can actually play the game, but as it stands right now, I don't think I can reccomend it if I cannot even play it to begin with.

ADDENDUM 17/09/2022:
Screen flickering issues are.. Gone!
Finally, Dualsense support, even if the buttons are all wrong. But I'mm glad I can finally, finally enjoy it!

It's exactly what I wanted.

ADDENDUM 25/09/2022:
The screen flickering issues are still here, but I've been able to play small increments as the updates go along,
as of right now, It's Ancestral Forge that's giving me severe screen flickering. I'll update this when I can cus Trail devs have been going HARD. thanks for such a peak game, I hope I can play the rest of it

author: {'steamid': '76561198382876245', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 13851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 932, 'last_played': 1710701179}
review:
An improvement on the original in every way possible. The game oozes polish, love and care all the way through. Gameplay has gone through a number of improvements to suit the chaos and better define itself as a mixture between high speed platforming and breakneck combat. Boss battles are as exciting as ever, and the levels are tons of fun to go through. Even the story mode, despite actually being longer than in the first game, is far better paced and is better at respecting the player's patience, on top of just generally having better written dialogue and dynamics. The voice acting I don't think was ever bad but it's definitely at its absolute best here.

This time around in the art department, Tyson Tan lends his distinctive art style and designwork to Freedom Planet's cast and world, and there's never been a better fit- it's clear they want to use his work to help define the visual identity of the series. Overall, Freedom Planet 2 just reeks of "we figured it out" energy across the board- this is a good thing. The first game was an excellent experience that felt 80% there - but this game feels like it has properly realized how to establish its identity as something truly unique and remarkable in its own right. Everything feels more purposeful, planned, and adds up to one of the most fulfilling gaming experiences I've played in a minute.

To say I'm addicted is an understatement. For anyone worried about a lack of content, don't be. This is 20+ full-fledged levels, each with their own themes and ideas they used to the fullest. Four playable characters all with their own distinct gameplay identities and feels - Sonic/Knuckles/Tails scenario this is not - the way you approach combat, speed, and platforming with each character is completely different. Items that allow you to customize your character's stats or play the levels with a tighter challenge. A "Battlesphere" mode which not only lets you rematch individual bosses but contains new arena challenges and obstacles courses for you to beat your records on. A sparring mode that lets you fight other characters in 1v1s or smash targets within a time limit. There's just so much here and it's all very well-thought out and meaty.

I can see some not liking the "cringe" story like with the first game (read: they're boring people and just hate a fun time) or the long, highly involved levels, but everything comes together for me in a way that feels remarkably solid, refined, and entertaining. It's just a blast and I invite anyone who loves action platformers to give it a try. But please, I implore you, don't go into it treating it like it's Sonic, and don't play it like it's Sonic. Because it's an entirely different beast - some things in common, but it must be tamed anew.

Mega Man Zero + Gunstar Heroes + Sonic the Hedgehog for people who wear thigh highs. play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139969450', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 6428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1710897299}
review:
こういったジャンルはあまり遊んで来なかったが、可愛らしいキャラクター、軽快な操作感、熱いストーリー展開に惹き込まれ夢中になって楽しめた。
[b][i]美麗なドット絵、気分を盛り上げる音楽、ステージを駆け抜ける爽快感、kawaiiキャラクターは健在。新システム、やりこみ要素等々盛りだくさん搭載しパワーアップ[/i][/b]

[h1][i]kawaii[/i]仲間達[/h1]
それぞれアクションや戦闘スタイルが異なり、ステージや幕間での会話、展開が変化したりキャラ固有のイベントが描写されたりと４人分のフリーダムプラネットを楽しめる。
気になったキャラから順にクリアしていくもよし、４キャラ並行して進め全視点から物語を楽しむもよし。

[b][i]LILAC[/i](DRAGON)[/b]
おさげで周囲を攻撃しつつ空に舞い上がったり、指定した方向に無敵状態で突進できる。正統派主人公。ストーリー上重要な情報を含む固有シーンが多い。
[b][i]CAROL[/i](WILDCAT)[/b]
壁を蹴って登れる。攻撃速度が速い。バイクに乗ったり、手裏剣(?)を投げたりバイクも投げたりする。自由奔放で表情豊か。固有シーンが最も多い。[strike]推し[/strike]
[b][i]MILLA[/i](HOUND)[/b]
一定時間耳をパタパタさせ空を飛べる。緑色のエネルギーを喚び出し敵に撃ち込んだり、盾にして飛来物を跳ね返す。ステージクリア時にキャンキャン鳴く。
[b][i]NEERA[/i](FROST KNIGHT)[/b]
氷技を扱い、ダブルジャンプが可能。クールビューティ然としているがわりと気が短い。[i]CAROL[/i]からの呼び名は『おっかないお姉さん』。とある登場人物の意外な一面が見られる。

[i]LILAC[/i]の突進は再入力で別の技に派生しその場に持続的な攻撃エリアを残す、[i]NEERA[/i]が氷技のひとつで生成する氷柱は[i]MILLA[/i]のように飛来物を跳ね返し、踏み台にすると高く跳びあがれる等、基礎チュートリアルでは説明されないテクニックが多々存在するためメニュー画面のGuideを読んだりプレイを通してキャラ知識を深めるとルートのショートカットや各ボスに適した立ち回りが可能になり攻略の助けになる。

[h1]ゲームの特色[/h1]
多種多様なボス戦は歯ごたえのある設計。初見ではしばしば圧倒されるものの、繰り返し挑戦しパターンを把握、それに合わせた戦い方を構築していくことで次第に動きが洗練されていく。手強いボスのアクションを見切りスムーズに倒せるようになった際の爽快感も本作の大きな魅力。

クリアランク、ランタイムがステージ毎に記録されるため、一度クリアした後もより高いランク、クリアタイムの短縮を目指してやり込みを楽しめる。最高ランクは色違いのS(ボーナス100%以上のハンデ装備でノーミスクリア)。

基本モードがマップ型となったことで今までは舞台装置の域を出なかった都市や国などを実際に訪れ、そこに住む人物たちと交流できるようになった。クセのある性格だったり、可愛い仕草をしたり、特徴的な口調だったりと皆個性的。
セリフは感情に応じ文字が震える、跳ねる、大きくなる、色がつく等の表現が成され、より豊かな人物像の描写に繋がっている。


豊富なやりこみ要素、４人のキャラクター、多彩なステージによりボリュームが大幅に増加。魅力的なストーリーと多数の登場人物達に彩られ深みの増した世界観。
１作目から更にパワーアップを遂げた文句なしの名作。

author: {'steamid': '76561198025079461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 830, 'last_played': 1665590293}
review:
A new engine, a new artstyle, new tricks, and a new plot.

just beat Lilac's story and hoo boy is it a ride. i'll have to beat the other character's stories to see where they diverge, but for the most part all of them stick together as a party.

that said, if you hated FP1's level design, you will loathe FP2's design. not my problem, however, i actually love the fuck out of this since it's more than "hold right to reach the finish" and offers rewards for more than just simply "reaching the end of the level as fast as possible" and while i did do that with Lilac, i'm definetly going to take my time with the rest of the cast that isn't her. there's so many secrets i have yet to collect so that'll be a while.

did get softlocked on one boss but that was during Day 1 and it was easy to just restart the fight without closing the game. kudos for making a solid game that has some (even if unintentional) anti-softlock measures.

the art and music is absolutely amazing. 10/10 would gawk at a boss and drool at how they look again. Lilac handles pretty good but definetly will take time to actually master. will edit later when i have beaten the game with the others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038047469', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1664081909}
review:
Back in 2015 the first Freedom Planet was a kind of anti-depression for me at the time. It was colorful, amazing soundtrack, had the pixel graphics I missed a lot and had a great personality to it. Sure, the dialogue oftentimes got a little cringe, but it was an indie game. Fast forward to now and in the sequel they improved upon pretty much everything. The dialogue still tastes the same as the previous game which may throw some people off, but it's cute if you try to embrace it. 

The graphics are bloody amazing. Some levels have like four levels of background scrolling and it looks incredible in action. There are sooooo many little animations and details. The water even has animations when you interact with it. I know how difficult it is to make pixel art and animating, so the fact they managed to cram so much of it in here is amazing, and with FOUR playable characters that are nothing alike. Even the music, just as the first game, remains catchy as heck. 

So yeah, definitely get this if 2d games are your thing, the levels are much bigger and more elaborate than the first game's, and overall amount of content and polishing is exactly what you'd want from a proper sequel. No wonder it took seven years. On Normal difficulty the bosses to my pleasant surprise actually get challenging too.
